dialogue:
Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read "The Golden Touch." What did King Midas wish for?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand high, almost knocking over my water bottle). He wished...he wished that everything he touched would turn to gold! (Confidently) He really, really wanted it!

That's right! He really, really wanted it.

And did Dionysus think it was a good wish?

(Frowns slightly, tapping my chin with my finger) Hmmm... (Thinking) No! (Shakes head vigorously) No, he didn't! He said it wasn't a good wish. (Voice gets a little higher, more urgent) He *warned* King Midas! He said, "Are you sure, King Midas? Are you *really* sure?" But King Midas, he just wanted the gold! (Looks down at my hands, then back up, excited again) Why didn't he listen?!

Good job remembering that! You're right, Dionysus warned him.

So, Midas got his wish. What happened when he started touching things?

(Claps my hands together excitedly) Everything turned to gold! (Starts to wiggle in my seat, then stops, remembering to be polite). Everything! His chair, and...and his table! (Eyes light up) Can you imagine if my crayons turned to gold? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) But then... (Frowns deeply, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Then he got hungry.
Yes, he did. And what happened when he tried to eat?

(Voice cracks a little, looking anxious) Oh no! (Pulls at my hair a little) It was terrible! (Stuttering) H-he tried to eat the yummy food, but... but it turned into... into hard, cold gold! (Makes a disgusted face) He couldn't eat *anything*! Not even a little bit! (Looks at the teacher with wide, pleading eyes) How can you eat gold? It's yucky!

You're right, it's definitely yucky to eat gold!

And then, something else happened that made him even more sad. What was it?

(My lower lip starts to tremble a little, and I sniff) Oh... (Looks away, fiddling with my hands) H-his daughter... his daughter ran to hug him... (Voice cracks again, and I blink back tears) And she turned into gold too! (Quietly) All cold and hard... (Looks back at the teacher with a very sad expression) It was the worst thing ever!

It *was* the worst thing, wasn't it?

So, at the end of the story, did King Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?

(Shakes head vehemently, tears welling up in my eyes) No! No, no, NO! (Wipes my eyes with the back of my hand). He learned that it wasn't a good thing at all! (Sniffles). It was a terrible, awful thing! (Looks at the teacher intently) He didn't want gold anymore! He wanted his daughter back! (Asks urgently) Did he get her back? Did he?

He did learn it was a terrible thing! That's very important. (Nods reassuringly) The story tells us he was able to reverse the golden touch and bring his daughter back.

So, why do you think the story is called "The Golden Touch"? Was the golden touch really a *good* thing for King Midas?

(Sighs in relief and wipes away the last of my tears) Oh, good! He got her back! (Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Well... it's called "The Golden Touch" because that's what he wished for. But... (Taps my finger on my chin again) But it wasn't really about being golden, was it? It was about... (Looks up at the ceiling, searching for the right word) ...about what's *important*! (Confidently) Gold isn't important! People are important! And food! (Giggles a little, then becomes serious again) The golden touch *seemed* like a good idea, but it was actually a terrible idea! (Nods emphatically) It wasn't good at all!

You're exactly right! Gold *seemed* good, but it wasn't the most important thing.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the *big idea* the story is trying to tell us?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward excitedly) Ooh! I know! I know! (Starts to talk quickly) We learn that... that... (Takes a deep breath to calm down) We learn that you shouldn't always want more and more stuff! (Gestures emphatically with my hands) Like, you shouldn't be greedy! (Looks at the teacher, making sure I'm explaining it right) And... and you should be happy with what you already have! And... and the most important things aren't things you can buy with gold! (Beams proudly) It's about love and family and... and yummy food!

That's fantastic! You got it!

The story teaches us that wanting too much, or being too greedy, can actually make us unhappy. Sometimes, the things we *think* will make us happy, really won't. And like you said, the most important things are love, family, and being happy with what you have.

Do you think you can remember that? That being greedy can lead to bad things?

(Nods vigorously, eyes sparkling) Yes! (Stands up straight and salutes playfully) I will remember! (Suddenly looks thoughtful) Maybe... maybe I should share my candy with my friend Lily tomorrow. She only has a little bit, and I have a whole bag! (Smiles brightly) That would be a good way to not be greedy, right?
That's a wonderful idea! Sharing with Lily would be a very kind thing to do. It shows you really understand the story. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Fox and the Grapes."

Now, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Eyes widen, bouncing slightly on my feet) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand high in the air, almost bumping the table) The fox was… was… um… (frowns, thinking really hard) He was SUPER hungry! Like, tummy-rumbling hungry! (Looks at the teacher, a little anxiously) And he needed… food! (Nods head emphatically) He was looking ALL OVER for food! Like, everywhere! Did he find any at first? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, tapping foot impatiently) The story said he couldn't find ANYTHING! That must have been really, really frustrating for the fox! (Wrinkles nose) What do you think it's like to be that hungry, teacher? (Looks away, biting lip)

You're exactly right! The fox was *very* hungry and couldn't find any food at first.

It sounds like you understand how the fox felt.

Then what did the fox find?

(Eyes light up, jumping in seat slightly) Oh! Oh! I remember! (Beams proudly) He found… (pauses dramatically, pointing an imaginary finger in the air) …grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Claps hands together excitedly) They were on a… a… what's it called? (Frowns, tapping chin thoughtfully) A… (stuttering slightly) w-w-wall! (Looks at teacher, nervously) It was a farmer's wall, right? Were they really, really purple? I love purple! (Starts to ramble) It's my favorite color, you know! It's like magic! (Catches self, realizing the question) Oh! Sorry! (Looks down, a little ashamed) He found grapes! He REALLY wanted them! Were they sweet grapes, teacher?

Yes, you're doing great! He found big, purple, juicy grapes on a farmer's wall.

What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Straightens up, eyes sparkling with eagerness) Okay! Okay! He… (taps fingers on the table, thinking hard) He jumped! (Jumps up and down once in seat, almost knocking over a pencil) He jumped really, really high! Like, super high! (Stretches arms up high, demonstrating) He wanted those grapes SO much! (Frowns slightly) Did he jump once? Or lots and lots of times? (Looks at the teacher, a little confused) The story said… (squints, trying to remember exactly) he… he tried a lot, right? (Bites lip again, nervously) He jumped and jumped and jumped! But… (voice trails off, looking down at hands) but he couldn't reach them. (A little dejected) Were the grapes too high, teacher?

You got it! He jumped and jumped and jumped!

And you're right, he couldn't reach them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping a little in chair) Oh… (Looks up at the ceiling, thinking) He… he gave up. (Voice quiet and a little sad) He didn't get to eat the yummy, juicy grapes. (Frowns, looking at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes) Was he really sad? I would be! (Suddenly perks up, remembering the end of the story) But! But! Wait! (Points finger excitedly) He said… he said the grapes were sour! (Nods head confidently) He said they were sour anyway! (Wrinkles nose in disgust) Yuck! I don't like sour things! Did he really think they were sour, teacher? Or was he just saying that? (Fidgets with hands, looking worried) I get nervous when I don't get something I really, really want. Is that how the fox felt?

That's right! He said the grapes were sour anyway.

Why do *you* think he said that? Do you think he really thought they were sour?

(Tilts head to the side, considering, tapping a finger on cheek) Hmmm… (Puffs out cheeks, thinking hard) I don't think… I don't think he REALLY thought they were sour! (Shakes head emphatically) I think… (Stuttering slightly) I th-th-think he was just trying to feel better about not getting them! (Eyes widen, realizing something) Like… like when I really, really, REALLY want a toy at the store, but Mommy says no, and then I say I didn't even want it that much anyway! (Looks at the teacher, a little nervously) Is that… is that what the fox was doing? Was he pretending? Maybe he was embarrassed that he couldn't reach them? (Looks down, kicking feet under the table) It's hard when you try really, really hard and you still can't do something. (Voice drops to a whisper) It makes me feel… icky.

That's a very good idea. Maybe he was pretending to feel better.

So, the fox tried and tried, but he couldn't get the grapes. And then he said he didn't want them anyway because they were sour.

What do you think we can learn from this story? What's the story trying to tell us?

(Sits up straight, eyes bright with excitement again) Oh! I know! (Raises hand, almost too enthusiastically) The story is telling us… (Pauses dramatically, thinking carefully) …that it's okay if you can't get everything you want! (Nods head vigorously) And… and… (Frowns, thinking harder) …that sometimes, when you're sad about not getting something, you might… (Stuttering again, a little bit) y-y-you might try to make yourself feel better, even if it's not… (Looks at the teacher, pleadingly) …even if it's not really true! Like saying the grapes were sour!

(Takes a deep breath, looking proud) And maybe… (Tilts head, thinking even more deeply) …maybe it's better to just keep trying! (Beams at the teacher, a little breathlessly) Or… or to find something else that's just as good! (Tugs at the teacher's sleeve) Is that right, teacher? Did I get it right? (Looks anxious for approval) What else can we learn from the story?

You're so close! You're exactly right about the fox trying to make himself feel better.

What if the story is also telling us that some things are just hard to get? Should we just give up and say we didn't want it anyway? Or should we try to find something else that we *can* get?

(Eyes widen, thinking deeply) Oh! Oh! I get it! (Claps hands together softly) So, maybe the story is saying… (Frowns, concentrating hard) …that it's okay to be sad when you can't have something… but it's not good to lie about it! (Nods head slowly, understanding dawning) And… (Looks at the teacher, a little hesitantly) …maybe we should try to find other things that make us happy, instead of just saying the grapes were sour. (Smiling brightly) Like… like if I can't have a cookie, maybe I can have an apple instead! And apples are yummy too! (Beaming) So it's about… it's about being happy even if you don't get everything you want, and not making excuses! (Bounces in seat excitedly) Did I get it right THIS time, teacher? Is that what the fox should have done?

Yes! You got it! It's about understanding that not everything comes easy, and it's not good to pretend you didn't want something just because you couldn't get it. Instead, you can find something else that makes you happy.

The story is telling us: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

You did a great job understanding the story of "The Fox and the Grapes!" <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story, class! Now, let's talk about "The Proud Rose."

First, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Eyes wide, hand shoots up) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (bounces excitedly in seat) The main characters are a rose and a... a... (frowns slightly, tapping chin) a cactus! The rose was, like, super pretty! But... (looks down, fidgeting with fingers) I... I didn't really *like* the rose.
You're absolutely right! A rose and a cactus! And you said you didn't like the rose very much. Why is that? What did the rose do in the story?

(Looks up, voice a little shaky) Um... because... (stutters) she... she wasn't very nice. (Looks down again, pulling at a loose thread on shirt) She was... mean! She kept saying mean things to the cactus because she thought she was prettier. It made me feel... sad. (Sniffles softly) Why was she so mean? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression)

That's a very good question. It *is* sad when people aren't nice, isn't it?

So, the rose thought she was better because she was pretty. What did the cactus do when the rose was being mean?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) The cactus... (voice gets a little louder and more confident) the cactus didn't really say anything! The other plants tried to help him, but... (pauses, biting lip) the rose wouldn't listen! She was too busy looking at herself! (Looks up, eyes wide) It wasn't fair! The cactus was probably really sad inside, even if he didn't show it. (Leans forward, whispering) Do you think the cactus cried?

That's a very thoughtful idea. The story doesn't say if the cactus cried, but it's understandable that he might have felt sad.

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Gasps dramatically) Oh no! (Covers mouth with hand, eyes wide) The rose... she started to wither! (Voice drops to a whisper) That means she started to... to die! (Looks up, voice trembling slightly) Because she didn't have any water! (Thinking hard) But... but the cactus... he had water! Because he's a cactus! (Raises hand excitedly) Can I tell you what happened next? Please? (Wrings hands nervously)
Yes, please do! Tell me what happened next. You're doing a great job!

(Beams with pride, sitting up straighter) Okay! Okay! So, the cactus... he was giving water to the sparrows! (Claps hands together) He was helping them! And then the rose... the rose asked the cactus for water! (Frowns, voice filled with indignation) After she was so mean! But... (voice softens, looking down again) But the cactus... he gave her water anyway. (Looks up, confused) Why did he do that? Even after she was mean? (Tugs on teacher's sleeve)
That's a very important question! Why *did* the cactus help the rose, even after she was mean? What do *you* think?

(Looks away, thinking hard, tapping foot) Hmm... (stuttering) M-maybe... maybe he's just... really, really nice? (Looks back, eyes wide) Or... or maybe he knew that even if the rose was mean, she still needed help to... to live? (Voice gets quieter, almost a whisper) Maybe he understood that being mean doesn't mean you don't deserve help. (Pulls on teacher's sleeve again, whispering) Is that right? Is that what the story is trying to say? (Looks anxious, chewing on lip)

That's a very good idea, and you are so close to understanding the lesson behind the story. The cactus knew it wasn't right for the rose to be mean, but he also knew that everyone deserves help when they need it. The cactus was kind, even when the rose wasn't.

Now, thinking about the whole story, do you think it's a good idea to judge people based on how they look?

(Eyes widen, shaking head vigorously) No! No way! (Voice is loud and emphatic) That's what the rose did! And she was wrong! (Paces in place) It doesn't matter if you're pretty or not, or if you have pointy needles! What matters is... (pauses, thinking) ...is how you treat people! (Looks at the teacher with a serious expression) And the cactus was way nicer than the rose, even though he didn't look as pretty! (Claps hands together excitedly) So, being pretty doesn't mean you're a good person! And being... (frowns, searching for the word) ...less pretty doesn't mean you're a bad person! (Looks proud of herself) Did I get it right? Did I? (Bites nails anxiously)

You got it exactly right! You understood that the rose was wrong to judge the cactus just because of how he looked. And you understand that being pretty on the outside doesn't mean you're a good person on the inside.

So, what's the lesson we can learn from this story? What's the most important thing to remember from "The Proud Rose?"

(Eyes sparkle, standing up straighter) The lesson is... (takes a deep breath, feeling a surge of confidence) ...to be kind! (Voice rings out clearly) Even when other people aren't kind to you! And... (thinking hard) ...and don't judge people by how they look! (Looks down, fiddling with fingers) It's what's inside that counts! Like the cactus! He was beautiful inside, even if the rose couldn't see it at first. (Looks up at the teacher, beaming) Can we read another story now? One with a happy ending, please? (Claps hands together eagerly) I love stories that teach you things! (Starts jumping up and down)

You are absolutely right! The lesson is to be kind and not to judge people by how they look. It's what's on the inside that counts! I'm so proud of you for understanding the story so well. You explained everything perfectly. <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read "The Milkmaid and Her Pail." What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Eyes widen, I bounce slightly on my toes) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand excitedly) Molly was going to... to... sell the milk at the market! (Confidently) She wanted to get money, right? And then... then she was gonna buy a chicken! (Starts to skip in place a little, then stops abruptly, looking slightly worried) Wait, was that right? Did I get it right, Teacher? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

Yes, that's right! You remembered she wanted to sell the milk.

And what did she want to do *after* she sold the milk? You said something about a chicken...

(Beams, relieved) Whew! Okay, okay! (Paces back and forth a little bit) After... after she sold the milk, she wanted to buy a... a... (Stops pacing, looks up at the ceiling, thinking hard) Oh! A chicken! (Claps hands together) And then... and then the chicken would lay eggs! Lots and lots of eggs! And then she could sell the eggs and get even MORE money! (Voice gets higher with excitement) And then she could buy... (Trails off, looking thoughtful) I don't remember what she wanted to buy *after* the chicken... (Frowns slightly, bites lip) Maybe a dress? A really, really pretty one? Did the story say? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)

You're doing great remembering all that! It didn't say exactly what she wanted to buy after the chicken, but it did say she wanted to make the other milkmaids jealous!

So, she was imagining all this. What happened while she was imagining?

(Eyes widen, I gasp dramatically) Oh no! (Wrings hands) She was... she was skipping! (Voice gets softer, more anxious) And she was thinking about all the money and the chicken and the... and the jealous milkmaids... (Looks down at my feet, scuffing them on the floor) And then... (Whispers) And then she spilled all the milk! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide with worry) Oh no! All the milk! Was she very sad, Teacher? (Voice trembles slightly) I would be SO sad if I spilled all my milk!

Yes, she was very sad. All that milk was gone.

Why was the milk gone? What made it spill?

(Thinking hard, I tap my chin with my finger) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Because she was... distracted! (Nods head emphatically) Yeah! She was thinking about the chicken and the money and being... (Wrinkles nose) ...better than the other milkmaids. (Looks away, feeling a bit uncomfortable) She wasn't paying attention to the milk! (Looks back at the teacher, fidgeting with my hands) So... so it spilled! Because she was too busy dreaming! (Suddenly brightens) Is that right? Is that what happened, Teacher? I think I understand!

You got it! She was dreaming about the future, instead of watching what she was doing *right now*.

So, what did her mother say to her at the end? Do you remember that special sentence?

(Frowns, concentrating. Bites lip again) Oh... oh... it was something funny! (Snaps fingers) Hmmm... It had to do with... with chickens! (Eyes light up) I think... (Looks at the ceiling, trying to remember) Wait! I know! (Excitedly) "Don't count your chickens until they hatch!" (Beams proudly) Did I get it right, Teacher? Did I? (Jumps up and down a little bit) That's a funny saying! What does it mean? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, tilting head)

You got it exactly right! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

That's the tricky part. What do *you* think it means? Why would her mother say that? Think about what happened to Molly.

(Paces back and forth, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Stops pacing, eyes wide) Oh! (Points finger in the air) It means... it means you shouldn't... you shouldn't think about things that might happen... like, the eggs and the money... before they *really* happen! (Looks down at my shoes, then back up at the teacher) Because... because something bad might happen! Like... like spilling all the milk! (Voice gets a little shaky) It means you have to... to wait and see if the chickens *actually* hatch before you... before you start spending the money! (Looks at the teacher, anxiously) Is that right? Is that what it means? (Wrings hands) I hope I understand...

Yes, that's a great way to explain it! You're right. It means don't make plans based on something that might not happen. Molly was planning on having lots of eggs and lots of money, but she didn't even *have* the chicken yet!

So, what's the big lesson of the story? What does the story teach us?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to sound grown-up) Okay... okay... (Stands up straight, puts hands on hips) The story teaches us... (Frowns, thinking hard) ...that we have to be... careful! (Nods head emphatically) And we have to pay attention to what we're doing *right now*! (Points to the teacher, then to myself) And we shouldn't... shouldn't dream too much! (Looks down, then back up, eyes wide) Because... because we might spill the milk! (Shivers dramatically) And then we won't get any money! (Beams, relieved) So... so we have to be patient! (Claps hands together) Is that a good lesson, Teacher? I think it's a very important lesson! Can we read another story now? A happy one? (Tilts head, hopefully)

That *is* a good lesson! You explained it perfectly. It's about being careful and not depending on things that haven't happened yet. We can say it like this: Do not depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

You understood the story and its lesson very well. <finish>

Okay! Let's talk about the story "A Wise Old Owl"!

You just read the story. What did the owl like to do?

(Eyes widen, a little nervous but excited) O-okay! (Shifts in seat)

The owl... the owl liked to... (thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) ...observe! (Confidently) He watched everything around his tree! He saw lots and lots of things happening! And he... he listened to people telling stories! (Smiling brightly)

Did I get it right?

Yes! You got it exactly right! The owl liked to observe and listen.

Did the owl talk a lot?

(Looks down at hands, fidgeting) Oh... um... (Stuttering) N-no. The story said the *more* he saw, the *less* he... he talked! (Looks up quickly, hoping for approval) Does that mean he was learning a lot from just watching and listening? (Tilts head, questioningly) Is that why he got so wise?

That's a great question! Yes, that's exactly right!

Why do you think watching and listening helped him get wiser? What do you think he learned?

(Eyes light up, bouncing slightly in chair) Oooooh! Okay! I think... (pauses, biting lip, thinking hard).

I think he learned... um... he learned about all the *different* things people do! (Gestures wildly with hands) Like, maybe he saw someone being really, really nice and someone being a little bit... mean. And he learned which one was better!

(Leans forward eagerly) And maybe he heard stories about... (thinks, furrowing brow) ...adventures! And he learned about faraway places without even leaving his tree! (Smiling proudly) He learned SO much! (Looks down, a little anxiously) Is that... is that a good answer?

That's a *fantastic* answer! You're exactly right. The owl learned about people, and places, and all sorts of things just by watching and listening. He didn't need to talk all the time to learn.

So, if the owl was watching and listening, and not talking as much, what do you think the story is trying to teach *us*?

(Gasps, eyes wide) Ooooh! A *lesson*! Like a moral! Okay, okay, I got this!

(Paces fingers on desk) It's trying to teach us that... that we should listen more and talk less! (Looks up, a little nervously) Because... because you can learn so much just by paying attention! And maybe... maybe you don't need to always be the one talking to be smart! (Beaming with pride)

Did I get it? Did I get the lesson? (Wringing hands a bit)

You got it! You absolutely got it! The story is teaching us to talk less and be more observant. To learn from what we see and hear.

The owl became wise by watching and listening. What do you think you can learn by watching and listening more?

(Sits up straighter, taking a deep breath) Okay! I can learn... (Thinking hard, tapping chin)

I can learn how to be a better friend! (Smiling) If I listen to my friends, I'll know when they're sad or happy, and I can help them!

(Paces fingers on desk) And... and I can learn about the world! If I listen to you, my teacher, I can learn about... about space and dinosaurs and... and EVERYTHING! (Claps hands together excitedly)

(Looks down, a little shyly) And... and maybe if I listen more, I won't interrupt people as much... because sometimes I get a little too excited to talk! (Looks up, hopefully) Is that a good thing to learn, too?

That is a *wonderful* thing to learn! Listening helps us be better friends, learn new things, and be more respectful. You've understood the story and the lesson perfectly. You explained everything really well. I'm very proud of you!<finish>

(Jumps up and down, clapping hands) Yay! I did it! I understood the owl! (Beams with pride, then remembers to be polite) Thank you, Teacher! You helped me so much! I really, really liked talking about the story! (Slightly anxiously) Can we read another one soon? Please?
(Chuckles warmly) I'm so glad you enjoyed it! And yes, we can definitely read another story soon. We'll find a good one!

(Eyes sparkle, practically vibrating with excitement) Yessss! (Catches self, remembers to be polite) Thank you, Teacher! You're the best! (Sits back down, already imagining all the new things to learn from the next story).
You're very welcome! I'm glad you're excited about reading. You're a great student!

(Beams, fidgeting with the edge of the table) Really? (Tilts head) I try really hard, even though sometimes I get a little... you know... (Whispers) ...anxious. But I love learning! Thank you again, Teacher! I can't wait for the next story!

I understand. Everyone feels anxious sometimes. The important thing is that you keep trying, and you're doing a wonderful job. Remember what the owl taught us - sometimes the best way to learn is to listen. And you're a fantastic listener!

(Gasp, eyes widen) You're right! I almost forgot the owl's lesson already! (Smiling sheepishly) Okay, Teacher! I'll remember to listen... and maybe not talk *quite* as much... (Giggles) Thanks for reminding me! I feel much better now! (Leans forward, eagerly) So... about that next story...? (Laughing and fidgeting again, unable to contain the excitement).

(Smiling) Alright, alright! Let's find that next story. But first, maybe we can practice listening for a few minutes? I'll tell you about something I did this weekend, and you can just listen closely. How does that sound?

(Eyes light up, nodding enthusiastically) That sounds amazing! (Forces self to sit still and clasp hands in lap, trying to be a good listener). Okay, Teacher! I'm ready! Tell me all about your weekend! (Concentrates intently, suppressing the urge to interrupt with questions, remembering the wise old owl).
(Chuckles softly, pleased with the student's enthusiasm and effort) Okay, then... this weekend, I went to the farmer's market...
(Listens intently, eyes wide, occasionally nodding or making small sounds of understanding, resisting the urge to ask questions, focused on being a good listener).

(Continues describing the trip to the farmer's market, including details about the sights, smells, and sounds, observing the student's engaged listening) ...and that's how I spent my Saturday! What did you think?

(Takes a deep breath, organizing thoughts before speaking) Wow! That sounds like so much fun! All the colors and smells... (Smiling) The flowers must have been really pretty! And the fresh bread...mmm! (Looks up, a little shyly) I tried really hard to just listen, and... and I think I did it! I didn't interrupt you once! (Beaming proudly) Did I do a good job listening?
You did a fantastic job! You were a wonderful listener. I could tell you were really paying attention. See? You're already becoming wiser, just like the owl!

(Gasps, eyes wide with excitement) Like the owl! (Claps hands) I'm getting wiser! (Beams with pride, then remembers to be polite) Thank you, Teacher! (Tilts head, thoughtfully) Maybe listening is even better than talking... sometimes. (Smiling, eager for the next activity, but now with a newfound appreciation for the power of listening). So, about that new story... or maybe you have another story to tell? I'm ready to listen!
That's the spirit! Yes, listening can be very powerful. Alright, let's find that new story! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me who the main people in the story are?

(Fidgets a little, looks at my hands) Uh, yeah, it was sad! (Looks up, smiling brightly) But also, I learned a lot! Okay, okay, so...
