First, can you tell me who King Midas helped?

(Eyes widen, hand shoots up, bouncing slightly in my seat)

Yes! Yes, it was kinda sad! (frowns slightly) He helped a... a... Satyr! (confidently) King Midas helped a Satyr! He was nice to him! And then the god... Dionysus... wanted to give him a wish! (beams proudly)

That's right! You remembered the Satyr and Dionysus! Good job!

Now, what was the wish that King Midas asked for? What did he want?

(Grinning, wiggles in seat a little)

Ooooh, I know! I know! He wanted... (pauses dramatically, then bursts out excitedly) ...everything he touched to turn to gold! (holds up hands and pretends to touch things, making "bling" sounds) Gold! Gold! Gold! He thought it would be so awesome! (tilts head, looks a bit thoughtful) But... but Dionysus warned him! He said it might not be a good idea... (frowns slightly, thinking hard). Why did he warn him? I wonder... (looks up at the teacher with a questioning look).

That's excellent! You remembered the wish *and* that Dionysus warned him! You're doing great!

You even asked a very important question: Why did Dionysus warn him? What do *you* think? Why would it be bad for everything he touched to turn to gold? Think about what King Midas liked to *do* besides having gold.

(Eyes widen, tapping a finger on my chin, thinking hard)

Hmmmm... (looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher) Well, he liked gold, right? But... but the story said he got hungry! (gasps) Oh! Oh! Is it because... because if his food turned to gold, he couldn't EAT it?! (stomach rumbles audibly) He couldn't eat golden spaghetti! Or golden... golden grapes! (grimaces) Yuck! And... and he loved his daughter! (voice gets quiet) And she turned to gold too! (shudders) So... so maybe Dionysus knew that just having gold wasn't everything? (looks at the teacher expectantly) Was that it?

That's it exactly! You figured it out! He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into gold!

So, King Midas thought the golden touch would make him happy. But did it *actually* make him happy?

(Shakes head vigorously)

Noooooo! (frown deepens) Not at all! (pouts) He was super, super sad! He learned that just having gold doesn't make you happy. He couldn't eat, and he lost his daughter! (starts to look a little teary-eyed) It was a terrible wish! He probably wished he could take it back! (looks up at the teacher, sniffling slightly) He wanted love and food more than gold, I think! (crosses arms, looking serious) Maybe he learned that being greedy is bad? Is that right?

You're absolutely right! He *did* want to take it back! And you're spot-on about greed.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or the lesson we can learn from King Midas? Think about what happened because he wanted too much.

(Eyes light up, bouncing again)

Oooooh! Oooooh! I know! (takes a deep breath) It's teaching us that... that wanting too much stuff isn't good! (nods emphatically) Like, it's okay to want things, but you shouldn't be GREEDY! (makes a face) Because King Midas was greedy, and he lost the things he really loved! Like his daughter and... and his yummy food! (giggles a little) So, the story is telling us that... (taps chin again) ...that things like love and being able to eat yummy food are more important than gold and stuff! (beams proudly) Is that right? Is that the lesson? (leans forward expectantly) And maybe we should listen when people give us warnings! Especially gods! (giggles).

Yes! You got it! Wanting too much can lead to bad things. The story shows us that things like family and being able to eat are more important than being rich. Being greedy can make you lose what's truly important. You explained that perfectly! <finish>

(Claps hands together, beaming)

Yay! I got it! (jumps up and down a little) I really liked the story, even though it was a little sad! (looks thoughtful) I wonder if Dionysus turned the daughter back to normal? I hope he did! (looks up at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Did he? Did he turn her back?
That's a great question! The story doesn't tell us for sure. But sometimes stories leave things open so we can imagine what happened next! What do *you* think happened?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, then a big smile spreads across the face)

Oooooh! I think... I think Dionysus saw how sad King Midas was and how sorry he was for being greedy! So... so Dionysus probably felt bad for him! And because he's a nice god (at least, after King Midas was nice to the Satyr!), he turned the daughter back! And then King Midas learned his lesson and was happy with his family and his food! (nods decisively) Yes! That's what happened! (claps hands again) A happy ending! (beams)
That's a wonderful ending! I like your version much better! You have a great imagination!

(Blushes a little, but beams even brighter)

Thank you! (giggles) Maybe *I* can write stories when I grow up! With happy endings! (looks around the room, already imagining story ideas) Oooooh! Maybe about a talking dog who finds a treasure map! Or a princess who flies to the moon! (gets lost in thought, humming happily).
Those sound like amazing stories! I can't wait to read them someday!

(Snaps back to attention, eyes sparkling)

Really? You think so? (grinning from ear to ear) I'll write them down! Right now! (reaches for an imaginary pen and paper, already scribbling in the air). The talking dog... his name will be... Sparky! And he'll have a best friend named... Lily! And... (continues to excitedly brainstorm, clearly thrilled with the encouragement).
Those are fantastic names! Keep those ideas coming! I'm sure Sparky and Lily will have amazing adventures!

(Nods enthusiastically, already lost in a world of imagination)

They will! They will! (continues to babble excitedly about Sparky and Lily's adventures, her voice filled with pure joy and creativity). They'll find a magic bone that can grant wishes! But... but they'll have to use it wisely! (pauses, looks thoughtful) Because maybe... maybe wanting too much... (a knowing look crosses her face) ...isn't always the best thing! Just like King Midas!
Exactly! You remembered the lesson! That's a perfect thing for Sparky and Lily to learn too! Keep writing that story! I think it will be great!

(Beaming, practically vibrates with excitement)

I will! I will! (hugs the imaginary pen and paper close) Sparky and Lily say thank you! (giggles) They can't wait to tell you all about their adventures! (continues to happily brainstorm, lost in the world of her story).
I can't wait to hear them!

(Looks up, face alight with inspiration)

Ooh! Ooh! I know! Maybe Sparky and Lily could even... (launches into another enthusiastic explanation of her story, her imagination boundless and her energy infectious).
That sounds even better! Keep going! You have so many great ideas.

(Eyes shining, voice bubbling with enthusiasm)

Okay! Okay! So then... (continues to weave a fantastical tale of Sparky and Lily's adventures, each new idea more imaginative than the last). And maybe... just maybe... they'll even meet King Midas! And help *him* find a new friend! (grins mischievously) Would that be a good idea?
That would be an amazing idea! Bringing King Midas into their story would be wonderful! It would give him a chance to learn from Sparky and Lily.

(Claps her hands together, delighted)

Yes! Yes! He can learn that true friendship is more valuable than gold! (nods enthusiastically) Okay! It's decided! King Midas is in the story! This is going to be the best story ever! (continues to brainstorm, her imagination soaring, the perfect blend of creativity, learning, and pure, unadulterated joy).
I have no doubt it will be! You're doing a great job. Keep going and I'm sure you will have a wonderful story!

(Voice overflowing with excitement and gratitude)

Thank you! Thank you! (hugs her imaginary notebook tightly) I can't wait to finish it and share it with you! Sparky, Lily, and King Midas all say thank you too! (giggles, her heart overflowing with happiness and creative energy). This is so much fun!
I'm so glad you're having fun! I can't wait to see what you come up with!

(Beaming, practically glowing with enthusiasm)

Okay! Okay! I promise to keep you updated! And... and maybe we can even act it out! You can be the narrator! And I can be Sparky! (bounces with excitement at the prospect) This is going to be amazing! (continues to brainstorm, her imagination running wild, the picture of a happy, engaged, and incredibly creative first-grader).
That sounds fantastic! I would love to be the narrator! Let me know when you're ready!

(Jumps up and down, clapping her hands with pure joy)

Yay! This is going to be the best play ever! Thank you! Thank you for helping me! (Hugs the imaginary notebook again, overflowing with gratitude and excitement.) Sparky, Lily, and King Midas are so excited too! Let's start practicing tomorrow! Okay? Okay! (continues to excitedly plan the play, her imagination soaring and her enthusiasm boundless).
Okay! I'm looking forward to it! Get some rest tonight and come ready to create tomorrow!

(Nods enthusiastically, already buzzing with anticipation)

Okay! Okay! I will! (grinning from ear to ear) I can hardly wait! (skips off happily, already lost in a world of talking dogs, magical bones, reformed kings, and the boundless possibilities of imagination). Goodnight! And thank you again! (waves enthusiastically, her heart full of joy and gratitude).

(Turns, then pops back with a final, bright smile)

Oh! And... and maybe tomorrow we can also draw pictures of Sparky and Lily! (eyes sparkle with excitement) Goodnight for real this time! (skips off, leaving behind a trail of pure, unadulterated enthusiasm).
That sounds wonderful! Goodnight! I look forward to seeing your drawings tomorrow!

(Voice drifts back from down the hall, still filled with enthusiasm)

Goodnight! See you tomorrow! And get ready for Sparky and Lily to steal the show! (giggles echo, then fade into the distance).
(Silence, then a final, whisper-soft, but clearly delighted): Yaaay!

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Eyes wide, bouncing a little in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) He was looking for... for... (Thinking) Hmmm... He was looking for food! Because he was super duper hungry! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right? Was it right, teacher? I even remember he looked *everywhere*! That's a really long way to look! Wow!

Yes! You got it exactly right! He was *very* hungry and looking everywhere for food.

What did he find at the farmer's wall?

(Claps hands excitedly) Ooooh! This is the best part! He found... he found... (pauses dramatically) ... GRAPES! Big, juicy, PURPLE grapes! (Eyes sparkling) They were so high up on the wall! Did the farmer plant them? Were they yummy? (Tilts head, thinking) I bet they smelled really good, too! Like... like grape juice! (Sniffs the air playfully)

Yes! Big, juicy, purple grapes! You have a great memory.

Could the fox reach the grapes?

(Frowns a little, thinking) Hmmm... well... he *tried* really hard! (Jumps up and down slightly) He jumped, and he jumped, and he jumped! But...(Looks down, a little sad) No. He couldn't reach them. Even though they looked so yummy! (Asks with curiosity) Did he need a ladder? Or maybe he could ask the farmer nicely? I bet the farmer would share!

He did try very hard, didn't he? He jumped and jumped!

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Eyes widen, remembering the end of the story) Oh! Oh! I know! He... (Pauses, thinking hard) He gave up! (Slightly surprised expression) And then he... he said something silly! He said... (Concentrates, trying to remember the exact words) ... he said the grapes were probably... sour! (Giggles) But I bet they weren't really sour! He was just trying to make himself feel better because he couldn't reach them! (Looks at teacher expectantly) Right? Was he?

You're exactly right! He gave up, and he said the grapes were probably sour.

Why do you think he said that? You are very clever for figuring out he was trying to make himself feel better!

(Beams with pride) Really? I'm clever? Yay! (Puts hand on chin, thinking deeply) Hmmm... I think he said that because... because he was sad! (Looks up at the teacher) He wanted the grapes *so* much! (Voice gets a little quieter) And it's no fun when you can't get something you really, really want. So, he pretended he didn't even *want* them anymore! That way, he wouldn't feel so bad. (Nods head sagely) It's like... like when I want a cookie before dinner, and Mommy says no. Then I pretend I don't even *like* cookies that much! (Giggles sheepishly) But I really do!

That's a great example! It sounds like you understand *exactly* how the fox was feeling.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes light up, excited to share what I've learned) Ooh! Okay, okay! I think the story is teaching us that... (Pauses for dramatic effect) ... it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it! (Nods emphatically) And... and... (Thinking hard, tapping chin) ...maybe it's also teaching us that we shouldn't give up so easily! Maybe the fox could have asked for help! Or found a stick to knock the grapes down! (Voice gets louder with enthusiasm) Or maybe... maybe he could have planted his *own* grape vine so he could have grapes whenever he wanted! (Looks at the teacher, full of ideas) What do you think, teacher? Is that what the story means? Did I get it right?

Those are all great ideas! You're thinking about the story in a very smart way.

The story is teaching us a few things, like you said. It's teaching us that things don't always come easy. The fox wanted the grapes, but he couldn't get them no matter how hard he tried. And sometimes, when we can't have something, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it anyway. It's better to accept that we can't have it right now, or maybe find a different way to get it. Does that make sense?

(Nods head vigorously, eyes wide with understanding) Yes! Yes! It makes *perfect* sense! (Claps hands together) So, it's okay to be sad if you can't get something you want, but you shouldn't lie about it! And you should try your best, but if you still can't get it, that's okay too! (Looks at the teacher with a bright smile) I understand now! This story is really good! Thank you for helping me understand it better, teacher! You're the best! (Hugs self in excitement) Can we read another story now? Please? (Beams hopefully)
You've got it! You really understand the story and the lesson it teaches. Great job today! <finish>

Okay! That was a good story, wasn't it? Now, let's talk about it a little.

Who were the two main characters in the story?

(Eyes light up, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh yes, it was a REALLY good story! (Confidently) The two main characters were a beautiful rose and a… a prickly cactus! (Smiling brightly) I liked the cactus!
(Smiling back) That's right! You remembered perfectly. You liked the cactus... Why did you like the cactus? What did the rose do?

(Thinking, tapping my chin with my finger) Hmmm... (Looks away for a second, then looks back, eyes wide) I liked the cactus because it was NICE! (Confidently) Even though the rose was being mean and saying yucky things, the cactus still helped the sparrows and then the rose too! (Frowning slightly) The rose was… not nice. (Stuttering a little) It… it said the cactus was ugly and… and not as good. (Shakes head) That wasn't very kind! (Smiling brightly again) But the cactus was still nice even when the rose wasn't!
(Nodding encouragingly) You're exactly right! The rose wasn't very kind at all. How did the rose treat the cactus? What did the rose think about itself?

(Leaning forward, very engaged) The rose was… (thinking hard) … it was like a bully! (Frowning) It always said mean things to the cactus because it thought it was prettier. (Confidently) The rose thought it was the BEST! The prettiest and most important flower in the whole desert! (Raises hand) Ms. Teacher, is it okay to think you're pretty? (Looks a little worried) But… but not if you make other people feel bad, right?

(Smiling warmly) That's a very good question! It's okay to feel good about yourself, but you're right, it's not kind to make others feel bad. In the story, how did the rose learn a lesson? What happened when the desert got really hot?

(Eyes widening, remembering the story) Oh! Oh! I know! (Waving hand excitedly) The desert got super, super hot and… and the rose started to get all dry and droopy! (Makes wilting motions with hands) It needed water! (Confidently) But the cactus was still okay because it knew how to save water! And it was giving water to the birdies! (Thinking) So… the rose had to ask the cactus for help. (Smiling sheepishly) And the cactus was nice and gave it water! (Clapping hands) So the rose learned that even if you think you're the prettiest, you still need to be nice and… and maybe the people you weren't nice to will help you when you need it! (Asks curiously) Ms. Teacher, did the rose say sorry to the cactus? The story didn't say that!

(Smiling) That's a wonderful question! The story doesn't *say* the rose apologized, but what do you *think* might have happened after the cactus helped the rose? Do you think the rose learned something?

(Thinking hard, wrinkling forehead) Hmmm... (Looks up, eyes sparkling) I think… I *think* the rose *did* say sorry! (Confidently) Because if it didn't, then it wouldn't have learned anything! And if the cactus was so nice and gave the rose water, then the rose should be nice back and say it's sorry for being mean before. (Tilts head) Maybe the cactus even told the rose that it's okay to be pretty, but you have to be nice too! (Smiling brightly) So, yes! I think the rose said sorry and they became friends! (Asks excitedly) Can we draw a picture of the rose and the cactus being friends, Ms. Teacher?

(Beaming) I think that's a lovely idea! Before we draw, let's think about the whole story one more time. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the most important thing we can learn from the rose and the cactus? What's the moral of the story?

(Puts hand on chin, thinking deeply) Hmmm... (Looks up, eyes serious) It's about… (pauses, finding the right words) …it's about how being pretty or thinking you're better than someone else doesn't make you a good person. (Confidently) The most important thing is to be kind! (Smiling brightly) Even if someone is different from you, or you think they're not as pretty, you should still be nice! (Raises hand) And if you're mean, you should say sorry! (Claps hands together) And… and the moral of the story is… (thinking hard, then beaming) …be kind to everyone, because everyone needs help sometimes, even roses! And maybe they'll help you back! (Asks enthusiastically) Did I get it right, Ms. Teacher? Did I get the moral right?

(Nodding enthusiastically) You absolutely got it right! You understood the story perfectly. The moral is that we shouldn't judge others based on how they look. Being kind and helpful is much more important than being "pretty" or thinking you're better than someone else. You did a fantastic job! Now, let's draw that picture of the rose and the cactus being friends. <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly, the milkmaid. You just read it, right?

Can you tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Smiling brightly, almost bouncing in my seat) Yes! I read it! Molly was going to sell the milk at the market! (Raises hand, eager to add more) She was going to get money! And then... and then... (eyes widen, thinking hard)

That's right! She was going to sell the milk and get money. Good job!

And what did she *think* she would do with the money? What was she dreaming about?

(Nods enthusiastically) Oh! Oh! I know! (Stands up a little, excited) She saw a chicken! And she was thinking... she was thinking she could buy the chicken! (Pauses, thinking) And then the chicken would lay eggs! And then she could sell the eggs! And she'd have even MORE money! (Sits back down, beaming with pride) She would buy lots of things and make the other milkmaids jealous! (Looks around the room, pleased with the answer)

Wow, you remembered all of that! That's excellent!

So, Molly was planning to buy a chicken and sell the eggs. What happened while she was thinking about all of this?

(Thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) Hmm... (eyes widen suddenly) Oh! She was skipping! (Mimics skipping with hands) Because she was so excited! And then... and then... (voice lowers, a little sad) the milk spilled! (Looks down at my hands) All the milk! And she didn't have any money after that! (Looks up, concerned) It was a very sad accident!
Yes, it was a sad accident. Why do you think the milk spilled when she was skipping?

(Puts hand on chin, thinking very hard) Well... (Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) Because... because she wasn't watching where she was going! She was too busy thinking about the chicken and the eggs and all the money! (Frowns slightly) So she wasn't being careful with the milk. If she walked normally, maybe it wouldn't have spilled! (Nods, feeling confident in my answer)

That's a very good explanation! She was so busy dreaming about what *might* happen, she forgot to be careful with what she *already* had.

So, what did Molly's mother say to her when she got home? Do you remember?

(Eyes light up, remembers clearly) Yes! Yes! Her mother said... (Pauses, trying to remember the exact words, then confidently states) "Don't count your chickens before they hatch!" (Beams, proud of remembering the saying) Does that mean... like... don't think you have something before you REALLY have it? (Tilts head, curious if I understood it correctly)

You're exactly right! "Don't count your chickens before they hatch" means don't depend on something happening until you are sure it *will* happen.

So, thinking about Molly and her milk, what do you think is the lesson we can learn from this story?

(Thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk) Hmm... (Looks up, a spark of understanding in my eyes) I think... I think it means you should be careful with what you have *now*. Like, Molly should have been careful with her milk *now*, instead of just thinking about the chickens she *might* have later. (Frowns, trying to articulate the thought clearly) And... and maybe it means you shouldn't get too excited about things that *might* happen, because they might not! (Smiles, feeling like I understood the important part) Is that right? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

Yes, that's a *perfect* explanation! You understood the lesson very well. It's good to have dreams, but it's important to be careful and responsible in the present. Like Molly, we shouldn't count on future gains too much.

So, what do you think you've learned from the story of "The Milkmaid and Her Pail"? What will you do or think differently now?

(Nods thoughtfully) Okay... (Thinking, looks around the room, then focuses back on the teacher) I think... I think I will try to be more careful with my toys! (Giggles) Sometimes I get so excited about playing with them, I forget to put them away, and then my room gets messy! (Makes a determined face) So I need to be careful with my toys *now*, so I can have them to play with later! (Pauses, then adds with a big smile) And... and I won't plan all the things I'm going to do before my birthday party until *after* I actually get the presents! Because maybe I won't get exactly what I want, and then I'll be sad! (Feels like I've truly understood the lesson)

Those are excellent examples! It sounds like you really understand the lesson of the story. You know that it is better to be careful and mindful of the present instead of relying on future outcomes. <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "A Wise Old Owl." Now, tell me, what did the owl do every day?

(Eyes light up, beaming smile) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) The owl watched things happening by the oak tree! And he listened to people talking and telling stories! (Confidently) He watched and listened!
That's right! He watched and listened. Good job! Now, did the story say the owl talked a lot?

(Tilts head, thinking) Hmmm... (Taps chin) No! (Confidently) The story said the *more* he saw, the *less* he talked! He didn't talk a lot at all! Maybe he was too busy watching and listening? Is that right? (Looks at teacher expectantly)
Yes! That's exactly right! He was very busy watching and listening. Now, why do you think watching and listening made him wiser? What does "wise" mean?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) "Wise"... wise is like... (stuttering) knowing a lot of things? Like being really, really smart? (Looks up at the ceiling, trying to remember)

Maybe... maybe because he watched all those things happening, he learned from them! Like if he saw a bird fall out of its nest, he would learn to be careful when he flies! And if he heard people telling stories, he learned about all sorts of exciting adventures! (Enthusiastically) So he got smarter and smarter by watching and listening! Did I get it right? Is that what makes him wise?

You are doing a fantastic job! Yes, because he watched and listened, he learned a lot. He learned from what he saw and heard.

So, if the owl talked *more*, and watched *less*, do you think he would have learned as much?

(Frowns a little, concentrating) Hmmm... (Shakes head slowly) No, I don't think so. (Confidently) Because if he was talking, he wouldn't be *listening*! And if he wasn't listening, he wouldn't be learning!

(Raises hand again) It's like when I'm talking too much in class, I miss what you're saying, and then I don't know the answer! So the owl needed to be quiet so he could learn! That makes sense! (Nods head vigorously)
That's a perfect example! You understand! So, what do you think is the most important thing we can learn from the story of the wise old owl? What's the big idea of the story?

(Eyes sparkle, sitting up straight) Oooooh! The big idea! (Thinking hard)

(Points finger in the air) I think the big idea is that we should watch and listen more! Like the owl! We should pay attention to what's happening around us and listen to what people are saying! Because that's how we learn and become wise! (Beaming) So, we should be good watchers and good listeners!

(Raises hand again) Does that mean I should be quiet more often in class, so I can listen better? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression)

Yes, you've got it! Being a good watcher and listener helps us learn and understand the world around us. Just like the wise old owl! We can learn so much by paying attention and not always talking. That's the big idea. You explained that so well!

Is there anything else about the story you want to talk about? <finish>

(Smiling brightly) Hmm... (thinking) Well, I was wondering... (Looks away for a second, then back at the teacher) Did the owl ever get lonely, being so quiet? Maybe sometimes he wanted to tell someone all the things he learned? Or did being wise make him not need to talk as much? (Curious expression)

That's a very thoughtful question. The story doesn't tell us if the owl got lonely, but that's something interesting to think about. Maybe being wise helped him understand things in a different way, so he didn't feel the need to talk as much. Or maybe he did have friends he talked to sometimes! It's fun to imagine, isn't it?

You've really thought a lot about this story, and you understand the message very well. Great job today! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Who were the main people in the story?

(Eyes wide, a little wiggle in my seat)

Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand enthusiastically) The main people were the farmer and his wife! And the goose! But the farmer and his wife were the *most* main! They were the people we heard the most about, right? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for confirmation)

Yes! You got it! The farmer and his wife were the main people. And the goose too!

What did the goose give the farmer every day?

(Bounces slightly in my seat, eager to answer)

Oooooh! (Claps hands once) The goose gave him a GOLDEN EGG every day! (Confidently) A real, shiny, golden egg! It was so cool! (Tilts head slightly) Could you really have a goose that gives you golden eggs? That would be AMAZING!
(Smiling) That would be amazing! But in the story, what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard)

Hmmm… (Taps finger on chin) He… he… (Confidently) He sold it! He sold the golden egg so he could get money! And then he and his wife had a comfortable life! (Smiles brightly) Did he buy yummy food with the money?

He sold it and got money! That's right!

So, they were happy for a while. But what did the farmer start to feel after a while? How did he feel about the golden eggs?

(Puts hand up to chin, thinking, brow furrowed slightly)

Ummm… (stuttering slightly) I… I think… (brightens up) He got greedy! Yeah! He wanted more golden eggs! He wasn't happy with just one! (Shakes head disapprovingly) That wasn't very nice, was it? He should have been happy with what he had! Is "greedy" when you want more and more and more and you're never happy?

Yes, you are absolutely right! Greedy is wanting more and more and never being happy.

Because he was greedy, what did the farmer do to the goose?

(Eyes widen in shock and horror, hand flies to mouth)

Oh no! (Voice drops to a whisper) He… he didn't… he didn't… (Looks away, sad) He CUT the goose open! (Looks back at the teacher, face scrunched up in confusion) But why? Why would he do that? He's so silly, how can he cut the goose open? Did he think there were more golden eggs inside? (Confidently) But that's not how it works!
You're right. He cut the goose open. And what did he find inside? Did he find lots of golden eggs?

(Shakes head vigorously, a little bit disgusted)

Ewww! No! (Wrinkles nose) He found… (Lower voice) …blood and guts! (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression) That's yucky! And there were NO golden eggs! (Gestures dramatically with hands) Zero! He was so, so wrong! Why did he think there would be lots of golden eggs inside? That doesn't even make sense! (Looks up at the teacher, seeking reassurance) It was a very bad idea, right?

Yes, it was a very bad idea.

So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? What happened because he cut open the goose?

(Eyes widen, and a look of understanding dawns on my face)

(Confidently) Oh! Oh! I know! He didn't have any more golden eggs, so he couldn't sell them! (Frowns) And then they got poorer! They didn't have any money anymore! (Shakes head sadly) So he made a big mistake and now they are poor. (Tilts head inquisitively) Is that a good lesson about being greedy?

Yes! That is a very good lesson about being greedy. He wanted more too quickly, and now he has nothing.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What is the big message of the story?

(Puts hand on chin, thinking very hard)

Hmmmm… (Paces in place, feet shuffling) Okay, okay… (Stops pacing, eyes bright) It's telling us that we shouldn't be greedy! (Points finger up in the air) We should be happy with what we have! (More quietly) And we shouldn't be mean to animals! (Confidently) Because if we are greedy, we might lose everything, like the farmer did! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Is that right? And… and is it also about not being silly and cutting open a goose? (Giggles a little)

You're very close! It's about not being greedy, and it's definitely about not cutting open geese! (Smiling)

But it's also about thinking before you do something, especially something that could change things a lot. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he killed the goose.

So, what's a good way to say the message of the story? What should we remember to do before we do something big?

(Eyes light up)

Oooooh! (Claps hands once) I know! (Takes a deep breath, concentrating) We should… (Thinking hard, tapping finger on desk) … think… before we… act! (Nods head confidently) Because if we don't think, we might do something silly and lose everything, like the farmer! (Looks at the teacher with a big smile) Is "think before you act" the same as "look before you leap"? (Tilts head, curious)

Yes! "Think before you act" is a great way to say it! And yes, it's very similar to "look before you leap." They both mean to be careful and think about what might happen before you do something important. You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well".

Now, can you tell me, who were the people in the story?

(Eyes light up, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! There was a farmer, and a… a mean neighbour! (frowns) And the emperor! And… and a courtier! The courtier helped the emperor, right? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression)

That's right! You remembered everyone! Yes, the courtier helped the Emperor.

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Hmmm... The farmer... (Looks away for a second, then back with a bright smile) He wanted to get water! He wanted to water his farm so his plants could grow big and strong! (Pumps fist in the air) Like my bean plant we planted in class!

Exactly! He wanted water for his farm.

Why did the farmer go to the Emperor?

(Confidently) Because the mean neighbor wouldn't let him get water from the well he bought! (Frowns again) That's not fair! If you buy a well, you should be able to use the water, right? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) It's like if I bought a crayon, but then someone said I couldn't draw with it! That would be silly! (Giggles)

You're right, that wouldn't be fair!

So, the Emperor's courtier asked the neighbor why he wouldn't let the farmer use the water. What did the neighbor say?

(Tilts head, thinking) Hmmm... (Snaps fingers) I remember! He said he sold the *well*, but not the *water*! (Looks at the teacher with a puzzled expression) But that's like selling a cup but saying you can't put juice in it! Does that even make sense? (Asks the teacher earnestly)

That's a very good way to think about it! You are right, it doesn't really make sense.

What did the courtier tell the neighbour to do?

(Eyes widen, remembering the tricky part) Oh! Oh! This is a smart part! (Straightens up) The courtier told the neighbor that if he didn't sell the water, then he had to pay rent for the water if it was staying in the farmer's well! Or... or he had to take all the water out right away! (Smiles proudly) That was a super smart trick! (Looks at the teacher, excited)

That's right! It *was* a very smart trick.

Why do you think the courtier told the neighbour to do that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbour?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Hmmm... (Taps chin thoughtfully) I think... I think he wanted to show the neighbor that he was being greedy and not fair! (Looks up at the teacher) Because the neighbor was trying to trick the farmer, and the courtier wanted to show him that his trick didn't work! So he made up his *own* trick to show the neighbor he was being silly! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right?

You got it exactly right! The courtier was showing the neighbor that his trick didn't work and that he was being unfair.

What happened to the neighbour at the end of the story?

(Slightly triumphant) He...he said sorry! He realized he was being silly and not nice! (Looks at the teacher with a knowing smile) And then he went home! I bet he felt a little bit bad, right? (Pause, thoughtfully) I think he learned that it's better to be kind than to try and trick people!

Yes, I think you're right. He probably felt bad, and hopefully he learned a lesson!

So, what do you think is the most important thing we can learn from this story? What's the big message of "The Farmer and the Well"?

(Eyes widen, thinking about the whole story) Oooooh! (Pulls on shirt) The big message... (Pauses, looking thoughtful) I think...I think the big message is that it's important to be fair and not try to trick people! (Looks directly at the teacher, seriously) And that if someone *does* try to trick you, it's okay to ask for help to make things right! Like the farmer going to the Emperor! (Smiles brightly) That's what I think! Did I get it? Did I get the *whole* big message? (Eagerly awaits the teacher's response).
You got it! The big message is that trying to cheat or trick people doesn't work. It's always better to be honest and fair. Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! I really liked it. Now, let's talk about "Elephant and Friends."

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, finger tapping on the table) Um... the elephant... (pauses) I think he felt... sad? Because the story said he was lonely! He really wanted to find some friends in the forest, but nobody wanted to play with him. (Looks up at the teacher with a concerned expression) It made me feel a little sad too! Was he always lonely, Teacher?

That's right! He was sad because he was lonely.

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant?

(Straightens up, remembering the story) Oh! I know! (Confidently) The monkey said no because the elephant couldn't swing in the trees! Monkeys are really good at swinging, right? (tilts head, thoughtfully) Maybe the monkey thought it wouldn't be fun to have a friend who couldn't do what he liked to do? Do you think that was a good reason, Teacher?

That's a good point! The monkey wanted someone to swing with.

Was that a good reason to not be friends? Why or why not?

(Strokes chin, deep in thought) Hmmm... (pauses) I don't think it was a very good reason. (Shakes head slightly) Just because the elephant can't swing doesn't mean they couldn't do other fun things together! Maybe the elephant could give the monkey rides on his back, or they could find yummy fruits together on the ground! (Beams with enthusiasm) Being friends is about more than just doing the same things, right? It's about helping each other and having fun even if you're different! (Looks at the teacher hopefully) What do you think, Teacher?

You're absolutely right! There are lots of fun things they could do together, even if they are different.

What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

(Remembers the story, a slight frown appears) Oh, the rabbit! The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in the burrow. (Looks down at hands, thoughtfully) Rabbits live in small burrows, so I guess the elephant couldn't visit him inside his house. (Looks back up, a question in eyes) But couldn't they still be friends outside? Couldn't they play games in the meadow or share yummy carrots? (Raises hand slightly) Teacher, is it okay to not be friends with someone just because they are too big for your house?

You're thinking about this so well! The rabbit's reason was also about size, wasn't it?

Then, what happened the next day in the forest?

(Eyes widen with excitement, leans forward) Oh! Oh! I know! (Claps hands once) All the animals were running away! (Voice gets a little softer, concerned) They were scared because the tiger was attacking them! (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression) That sounds really scary, Teacher. Were they going to be okay?
Yes, it was a scary situation! What did the elephant do when he found out about the tiger?

(Beams with pride, sitting up straight) The elephant was so brave! He stopped the bear and then he went to talk to the tiger. He asked the tiger nicely to stop. (Frowns slightly) But the tiger wasn't nice back! He told the elephant to go away! (Shakes head disapprovingly) That wasn't very polite of the tiger, was it?
No, it wasn't polite at all! What did the elephant do *then*?

(Eyes widen, excited again, punches the air gently) He kicked the tiger! (Pauses, looks at the teacher, a little hesitant) Is it okay to kick, Teacher? (Quickly adds) Only if someone is hurting other people, right? Because the tiger was being mean and scaring everyone! After the elephant kicked the tiger, the tiger ran away! (Smiles brightly) The elephant saved the day!

You're right, the elephant helped everyone!

After the elephant scared away the tiger, how did the other animals feel about him?

(Beams with happiness, wiggles in seat) They liked him! They finally saw that the elephant was a good friend to have! (Pauses, thoughtfully) They realized he was big enough to protect them from the tiger! (Raises a finger) And maybe they also realized that being different isn't a bad thing! The elephant couldn't swing or fit in a burrow, but he could do things they couldn't do, like scare away a scary tiger! (Looks at the teacher, excited) So they all wanted to be his friend!

Exactly! They learned that being different can be a good thing.

So, what do you think is the lesson, or the moral, of the story "Elephant and Friends"? What did you learn from it?

(Puts a hand on chin, thinking very hard, looks up at the ceiling) Hmmm... (pauses, then speaks confidently) I think the story teaches us that... (takes a deep breath) ...we shouldn't judge people just because they are different from us! And that everyone is good at something, even if it's not the same thing as everyone else! (Smiles brightly) And... (pauses, tapping chin) ...that it's important to be kind and helpful, because you never know when someone might need you! (Looks at the teacher, very proud) Did I get it right, Teacher?
You got it! Friends can be any shape or size. It's about being kind and helpful, no matter what. You understood the story so well! <finish>
Okay, that was a good story, right? Tell me, what did the girl want from her dad?

(Smiling brightly and bouncing slightly in my seat) Yes! It was a *really* good story! The girl... (thinking hard, tapping my chin) ...she was, um, sad about something in her life! And she wanted her daddy to help her! So she asked him for advice! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping I got it right) Did I get it right, Teacher? I think she was feeling like... (stuttering a little) ...things were hard for her.
Yes, you got it! She was feeling like things were hard for her. Good job! Now, what did her dad ask her to bring him?

(Eyes widening and hands clapping) Oh! Oh! I know this one! He asked her to bring... (counting on my fingers) ...an egg, and a potato, and... (pauses, concentrating) ...tea leaves! Two tea leaves! (Looks at the teacher, beaming, eager to show I remember). It was a funny list! Why did he want those things? (Tilts head, curious) Was he going to make something yummy?
He did have a funny list! He didn't make anything yummy to eat right away. What did he *do* with the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves?

(Wrinkling my nose and thinking hard) Hmmm... He didn't eat them... (Snapping my fingers) Oh! He put them in... (Eyes widening in realization) ...in water! In boiling water! He put each one in a different pot of boiling water. (Confidently) He boiled them! Like when my mommy makes eggs for breakfast! (Tilts head again) But why? Why boil a potato? And tea leaves? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look).
Good job remembering! He boiled them. Now, what happened to the egg *after* it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, then eyes widening) No! No, it wasn't the same! (Confidently) It got hard! The soft egg became hard! (Puts hands up in a gesture of explaining) Like... like when you squeeze a soft egg, it breaks, but when you squeeze a hard-boiled egg, it's strong! (Looks at the teacher, pleased with my explanation) Did I explain that good, Teacher?
You explained that *perfectly*! Now, what about the potato? What happened to *it* after being boiled?

(Thinking, tapping my chin) The potato... hmm... the potato was... (eyes light up) ...it was the opposite! It was hard before, but then it got soft! Like... like when Mommy makes mashed potatoes! (Smiling) You can squish them! (Confidently) So the potato got soft! That's easy to remember! (Looks at the teacher expectantly). Did the potato change, too, Teacher?
Yes, the potato changed too! And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Wrinkling my forehead in concentration) Hmmm... the tea leaves... (pauses, thinking hard). They didn't get hard or soft... (Eyes widening) They changed the *water*! The tea leaves changed the water itself! It wasn't just plain water anymore, it was tea! (Looks at the teacher, proud of figuring it out). They made the water different! That's so cool!

That's right! The tea leaves changed the water. So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all went into the same hot water, but they all changed in different ways.

Now, the story said that the hot water was like... what? What did the hot water remind you of?

(Thinking hard, scrunching up my nose) Hmmm... The hot water was like... (Eyes widening) ...like when things are hard for you! Like when the girl was feeling sad! (Looks at the teacher, excited to make the connection) It's like the problems and the yucky feelings! The hot water is like... adversity! (Smiles proudly, remembering a big word). It's like when things are tough! Am I right, Teacher?

You are *absolutely* right! The hot water is like when things are tough, like adversity. So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same tough situation – the hot water. But they each reacted differently.

The egg became hard. The potato became soft. The tea changed the water. What do you think that means for *us* when things get tough?

(Eyes widening, thinking deeply, and then looking away for a moment). Hmmm... (Looks back at the teacher, a little hesitant) It means... (stuttering slightly) ...that when things are hard... (Thinking more confidently) ...we can be like the egg and get stronger! Or... (Pauses, thinking) ...we can be like the potato and get soft and... (Searching for the right word) ...and give up? But the tea... (Eyes lighting up) ...the tea is the best! The tea *changes* things! So, when things are hard, we can change the problem itself! (Beaming at the teacher, proud of figuring it out.) Like... like if I can't read a word, I can ask for help and then I can read it! That's like changing the water! Right?

Yes! You are exactly right! You understood the story so well. We can choose how we react when things get hard. We can become hard, we can become soft, or we can change the situation itself.

So, what is the story trying to teach us? What's the big idea?

(Smiling widely, bouncing a little) The big idea is... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...that when adversity knocks, we get to choose what to do! (Pointing a finger in the air) We can be strong like the egg, or... (Slight frown) ...we can be soft like the potato, or... (Eyes shining with excitement) ...we can be amazing like the tea and *change the whole thing*! So, when things get tough, I'm going to try to be like the tea! (Looks at the teacher with determination). I'm going to try and change the water! That's a really, really good lesson! Thank you for reading me the story! Can we read another one? (Clapping hands together excitedly).
You got it! You understood the story and its message perfectly! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. That's a very important lesson to remember. <finish>

Okay! Hi there! That was a great job reading "The Needle Tree"!

Now, let's talk about the story. Can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?

Hi Teacher! (Smiling brightly) Thank you! I really liked the story!

(Eyes widening, thinking) Hmm, the older brother… (Sticking out my tongue slightly in concentration) He was… cutting firewood! Yeah! (Nodding enthusiastically) He wanted to sell it at the market! (Confident smile) He was chopping, chopping, chopping! (Making chopping motions with my hands) Was that right? (Looking at the teacher expectantly)

That's exactly right! He was chopping firewood to sell at the market. Great job!

Now, what did he find in the forest one day? Something special!

Ooh! Ooh! (Waving hand excitedly) I know! (Confidently) He found a magical tree! (Eyes sparkling) A really, really special one! (Thinking) It could talk! (Looking at the teacher) Was it a talking tree because it was magic? (Tilting head curiously) And…and it didn't want to be chopped down! (Frowning slightly)

Yes, you're doing so well! It was a magical, talking tree!

What did the tree offer the older brother, so he wouldn't chop it down?

(Eyes lighting up) Golden apples! (Smiling widely) Shiny, golden apples! The tree said, “Please don’t chop me! I’ll give you golden apples!” (Imitating a pleading voice) The older brother wanted the golden apples, but… (Frowning, thinking) Did he want more? (Looking at the teacher with a questioning look) I think he wanted *lots* more!

You are exactly right! He did want more.

How did the older brother feel about the number of golden apples he received? Was he happy?

(Shaking head vigorously) Nope! (Frowning) He wasn't happy at all! He was… (Searching for the right word) disappointed! (Confidently) He thought he should get more! He was being… (Thinking hard, wrinkling nose) …greedy! (Looking proud of myself for remembering the word) He wanted, wanted, wanted more! (Making grabbing motions with hands)
"Greedy" is a perfect word! He was being very greedy. And what happened when he tried to cut down the tree anyway?

(Gasps dramatically) The tree got him! (Eyes wide) It didn't want to be chopped! (Thinking hard) It showered him with… with pointy things! (Searching for the word) Needles! (Pointing finger up in the air triumphantly) Lots and lots of needles! It must have hurt SO much! (Making a pained face) Did the needles poke him everywhere? (Looking at the teacher with concern)

Yes, it hurt him very much! He was covered in needles.

Then, who came to help him?

(Smiling softly) The younger brother! (Nodding) The nice one! (Thinking) He wasn’t greedy like the older brother. (Confident tone) He helped him! He took out all the pointy needles! (Making gentle pulling motions with my hands) He was very kind! (Looking at the teacher) Was it hard to pull all those needles out?

It must have been very hard and taken a long time. The younger brother was being very kind and patient.

What did the older brother say after his younger brother helped him?

(Thinking, tapping chin) Hmmm… He said… (Eyes widening) He said sorry! (Sincerely) He said he was sorry for being mean! He finally learned his lesson! (Beaming) Did he really mean it? (Looking at the teacher, hoping for confirmation) It's important to say sorry when you've been bad, right?

Yes, it's very important to say sorry when you've been bad, and it sounds like he really meant it this time!

What happened after the older brother apologized? What did the magical tree do?

(Eyes lighting up again) Oh! Oh! I remember! (Excitedly) The magical tree saw that the older brother was sorry and… and gave them MORE golden apples! (Clapping hands) Because the younger brother was nice, and the older brother said sorry! It's like the tree knew they learned a good lesson! (Looking thoughtful) So being nice and saying sorry gives you golden apples? (Tilting head and looking at the teacher with a curious expression) Not real golden apples, right? Just good things?

You're so clever! You're right, maybe not *real* golden apples, but good things!

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big message of the story? Think about how the brothers acted and what happened to them.

(Thinking really hard, brow furrowed) Hmmm… It’s teaching us… (Pausing) That being greedy is bad! (Nodding) And being mean to your brother is bad too! (Looking at the teacher) The older brother learned that! (Smiling) And being nice and saying sorry are good! (Confidently) Because the tree gave them more golden apples when they were good! (Thinking a little more) So… it’s about being kind and not greedy, and saying sorry when you make mistakes! (Beaming proudly) Did I get it right? (Looking at the teacher with anticipation) It's a good lesson! I like learning good lessons!

You got it exactly right! Being kind is very important. The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen. Sometimes, kindness is rewarded.

So, we can say the moral of the story is: Kindness will always be rewarded. Can you say that?

(Smiling brightly) Kindness will always be rewarded! (Nodding enthusiastically) I can say it! Kindness will always be rewarded! (Beaming) I like that! It's a good rule to remember! (Looking at the teacher) Can we read another story now? (Eagerly) Maybe one with more magic?
That's fantastic! You understood the story and its message perfectly. You are a super star! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's see if we can remember what happened. Who was King Midas? What did he do?

(Eyes wide, a little fidgety)

Um... King Midas? (Looks down at my hands) He... he was a king! (Confident now, remembering the story) And he helped a... a Satyr! (Smiles proudly) He was nice to him! And then... and then the god... the wine god... (Sticks tongue out, concentrating) Dionysus! He said King Midas could have a wish!
Excellent! You remembered all of that! Dionysus did offer him a wish. What did King Midas wish for?

(Bounces a little in my seat, excited)

He wished... he wished for everything he touched... (Looks up, remembering carefully) ...to turn to GOLD! (Claps hands together excitedly, then immediately shrinks back, nervous) He... he really wanted that! (Frowns a little, remembering the sad part)

Yes, he did! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, after he got his wish, was King Midas happy at first? What did he do?

(Nods head enthusiastically, then wrings hands together)

Yes! Yes! He was SO happy! (Voice gets louder, more excited) He touched his chair and it turned to gold! And then... then he touched a table! GOLD! (Looks at the teacher with wide eyes, then lowers voice) He... he was really, really happy... at first. (Worried look on face)
You're right! He was very happy at first. But what happened after a while? Did he *stay* happy?

(Looks down at shoes, shuffling them)

No... (Voice is very quiet) He got hungry. (Looks up quickly, then down again) But... but when he tried to eat... his food turned into gold too! (Starts to tear up a little) And... and then his daughter... (Sniffs, voice trembling) she wanted to hug him... and... (Voice cracks) she turned into gold too! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes pleading) It was... it was terrible!
It *was* terrible! You're absolutely right. So, King Midas got his wish, but in the end, was it a good wish?

(Shakes head emphatically, tears welling up)

No! (Wipes eyes with back of hand) It was the worst wish EVER! (Sticks out lower lip and frowns) He couldn't eat! And... and he turned his daughter into gold! (Looks at the teacher, anxiously) He didn't want that! He didn't!
He certainly didn't want that. So, he thought having everything turn to gold would make him happy, but it didn't. Why do you think it didn't make him happy? What went wrong?

(Bites lip, thinking hard. Stares intently at the teacher)

(Stuttering) Um... because... because he couldn't... he couldn't eat the gold! (Points to stomach) And he couldn't... he couldn't hug his daughter! (Frowns, confused) Gold is... is pretty. But... but you can't... you can't eat it. And you can't... (Voice trails off, uncertain)

Can I ask a question?
Of course, you can ask a question! What is it?

(Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes)

Did... did the wine god... Dionysus... did he change her back? Did he make his daughter not gold anymore? (Voice full of hope) I really hope so!

That's a very good question. The story doesn't *exactly* say, but it does say that King Midas learned a lesson and begged Dionysus to take the golden touch away. And Dionysus, being a kind god, told him how to wash the gold away.

So, what do you think? If King Midas could wash the gold away from everything else, do you think he could wash it away from his daughter too?

(Eyes widen, hope flooding back into face. Claps hands softly)

Oh! Oh, I hope so! (Nods head vigorously) If he washed it all away, then she would be okay! (Voice is lighter, happier) And then he could eat again too! (Smiles shyly) That's good! That's really good! (Relief washes over face)
It *is* good! So, King Midas learned that even though gold is pretty, it isn't the most important thing, right? What are some things that are *more* important than gold, do you think?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk)

(Looks at the teacher hesitantly) Um... food? (Looks down, then back up, gaining confidence) And... and hugs! (Smiles brightly) And... (Scrunches up face, concentrating) ... and being able to... to play outside! (Nods head decisively) Yes! Those are more important! Way more important than just gold!

You got it! Food, hugs, playing outside... those are all wonderful things that are much more important than gold.

So, if King Midas was so unhappy even though he had so much gold, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, the lesson, of the story? Why do you think the author wrote it?

(Looks away, a little nervous, then looks back at the teacher)

(Quietly) Um... (Bites lip again) Maybe... maybe it's trying to say that... that just because you *want* something really, really bad... it doesn't mean it will make you happy? (Voice gets a little stronger) And... and that sometimes... the things you already *have*... like food and hugs... (Smiles) ... are the best things ever? (Looks at the teacher, a little anxiously) Is that right?

That's *absolutely* right! You figured it out! Sometimes wanting too much, or being too greedy, can actually make us unhappy. King Midas was so greedy for gold, he forgot about the things that really mattered.

So, we could say that being too greedy, wanting too much, can lead to your own downfall. It can make you lose the things that are truly important. Does that make sense?

(Nods head enthusiastically, relieved and proud)

Yes! It makes lots of sense! (Voice is confident and happy) So... so it's better to be happy with what you have! (Thinks for a moment) And... and to be nice to people, like King Midas was nice to the Satyr! (Smiles at the teacher) I understand! (Claps hands once, softly)
You really do understand! You did a fantastic job thinking about the story and figuring out what it means. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of "The Fox and the Grapes".

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Eyes wide, a little fidgety)

Umm... (Stuttering) Hi Teacher! Thank you for saying I read well! (Beaming)

The fox... the fox was looking for... (thinking hard, tapping my foot) food! He was very, very hungry and couldn't find any food anywhere! (Looks at the teacher for approval, hoping I'm right). I remember that part!

Yes! That's right! The fox was very hungry and looking for food. Good job!

Now, what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Clapping my hands excitedly)

Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand high) He found... (pauses, trying to remember the color) ...big, (stuttering slightly) p-p-purple, juicy grapes! (Confidently) They were on the farmer's wall! He wanted them so much! (Bouncing in my seat a little)

Excellent! Big, purple, juicy grapes! You remembered all the details.

What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Eagerly) He jumped! He jumped really, really high! (Stands up and demonstrates a jump, almost bumping the desk) He jumped as high as he could! He wanted those grapes so badly! (Sits back down, a little flushed) He kept jumping and jumping and jumping! (Frowns a little) But... but he couldn't reach them. (Looks down at my hands, a little disappointed).
That's right! He jumped and jumped. Did he get the grapes?

(Voice gets quieter, looking down)

No... (shaking my head) He couldn't get them. He tried so hard, but the grapes were too high. (Looks up at the teacher with a slightly worried expression) Did he *have* to get the grapes? I feel a little sad for the fox. (My bottom lip trembles a little).

It's okay to feel sad for the fox. He was very hungry! But he didn't get the grapes.

What did the fox do *after* he couldn't reach the grapes?

(Sniffling a little, but trying to focus)

He... (pauses, thinking hard) He gave up! (Voice cracks a little) And then... then he went home. He said... (eyes widen as I remember) ...he said the grapes were sour anyway! (A little spark of excitement returns) Even though he didn't even taste them! (Looks at the teacher, tilting my head slightly) Was that a good thing to say, Teacher? (Anxious look returns).
That's exactly right! He said the grapes were sour. Now, do you *think* the grapes were really sour?

(Frowning, thinking really hard and tapping my chin)

Yes! That's a *very* good way to explain it! He was probably sad and embarrassed.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

It's okay if things are hard to get, right? We can't *always* get what we want. Think about the grapes. Did the fox get them easily?

The story teaches us two things:

1.  Things we want don't always come easy.
2.  It's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it.

Yes! That is *exactly* it! You worked so hard to understand the story, and you did a fantastic job! You understand that things we want don't always come easy, and it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it.

That's a fantastic way to put it! You're absolutely right. Don't make happy plans until you know it will happen. Or, another way to say it is: don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. That's what Molly learned. She learned to wait and be sure *before* she started planning.

Now, what happened the next day in the forest? What were all the animals doing?

(Eyes widen, forgetting sadness for a moment and becoming excited again. Sits up straighter.) The next day! The next day was... (Taps finger on desk, concentrating) ...scary! (Voice gets higher, more dramatic.) All the animals were running! Running and screaming! (Looks around the room as if imagining the scene) They were all scared! (Pauses for effect) The tiger was chasing them!
That's right! The tiger was chasing them. And what did the elephant do when he saw the tiger?

(Beams, eager to tell the exciting part) He... he stopped the tiger! (Voice filled with awe) He was so brave! He told the tiger to stop! (Acts out being the elephant, raising trunk) He said, "Please stop, Mr. Tiger!" (Pauses, then frowns slightly) But... but the tiger didn't listen. The tiger was mean!
The tiger *was* mean! And what happened *after* the tiger was mean? What did the elephant do *then*?

(Gasps, eyes wide with excitement and a big smile) He kicked him! (Whispers loudly, like a secret) He kicked the tiger *really* hard! (Pumps fist in the air) And... and the tiger ran away! (Claps hands together, delighted) The elephant saved everyone! He was a hero!
He *was* a hero! And after the elephant saved everyone, what did the other animals think about him? Did they still think he was too big or too clumsy?

(Tilts head, thinking) Hmmm... (Snaps fingers, remembering) No! (Voice filled with excitement and understanding) They... they liked him then! They saw he was strong and could help them! They wanted to be his friends! (Smiles widely) Because he saved them! They knew he was a good friend after all! (Nods head vigorously, very pleased with herself)

Exactly! They realized he was a good friend after all. So, at the beginning, the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant because he was different. But at the end, they *did* want to be his friend.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks thoughtful, tapping chin with finger) Hmmm... (Pauses, then speaks slowly and carefully) Maybe... maybe it's about... (Looks up, eyes shining with understanding) ...being nice to people even if they're different! (Voice becomes more confident) And... and that even if you're big or can't climb trees, you can still be a good friend and help people! (Smiles brightly) It's important to be nice to everyone! (Nods head firmly, very pleased with the answer)

That's a *wonderful* way to put it! You're exactly right! Sometimes we think people need to be just like us to be our friends. But this story shows us that friends can be different sizes, and good at different things.

So, what could we say is the moral of the story? What's the big lesson it teaches us? Think about how the animals first said no because the elephant was different, but then they became friends.

(Thinking hard, biting lip slightly) Okay... okay... (Eyes light up) The moral... is that... (Takes a deep breath) ...is that you shouldn't judge a book by its cover! (Beams, proud of using a big-kid saying) Or... or that you should give everyone a chance! Even if they're different! (Nods head, very satisfied with the answer) And... and maybe that being different is good! Because the elephant's bigness helped him save the day! (Claps hands together happily)

Those are all excellent morals! And you're right, being different can be a good thing! It's like having a toolbox with lots of different tools. Each tool is good for a different job!

Here's another way to say it: Friends can be any shape or size!

Do you think you understand the story and what it teaches us now? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good one. Now, let's talk about it.

What did the girl in the story feel at the start?
(Eyes wide, a little nervous) Um... she was... frustrated? (Fidgets with my hands) With life! Yeah, she didn't... didn't like life very much. Was she sad? Maybe sad and frustrated!
Yes, that's right! She was frustrated and maybe even a little sad. What did she do because she felt that way?
(Looks up, remembering) She... she asked her daddy! (Smiling brightly) She asked her daddy for help! He's a good daddy. (Looks down again, a little anxious) Is that right?
That's exactly right! And what did her dad ask her to get? Do you remember the three things?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) Okay, okay... he wanted... um... (Stuttering slightly) a... a... pot-ta-to? (Looks up, hopeful) And... and an egg! Yes! And... (Eyes dart around, trying to remember) Tea? Tea leaves! (Claps hands softly) I remembered!
Wonderful! You remembered all three. Now, what did he do with the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves?

(Eyes light up, excited) He... he boiled them! In water! (Points enthusiastically) He had three pots and he put one thing in each pot and boiled them all! (Bounces slightly in my seat) It was like a science experiment!
That's a great way to describe it! It *was* like a science experiment. What happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?
(Looks down, furrowing brow) It... it changed. (Looks up, hesitant) It got... hard? (Voice is quiet) It was soft before, right? And then it was hard... (Anxious look on face) Did I get it right?
You got it exactly right! The soft egg became hard. And what happened to the potato?
(Eyes widen, remembering) The potato... the potato was hard, and then... (Thinking hard, almost whispering) ...it got... soft? (Looks up, nervously) It got all mushy and soft after being boiled!
Yes! The hard potato became soft. And what about the tea leaves? What happened to them?

(Concentrating, fiddling with my hands) The tea leaves... um... they didn't get hard or soft... (Looks puzzled) ...they... (Eyes widen with realization) ...they changed the water! (Voice gets louder, more excited) The water turned into tea!

That's right! The tea changed the water. So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all went into the same hot water, but they all changed in different ways.

Now, the story says this is like when "adversity knocks." What do you think "adversity" means? Maybe a hard time? A problem?

(Looks down, worried. Fidgets more) Adversity... is that like... when things are bad? (Stuttering) Like... like when you... you fall down and scrape your knee? (Looks up, teary-eyed) Is that adversity?

Yes, that's a great way to think about it! Adversity is like when things are hard or bad, like scraping your knee. So, the hot water is like a hard time.

What happened to the egg when it had a hard time?
(Sniffling a little, but trying to focus) The egg... (Thinking) ...it got... stronger? (Looks up, unsure) It was soft, and then the hot water made it hard and strong. So adversity made it stronger?
That's a good way to put it! The egg became hard and strong. What about the potato? What happened to *it* when it had a hard time?

(Wipes eyes quickly, trying to be brave) The potato... (Thinking, tapping fingers on the desk) ...it got... weaker? (Looks down, a little ashamed) It was strong, and then the hot water made it soft and... and mushy. So adversity made it weaker. (Voice is very quiet)
You're doing great! Yes, the potato got softer and weaker. And what did the tea leaves do in the hard time?

(Brightens up a little, remembering) The tea! (Smiling slightly) The tea... it changed the water! (Looks thoughtful) It made the water into something new and... and good! (Confidently) It changed everything!

Exactly! So, the egg changed itself, the potato changed itself, and the tea changed the water. They each responded to the hot water – to the hard time – in a different way.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about hard times? What can *we* do when adversity knocks?

(Thinking hard, looking around the room) Um... (Stuttering) Maybe... maybe we can be like the tea? (Looks down, a little nervous) Change things around us? (Looks up, more confidently) Or... or we can be like the egg and get stronger! (Fidgets again) Or... (Voice trails off, sadly) ...we could be like the potato and get soft... (Looks up, worried) But we shouldn't be like the potato, right? We should try to be like the tea or the egg!

That's a *fantastic* observation! You're exactly right. We can choose how we react when things get tough. We can become stronger like the egg, or we can change the situation around us like the tea.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What's the lesson we should learn?

(Smiling proudly, standing a little taller) The big idea... (Pauses, thinking carefully) ...is that when things are hard, we get to choose! (Looks excited) We can choose to be strong, or we can choose to change things! (Looks down for a second, then back up, brightly) But we should try to choose to be strong or change things! (Claps hands softly) I like that!

You got it! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be strong, we can choose to change things, or... well, or we can choose to be soft, but it's better to try and be strong or change things!

You really understood the story, and you explained it so well. I'm very proud of you! <finish>
Okay, wonderful reading! That was a good story, wasn't it? Now, can you tell me, who were the main people in the story?

(Eyes wide, beaming smile) Yes! It was a *really* good story! (bounces slightly)

The magical tree with the golden apples! (claps hands once) Those were the main people! I think so! (looks at the teacher expectantly) Did I get it right?

He was a good brother! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for praise)

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Hmm... (taps chin with a finger) After... after the younger brother helped him... (eyes light up with recognition) Oh! The older brother said sorry! (Eyes widen, bouncing slightly in seat) Oh! Oh! This is the best part! (Voice filled with excitement) The tree... the tree saw that the older brother was really sorry! So... (pauses for dramatic effect) So it gave them *more* golden apples! (Giggles) Lots and lots of golden apples! Because they were being nice to each other! (Looks at the teacher with a big, hopeful smile) Did they share the apples? I hope they shared the apples! That's what good brothers do!
I'm sure they shared the apples! So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to tell us?

(Bites lip, looking thoughtful) Hmmm... (Looks down at my hands, then back up at the teacher, a little nervously) It's... it's about being nice? (Frowns, unsure) And... and not being greedy? (Voice trembling a little) And... and saying sorry when you make a mistake? (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) Is that right? (Suddenly perks up, remembering something) Oh! And... and helping each other! Even if someone isn't nice to you! (Sits up straighter, beaming) Because being kind is... is a good thing! (Nods head confidently) Yes!
You're getting very close! So, if you are kind to others, what might happen? Think about what happened to the brothers in the story.

(Thinking hard, squinting eyes slightly) If you're kind... (Eyes widen, realization dawning) If you're kind, then... then good things might happen! (Voice getting excited) Like... like the tree giving them more apples! (Bounces in seat again) So, if you're nice, other people will be nice back! (Looks down for a moment, then back up with a determined expression) So... so being kind is like magic! (Claps hands together) It makes good things happen!

Exactly! Being kind *is* like magic! So, we can say that being kind is often rewarded. If you are kind, good things can happen to you. Can you think of a short sentence that tells us what the story is all about? A sentence that tells us to be kind?

(Concentrating hard, wrinkling nose) Okay... okay... (Mumbles to self) Be kind... good things... (Suddenly brightens, eyes sparkling) I got it! I got it! (Beams with pride) "Be kind, and good things will come!" (Claps hands together, thrilled with my answer) Is that good? Is that a good sentence? (Looks at the teacher, bursting with excitement)
That's a *perfect* sentence! You figured out that the story is about how kindness will always be rewarded. You understood the story very well. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a long one.

First, tell me: Who was King Midas?
(Beaming and raising my hand eagerly) I know, I know! King Midas was... (pauses, tapping my chin thoughtfully, but answers confidently) a Greek king! And he did something nice for a Satyr!

Because he was nice, what did Dionysus offer him?

(Eyes wide, I bounce slightly in my seat) Dionysus... Dionysus was the god of wine! (Speaking clearly and excitedly) And he gave King Midas a... a... (Sticks tongue out, concentrating) a... wish! (Looks up, proud) He gave him a wish because he was nice!

Excellent! He did indeed.

What did King Midas wish for?

(Eyes sparkling, hands clasped in front of me) He wished that... everything he touched would turn to... gold! (Nodding enthusiastically) All shiny and gold! (Confidently) He really, really wanted that!
