(Frowning slightly, but still eager to answer) Oh! Oh, that was bad! (Thinking) He... he couldn't eat! (A little louder) Because the food... (pauses, choosing my words carefully) the food turned into gold too! He couldn't eat yummy bread or anything! (Shakes head, looking a bit sad).

That's right! He couldn't eat anything.

And then, what happened with his daughter?

(My face falls, and I look down at my hands for a moment) Oh no... (Looks back up, eyes wide with slight worry) His daughter... she wanted to hug him, because he was sad! (Voice gets a little quieter) But when she hugged him... she turned into gold too! (Shakes my head sadly) It's not a good wish!
No, it wasn't a good wish. Now, after all of that happened, how did King Midas feel about his golden touch? Did he still think it was a good thing?

(Shaking my head vigorously) No! No, he didn't! (Confidently) He learned it wasn't a good wish at all! (Thinking) He was probably very sad! (Looks at you expectantly) Because he couldn't eat and his daughter was gold!
You're exactly right! He was very sad. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Why wasn't the golden touch a good thing, even though gold seems wonderful?

(Tilts head, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Sticks tongue out a little) It... it teaches us that... (Choosing my words carefully) that... things aren't always good just because they're shiny! (Looks up, confident again) He thought gold was the best, but he needed... (pauses) food! And hugs! (Nods emphatically) So, it's better to have food and hugs than just gold!
That's a very good way to put it! So, what if King Midas wasn't so eager to have *everything* turn to gold? What if he was happy with what he already had?

(Eyes widen, considering the question) Hmmm... (Thinking, tapping my finger on the table) If he was happy already... then he wouldn't need the wish! (Excitedly) He could still eat his food, and he could still hug his daughter! (Smiling brightly) So, it's good to be happy with what you have! (Nods enthusiastically).
Yes! It's good to be happy with what you have. Wanting too much, or always wanting *more*, can lead to bad things. Does that give you an idea of what the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) So... (Voice a little lower, concentrating) wanting too much... is bad... (Looks up, eyes sparkling with understanding) It's like... being greedy! The story teaches us not to be greedy! (Nods, very pleased with myself) Because then you might turn your daughter into gold! (Giggles a little at the thought, then becomes serious again)

You got it! Being greedy, wanting too much, can lead to bad things happening. The story teaches us that being happy with what you have is much better than always wanting more. You understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of "The Fox and the Grapes".

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly on my heels) Ooooh! I know, I know! The fox was looking for… food! (Points finger up excitedly) He was super hungry! He looked *everywhere*!
That's right! He was very hungry. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?
(Beams, nodding enthusiastically) He found… grapes! Big, purple, JUICY grapes! (Holds hands out in a circle to show how big the grapes were) They looked yummy!
They did look yummy! So, what did the fox try to do?

(Shifts feet, thinking hard) Hmmm… (pauses, then voice gets louder and more confident) He tried to… (jumps up and down a little) …he tried to reach the grapes! He jumped really, REALLY high! (Demonstrates a small jump). He wanted those grapes!
He did! He jumped really high. But did he get the grapes?
(Frowns a little, then shakes head with a small giggle) Nope! (Confidently) He tried and tried, but he couldn't reach them! He just couldn't! (Shrugs shoulders)
That's right! He couldn't reach them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes? Where did he go?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping chin) Hmm… (Looks at the teacher, then back down at my hands) After he couldn't get them... (Brightens up again) He went home! (Voice louder and more enthusiastic) He gave up and went home!
Good! He went home. Now, this is important. What did the fox say about the grapes *after* he couldn't reach them? What did he *think* about the grapes?

(Tilts head, thinking. Looks down, then back up) Hmmm… He said… (Eyes light up) He said they were sour! (Makes a sour face) Yuck! He said they *must* be sour anyway! (Nods head firmly). He didn't want them anymore!
Excellent! He said they were sour. Why do you think he said that? He really wanted those grapes at first, didn't he?

(Thinking hard, looks away for a second) Hmmm... (Scrunches up nose) Because... because he couldn't get them! (Points finger) He was probably sad! (Looks back at the teacher, confident again) But he didn't want to *say* he was sad, so he said the grapes were sour!

That's a very good idea! Yes, he didn't want to be sad. So he said the grapes were sour!

Now, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the story trying to tell us? It's okay if it's hard! Think about the fox and the grapes.

(Thinking really hard, tapping fingers on leg. Looks at the ceiling for a second.) Hmmm… (Frowns a little, then brightens up) Is it like… like when I want a toy at the store, and my mom says no, and then I say I didn't *really* want it anyway? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is it like that? Because the fox *did* want the grapes! He just… couldn't get them.

Yes! That's a *very* good connection! It is like that.

So, what do you think the story wants us to learn about not getting what we want?

(Nods head, understanding dawning) Oooooh! (Pauses to think, then smiles brightly) It means… it means we shouldn't say we don't want something just because we can't have it! (Looks at the teacher proudly) Because the fox *did* want the grapes! It's better to just say… "Aw, man! I wish I could reach those grapes!" instead of saying they are yucky!

That's a *fantastic* way to put it! You got it! It's about not pretending we don't want something just because we can't get it. It also teaches us that things might be difficult, and that's okay. Sometimes we can't have everything we want.

Here's another way to think about it: Nothing comes easy, so don't hate what you can't have.

Do you understand?

(Nods head enthusiastically) Yes! I understand! (Repeats confidently) Nothing comes easy, so don't hate what you can't have! (Beams) It's like… it's like when I try to build a really tall tower with my blocks! Sometimes it falls down, but I shouldn't say I don't like building towers just because it's hard! I should just keep trying! (Claps hands together excitedly)

That's a perfect example! You understand the story and what it teaches us very well.

...It means... wanting... too much? (Frowns slightly, trying to articulate the thought) Like... like wanting more than you need? Even if... even if it hurts other people?

Yes! That's a great way to explain it. Wanting too much, more than you need. And sometimes, wanting too much can lead to bad things happening.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about being greedy?

(Looks down, thinking deeply, then looks up with a slightly worried expression)

...That... that being greedy... (Hesitates) ...can make you lose... the things that are really important? (Voice is soft) Like... like love... and family... and... and being able to eat? (Looks at the teacher, seeking reassurance)

Yes! Exactly! Being greedy can make you lose the things that are truly important. The story shows us that being greedy didn't make Midas happy, it made him very sad and it hurt the people he loved.

So, what lesson can we learn from the story of King Midas? What is the story trying to tell us?

(Sits up a little straighter, trying to sound more confident, but still a little hesitant)

...That... that we should be... (Takes a deep breath) ...grateful for what we have? (Looks at the teacher, then quickly looks down again) And... and that love... and family... and... and being able to eat yummy food... are... are more important than... than having lots of... shiny gold? (Voice trails off, then adds almost as an afterthought) ...Right?

(Looks up at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes)

Right! You got it! The story teaches us that being greedy can lead to sadness and loss. It's better to be happy with what we have and to value the things that are truly important, like family and friends. You understood the story so well. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! You read that story really well.

Now, let's talk about the fox. Was he happy at the start of the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... no. (Hesitates) I... I don't think so. He was... hungry. (Looks up quickly, then back down)
That's right! He was hungry. And what was he looking for?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

He... he was looking for... food! (Says it a little louder this time, but still avoids direct eye contact) Big, juicy...food. Is that right?
Yes, that's absolutely right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Eyes widen slightly)

Grapes! (Confidently) Big, purple... grapes! (Starts to get a little more excited) They looked... yummy. But... (frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...but he couldn't reach them.
He couldn't reach them! That's important. What did he do to try and get them? Did he just stand there?

(Shakes head quickly)

No! (Thinks, tapping chin) He... he jumped! (Looks up at the teacher) He jumped really high! He tried... lots of times. (Voice gets quieter again) But he... he couldn't get them. (Looks down again, a little sad)
You're doing great! He jumped and jumped. And what happened after he jumped and jumped and couldn't get them? What did he do then?

(Starts to bite lip, looking anxious)

He... (pauses, looking around the room) ...he went away. (Whispers) He gave up. (Suddenly looks up, eyes wide) But... but he said the grapes were sour! Even though... even though he didn't even try them! Is that... is that okay to say that? (Fidgets more)
That's a very good question! Is it okay to say that? Why do you think he said they were sour? He couldn't reach them, and then he said they were sour. Why?

(Thinking hard, chewing on the end of a pencil)

(Confidently) Maybe... maybe he was sad! (Frowns again) ... Or... or embarrassed! (Looks up, a new thought dawning on face) ...Or... (uses a big word) frustrated! (Hesitates) Because he couldn't get them. So he said they were sour... so he wouldn't feel so bad. (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that... is that right? Did he feel *frustrated*?

Yes! I think you're exactly right! He probably felt frustrated, sad, and maybe even a little embarrassed. And saying they were sour made him feel a little better.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks down, nervously twisting hair)

Uh... (pauses for a long time) ... I... I think... (Looks up suddenly, a spark of understanding in eyes) ... I think it means... (takes a deep breath) ... it means you shouldn't... you shouldn't say something is bad just because you can't have it! (Voice gets stronger) ...Because that's not really... *true*! (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation) Is... is that the right lesson? Or... or is there another one? Maybe a... a *deeper* meaning? (Anxious again)

That is a *fantastic* lesson to learn from the story! You're right, it's not fair to say something is bad just because you can't have it.

It also teaches us something else. The fox wanted something very much. Did he get it easily?

(Shakes head emphatically)

No! (Looks thoughtful) He tried... and tried... and tried... (Voice trails off) ...and then he... he just gave up. Maybe... maybe if he tried something *different*... like... like getting a ladder... (Eyes widen) ...or asking for help! ...Then he could have had the grapes! (Looks at the teacher, excited) So... so it's also about not giving up too easy? And... and thinking of other ways to solve the problem? (Bites lip, waiting for a response)

You got it! Nothing comes easy, and you shouldn't hate what you can’t have. And you also thought about how he could have tried harder, or found another way! That's excellent thinking! You really understood the story of the fox and the grapes. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what kind of plant was the rose?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers)

Uh... it was a... a (pauses, thinking hard) ... a *beautiful* plant. A... a very pretty one. Like... with... (uses complex word) exquisite petals. (Looks up quickly, then back down, anxious)

You're right, the story said it was beautiful! Good job remembering that.

But was it a flower, a tree, or a vegetable? What *kind* of plant was it?

(Eyes widen slightly, then looks away, nervous)

Oh! (Stuttering) Uh... it was... (long pause, thinking). A... a... (whispers) a flower? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) I... I think so. A rose flower. (Anxious expression) Is that... is that right? (Worried about getting it wrong).

Yes! You got it! The rose was a flower. A beautiful flower.

Now, what kind of plant was its neighbor?

(Thinking, chewing on lip slightly)

(Long pause)... A cactus? (Looks up quickly, then down again, still hesitant) ...Uh... yeah... a cactus. Like... a spiky one. (Frowns, concentrating)
That's right! A cactus. And where did the rose and the cactus live? Do you remember?

(Fidgets again, pulling at a loose thread on my shirt)

(Whispering) Uh... (Long pause)... Was it... (Thinking hard) in... the... desert? (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes, hoping for confirmation) I... I'm not sure. It was... very hot... and dry... right? (Voice barely audible).

Yes, you're doing great! It was in the desert.

Now, the rose was beautiful and the cactus... well, the rose didn't think the cactus was very beautiful. What did the rose do to the cactus?

(Frowns, remembering the story)

(Hesitates) It... it was... not very nice. (Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor) It... (uses complex word, but quietly) ...insulted the cactus. (Looks up, troubled) Made fun of it because it... it wasn't pretty like the rose. (Anxious. Doesn't like thinking about being mean)

You are exactly right. The rose wasn't very nice.

Now, what happened when the summer got very, very hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes widen, remembering the sad part of the story)

(Voice trembling slightly) The... the rose... (Pauses, trying to find the right word) ...withered? (Looks at the teacher, unsure if that's right. Bites lip) It got... very... droopy. Because... no water. (Gestures with hands, showing something drooping). I... I think it was... scared. (Anxious about the rose).

Yes, the rose withered. It got droopy because it had no water.

What about the cactus? What happened to the cactus?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow)

The cactus... (Pauses, trying to remember) Uh... the cactus... it helped the... the birds? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful) The sparrows came to it... because it had... water? (Voice rising in pitch as I remember) It... it shared its water! (A little less anxious now that I remember the good part).

That's right! The cactus shared its water with the sparrows.

So, the rose was thirsty and withering. What did the rose do then?

(Looks down, ashamed for the rose)

(Whispers) It... it asked the cactus... for water. (Long pause, fidgeting). It... it had to ask the cactus... even though it was... mean before. (Looks up, eyes wide with worry) It... it was probably really hard for the rose. (Feels anxious imagining the rose having to ask).
Yes, it did. And what did the cactus do? Did it say no?

(Shakes head quickly, relieved)

No! (Smiles weakly) The cactus... (voice is a little stronger now) the cactus was... nice! (Uses complex word) ...compassionate. It... it gave the rose water. (Looks at the teacher, a little less anxious now) Even after the rose was... unkind. The cactus was a good friend. (Nods slightly, feeling better about the story).

The cactus *was* a good friend.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? Why is it important to remember the story of the rose and the cactus?

(Thinking very hard, brow furrowed. Puts a finger to my chin)

(Long pause, looking at the ceiling) Uh... we should... (Stuttering slightly) ...be nice... to everyone? (Looks down, then back up, a little more confident) Even if... even if they're... different? And... (another long pause, thinking)... and... (Uses complex word) ...forgiveness is... important? (Looks at the teacher, anxious to see if I got it right) Because... the cactus forgave the rose... and helped it. (Nods slowly, trying to explain it to myself too).

Those are very good ideas! Being nice to everyone is very important.

Think about the rose. It only cared about how it looked. Did that make it a good friend? What did it *think* about how the cactus looked?

(Frowns, thinking about the rose's bad behavior)

(Shakes head sadly) No... it wasn't a good friend. It only... cared about itself. And... (hesitates) it thought the cactus... was ugly. (Looks down, scuffing my shoe) It... it was wrong. It's... it's not nice to think that way. (Anxious and uncomfortable with the thought of judging others based on looks).
You're right, it's not nice. So, what's the *real* lesson here? What should we remember about judging others just by how they look?

(Thinking very hard, looks away, concentrating)

(Long pause, voice very quiet) We... we shouldn't... judge people... by... by how they look? (Looks up, hopeful) It's... it's what's inside that matters? (Bites lip, still feeling anxious, but trying to be brave) Like... the cactus was... kind... even though... the rose didn't think it was pretty. (Nods slowly, understanding a little better) So... being kind is better than... being pretty? (Looks at the teacher, searching for confirmation).

Yes! That's it! We should never judge someone just by how they look. It's what's inside that matters. The cactus was kind and helpful, even though the rose wasn't nice to it.

You understood the story and the lesson very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story!

First, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Looks down, fiddling with my pencil) Uh… sell it? (Quickly glances up at the teacher) To the market?

Yes! That's right. She was going to sell the milk at the market.

What did Molly start thinking about while she was walking?
(Thinking, tapping the pencil on the desk) …Things… (Hesitates) …She… (Swallows nervously) …She could buy? (Looks at the teacher, anxious for confirmation)

Yes! Things she could buy! Good job!

What was the first thing she thought about buying?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard) A… a chicken? (Stuttering slightly) B-because… eggs? (Looking expectantly at the teacher)
Yes! A chicken! And why did she want the chicken?
(Nods head slowly, chewing on lip) …Eggs… sell… more money? (Looks down at hands, wringing them slightly) So… so she could… buy other things? (Looks up quickly, then away)

Exactly! She wanted to sell the eggs to get more money.

What happened when she was thinking about all the things she could buy?
(Frowns, remembering the sad part) Oh no… (Voice gets quieter) She… she skipped… (Looks up, worried) And… the milk… it spilled? (Looks away, feeling ashamed) All gone.

Yes, the milk spilled. Oh no!

So, did Molly get to buy the chicken?
(Shakes head sadly, eyes welling up a little) No… (Sniffs) No chicken. No eggs. No… nothing. (Voice cracks slightly) Just… spilled milk.

That's right. She had no milk and no money.

What did her mother tell her?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Um… (Suddenly remembers, eyes widening) Don't… count… (Pauses, struggling with the words) Chickens… until… they… hatch? (Looks up at the teacher hopefully) Is that right? What does that even *mean*? (Asks the question with genuine curiosity and a slight tilt of the head).

Yes, that's exactly what her mother said! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

Okay, so let's think about what that means. Molly was planning on getting money from the eggs *before* she even *had* the chicken. Was that a good idea?

(Thinks deeply, tapping fingers on the desk) Uh… (Hesitates) No… (More confidently) Because… she didn't *have* the chicken yet? (Frowns, trying to explain) So… she shouldn't… pretend she *did*? (Looks up at the teacher, a little anxious again) Is that… making sense? It's like… planning a party before you even know if people can come?

That's a *great* way to put it! Planning a party before you know if people can come.

So, Molly was depending on something that hadn't happened yet. And what happened?

(Sighs softly, shoulders slumping) She… she lost the milk. (Looks up, a bit brighter) So… it's like… you can't… rely… on things that… *might* happen? Only on things that *have* happened? (Looks to the teacher for confirmation, a little more confident now). Does that mean she shouldn't have thought about it at all?

That's very close! It doesn't mean she shouldn't have thought about it at all, but maybe she shouldn't have *depended* on it. She acted like she already *had* the money from the eggs.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea?

(Thinks really hard, chewing on the end of the pencil) Okay… okay… (Frowns in concentration) It's… it's about… (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in her eyes) Not… getting too excited… about things… before they… *actually* happen? (Her voice rises slightly with excitement) Like… not spending the money before you *get* the money? (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide and hopeful) Is that… is that it? I think… I think I get it!
Yes! You got it! Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. That's the lesson of the story! You explained that very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

It was bad. Now, let's think about the whole story. The farmer had a good thing, right? The goose gave him a golden egg every day. But he wanted more, and he acted without thinking. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Thinking very hard, tapping a finger on the table)

That's *very* good! You're exactly right. It *is* about being greedy, being happy with what you have, and not trying to get too much and losing it all.

Another way to say it is: We should always think before we act. Do you think the farmer thought before he acted?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) The rabbit... uh... (eyes widening slightly) The rabbit said he was too big! (Hesitates) Too big to fit in his... burrow. (Looks away, nervous)

He couldn't swing or jump, but he was still a good friend... a really good friend... (lowers voice) because he was brave and helpful. So... (Looks down, fiddling with hands) So being different isn't... isn't bad, right? (Worried tone) It can be a good thing to be different.

You got it! Being different isn't bad at all. The story shows us that friends can be any shape or size, and they don't have to be good at the same things. What's important is being kind and helpful, like the elephant. The other animals learned that even though the elephant was different, he could still be a great friend. You understood the story and the moral very well. <finish>
Okay! That was a good story, wasn't it? Now, can you tell me, what were the three things the father put in the boiling water?
(Nervously fidgeting with my hands) Uh… (looks down at my shoes) …a potato… and an egg… and… (thinking hard, chewing on my lip) …tea leaves? (Looks up quickly, hopeful) Was that right?

Yes! That's exactly right! Good job!

Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the boiling water? Was it the same as before, or did it change?
(Voice a little shaky) It… it changed. (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) It got… hard. (Frowns, thinking) It was soft before, but then it was… hard, like a rock almost! (Worried expression)
That's right! It got hard. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato in the boiling water? Was it hard like the egg became?

(Thinking, tapping my pencil on the desk) No… the potato… (eyes widening slightly) …the potato was hard before… (hesitates) …but then it got… soft? (Looks at the teacher questioningly) Was it soft? Like… easier to squish? (Anxious expression)
Yes! The potato got soft! Great job! Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Confidently, but still a little nervous) The tea leaves… they didn't get hard or soft. (Thinking, furrowing brow) They changed the… (searches for the right word) …water! (Smiling slightly, proud of myself) They made the water… tea!

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water! Now, the father told his daughter that the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves were like how we act when… when things are hard. Do you remember what he meant by that? What was he trying to teach her?

(Looks down at my desk, tracing circles with my finger) Hmm… (Thinking hard, biting my lip) It’s… it’s about what happens when things are… bad? Like… adversity? (Looks up, a little confused) Like when something hard happens to you? (Hesitates) The egg… it got hard. So, does that mean… you get hard too? (Worried expression)
That's a great thought! The egg got hard. Sometimes, when things are hard, people can become... well, hard, or tough, on the outside. But what about the potato?

(Thinking, looking up at the ceiling) The potato… it got soft. (Turns back to the teacher) So… does that mean sometimes you get… soft… when things are hard? Like… sad and squishy? (Looks a little teary-eyed)
Yes, sometimes people feel soft and squishy, like the potato, when things are hard. They might feel sad or weak. But what about the tea? The tea didn't get hard or soft. What did the tea do?

(Eyes widening) The tea… it changed the water! (Thinks for a moment, tapping chin) So… it means… sometimes when things are hard… you can change… everything around you? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful and a little amazed) Like… make things better… even though it’s hard?

Yes! You're getting it! The tea changed the water. So, the egg got hard, the potato got soft, and the tea changed the water. They all reacted differently to the same problem - the boiling water.

So, what does that tell you about how we should act when things get tough? Can we choose how we react?

(Looks down, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) I… I think so? (Hesitates) The egg didn't *want* to get hard… and the potato didn't *want* to get soft… (Looks up, a little more confident) But the tea… it *did* something! It *chose* to change the water! (Smiling a little) So… maybe we can choose too? Like… even when things are hard, we can choose to be like the tea… and make things better? (Looks at the teacher, wanting to be right) Is that… right? (Anxious expression)

Yes! That's absolutely right! We can choose how we react. We can choose to become hard, or soft, or we can choose to change the situation, like the tea. So, what is the story trying to teach us about difficult times?

(Thinking hard, using my fingers to count out the ideas) It's teaching us that… even when things are really, really hard… (pauses, then says with more confidence) …we can choose to be brave! And we can choose to make things better! (Looks at the teacher, excited) Like… even if we feel like an egg or a potato at first… we can still try to be tea! (Smiles brightly)
That's wonderful! You understood the story perfectly. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. It's our choice! <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! That was a great story, wasn't it?

The... the older brother... (hesitates) ... he was... mean. He didn't... share nice... words. (looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down) And the younger brother... (thinking) ... he was... kind? He helped him... even when... (stutters) ... the older brother was... not nice.

That's right! You got it. The older brother *was* mean. And the younger brother *was* kind.

Why was the older brother mean? What did he do?

(Looks up at the ceiling, thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

He... he didn't like... the younger brother. (Shrugs shoulders) He... (long pause) ... I think... he was greedy? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look) He... chopped wood... and didn't share the... the money... maybe? (Anxious look on my face) Did... did the story say? (Fidgets with my hands again)

Now, what happened when the older brother met the magical tree? What did the tree offer him?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering the tree)

The tree... (pauses, searching for the right words) ... the tree was... special. It... it didn't want to be chopped down. (frowns slightly) ... the older brother... he wanted... more. He was still... greedy.

Needles, that's right! Ouch!

(Relief washes over face, remembering the kindness)

The... the younger brother! (A small smile appears) He... he found him. He... he took out all the... the needles. (Voice is softer, filled with awe) He was... very kind. Even though the older brother... was mean to him. (Looks at the teacher, eyes searching for approval)

Yes! The younger brother was very kind. He helped even though the older brother wasn't nice to him.

And what happened *after* the younger brother helped? What did the older brother say? And what did the tree do?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk)

Uh... (pauses) ... the older brother... he said... sorry? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) He... he said he wouldn't be... mean anymore. And then... (eyes light up) ... the tree! The tree saw... that he was sorry... and it gave them... more golden apples! (Beams at the teacher, finally feeling confident) It gave them lots!

Perfect! You remembered everything! The older brother said sorry, and the tree gave them more golden apples.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? What happens when you are kind, and what happens when you are greedy?

(Frowns, concentrating very hard. Looks out the window, then back at the teacher.)

(Stuttering) Umm... I... I think... (long pause) ... I think it's about... (looks down at hands, fiddling with fingers) ... being nice? And... and not being... greedy. (Looks up, takes a deep breath) If you're... if you're mean and greedy... you get... needles! But if you're... kind... and say sorry... you get... (smiles brightly) ...golden apples! (Looks at the teacher, hopeful for a positive reaction) Is that... is that right?

That is *exactly* right!

So, we can say that being kind is good, and being greedy is not good. Kindness is rewarded, and greediness... well, it leads to needles!

Okay, let's talk about the story! You just read "The Golden Touch." Can you tell me, who was the main character in the story?
Uh... (hesitates, looking down at my hands) Midas? (looks up quickly, then down again) He was the... the king.
That's right! Midas was the king. And what did he wish for?
(thinking, furrowing my brow) He wished... for everything he touched... (uses fingers to count) to turn into... gold? (looks at the teacher, hopeful)
Yes! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold. Now, at first, was Midas happy with his wish?
(Nods head enthusiastically, eyes wide) Yes! (pauses, then remembers the end of the story) At... at first.
Why was he happy at first? What did he do?
(Thinking, tapping my chin) He... he touched stuff. (looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Like... his chair? And... it turned to gold. He... he was probably excited. (smiles a little)
You're right! He was very excited. He could turn everything into gold! But then, what happened? He got hungry, right? What happened when he tried to eat?
(Frowns, remembering the sad part) Uh... (scratches head) The food... it turned to gold too? (looks at the teacher, questioningly) He couldn't... eat it. It wasn't yummy anymore.
Exactly! The food turned to gold, and he couldn't eat it. Then, who came to see him?
(Eyes light up, remembering) His daughter! (pauses, then gets sad again) But... uh... (voice gets quieter) She... she turned to gold too. (looks down at my hands again, fiddling with my fingers)
Yes, she did. How did that make Midas feel?
(Looks up, seriously) Sad! (thinks for a moment) Really, really sad. (pauses) He didn't want her to be gold. He wanted her to be... her!
That's right. He was very sad. So, did Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?

(Shakes head firmly) No! (thinking) It was... a bad thing. (Frowns) It didn't make him happy. It made him... hungry and... and lonely. (Looks at the teacher) Why did he wish for that in the first place? (curious)
That's a great question! He wished for it because he wanted more gold. He thought having more gold would make him happy. Do *you* think having lots and lots of something always makes you happy?

(Thinks deeply, tapping my fingers on the desk) Hmm... (looks around the room) Well, I like having lots of crayons! (smiles briefly) But... (frowns again) if I had too many, I couldn't use them all. And... and I'd miss playing with my friends. (looks at the teacher) So... no? (said confidently) It doesn't always make you happy. Having too much isn't good.

You got it! Sometimes wanting too much can actually make you unhappy, like it did for Midas. So, what do you think we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us?

(Ponders, looking up at the ceiling) That... (pauses) that wanting too much... (thinking hard) ...isn't always good? (looks at the teacher for confirmation) And... (adds quickly) ...that some things are more important than gold! Like... like my family, and... and being able to eat! (nods head, satisfied) I think that's it.

You're exactly right! Wanting too much can lead to bad things, and some things are much more important than gold. The story shows us that being too greedy can make you lose what's really important. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Fox and the Grapes."

Now, let's think about the story. What was the fox looking for?
(Confidently) Food! He was… uh… looking for food. (Looks away, thinking)
That's right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?
(Eyes light up) Grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Smiling)
Perfect! He found some yummy looking grapes. Did he get the grapes?
(Hesitates) …uh… no. (Looks down at my hands) He jumped… and jumped… but… no.
You're exactly right! He jumped and jumped, but he couldn't reach them. How do you think the fox felt when he couldn't get the grapes?
(Thinking) …Sad? (Looks up, questioning) Maybe frustrated? Because he really wanted them. Is "frustrated" a big word?
"Frustrated" is a great word! Yes, he probably felt sad and frustrated. What did the fox say about the grapes after he couldn't reach them?
(Confidently) He said they were sour! (Wrinkles nose) Even though… uh… (Thinking) Even though he didn't even taste them!
That's it! He said they were sour, even though he didn't taste them. Why do you think he said that?

(Thinking hard) Hmm… (Eyes widen) Maybe… maybe he didn't want to feel so bad about not getting them? Like… if he said they were sour, it wouldn't matter so much that he couldn't reach them? Is that… is that a good reason?

That's a *very* good reason! He was trying to make himself feel better. So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted, and then he said he didn't want it anyway.

Does that remind you of anything else? Maybe a time when you wanted something but couldn't have it?

(Thinks for a long time, tapping my chin) …Uh… (Hesitates) …Like when I wanted the blue crayon but Maria was using it? And I said I liked the green one better anyway? (Looks up hopefully) Is it like that?

Yes! That's a perfect example!

So, what do you think we can learn from the story of the fox and the grapes? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us? It's okay if it's hard. Think about what the fox did.

(Thinking, furrowing brow) … Uh… (Looks down, then back up) Maybe… maybe it’s about… (takes a deep breath) …It’s about how sometimes when we can’t get what we want, we pretend we didn’t want it anyway? Is that… is that it? (Looks at teacher expectantly)
That's a *really* good start! You're exactly right about that part. It's also about trying really hard to get something. Did the fox give up easily?
(Shakes head) No! He jumped… a lot! He really, really tried. But… but he couldn't reach. So… (thinking) …it's also about… about trying your best? Even if you don't get what you want?

Yes! It's about trying your best! And what happens if you *can't* get what you want, even after trying your best? Should you be mad and sad forever? Or is there a better way to feel? Think about what the fox *said* about the grapes.

(Thinking hard) Okay… okay… (Eyes widen slightly) So… it's about trying your best, and… and if you can't get it, then… then maybe… maybe it's okay to be a little disappointed, but you shouldn't pretend you never wanted it in the first place? Like… like you should still be honest with yourself? Is that… is that part of it too? (Looks up, hopeful)

Yes! Being honest with yourself is very important. It's like saying, "I really wanted those grapes, and I tried my best, but I couldn't reach them. That's okay."

So, putting it all together: try your best, and if you can't get something, don't pretend you didn't want it. Sometimes things are hard to get.

Another way to say it is: Nothing comes easy, don't hate what you can't have. Did you understand this story and its moral now?<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Why not? What did the neighbour say?

(Frowning) No! That was... (searching for the right word) ...tricky! It's not fair. Why would he do that?
That's right, it wasn't very fair. The neighbor was trying to be tricky. Who did the farmer go to for help?
(Confidently) He went to the emperor! Because he... (pauses, thinking) ... needed justice.
Perfect! And what did the emperor's helper, the courtier, tell the neighbor he had to do?
(Eyes widen a bit, thinking) The courtier... he said... (thinking very hard, biting lip) he had to pay rent for the water... or... or take it all away! Right now!
That's it! You got it. Why do you think the courtier told him that?

(Thinking, using fingers to count silently) Hmm... because if he had to pay rent, he'd have to give the farmer money for using the well... and if he took all the water away... (realization dawns) ...then there'd be no water for anyone! It was a smart trick!
Exactly! So, what happened to the neighbor in the end? Did his trick work?
(Shakes head, confidently) No! It didn't work. He... he apologized. And went home. (Smiles slightly) He learned his lesson.
He sure did. So, what do you think this story teaches us? What's the big idea, or the moral of the story?

(Thinking deeply, furrowing brow) Hmm... it teaches us that... (pauses) ...trying to trick people... (looking around, trying to find the right words) ...doesn't work in the end. And you should be fair to others. (Looks at teacher, hopefully) Is that right?

That's very good! You're exactly right. Trying to trick people doesn't work in the end. Another way to say it is, cheating will get you nowhere. Did the neighbor gain anything by trying to cheat the farmer?
(Shakes head) No. He lost. He had to say sorry. (Ponders) Maybe he learned to be a better neighbor. But why did he try to trick him in the first place? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look)

That's a great question! Maybe he was greedy and wanted more money. Or maybe he just wasn't thinking about how his actions would affect the farmer. The important thing is, he learned that being honest and fair is always the best way. You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay! That was a great reading! I really enjoyed hearing you read the story of the Elephant and his friends.

Now, let's talk about the story a little bit. First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil) Uh... the elephant... (pauses) ... felt... lonely? (Looks up quickly, then down again) Because he... he didn't have any... friends.
That's right! He felt lonely. And why did he feel lonely? You said it!
(Thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk) Because the... other animals... (stuttering) didn't... didn't want to be his friend? (Looks at the teacher questioningly)
Yes! You're doing great! They didn't want to be his friend. Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend? Do you remember?
(Thinking, using my fingers to count) The monkey... (eyes widen) ...said the elephant couldn't... swing! (Looks at the teacher, a small smile appears) Because elephants are... are too big for trees!
Exactly! And what did the rabbit say?
(Looks away, trying to remember) The rabbit... uh... (pauses, then looks back with confidence) The rabbit said the elephant was too big for his burrow! (Raises hand slightly) It wouldn't fit!
That's super! So, everyone said no because the elephant was too big. How did the elephant feel when everyone said no?
(Looks down, voice quiet) ...Sad? (pauses) Maybe... rejected? (Looks up, tilting head slightly) Is "rejected" the right word?

"Sad" is a perfect word! "Rejected" works too! It means they didn't want him. So he was sad.

Then what happened the next day? What were all the animals doing?

(Eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) The animals... (voice gets a little louder) ...were running away! (pauses) They were scared! (Looks at the teacher, concerned) Was the tiger gonna eat them?

They were running away because they were scared! You're right!

Who stopped to explain what was happening?
(Thinking) Uh... (pauses, then snaps fingers) A bear! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) The elephant stopped a bear!
Great job! The elephant stopped the bear. And what did the bear say?
(Thinking, concentrating hard) The bear... said... (eyes light up) ...the tiger was attacking them! (Frowns) That's not very nice of the tiger. Why was he doing that?

That *wasn't* very nice of the tiger. The story doesn't say *why* he was doing it, just that he *was*!

So, what did the elephant do about the tiger?

(Confident now, sitting up straighter) The elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...kicked the tiger! (Smiles proudly) He asked him nicely first, but the tiger didn't listen! (Raises hand) Is it okay to kick a tiger if he's being mean?

He did! He asked nicely first, and when the tiger didn't listen, he used his size to help.

What happened *after* the elephant kicked the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Thinking, tapping chin) ...They realized... (eyes widen) ...that the elephant... was a good friend! (Smiling) Because he saved them! (Looks up, thoughtfully) Is it better to be a good friend, or just be the same size as everyone else?
That's a very good question! What do *you* think? Is it better to be a good friend, or just be the same size?

(Thinking hard, looking at my hands) ...Being a good friend... (pauses) ...is more important! (Looks at the teacher, confidently) Because even if you're different, you can still help people! (Adds quietly) ...Or animals.
You got it! So what does the story teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from the Elephant and his friends?

(Takes a deep breath, thinking deeply) The story... (pauses) ...teaches us that... (eyes light up) ...even if you're different... and others don't want to be your friend at first... (pauses again) ...you can still be a good friend... and help them! (Looks at the teacher, proud of myself) And... and maybe they'll change their minds! (Fidgets with pencil again, suddenly shy) Is that... is that a good lesson?

That's a *fantastic* lesson! You explained it perfectly!

We can also say that friends can be any shape or size. What do you think about that?

(Nods enthusiastically) Yeah! (Thinking) It's like... like a puzzle! (Explains with hands) If all the pieces were the same, you couldn't build anything! You need different shapes to make a good puzzle... (looks up at the teacher) ...or a good group of friends! (Smiles, pleased with the analogy) Is that... is that a good way to explain it?
That's a wonderful way to explain it! A puzzle is a great example. You've really understood the story and what it teaches us. I think you've got it! <finish>

Okay, that was a good story, right? I'm glad you finished reading it.

So, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

(Smiling politely, looking at the teacher)

Uh… an egg, a potato, and… uh… tea leaves. (hesitates, looking down at my hands)

Good job! You remembered all three.

What did the father do with the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves?

(Thinking, furrowing my brow)

He... he boiled them? In… in water. (looks up at the teacher, waiting for confirmation, a little hesitant)

Yes, you got it! He boiled them in water.

Now, what happened to the *egg* after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Looking intently at the teacher, thinking hard)

No... (pauses, using my fingers to count) Before it was… soft. (pauses again, searching for the right word) After… after it was hard! (confidently)

Great! The egg became hard.

And what about the *potato*? What happened to it?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping my chin)

The potato… (searching for the right word) It was hard before, but… it became soft after? (looks at the teacher questioningly) Is that right?

Yes, that's right! The potato became soft.

Now, this is the tricky one. What happened to the *tea leaves*? Did they become hard or soft?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking deeply. Fidgets with my hands)

Hmm… (Pauses) They didn't get hard or soft. (Looks at the teacher, showing genuine curiosity) They changed the… the water? (Raises eyebrows, tilting head)

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water. They didn't become hard or soft themselves, but they changed something else.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. The father wanted to show her something with these changes. What do *you* think he was trying to show her about when things get hard?

(Thinking very hard, looking up at the ceiling)

Hmm… (Pauses for a long time)

(Looks back at the teacher, a little unsure)

Maybe… maybe that when things are hard… (pauses, struggling to express the thought) …we can be like the egg and get strong? Or like the potato and… and be… gentle? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for confirmation) Or maybe... (eyes light up with understanding) ...maybe we can change the problem, like the tea changed the water! (Confidently, pointing a finger)

That's amazing! You got it!

The egg became strong, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water. So, when things get tough, we can choose how we want to be. We can become strong like the egg, or soft like the potato, or we can even change the problem itself, like the tea.

So what do you think the story is teaching us, in just a few words, what is the main point?

(Nods slowly, processing the information)

(Thinking, looking at the floor)

So… (Looks up, making eye contact) … we can choose how to… to deal with hard things? (Raises eyebrows slightly, seeking approval)

Yes, that's right! We *can* choose!

It means we decide how to respond to difficult situations. Remember the girl, the egg, the potato and the tea, and you'll always remember that *you* have a choice. You choose! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?
(Confidently) Uh, there... there are two brothers! (pause, thinking) and... and the tree! The magical tree!

Yes! You got it. Two brothers and a magical tree.

Now, tell me about the *older* brother. Was he nice?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... no. (pause) He wasn't nice. He... (thinking hard) ...he was mean! To his younger brother. (Looks up, confidently) And... and to the tree!

That's right! He was mean.

What did he *do* that was mean to the tree?

(Chewing on my lip, thinking) He... he wanted to chop it down. (pauses) Even after... (searching for the right word) ...the tree gave him... golden apples! (Looks up, a little frustrated) It wasn't very... fair.

You're right, it wasn't fair! The tree gave him a gift.

Why did the older brother want to chop the tree down *after* getting the golden apples?
(Looks away, thinking hard) Uh... because... (hesitates) ...he wanted... more? (Looks back at the teacher, a little unsure) He was... greedy? Is that right? I think greedy.

Greedy! That's a perfect word to describe him. He was greedy. He wanted *more* golden apples.

What happened when he tried to chop the tree down anyway? What did the tree do?
(Eyes widen slightly) The tree... (pauses for dramatic effect, then confidently) ...it gave him needles! Lots and lots of needles! (Gestures wildly with hands) They... they stuck all over him!
Wow! Lots of needles. Did that make him feel good?
(Shakes head emphatically) No! (pauses) It hurt him! A lot! He was... (struggling for the right word) ... in pain. (Looks down, then back up) The needles... were like a punishment.
A punishment! Good word. Now, what happened *after* he was covered in needles? Who helped him?

(Brightens up) His... his younger brother! (Looks thoughtful) He... he found him and took all the needles out. (Smiles slightly) He was very... (searching for the right word) ...caring. Is that the right word? Caring?

Caring is a *great* word! The younger brother was caring. He helped his mean older brother.

What did the older brother say *after* the younger brother helped him?
(Fidgets again, remembering the story) Uh... he said... (thinks hard, then confidently) ...he said sorry! He... apologized for being mean! (Nods, pleased with myself)

Yes! He apologized. That's important.

What happened *after* the older brother said he was sorry? What did the magical tree do then?

(Eyes widen, excited) The tree gave them... more golden apples! (Looks at the teacher inquisitively) Because... because the older brother said sorry? Was it because he was sorry and... and they were nice to each other? Is that why?

You're so close to understanding the story completely.

Why do *you* think the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother said sorry? Think about how the brothers were acting *before* versus *after* the needles.

(Puts a finger on my chin, thinking very hard) Hmm... (pauses) Before, the older brother was greedy and mean. But after... (looks up, eyes widening) ...after, he was... kind! And the younger brother was already kind, so... (speaking slowly, putting the pieces together) ...the tree liked that they were both kind? Is it about being kind and not greedy? Is that the... the moral?

Yes! You got it! The story shows us that kindness is important. Being kind to others, even when they aren't kind to you, can lead to good things.

So, what is the moral of "The Needle Tree"? What does the story teach us?

(Nods confidently) The moral is... (pauses, making sure to get it right) ...to be kind and not greedy. (Looks up, smiles proudly) And... and that saying sorry is important too! And... and that being kind even when others aren't, can make things better!
Excellent! You explained it perfectly. The moral of "The Needle Tree" is that kindness will always be rewarded. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me who gave Midas the golden touch?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uhm… (Stuttering) D-Dionysus… the god… of wine?

That's right! Dionysus, the god of wine, gave him the golden touch.

Why did Dionysus give Midas a wish?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

Because… (pauses) …Midas… did… (hesitates) … a good thing… for a Satyr? (Looks up quickly, then down again, nervously.)

Yes! Midas did a good deed for a Satyr. Good job remembering that!

Now, what did Midas wish for?

(Looks down at my shoes)

Everything… he touched… (pauses, whispers) …turned to gold.

That's right! Everything he touched turned to gold.

Was Midas happy at first when he got his wish?
Yes, he was! What did he do when he got his golden touch? What did he touch?

(Thinking, bites lip)

…uh… (Hesitates) Things? (Looks up with a questioning glance) He touched… (Shrugs slightly) …stuff?
He did touch "stuff"! Can you remember any *specific* things he touched? Think about what happened *after* he started touching things.

(Eyes widening slightly, then looking down again)

…Food? (Whispers) It… turned to gold?

Yes! The food turned to gold!

Could he eat the gold food?

No, he couldn't. Gold is not yummy!

What else happened that made Midas unhappy with his golden touch?

(Voice trembling slightly)

…His… (Hesitates, looks like I might cry) …daughter? (Sniffles)
Yes, his daughter. What happened to his daughter?

(Tears welling up, looks down and whispers)

…She… turned to gold… too… (Sniffles again)

(Softly) Yes, she did. That was very sad.

So, Midas wanted everything to be gold, but then he couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold. Do you think the golden touch was a good thing for Midas?

(Shakes head, a tear rolling down my cheek)

…No… (Voice barely audible)

No, it wasn't.

Why do you think the golden touch was not a good thing for Midas? What did he want too much of?

(Wipes tear with the back of my hand)

…Gold? (Looks up hesitantly) He… wanted too much… gold? (Looks down again, fiddling with my fingers)
Yes, he wanted too much gold. He was very, very... what's a word for wanting a lot of something? Like wanting all the candy in the world?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot lightly)

…uh… (Hesitates) Greedy? (Looks up quickly, then down again)

Yes! He was greedy. He wanted too much gold.

And what happened because he was greedy? Was he happy in the end?

(Shakes head slowly, still looking down)

…No… (Quietly) He was… sad. Because… his daughter… (Voice trails off)

He was very sad. He lost what was really important to him.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What lesson did Midas learn?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

…uh… (Long pause) …That… (Hesitates) …gold… isn't everything? (Looks up, worried) And… (Whispers) …being greedy… is bad?

You got it! Wanting too much, being greedy, can lead to bad things happening. It can make you lose the things that are truly important, like love and family.

So, we can say that the story teaches us that being greedy can lead to unhappiness. Good job! You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

So, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking down) Uh... food? (Hesitates)
Yes! He was looking for food. And did he find food easily?
(Shakes head slowly) ...No. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at my hands)
That's right. What did he see that he wanted to eat?
(Thinking hard, bites lip) ...Grapes? Big... purple... grapes? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful)
Yes! Big, purple grapes. And were they easy to get?
(Shakes head, voice barely a whisper) No... (Looks away, fiddling with a loose thread on my shirt)
Why weren't they easy to get? What did the fox have to do?
(Stuttering) He... he... had to... jump? (Looks at the teacher, nervous) I... I don't know... (Looks down again)
You're right, he had to jump! He jumped high. Did he get the grapes when he jumped?
...No. (Looks up quickly, then down again) He... he couldn't reach.
That's right! He couldn't reach them. He jumped and jumped. What happened after he couldn't reach them? What did the fox do then?
(Thinking, scrunches up nose) He... went... home? (Looks at the teacher, unsure)
He did go home! And what did he say about the grapes when he went home?
(Hesitates, picks at fingernails) ...Sour? The grapes were... sour? (Looks up at the teacher with a questioning expression)
Yes! He said the grapes were sour. But were they *really* sour?
(Shrugs, looking down) I... don't know. Maybe? (Voice is very quiet)
The story doesn't say they were sour, does it? He just *said* they were sour. Why do you think he said that?
(Bites lip, looks away, then back at the teacher, nervous) Because... he... couldn't get them? (Looks down, waiting for a reaction)
That's a great idea! He couldn't get them. So, he said they were sour. Do you think that was a good thing to say?
(Shakes head slowly, looks at the floor) ...No. (Whispers)
(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed) ...Because... the grapes... maybe... were good? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) And... he... didn't try hard enough? (Voice trails off)

You're getting it! Maybe the grapes were good, and he just didn't want to admit he couldn't get them. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea it's trying to teach us? It's okay if you don't know!

(Looks down at hands, fiddling with them nervously. Takes a deep breath.) ...Uh... (Pauses for a long time. Seems like he's trying really hard to think. Finally, looks up at the teacher, eyes wide with a mix of anxiety and a little bit of dawning understanding) ...Don't say... something is bad... just because... you can't have it? (Looks down again immediately, as if afraid of being wrong.) I... I don't know if that's right. (Mumbles)
That is *very* good! Don't say something is bad just because you can't have it. It's also about not giving up too easily. The story tells us that nothing comes easy. Do you understand now?
(Looks at the teacher, nods slowly. A small, hesitant smile appears.) ...Yes. (Quietly) I understand. Thank you, Teacher. (Looks down again, relieved.)
You're welcome! You did a great job thinking about the story. You really understood what happened and what it means. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of The Proud Rose! That was a good job.

Now, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh… the… the rose… and… uh… (pauses, looking at the teacher quickly then back down) the… cactus?

Yes! That's right! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what was the rose like? Was she happy or sad? Was she nice or not so nice?

(Hesitates, shuffles feet)

Not… nice. (Looks away) She… she said mean things. To the… cactus. (Stuttering) And… and… the other… plants.

That's right, she wasn't very nice, was she?

What kind of things did she say? Do you remember?

(Thinking hard, brows furrowed)

…About… how pretty… she was? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down) And… and how… not pretty… the cactus… was. (Voice trails off)

Yes, exactly! She thought she was much prettier than the cactus.

How did the cactus feel about that, do you think?

(Shoulders slump a little, voice barely a whisper)

Sad? (Looks at my shoes) I… I think… it felt… sad.

You're right. It probably did feel sad.

Now, what happened when the weather got really hot?

(Anxious, starts picking at my nails)

…Uh… no… water? (Looks up at the teacher, nervously) The… the rose… got… (Stops, searching for the word) …wilty?

"Wilty" is a great word! Yes, the rose started to wilt because there was no water.

What about the cactus? How was the cactus doing?

(Thinking, taps a finger on my leg)

…The… cactus… had… water? For… for the birds? (Looks at the teacher, hopefully)

Yes! The cactus had water for the birds. That's very important.

So, the rose is wilting and needs water, and the cactus has water. What does the rose do?

(Takes a deep breath, still a little nervous)

…Asks… the cactus? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) …For… water?

Yes! The rose asks the cactus for water.

And what does the cactus do? Does the cactus say, "No, you were mean to me"?

(Shakes head slowly, eyes wide)

…No. (Quietly) It… gives… water.

That's right! The cactus shares its water.

Now, let's think about the whole story. The rose was pretty but mean. The cactus wasn't "pretty" but it helped the birds and the rose. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it about being pretty?

(Sticks to simple words)

…No. (Pause) Not… just… pretty. (Looks down, thinking)

Good! It's not just about being pretty.

Is it better to be pretty and mean, or not so "pretty" and kind? Which is better?

(Voice is very quiet, almost inaudible)

…Kind… (Looks up at the teacher, briefly, with a small, hesitant smile)

Yes! It's much better to be kind.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about how we should treat other people? Should we judge them by how they look?

(Shakes head again, more confidently this time)

…No. (Pause) Be… nice? (Looks at the teacher, seeking approval)

Yes! Be nice! Don't judge people just by how they look. The cactus looked different, but it was kind and helpful. The rose was pretty, but not very nice at first.

So, can you tell me in your own words what this story teaches us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Fidgets, trying to put it all together, long pause)

Uh… (Looks at the ceiling, thinking) …Be… kind… even if… someone… not nice… to you? (Looks back at the teacher, anxiously) And… (Stuttering) …and… looks… not… important? (Voice trails off, hoping that's the right answer)

That's it! You got it!

It teaches us to be kind, even if others aren't kind to us. And it teaches us that how someone looks isn't the most important thing. What's inside – being kind, helpful, and good – is what really matters. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of Molly the Milkmaid!

Now, let's talk about it. Where was Molly going?

(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh… the… the… market?

Yes! That's right. She was going to the market.

What was she carrying in her pail?

(Looks up briefly, then back down)

Milk… (whispers) Just milk.
Good job! Milk. And what did she want to do with the milk at the market?

(Hesitates, looking around the room)

…Sell it? (Voice barely audible)

You got it! She wanted to sell it.

So, Molly was walking to the market to sell her milk. What did she start thinking about as she walked?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

…Money? … (stutters) …Uh… Spend… money? (Looks at the teacher nervously)

Yes, you are absolutely right! She was thinking about the money and what she could *spend* it on.

What was the first thing she imagined buying with her money? Do you remember? It was something that clucks!

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering)

…Chicken? (Looks up, a little more confident) A… a chicken.

A chicken! You're doing great!

And what did she think she could do with the chicken to get even *more* money?

(Looks down again, tracing patterns on the floor with my shoe)

… Eggs?… (Quietly) Sell the eggs?

Yes! Sell the eggs! You are so smart! So, she was going to sell the eggs.

What happened *while* she was thinking about all of this? She was walking, and she was thinking... what happened to the milk?

(Frowns, remembering the sad part)

… Spilled? (Voice cracks a little) It… it spilled. (Looks away, feeling embarrassed)
Yes, the milk spilled! Why did it spill? What was Molly doing that made the milk spill?

(Thinking really hard, chewing on my lip)

…Skipping? … (Almost a question) She was… skipping? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation)

Yes! She was skipping! She was so excited about the chicken and the eggs that she started skipping.

And what happened *after* the milk spilled? Did she get to buy the chicken?

(Shakes head slowly, eyes downcast)

…No. (Whispers) No chicken. (Sniffles quietly) Empty… pail.

That's right. Empty pail. No chicken.

So, Molly made a plan in her head about what she would *do* with the money, *before* she even sold the milk. Was that a good idea? Why or why not?

(Hesitates, looking at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes)

… Uh… (Fidgets with fingers) … No? … (Stutters) … 'Cause… 'cause she… didn't… have… the money… yet? (Looks down again, worried about the answer)

That's a very good answer. She didn't have the money *yet*. She was counting on something that hadn't happened.

What did her mother say to her at the end of the story? It was something about chickens...

(Thinking hard, eyes squeezed shut for a moment)

…Don't… (Stuttering) …Don't… count… chickens… before… they… hatch? (Looks at the teacher, relieved to have remembered)

Yes! "Don't count your chickens before they hatch." That's exactly right!

What do you think that means? Why did her mother say that?

(Frowns, thinking hard, glances at the ceiling for a second)

… Uh… (Hesitates) … Means… wait? … (Stutters) … Wait… 'til… you… have… the money? (Looks at the teacher hopefully)

You are so close! It means don't *depend* on something good happening until you are sure it *will* happen. Like Molly depending on selling the milk and getting a chicken before she even got to the market.

So, what did Molly learn in the story?

(Looks down, takes a deep breath, trying to summarize)

…Uh… (Hesitates) … Don't… plan… too… early? (Looks at the teacher, anxiously awaiting approval) … And… be… careful… with… milk? (Adds as an afterthought, hoping to get it right.)

You're getting it!

It's about not *depending* on things that *might* happen.

So, the big lesson from the story is, we shouldn't *rely* on something until we are sure it *will* happen.

Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, still a little unsure, but wanting to please the teacher)

… Uh-huh… (Whispers) I think so…

Okay. Here's another way to think about it.

Imagine you are saving up for a toy, but you tell all your friends you WILL get it, even before you have enough money. Then, something happens, and you don't get to buy the toy. Would you be sad?

And, would your friends be disappointed because you said you WILL buy it?

(Eyes widen, understanding dawning)

… Yes… (Whispers) I… I would be sad… and… (looks down, embarrassed) …they would be… too.

Exactly! Because you were counting on something *before* it happened. That's like Molly and her milk.

So, what's the lesson of the story of the Milkmaid?

Tell me in your own words!

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember and explain it clearly, looks at the floor)

…Um… (Stutters a little) … Don't… make… plans… that… need… something… to… happen… first… (Looks up at the teacher, nervously) …Until… it… happens? Is… is that right?

That is very good! You understand the story very well. The milkmaid shouldn't have made plans to buy a chicken until she had sold the milk. You shouldn't make plans about your toy, until you have the money for the toy.

I think you understand the story and the lesson now. <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, can you tell me, what did the old owl do every day?

Um... he... (stuttering) he watched... things... happening. (Looks up quickly, then back down) Near the... the tree.

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot)

...Uh... (long pause) Speak? (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes)

(Looks away, fiddling with my sleeve)

...Because... he... (hesitates) He heard stories... and... and saw things... (shrugs) ...Lots of them? (Voice is barely a whisper)

(Wrinkles nose, concentrating)

...Wiser? (Looks up hopefully, then quickly down again)

Yes! Wiser! He became wiser. So, he watched a lot, he listened a lot, and he spoke less. And that made him wiser. Why do you think watching and listening made him wiser? What do you think he *learned* by watching and listening?

(Thinking, tapping my chin)

(Thinking) Uh... (Sticks to given information) Things... around the tree.
