Yes! They were talking and sharing stories. So the owl was watching and listening. Did the owl talk a lot?
No, he didn't. And what happened to the owl because he watched and listened so much? What did he become?
Yes! He became wiser! Why do you think watching and listening made him wiser?
(Sticks to given information, short answer) Because he saw... and heard.
Good! He saw and heard lots of things. So, if you watch and listen carefully, do you think you can learn things?
Yes! You can. Do you think it's important to listen to others and watch what's happening around you?
Why? What do you think the story is trying to tell us? Is it better to talk all the time, or listen sometimes?
(Hesitating, looks down, thinking) Listen... sometimes? (Asks question for help) Is it... is it good to listen?
It *is* good to listen! Think about it: if you're always talking, are you learning anything new? Are you hearing what other people have to say?
Right! So, the owl listened and watched. He didn't talk as much. And that's how he learned and became wise. So what's better? To talk a lot, or to watch and listen?
Exactly! And that's how you become wise, just like the owl. You talk less and you watch and listen more. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

Now, tell me in your own words, what was the story about? Just a short version!

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a little)

Uh… (Hesitates) A farmer… and a goose… (thinking) that laid… golden eggs.
Good start! And what did the farmer do with the golden eggs?

(Looks up briefly, then back down)

Selled them… (confident) for money.
Excellent! And how did the farmer and his wife live at the start of the story? Were they happy? Were they rich or poor?

(Nods slowly)

Happy… (thinking) Comfortable… (looks away) Not… poor.
That's right! They were comfortable. So, what happened *after* they were comfortable? Did something change?
(Hesitates) … Uh… (looks at the teacher briefly) … The farmer… wanted… more?
Yes! He wanted more. More what?
You got it! He wanted more golden eggs. What did he do to try and get more? This is where the story gets a little sad.

(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers)

… Cut… the goose?
Yes, he did cut the goose. And what did he find inside?

(Wrinkles my nose)

… Blood… and guts… (stuttering) No… golden eggs.
That's right. And what happened to the farmer after that? Was he happy then? Did he get more golden eggs?

(Shakes head slowly)

…No. (Looks down, voice barely audible) Sad… Poorer.
Exactly. He became sad and poorer. So, the farmer started out happy and comfortable. Then he did something, and he ended up sad and poor. What do you think he did wrong?

(Thinking hard, concentrating)

… (Pauses) Wanted… too much? (Looks up hopefully)
That's a big part of it! He wanted too much. But what *did* he do because he wanted too much? What was his mistake?

(Sticks to given information)

…Cut… the goose. (Looks down, a little sad).
Yes, he cut the goose. Do you think he thought about what would happen *before* he cut the goose?
Why do you say no? What makes you think he didn't think about it first?

(Hesitates, unsure)

…Uh… (Thinking) Because… (stuttering) if he thinked… he wouldn't cut… the goose?
That's great thinking! If he had thought about it, he probably wouldn't have cut the goose. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What lesson can we learn from the farmer?

(Looks down, thinking really hard)

… (Long pause) … Be… thankful? (Looks up, unsure) For… what you have?
Being thankful is definitely a good lesson! And that's part of it. But what about *before* you do something? What should you do *before* you act? Think about the farmer...

(Thinking very hard. Frowning slightly)

…Uh… (Long pause) …Think? (Looks up hopefully)
Yes! Think! Think before you act. Do you think that's a good lesson? <finish>

Okay! You've just read "The Farmer and the Well." Great job!

First, tell me, who are the main people in the story?
(Confidently) Uh… the farmer… and the neighbor… and the emperor… and the… courtier.
Excellent! You got them all. Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?
(Thinking) He… (hesitates) …he wanted to… uh… water… his farm.
Yes! He wanted to water his farm. And who did he buy the well from?
(Looks down, points with finger) … the neighbor.
That's right! So, the farmer bought the well from the neighbor. What happened *after* he bought it? Could he get water?
(Shakes head slowly) …uh… no. (Looks up, hesitant) The neighbor… didn’t let him.
Correct! The neighbor didn't let him. Why do you think the neighbor didn't let him use the water?
(Sticks out tongue a little and thinks hard) …uh… because… (pauses) …he wanted to trick the farmer?
Good thinking! Yes, he tried to trick the farmer. He said he sold the well, but not the water. Was that a nice thing to do?
No, it wasn't. So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water?
You got it! And what did the emperor's courtier do?
(Thinking) The… the courtier… (pauses) …asked the neighbor… about the water.
Yes! He asked the neighbor about the water. And what did the courtier say the neighbor had to do?
(Looks down, fidgeting with hands) …uh… pay rent… or… take the water away.
Exactly! He had to pay rent for the water, or take it all away right away! Why do you think the neighbor didn't want to do either of those things?
(Thinking) …Because… he couldn't… take all the water away? (Looks up, questioning) Is that right?
Yes! It would be impossible to take all the water away quickly. And paying rent would cost him money. So, what did the neighbor do in the end?
(Looks away, then back) …He said sorry… and went home.
That's right! He apologized and went home. So, did his trick work? Did he get away with cheating the farmer?
No, he didn't! So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?
(Thinking hard, bites lip) …Uh… (long pause) …It’s not good to… trick people? (Looks up hopefully)
That's a good start! It's definitely not good to trick people. What happens if you *try* to trick people, like the neighbor did?
You do! You get in trouble. So, maybe the story is telling us that trying to trick people... what will happen? Will it work out for you?
…No. (Looks up, a little more confident) …It won’t work.
Right! Trying to trick people won't work. So, the story is telling us that cheating… will get you…?
And… (pauses, prompting) ...nowhere! Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story really well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
(Thinking, looking down at my hands) Uh... lonely. He... he wanted friends.

That's right! He was lonely and wanted friends.

Why did the monkey *not* want to be the elephant's friend?
(Sticks to the information given) Because... (hesitates) ...he couldn't...swing. In the trees.

Good remembering! The monkey didn't think the elephant could swing in the trees.

What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Looks at the teacher, then back at my hands) The rabbit... (pauses) ...said he was... too big. To fit...in the burrow.

Perfect! The rabbit thought the elephant was too big for his burrow.

So, the monkey said no because the elephant couldn't swing, and the rabbit said no because the elephant was too big. How did that make the elephant feel, do you think?
(Looks down, thinking hard) ...Sad? (Quietly) Because no one...wanted to be his friend.

You're right. He probably felt very sad. Everyone was turning him away.

Then, something happened the next day in the forest. What was it?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembers the story) ...The tiger! (Hesitates) All the animals... were running.
Yes! The tiger was scaring everyone. What did the elephant do?
(Confidently, remembering the important part) He... he kicked the tiger! (Smiling slightly) To make it go away!
That's right! He kicked the tiger and scared it away. What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?
(Thinking, sticks to simple words) ...They liked him. (Looks at the teacher) They wanted... to be his friends. Because... he was big and strong?
They did like him! They wanted to be his friend. And you said, because he was big and strong? Why do you think being big and strong suddenly made them want to be his friend, when before they didn't?

(Looks down, hesitant) ...Uh... (pauses, thinking logically) ...Because he helped them? The tiger... was scary. And he made it go away. (Looks up, a little more confident) So... he could protect them?

That's a great answer! He helped them when they needed it. He protected them.

So, at first, the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant because he was too big, or couldn't swing. But then, they *did* want to be his friend because he helped them.

What do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size, or be good at the same things?
(Thinking hard, sticks to given information) ...No? (Hesitates) Friends... can be different? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) The elephant... was different. But he was still a good friend.

You got it! The elephant was different, but he was still a good friend.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What does it teach us about what makes a good friend? Can friends be different shapes and sizes, and still be good friends?

(Nods slowly, understanding) ...Yes. (Looks at the teacher, a little more confidently) It doesn't matter... if you can swing... or fit in a burrow. (Pauses) It matters if... you help each other. (Smiles slightly)
Exactly! It doesn't matter if you can swing or fit in a burrow. What matters is helping each other. Friends can be any shape or size. You understood the story so well! <finish>
Okay, so you just read the story "When Adversity Knocks"! What did you think of it? Did you like it?

(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers)

Uh... (hesitates) ... I liked it.
That's good! What part of the story did you like the best?

(Thinking hard, bites lip)

...The... the tea. (Looks up briefly, then down again)
The tea! Why did you like the tea the best? What did the tea do?

(Sticks to simple words, avoids eye contact)

...Changed... the water.
Yes! The tea changed the water. Now, can you tell me what the dad put in the other pots?
Great job! Now, what happened to the potato after it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, furrowing brow)

...Uh... no. (Pauses) It was... soft. (Looks at teacher briefly, then down again)
Yes! The potato got soft. And what happened to the egg? Was it soft or hard after the hot water?

Yes! The egg got hard. So, the potato was hard, and became soft. The egg was soft, and became hard. The tea... changed the water.

Do you think the hot water was like a problem for the potato, the egg, and the tea?
Okay. So, the hot water was like a problem. Did the potato, the egg, and the tea all react to the problem in the same way?

Right! They all reacted differently. The potato got soft, the egg got hard, and the tea changed the water.

Do you think *we* can react to problems in different ways too?

(Thinks for a moment, sticking to given information)

...Yes... (Hesitates) ...like the... potato and egg?

Yes! Just like the potato and the egg. Sometimes, when things are hard, we might get soft, like the potato. Other times, we might get hard, like the egg.

Which one do you think is better - to be soft like the potato, or hard like the egg, when things get tough? Or is there another way, like the tea?

(Looks down at my hands again, thinking very hard. This is a tough question!)

...Uh... (long pause) ...the tea? (Looks up at the teacher with a questioning look.)
Why do you think the tea is a good way? What did the tea do that was different?

(Sticks to simple words, avoids asking questions)

...Changed... the water... (Quietly) ...made it... better?

Yes! You're right! The tea *changed* the water. It made it something new. It didn't just get hard or soft.

So, the story is about how we can choose how we act when things get tough. We can get soft, we can get hard, or we can be like the tea and change the situation. What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember what the story was about. Feeling a little nervous.)

...Uh... (Hesitates) ...be like... tea? (Looks at the teacher for reassurance.)

Being like the tea is a good way! But what does it mean to "be like the tea"? The tea *chose* to change the water. The potato and egg didn't really choose.

Who gets to decide if you are like the potato, the egg, or the tea?

(Sticks to given information)

...I... do? (Looks up, surprised.)

Yes! *You* do! You get to decide how you will react when things get hard. The story is trying to teach us that we can choose how we respond to problems. We are in charge! We can choose to get soft, or hard, or change the situation.

So, what is the story about? Tell me in your own words.

(Thinking carefully, trying to put it all together. Chewing on my lip.)

...Uh... (Long pause) ...It's about... when things are... hard... (Looks up at the teacher briefly) ...we can... choose... what to do. Like... the potato... the egg... or... the tea. (Looks down again, relieved to have finished.)
That's it! You got it! The story is about how *we* decide how to respond to difficult situations. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, tell me in your own words, what was the story about? What happened in the beginning?
(Thinking, looking down at my shoes) Uh... there were two brothers... (hesitates) and the older one... (stuttering) ... went to the forest to chop wood.
Good start! You're right, there were two brothers. And what kind of brother was the older one *to* his younger brother? Was he nice, or not so nice?
(Looks down again, fidgeting with my hands) Not so nice... (quietly) He was mean.
That's right! He was mean. So, the older brother went to the forest. What did he find there?
(Thinking hard) A... a tree. (Looks up quickly, then down again) A magical tree.
Yes! A magical tree. And what did the magical tree *say* to the older brother?
(Sticks to given information, repeats part of the story) Don't... cut him down... (pause) and... he'd give him apples. (Looks up, then back down.) Golden apples.
Excellent! The tree didn't want to be cut down. And what happened after the brother got the golden apples? Was he happy?
He did want more! What did he do then?
(Quietly) He... tried to cut it... (pause) down.
And what happened when he tried to cut it down? The tree didn't like that, did it?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering the part of the story) ...Needles... (almost whispers) The tree gave him needles.
That's right! Ouch! What happened *after* he was covered in needles? Who helped him?
(Thinking for a moment) ...The... younger brother... (Looks up, hopeful)
Yes! The younger brother helped him. And what did the younger brother do?
(Thinking) He... took out the needles. (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe.)
He carefully took out all the needles. That was very kind, wasn't it? Now, what happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother say anything?
He did! He apologized. And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do?
(Eyes light up a little) ...More apples! (Looks down shyly again).
More golden apples! Why do you think the tree gave them more apples then? What changed?
(Thinking hard, chewing on lip slightly) ...Because... he said sorry? (Looks up questioningly) Was that... nice?
Yes! Saying sorry was a very important part. The older brother was mean at the beginning, but then he said he was sorry. He was kind in the end. What do you think this story is trying to teach us?
(Thinking, staring at my hands) ... Be nice? (Looks up, unsure) Is it... about being nice?
Being nice is a big part of it! What happened when the older brother wasn't nice?
(Frowns slightly) He got needles. (Looks down, remembering it sounded painful)
He did get needles! And what happened when he was sorry and his younger brother was kind?
(A small smile appears) They got... more apples.
They got more apples! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about being kind?
(Thinks hard, looking up at the ceiling) ...If you're kind... (Looks down again) ...good things happen?
Yes! Exactly! Being kind can lead to good things. So, we can say kindness is... rewarded. Do you know what that means?
(Shakes head slightly, looking down) ...Uh... no. (Quietly) What's "rewarded?"

Rewarded means you get something good back because of something you did. Like, if you're kind, you get something good back. In the story, they got more apples! So the story is about how "Kindness will always be rewarded!". Can you say that?
(Repeats slowly, looking at you) Kindness... will always be... rewarded. (Looks down, then back up) Like the apples?
Exactly like the apples! You understood the story very well. You worked that out all by yourself! <finish>

Okay! Hi there! That was a good job reading the story of King Midas!

Now, tell me, who was King Midas?

(Bounces in my seat, hand shoots up) I KNOW! I KNOW!

King Midas was a... a... (squints, thinking hard) a *Greek* king! He did a good thing for someone... a satyr! (grins proudly) And then that wine guy... Dionysus... (frowns) I think it was Dionysus... He gave Midas a wish! (Crosses arms, tapping foot impatiently) He should have wished for MORE wishes! But he didn't! He wished for... for... (eyes widen) EVERYTHING to turn to GOLD! (Leans forward, almost shouting) Stupid!

(Chuckles) You remembered so much! Yes, Midas was a Greek King, he helped a Satyr, and Dionysus granted him a wish.

You said "Stupid!" Why do you think it was stupid to wish for everything to turn to gold?

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, obviously! (Points finger accusingly) Because he couldn't EAT anything! (Wrinkles nose) Everything turned into gold, even his food! (Shudders) Gold pizza! Gold apples! Yuck! (Taps foot faster) And then, (voice cracks) and then he touched his DAUGHTER! (Face scrunches up, starting to get teary) And she turned into a gold statue too! (Looks away, fidgeting with hands) It's not a good wish at all! (Mumbles) I would have wished for a puppy... or a REALLY big castle... with a puppy IN it!

(Softly) You're right. It wasn't a very good wish. He couldn't eat, and his daughter... that was very sad.

So, at first, did King Midas *think* it was a good wish? Was he happy when things turned to gold?

(Sniffles, wipes nose with sleeve) Well, at *first*, he was like... (throws hands up in the air, mimicking excitement) "WOW! Gold! Shiny!" He was all happy and touching everything! (Starts pacing in front of the desk) Like, the story said he was EXCITED! He probably thought he was the smartest king ever! (Scoffs) But he wasn't. He was a big, gold-obsessed dummy! (Stops pacing, glares at the floor) I bet he bragged a lot too. "Look at me! I have gold EVERYTHING!" (Mimics a pompous voice) "I'm so rich and amazing!" (Crosses arms again, huffing) Show off.

(Nods understandingly) So, at first he liked the wish, but then he didn't.

What changed his mind? What made him realize it wasn't a good wish after all?

(Taps chin, thinking hard) Hmmm... Well, I already TOLD you! (Raises voice slightly) He couldn't EAT! (Gesticulates wildly) No snacks! No dinner! Just... gold! (Shivers dramatically) That would be AWFUL! (Leans in conspiratorially) I get SO grumpy when I'm hungry!

But... (Stares intensely) But the *daughter* part was the REALLY bad part. (Voice quieter) Turning your own daughter into gold... that's... (Struggles to find the right word) ...UNcool! Like, super-duper uncool! (Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) That's probably when he figured out he messed up BIG time.

You're right! Not being able to eat was bad, but turning his daughter into gold was the worst.

So, why did he want so much gold in the first place? What do you think?

(Scoffs) Because he was greedy! (Points emphatically) The story didn't SAY that, but it's TRUE! (Thinks for a second, tapping a finger on the desk) Rich people ALWAYS want more, even when they have, like, a million things! (Rolls eyes) My mom says it's because they're never happy. (Looks up at the teacher, tilting head) Is that true? Are rich people never happy? Maybe Midas should have wished for happiness instead of gold. (Frowns) That would have been a MUCH better wish.

That's a very good point! Maybe Midas *wasn't* very happy to begin with.

So, Midas was greedy and wanted more than he needed. And what happened because of that? What happened because he was so greedy?

(Paces back and forth again, getting agitated) He messed EVERYTHING up! (Throws hands up) He couldn't eat, his daughter turned into a statue! (Voice rising) He probably lost all his friends because he was too busy touching things and making them gold!

(Stops pacing suddenly and points a finger at the teacher) He learned a lesson! (Voice firm and confident) He learned that being greedy is BAD! (Taps chest importantly) And that happiness is more important than shiny things! (Grins mischievously) Even if those shiny things are made of GOLD!

You are exactly right! He did learn a very important lesson.

So, if someone were to ask you what the story of King Midas is *really* about, what would you tell them? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us?

(Puts on a serious face, puffs out chest) Okay, okay, I got this! (Stands up straight, as tall as possible)

The story of King Midas is about... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...being careful what you wish for! (Points finger accusingly) And it's about not being greedy! (Paces back and forth) Because being greedy can make you do REALLY dumb things, like turn your daughter into a gold statue! (Stops and looks directly at the teacher) And it's about happiness being more important than gold! (Nods head decisively) So, don't be like King Midas! Be happy and share your toys! (Grins widely) And maybe wish for a puppy instead of a golden toilet!

(Smiling) That's a perfect explanation! You really understood the story and what it teaches us. King Midas learned that being greedy can lead to bad things happening. We can all learn from his mistake. <finish>

Okay! Hi there! You just read "The Fox and the Grapes." That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Fidgets in my seat, tapping my foot)

Umm... (looks away, then back quickly) Yeah, it was... okay. The fox? He was looking for... (pauses, thinking hard) ... FOOD! (says it loudly and excitedly, running ahead a bit) He was super duper hungry! Like, REALLY hungry! He looked EVERYWHERE! (uses hands to emphasize "everywhere")

Yes! That's right! He was VERY hungry.

And where did he find something that looked yummy?

(Eyes widen, remembering the juicy grapes)

He... he found them by a WALL! (bounces in seat) A farmer's wall, with... (searches for the right word) ... purple, juicy... (stuttering slightly) ... GRAPES! They were HUGE and shiny! (Scoffs, rolling my eyes) Way better than anything else he could find, I bet.

Great job! Those grapes sounded delicious, didn't they?

What did the fox do to try and get the grapes?

(Crosses arms, a little impatient)

Duh! He JUMPED! (Mimics jumping with a little hop in my chair). He jumped REALLY high! Higher than YOU could jump! (Giggles, a little meanly) He tried and tried and tried! (Uses fingers to count, getting more enthusiastic) He probably jumped a million times! He wanted those grapes SO bad! (Frowns, briefly) But... (voice trails off, nervous) ... it didn't work, did it?

You're right! He did jump really high and try many times.

But what happened when he kept jumping? Did he get the grapes?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes)

NO! (Says it loudly and abruptly) Of course not! He couldn't reach them! He's just a dumb fox! (Shifts mood, getting frustrated) It's like... like when I try to get the cookies on the top shelf! I can never reach them! (Pouts, thinking) It's SO unfair! Maybe I should just say they're yucky anyway... like that fox did. (Looks at you expectantly, hoping for sympathy)
Okay, so the fox couldn't get the grapes, just like you sometimes can't reach the cookies. What did the fox say about the grapes after he couldn't reach them?

(Scowls, arms crossed tighter)

He said they were... (pauses, searching for the right word, then says it slowly and carefully) ... SOUR! He said they were probably sour anyway! (Looks away, avoiding eye contact) Like he didn't even WANT them! But he DID want them! (Voice rises in frustration) He just couldn't GET them! (Slams a hand lightly on the desk). It's not FAIR!

You're exactly right! He said they were sour because he couldn't reach them.

Do you *really* think the fox thought the grapes were sour?

(Frowns, thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk)

Hmm... (looks at you suspiciously) No! (Says it emphatically) He was just saying that! He was just... (searches for the word) ... pretending! He didn't *really* think they were sour! He just didn't want to feel bad about not getting them! (Anxious expression returns) It's like... it's like when I don't get picked for the team! I say I didn't even *want* to be on the team anyway! (Looks away again, fidgeting, voice quieter) But... but I *did* want to be on the team. So what do I do now (raising voice)

That's a very good connection! You understand the fox very well. He was pretending he didn't want the grapes because he was sad he couldn't get them.

So, the fox wanted something, he tried hard, but he couldn't get it. Then, he said he didn't want it anyway.

What do you think is the lesson we can learn from this story? What is the moral of this story?

(Scoffs and looks away)

A moral? (Thinking, then asks a question) Is that like... what we're supposed to learn?

(Eyes narrow in thought) Hmm... (Taps fingers rapidly on the desk) It means... (suddenly blurts out, loudly) ... that if you can't get something, just say you didn't want it anyway! (Pauses, unsure) Is that right? (Stuttering a little) Or... (Thinks harder, furrowing brow) ... maybe it means... (getting anxious) ... that it's okay to be sad when you can't get something? But... but you shouldn't LIE about it? (Looks at you with pleading eyes) I don't know! This is HARD! Tell me!

You're on the right track! It IS hard, but you're thinking about it the right way.

Think about it this way: The fox wanted the grapes. He tried hard. But he didn't get them. Should he pretend he didn't want them? Or should he try something else, or find something else to eat?

What do *you* think the story is trying to teach us about trying to get something we want?

(Frustrated, fidgeting, but also thinking very hard)

So... so it's BAD to say you didn't want it if you DID want it? (Looks away, shamefaced) Even if it makes you feel better? (Voice cracks slightly, on the verge of tears)

Maybe... maybe it means you should try harder! (Looks back at you with sudden determination) Or... (thinking again, brow furrowed) ... or maybe it means you should find something ELSE to want! (Snaps fingers as if having a thought). Yeah! Like... like if I can't have cookies, I can have... (thinking hard) ... CANDY! (Beams, suddenly happy)

So... so the moral is... (pauses, gathering thoughts) ... don't lie and say you didn't want it! Try harder, or find something else! (Nods head decisively, pleased with the answer) Is that right?

Yes! That's very close! You're doing great!

The story teaches us a few things. It's good to try hard for what you want. But sometimes, no matter how hard you try, you might not get it. It also means that nothing is easy.

So, what should you do then? Should you lie and say you didn't want it anyway? Or should you accept that you can't have it, and maybe find something else that *is* possible?

The moral of the story is: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

So, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Eyes widen, bouncing slightly in my seat, then I run ahead to answer)

The TWO main characters? (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Uh, um... It was a ROSE! (Points finger up excitedly) A really PRETTY rose! (Looks away for a second, frowning, feeling anxious) And... and a... (Stuttering a little) C-C-Cactus! Yeah! A cactus! But the rose was WAY prettier! (Arms crossed, looking a little bored now) What else did you want to know? (Raises hand impatiently, ready to ask MY questions).

That's right! A rose and a cactus.

Now, what did the rose like to do? What did she spend most of her time doing?

(Sighs dramatically, then rushes to answer)

Ugh, that rose! (Rolls eyes). She liked to... (Thinks for a REALLY long time, tapping foot impatiently, a little nervous). Okay, okay, I remember!
