(Looks up suddenly, eyes bright) Even if they're just elephants who are lonely! (Sits up straighter, feeling more confident) Is that right? Is that the lesson?

That's absolutely right! You figured it out perfectly. The story shows us that friends can be different sizes and shapes, and they don't have to be good at the same things. What matters is being kind and helpful. So, can friends be any shape or size?

(Nods enthusiastically, bouncing in seat) Yes! Yes, they can! (Pauses, thinking) But... but they still shouldn't be mean! Even if they're small and can swing in trees! (Glares off into space, remembering the monkey) Friends should be... (searches for the right word) ...considerate! And brave! Like the elephant! And not just like you when you kick a tiger! But all the time! (Looks at teacher, expecting approval)
You got it! Friends should be considerate and kind all the time. The elephant was brave, but he was also kind when he asked the tiger to stop. You've understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay, that was a good story, right?

Now, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

(Taps foot impatiently, eyes darting around the room) Uh, yeah, it was… okay. She brought an egg! And, uh… (wrinkles nose) a potato. And those… (thinks hard, biting lip) tea leaf things. Duh! (rolls eyes slightly)
Good job remembering! You got them all. Now, what did her father do with those things?

(Raises hand before the teacher finishes the sentence, nearly knocking over a pencil cup) He BOILED them! (Stands up excitedly, then quickly sits back down with a thump) In… in different pots. With water. Like, obviously! (Crosses arms, huffing a little. Looks out the window) Why are you asking such easy questions? (Stuttering) I know… know the answer. It's just…just so easy.

Okay, okay! I just want to make sure you remember the story.

Now, after they were boiled, what happened to the egg? Was it the same as before?

(Scoffs, fidgeting with a loose thread on shirt) No! (Voice rising) Of course not! The egg… the egg was all… hard! (Looks away, suddenly quiet) It wasn't… squishy anymore. Like… like a rock. (Eyes widen, leans forward conspiratorially) I bet she couldn't even smash it on her head anymore! (Giggles nervously)
You're right! The soft egg became hard. What about the potato? What happened to that?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in seat) Ugh, the potato… That dumb potato. (Pokes at the desk with a finger) It got all… (Struggles to find the word) …mushy! Like baby food! (Makes a face) Yuck! It was hard before, but then it was all soft and… (shudders) …gross. I would never eat it. Never, never, never! (Stands up again) I hate potatoes. (Immediately sits down again, face turning red) Sorry!
It's okay! You don't have to like potatoes. But you remembered what happened to it! The hard potato became soft. And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Taps fingers on the desk, thinking hard. Furrows brow) The tea… the tea… (Suddenly brightens, pointing a finger in the air) They changed the WATER! (Voice full of excitement) They didn't get hard or soft! They made the water all… (searches for the right word) …tea-y! (Beams proudly) It was like magic! (Pauses, then frowns) But… what kind of tea was it? Was it green tea? I like green tea. (Looks expectantly at the teacher)

That's right! The tea changed the water.

Now, the father said all those things showed how we can deal with hard times. The egg started soft but got hard. The potato started hard but got soft. And the tea changed the water.

Which one do you think is the *best* way to be when things get hard? Is it best to become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or change things like the tea?

(Paces back and forth, then stops abruptly, pointing at the teacher) The TEA! (Stomps foot) It's OBVIOUS! The egg just got hard and boring! The potato got all mushy and useless! But the tea… (eyes sparkling) the tea CHANGED things! It made the water different! Better, maybe! (Stands on tiptoes, whispering) You have to be like the tea! Make things… make things… awesome! (Sits down, suddenly deflated) Unless it was bad tea. Then it's a terrible idea. (Worried expression) What if it was *really* bad tea?

Okay, okay, let's say it was GOOD tea. Not bad tea.

So, the tea changed the water. The story says that when things get hard, we can be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. If we are like the tea and *change* things, what do you think that means we can do when things are difficult?

(Pulls a face, picking at a scab on their knee) Change things… (Thinking hard, mumbling to self) If things are hard… like, REALLY hard… and you're the tea… then you gotta… (Snaps fingers) …make them DIFFERENT! (Eyes light up) Like, if someone's being mean, you don't get all hard and punch them (demonstrates a weak punch), and you don't get all mushy and cry (pretends to sob loudly), you change the situation! You… (Stands up again, pacing) …you tell a joke! Or you… you draw a picture of them with a funny nose! (Giggles, then sits down abruptly) Or… or you just go play somewhere else! Yeah! You change the whole game! (Looks proud, then glances nervously at the teacher) But what if they don't think my joke is funny? (Worried tone) What if they get even MORE mad?

That's a very good way of putting it! You can change the situation!

So, the story is about how *we* can choose what to do when things are hard. We can choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea the story wants us to remember?

(Crosses arms, leans back in chair, looking bored) Ugh, another question? (Taps foot impatiently) Fine. (Thinking) It's trying to say… (Draws a circle on the desk with a finger) …that when things are crummy, you can decide what to do. You can be a hardhead, or a mushy baby, or… (Smiles slightly) …or you can be TEA! (Jumps up, knocking over a book) And make things BETTER! (Quickly picks up the book, shoving it back on the desk) But… but what if you don't *know* how to make things better? (Frowns, biting lip) What if you're just… stuck? (Looks anxiously at the teacher)

You're right! You decide what to do.

You can choose how you want to be, and you can try to change things! You can always ask for help if you feel stuck. Now, you understand that we decide how to respond to difficult situations.

Do you have any other questions about the story? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it a little bit. Who are the main people in our story?

(Bounces in my seat, practically vibrating with energy) Uh-huh, it was! It was *so* cool! (runs ahead with the answer, not waiting for the teacher to finish)

Okay, so, the main people were... were... um... (taps chin, furrowing brow, thinks *hard*) There were two brothers, right? (looks up at the teacher, waiting for confirmation, a little anxiously) And, and... uh... the magical tree! (eyes widen, gesturing wildly) The tree was *totally* a person 'cause it *talked*! It *begged*! That's like, super important! (voice rising in excitement)

So yeah! Two brothers, one mean and one... not mean! And the *talking* tree! Did the tree have a name? (eyes the teacher expectantly, already formulating a complex question about tree communication in my head) Was it a boy tree or a girl tree? (fidgets, already restless for the next question or to ask my own)

Yes, you're exactly right! Two brothers and the magical tree. You remembered everything! We don't know if the tree was a boy or a girl tree, but that's a good question to think about.

So, the older brother and the younger brother... what was the older brother like? Was he nice?

(Scowls, crossing arms) Nice? (scoffs) No way! He was the *worst*! (looks away, fidgeting, a dark mood settling in quickly) He was, like, super mean to his little brother! (voice dripping with disdain) He only cared about the golden apples! (voice rising in anger, a hint of a whine creeping in)

He chopped wood and... (pauses, thinking hard, accessing memory) ...and he wasn't nice *at all*! I wouldn't want *him* for *my* brother! (eyes narrowing, a look of genuine dislike on my face) He was... greedy! (says the word with extra emphasis, like it's a really complex and important word) What does greedy *really* mean? Does it mean you don't share your crayons? (looks at the teacher expectantly, genuinely curious, the previous anger fading slightly)

That's right! He was very mean and greedy. Greedy means you want way more than you need, and you don't want to share.

What did the *younger* brother do? Was he mean like his older brother?

(Shifts in seat, mood brightening considerably) No! The younger brother was *way* better! (beams, eager to show my knowledge) He wasn't mean at all! (confidently) He was... (thinking, searching for the right word) ...he was *helpful*! (eyes light up)

When the older brother was all covered in needles... (grimaces, shuddering dramatically) ...the younger brother *helped* him! He took out all the needles! (makes exaggerated pulling motions with my hands) That's *super* nice! I would *never* do that if someone was mean to *me*! (pouts, a hint of anxiety creeping in about whether I would be that nice)

So, yeah! Younger brother: nice and helpful. Older brother: mean and... and... (struggles to recall the word) ...greedy! (snaps fingers, triumphant) Did the younger brother *have* to help? Or could he just left him there? (eyes wide, genuinely pondering the moral implications)

That's a great question! No, the younger brother didn't *have* to help. He *chose* to help.

Why do you think the younger brother helped even though the older brother was mean to him?

(Frowns, biting lip, deep in thought. This is a *hard* question!) Hmmm... (taps pencil on the desk, a little nervously) Maybe... (stuttering slightly) ...maybe because... (eyes dart around the room, avoiding eye contact) ...maybe he was... scared? (voice barely a whisper) Scared that if he didn't help, nobody would? (looks at the teacher with a worried expression)

Or... (suddenly brightens, a new idea sparking) ...or maybe he just *knew* it was the right thing to do! (voice gaining confidence) Like when you help someone who fell down, even if they were mean to you before! (nodding vigorously) It's just... (searching for the word) ...it's just *kind*! (says the word proudly, but still a little unsure if that's the right answer) But it's *really* hard to be kind when someone is mean! (shudders, hugging self) I get *really* mad! (eyes welling up a little)

You're right, it *is* really hard to be kind when someone is mean to you. But you're also right that the younger brother probably knew it was the right thing to do. He was being kind.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped the older brother? Did the tree stay mad?

(Sniffles, wiping eyes quickly with the back of my hand. Mood swings again, getting excited, the negative feelings momentarily gone) Oh! Oh! I know! (practically leaps out of seat) The older brother said sorry! (voice ringing with satisfaction) He finally said he was... he was... (struggling for the right word again) ...he said he was... sorry for being *mean*! (says the words with emphasis, like it's a huge accomplishment)

And then... (eyes widen, a huge smile spreading across face) ...and then the tree wasn't mad anymore! The tree gave them *more* golden apples! (clapping hands together) So, being sorry *works*! (looks at the teacher with intense curiosity) Does saying sorry *always* work? Even if you broke someone's really important toy? (voice laced with anxiety, clearly remembering a past transgression)

That's right! The older brother said sorry, and the tree gave them more golden apples. Saying sorry is a very important step. It doesn't always fix everything completely, but it's a good start.

Why do you think the tree gave them *more* golden apples after the older brother apologized and the younger brother helped him? What changed?

(Tilts head, chewing on a fingernail, thinking *hard* again. Complex stuff!) Hmmm... (long pause, punctuated by fidgeting) I think... (stuttering slightly, unsure of myself) ...I think the tree... (voice dropping to a near whisper) ...the tree saw they weren't... weren't... *bad* anymore? (eyes searching the teacher's face for confirmation)

Like, the older brother was mean before, but then he said sorry, so maybe he learned his lesson? (voice becoming more confident) And the younger brother was *always* good, so the tree knew they deserved the apples? (nods slowly, convincing self) It's like... (searching for a relatable example) ...it's like when you're coloring, and you color *really* messy, and then you start coloring *really* neatly! Then you get a sticker! (beams at the teacher, proud of the analogy) Is that what it's like? Is that why the tree gave them more apples? (eager for validation, but already formulating a follow-up question about reward systems)

Yes, I think you're exactly right! The tree saw that the older brother learned his lesson and that the younger brother was always kind. They showed they could be good, and the tree rewarded them.

So, if you were going to tell someone what this story is trying to teach us, what would you say? What's the big idea of the story?

(Jumps up, nearly knocking over the desk in excitement. This is it! The big conclusion!) Okay! Okay! I know! (paces back and forth, waving arms emphatically) The story is trying to teach us... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...that it's *always* better to be *kind* than to be *mean*! (points finger for emphasis with each word)

And... (thinking, adding a crucial point) ...and that even if you *are* mean, you can still say sorry and change! (voice filled with newfound hope) And... (even more excited now) ...and that sometimes, if you're good, you get rewarded with golden apples! (eyes sparkling) But you should be good even if you *don't* get golden apples, right? (looks at the teacher, suddenly anxious about getting it wrong) Because it's just the right thing to do? (pleading for confirmation) Can I get a sticker for understanding the story? (grinning mischievously)
Yes! You got it! Being kind is always the right thing to do, and the story shows us that kindness can be rewarded. You understood the story perfectly. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

So, tell me, who was King Midas?

(Bounces in my seat, eager to answer)

King Midas! (Points finger excitedly) He was, like, a REALLY greedy king in the story! He did a good thing for a satyr... I think satyrs are kinda like goat-men? (Tilts head, thinking). And then Dionysus, who's like, the god of party juice... I mean wine! Gave him a wish!

(Chuckles) Party juice! That's a good way to remember Dionysus.

You're right! He *did* do a good thing. And Dionysus offered him a wish. What did Midas wish for?

(Eyes widen, leans forward)

He wished for... (pauses dramatically) EVERYTHING he touched to turn to GOLD! (Claps hands together loudly). Even though Dionysus said it was a bad idea! But Midas didn't listen because he wanted ALL the gold! Stupid king! (Frowns, crosses arms). I would've wished for something better, like a lifetime supply of... of... (Struggles to think of something) Rainbow Sherbet!

(Laughs) Rainbow Sherbet! That *is* a good wish! Much better than all that gold, maybe.

So, Midas got his wish. What happened next? He started touching things, right? What did he touch?

(Nods head vigorously)

Yup! He touched, like, everything! He probably touched his chair first! (Points at the teacher's chair). And then his table! (Slams hand on my own desk, making a loud bang). And then, like, all his toys! Wait...did he have toys? Maybe he had a golden crown! And then he touched his food! (Makes a disgusted face) And that was a HUGE problem! (Stares intently, waiting for the next question). He turned his YUMMY food into yucky gold! (Grimaces).

You're doing great remembering the story!

Yes, he touched his food! Why was turning his food into gold a problem for Midas?

(Rolls eyes, like it's obvious)

Because he couldn't EAT it! (Gestures wildly with hands). You can't eat GOLD, silly! It's hard and yucky and doesn't taste like anything! He was probably SUPER hungry! (Rubs tummy dramatically). I get grumpy when I'm hungry! (Sticks out tongue). He should have thought about that before wishing for stupid gold! (Looks away, slightly embarrassed by the outburst).

(Nods understandingly)

Being hungry *is* grumpy-making! You're right, he couldn't eat the gold. And what happened after he couldn't eat? Who came to see him?

(Sits up straighter, remembers the dramatic part)

His DAUGHTER! (Voice gets softer). His little girl! She was probably, like, really worried about him because he was sad and hungry! She ran to give him a big hug! (Opens arms wide, then claps hands over mouth, realizing what's coming). Oh no! (Looks down at desk, fiddling with a pencil). She turned into... into... a golden statue! (Whispers). That's SO sad!
Yes, it *is* very sad. How do you think Midas felt when his daughter turned to gold?

(Furrows brow, thinking hard. Taps pencil on desk impatiently).

(Confidently) He felt TERRIBLE! (Voice loud again). SUPER duper terrible! He probably wanted to UN-wish his wish! He finally learned that gold isn't everything! (Looks at the teacher pointedly). It's better to have rainbow sherbet and a hug from your daughter than a pile of gold you can't eat or hug! (Nods decisively, convinced of the correctness of my assessment).

You're absolutely right! He did feel terrible. He learned a very important lesson.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, the message of the story? Why should people read it?

(Puffs out cheeks, thinking deeply. Scratches head, then snaps fingers).

(Excitedly) It's trying to teach us that... (pauses for effect)... being GREEDY is bad! And that things that are really important, like hugs and food and... and... friends! (Looks around the room, searching for a friend, but quickly loses interest) are way more important than having lots of money! (Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt). The story is trying to say that being greedy will make you SAD! (Looks up at the teacher again, waiting for approval).

That's a *fantastic* explanation! You got it exactly right. Being greedy can make you very unhappy. Wanting *too* much can lead to bad things. Sometimes, the things we already have are the most valuable.

So, we can say that the story of King Midas teaches us that greed can lead to unhappiness. Do you think you'll remember that?

(Stands up suddenly, energized again)

Yeah! (Starts pacing back and forth in front of the desk). I'll remember it FOREVER! I'm gonna tell all my friends that King Midas was a big, fat, greedy head! (Stops pacing and grins mischievously). And that they should always share their rainbow sherbet... unless they don't want to, because it's THEIR sherbet! (Tilts head, considering this new thought). But being greedy is still BAD! (Crosses arms again, reaffirming the lesson). Can we read another story now? One with dragons, maybe? (Looks at the teacher expectantly).

(Smiles) I think you've really understood the story of King Midas. You explained it wonderfully. Yes, being greedy is not a good thing.

We can definitely read another story later, and maybe it will have a dragon! For now, let's move on to something else. <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story, [User's Name]! That was the story of the Fox and the Grapes.

Now, can you tell me what the fox was looking for?

(Bounces foot impatiently)

Uhm, yeah, yeah. (Rolls eyes slightly) The fox wanted food! Duh. Like, he was, like, super hungry, right? He couldn't find anything. Then he saw the grapes. Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Gestures wildly with hands, almost hitting the teacher) But, he couldn't get them. So, yeah... food! Was that the right answer? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, but not really caring) Why are we even talking about this? It's so obvious. (Thinking)

Yes, you're right! The fox was looking for food. Excellent!

And what did he find that he really, *really* wanted? What did he try to get?

(Sighs dramatically) Grapes! I already SAID that. Are you even listening? (Folds arms across chest) Big, juicy, PURPLE grapes! (Thinking) Why are you asking me again? Do you think I'm, like, dumb or something? I know the story! (Confidently) He wanted the grapes! Next question! This is taking too long. (Taps foot faster)

Okay, okay! You're doing great! I just want to make sure we understand everything.

So, he wanted the grapes. Did he get the grapes?

(Scoffs) No! (Rolls eyes) If he got the grapes, there wouldn't be a story, would there? He jumped and jumped and jumped! (Mimics jumping with hands, then stops abruptly) But he couldn't reach. He was, like, a total loser. (Confidently) No, he did NOT get the grapes. It's, like, the whole point of the story. (Looks around the room, bored) Can we move on now? This is easy-peasy. I bet I could write a way better story than that one! (Smirks slightly)

You're absolutely right, he didn't get the grapes! He tried really hard, but he couldn't reach them.

What did the fox say *after* he couldn't get the grapes? What did he think about them then?

(Taps fingers on desk impatiently) Ugh, finally! (Thinking) Oh, yeah, yeah, I remember! (Smirks) He said... he said the grapes were probably sour anyway! (Confident chuckle) (Looks away, feeling superior) He was just saying that because he couldn't get them. Like, "Oh, I didn't want them anyway!" What a baby! He just gave up. (Thinking) Serves him right for not being tall enough, I guess. Is that all? Can I go draw now? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)
That's right! He said they were sour. Why do you think he said that? You said he was just saying it because he couldn't get them. Why would he do that?

(Sighs loudly and leans back in chair) Ugh, this is SO boring. (Thinking, furrowing brow slightly) Okay, fine. (Points finger) He said it because... (pauses, searching for words, then blurts out) ...because he didn't want to feel bad! (Confidently) Like, he was embarrassed that he couldn't get the grapes, right? So he pretended he didn't even WANT them in the first place. (Smirks knowingly) People do that ALL the time! It's, like, a total cover-up. He didn't want anyone to know he was a failure. (Rolls eyes) So, yeah. That's why he said it. Now can I *please* go draw?

That's a really good answer! He didn't want to feel bad. He was trying to make himself feel better about not getting what he wanted.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Glares at the teacher, as if they should already know the answer) What? (Thinking) Ugh, another question? (Taps fingers) The big idea... (pause, then blurts out impatiently) ...is that you shouldn't say you don't want something just because you can't have it! (Confidently) It's, like, being a liar! (Shrugs) And it makes you look stupid. The fox looked super dumb saying the grapes were sour. (Thinking) He should have just kept trying. Or maybe asked for help! (Rolls eyes) But noooo, he had to be all dramatic. (Sighs) So, yeah, don't be a liar and a quitter. Is that good enough? Can I PLEASE go now? (Starts packing up crayons and paper aggressively)

That's a *really* good answer! You're right, the story is about not pretending you don't want something just because you can't have it.

It also teaches us that sometimes things are hard to get. The fox had to work hard to try and get the grapes. Do you think the story is trying to say something about things that are hard to get?

(Stops packing crayons for a split second, eyes narrowing) Hmm... (Thinking harder, but still impatient) Things that are hard to get... (Taps chin with a crayon, leaving a mark) Well, duh! If it was easy, everyone would have it! (Rolls eyes) (Confident again) The story's saying that sometimes you have to work for stuff! Like, REALLY work! (Scoffs) But the fox was a quitter. He didn't work hard enough. (Shrugs) So, yeah, work hard or go home, I guess. But if you go home, don't be a baby about it! (Grabs all art supplies and stands up abruptly) Okay, NOW can I go? I GET it. Hard things are hard. The fox was a loser. End of story! (Heads for the door without waiting for a response)

You've got it! Sometimes things are hard work, and it's important to try your best. And even if you don't get what you want, it's not good to pretend you didn't want it in the first place! The fox should have kept trying or accepted that he couldn't reach.

You understand the story really well. Great job, [User's Name]! <finish>

Okay, that was a good story!

So, tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Bounces in my seat, then looks away for a second, thinking) Okay, okay! The two main characters... (confidently) ... were a rose and a *cactus*! (Raises hand eagerly) I knew that! The rose was super mean, right? (Giggles a little)

Yes, you're exactly right! A rose and a cactus.

And you said the rose was mean. What did the rose *do* that made it mean?

(Frowns, tapping a finger on the desk) Hmph. (Rolls eyes slightly) It kept... (searching for the right word) ...insulting the cactus! Like, all the time! (Points a finger) It probably thought the cactus was ugly. The rose was too busy looking at itself! I bet it looked in the mirror all day. (scoffs) Stupid rose.

You're doing a great job! So, the rose insulted the cactus because it thought it was ugly.

How did the *other* plants feel about the rose insulting the cactus?

(Sighs loudly) Ugh, (crosses arms) the other plants were probably, like, totally annoyed. (Thinks hard) They tried to... (snaps fingers) ...defend the cactus! But the rose didn't listen! (Shakes head dismissively) It was too busy being a... (struggles for a word) ...a *show-off*! (Looks at the teacher, expecting praise)

Yes, you're absolutely right! They tried to defend the cactus, but the rose wouldn't listen.

Then the summer came. What happened during the hot summer in the desert?

(Eyes widen, leaning forward) Ooooh, the summer! (Taps chin, thinking) It got REALLY hot! And there was NO water! (Gasps dramatically) The rose started to... (pauses, struggling with the word) ...wither! Yeah, *wither*! (Looks proud of using a big word) It was all droopy and sad. (Smirks a little) Serves it right!

"Wither" is a great word! Good job!

So the rose started to wither. What about the cactus? What was happening to the cactus during the hot summer?

(Puffs out cheeks, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Suddenly grins) Oh! Oh! I know! The cactus... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...became a water source for the sparrows! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, expecting to be amazed) It was helping them! (Folds arms again, a little smug) The rose wasn't helping anyone!

That's right! The cactus was helping the sparrows.

Now, what happened at the end of the story? The rose was withering, and the cactus was helping the birds... what happened *between* them?

(Taps foot impatiently) (Looks up at the ceiling, trying to remember) Ummm... (Snaps fingers) Oh! The rose... (lowers voice conspiratorially) ...*asked* the cactus for water! Can you believe it?! (Scoffs) After being so mean! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for a reaction, a little disgusted)

Yes, you're right! The rose asked the cactus for water.

And what did the cactus *do*? Did it say no?

(Scoffs again, shaking head) Nope! (Rolls eyes, but then a flicker of surprise crosses face) The... the cactus... (reluctantly) ...gave the rose water. (Looks down at hands, picking at a fingernail, a little confused) Even though the rose was a big jerk! (Looks back up, challenging the teacher) Why did it do that? (Frowns, waiting for an explanation)
That's a very good question. Why *did* the cactus give the rose water after the rose was so mean? What do *you* think?

(Stares blankly for a moment, then wrinkles nose) Hmmm... (Thinks hard, tapping fingers on the desk) Maybe... maybe the cactus was just... nice? (Says the word "nice" like it's a disease) Or... (eyes light up with a new idea) ...maybe it knew that if the rose died, there would be no one left to make fun of! (Giggles) So it kept the rose alive so it could still have someone to feel better than! (Looks at the teacher, pleased with own cleverness) Which one do you think it is? (Asks the teacher for the answer)
Those are both interesting ideas! But think about the cactus helping the birds. Was it doing that to feel better than them?

(Considers this, brows furrowed) Well... no. (Sighs, feeling like the right answer is elusive) The cactus was just... helping. (Says it quietly, almost reluctantly) So maybe... (pauses, thinking carefully) ...maybe it helped the rose because... that's just what you're supposed to do? (Looks up, unsure, but also wanting the teacher to say it's right) Even if someone is mean? (Confused) That's... weird.

It can seem weird, can't it? But think about what the story is trying to teach us. The rose thought it was better than the cactus because of how it looked. But in the end, who was really helpful and kind?

(Glares at the table, then back up, a glimmer of understanding dawning) The cactus! (Says it triumphantly) Because being pretty doesn't matter if you're a big meanie! (Smiles, proud of figuring it out) The rose was all looks, but the cactus was... (searches for the right word) ...useful! And nice! So... being nice and useful is better than just being pretty and mean? (Looks at the teacher, wanting confirmation) Did I get it right? (Beams, ready for praise)

You got it exactly right! The story shows us that it's not good to judge others based on how they look. The rose was pretty, but it was mean. The cactus might not have looked as fancy, but it was kind and helpful.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we learn from the rose and the cactus?

(Puffs out chest, ready to share newfound wisdom) Okay, okay! The lesson is... (pauses for dramatic effect, points a finger) ...don't be a show-off rose! (Grins) Be a helpful cactus! (Nods sagely) And... (thinks for a moment, making sure to include everything) ...and don't judge people by how they look! Judge them by how... (struggles for the word) ...how *helpful* they are! (Claps hands together, pleased with own explanation) Boom! Nailed it!
You absolutely nailed it! You understood the story and the lesson perfectly. The story teaches us that we should never judge someone according to how they look. <finish>

Okay! You just read the story about Molly, the milkmaid.

What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Eyes wide, jumping a little) Sell it! At the market! (Looks away, like thinking of something even better) She was gonna get money for it! Lots and LOTS of money! (Sticks tongue out a little, picturing all the things she could buy).
Yes, she was! And what did she start thinking about as she walked? What did she want to buy with her money?

(Puffs out cheeks, thinking hard, then blurts out) A CHICKEN! (Looks at the teacher, waiting for praise) She was gonna buy a chicken, and then the chicken would lay eggs, and then she'd sell *those* and get even MORE money! (Crosses arms, a smug look on face) I bet *you* didn't even think about that part! (Taps foot impatiently) She'd be richer than ANY milkmaid!
Wow, you remembered all that! That’s great! So, she was thinking about the chicken and the eggs and getting richer. What happened then?

(Scoffs, rolling eyes) Ugh, that's the dumb part. (Looks down, kicking the floor a little) She started skipping...like a baby! (Mimics skipping, then stops abruptly, looking annoyed) And then... (mumbles) ...the milk spilled. ALL of it! (Looks up, arms crossed again, defiantly) Stupid milk. It's HER fault for skipping! I would have walked *really* carefully!
Okay, so the milk spilled. How did Molly feel then? And what did she have when she got home?

(Shrugs, not really caring) I dunno... sad, maybe? But it was her own fault! (Thinking for a moment) She went home with... uh... (counts on fingers) ...empty pails! And no money! (Bursts out laughing) Ha! Serves her right for skipping! (Confident, points a finger) She should have thought about it more! I would have!
You're right, she did end up with empty pails. What did her mother tell her? Do you remember the saying?

(Wrinkles nose, thinking. Stutters a bit) Umm... uh... (looks at ceiling, trying to remember, then snaps fingers) Oh! Oh! I know! (Says it very fast and loud) Don'tcountyourchickenstheyhaven'thatchedyet! (Beams proudly, waiting for praise) Did I get it right? Did I? (Taps foot impatiently) What does it even MEAN though? (Frowns, confused.)
Yes, you got it right! Now, let's think about what it means. Molly was already planning what to do with the egg money BEFORE she even bought the chicken. Do you see the problem with that?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes again) Of *course* I see the problem! (Looks away, thinking) The chicken might not EVEN lay eggs! Or... (eyes widen) ...a fox could eat the chicken! Or... (starts listing on fingers) ...she could drop the eggs! Or... or... (trails off, runs out of fingers) There are LOTS of problems! (Looks at teacher, smugly) I told you she should have thought about it more! I would have made a LIST!

Exactly! So, Molly was depending on something that wasn't certain to happen. She was counting on those eggs before they even existed! What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What is the story's message?

(Crosses arms, thinking hard, then blurts out) Don't be a dummy like Molly! (Pauses, thinking a bit more logically) Uh... don't... (frowns) ...don't plan stuff before it happens? (Looks at teacher, expectantly) Like... don't spend your birthday money before you GET your birthday money! (Nods head, confidently) Is that it? Is that the message? I'm good at messages!

Yes, that's a great way to put it! Don't plan to spend money before you have it!

The story is teaching us that we shouldn't depend on things until we are sure they will happen. Just like Molly shouldn't have counted on the egg money before she even had a chicken. Do you understand now? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl! That was a good read.

Now, can you tell me, what did the owl do every day?

(Stands up suddenly, excited) I KNOW! I KNOW! (Waving hand enthusiastically)

He watched! He watched EVERYTHING happening around his tree! People talking and stuff! (Looks at the teacher, then starts to run in place a little) He saw LOTS of things. Did he see squirrels too? Were they fighting over acorns? (Thinking, brow furrowed)

(Smiling encouragingly) Yes! He watched everything. That's right! He saw people talking and lots of things happening. And maybe he saw squirrels too!

Did the story say he talked a lot?

(Stops running and looks at the teacher, a bit impatient)

No! (Shakes head firmly) The story said... (Thinking hard, taps foot) ...the *more* he saw, the *less* he talked! Like, zero talk, right? Just... looking. But that's kinda weird, isn't it? Why wouldn't he talk? (Looks away, fiddling with a button on shirt) Did he not LIKE talking? Was he mean? (Looks back at the teacher, a little suspicious) Did *you* like talking when you were a kid?

(Chuckles softly) Good question! The story doesn't say he was mean. It just says he talked less.

Why do *you* think he talked less the more he saw and heard? What happened because he watched and listened so much?

(Puffs out cheeks, thinking hard, paces back and forth a few steps)

Because... because if you talk ALL the time, you can't hear anything, right? (Points finger in the air) Like, blabber, blabber, blabber! (Makes blabbering motions with hands) Then you don't LEARN anything! (Stops pacing, looks at the teacher confidently) The owl was smart! He wanted to know stuff! That's why he got wise! He *learned*! (Raises eyebrows expectantly, waiting for confirmation) He's the smartest bird EVER! (Crosses arms, a little defiant) Way smarter than those noisy pigeons outside!

(Nodding, impressed) You got it! Yes! If you talk all the time, you can't hear and learn. The owl listened and watched, and that helped him learn and become wise.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Should we talk a lot, or listen a lot, like the owl?

(Rolls eyes slightly, like the answer is obvious)

Listen! (Points to ears dramatically) Of COURSE we should listen! But not ALL the time! (Taps chin thoughtfully) Sometimes talking is good... like if you need to tell someone they're sitting on your favorite crayon! (Looks directly at the teacher, a little accusatory) Or if someone is being mean! (Frowns) Then you HAVE to talk. But mostly... (Shrugs) ...mostly listening is better. So you can learn! So you can be as smart as the owl! (Smiles proudly) I'm gonna be SUPER smart! Am I smart now?

(Smiling warmly) You *are* smart! You understood the story very well. You're right, sometimes talking is important, like when someone is being mean. But the story teaches us that listening and watching can help us learn and become wise, just like the owl. We should try to talk less and pay more attention to what's happening around us.

Do you understand now what the moral of the story is?

(Nods head enthusiastically)

Yeah! (Pulls out a crumpled piece of paper from pocket) It's like... it's like when I'm drawing! (Unfolds the paper, revealing a messy drawing of a rocket ship) I have to LOOK at the picture in my head REALLY good before I start coloring, or it'll be all WRONG! (Points to a smudged green area on the rocket) See? I talked too much to my friend while I was coloring that part, and I colored it the WRONG color! (Looks up at the teacher, a little frustrated) So... listening and looking is like planning your coloring! (Grins widely) I get it! (Crushes the drawing back into a ball and shoves it back in pocket) Can we read another story now? One about robots? Are there any with a moral in them?

(Smiling) That's a fantastic example! You're exactly right. Listening and looking are like planning your coloring, so you don't color the rocket the wrong color! You understood the story and its message perfectly!

Yes, there are lots of stories with morals! But for now, it seems like you understand the story and the moral of "The Wise Old Owl" very well. <finish>

(Jumps up and down excitedly) YAY! I'M SMART! (Suddenly stops jumping and points a finger at the teacher) But you KNOW what? I bet *I* could write an even BETTER story about a wise owl! It would have SPACE SHIPS and aliens! And maybe... (Taps chin thoughtfully, considering the possibilities) ...maybe the owl would TEACH the aliens how to listen! (Grins mischievously) It would be the BEST story EVER! (Runs to the other side of the room, then stops abruptly and shouts) Can I go draw it now? (Looks expectantly at the teacher)
</finish>
(Laughing) Yes, you can go draw it now! That sounds like a wonderful story! I can't wait to hear all about it when you're done. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?

(Rolls my eyes) Uh, yeah, it was kinda sad, I guess. (Taps foot impatiently).

The main people? (Confidently) That's easy! It was the farmer and his wife. And the goose, but the goose isn't a *person*, right? It's a *goose*. (Pulls a face, like the goose being a "person" is ridiculous). Are we done now? I wanna go play! (Starts fidgeting).

You're right! The farmer and his wife are the main *people* and the goose is a goose.

What did the goose do every day?

(Sighs loudly, like this is taking too long) It laid a golden egg! Duh! (Looks away, bored). What else would a *golden* goose do? Lay regular eggs? (Scoffs). That's so... (searches for a complicated word) ...illogical! Can we talk about something *interesting* now? Like... space? Or dinosaurs? (Eyes light up at the mention of dinosaurs)
Okay, okay, a golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Sighs again, even louder this time and fidgets more) He... he *sold* it! (Speaks very slowly and deliberately, like you're incredibly slow). He sold it to get money! What do YOU do with eggs? Eat 'em? (Wrinkles nose in disgust). Golden eggs are for selling, not eating! That's like... economics! (Puffs out chest proudly, even though the word might be slightly misapplied). Can I draw a dinosaur now? (Starts reaching for a crayon).
You're doing great! He sold it for money. And what did the farmer and his wife do with the money?

(Taps chin, thinking, actually concentrating for a moment). Hmm... they... they lived good! (Confidently) They had a comfortable life! The book said so! (Points to the book, even though it's closed). They probably bought... (eyes dart around the room, searching for inspiration) ...a really big TV! (Nods decisively). And maybe some... robot toys! 'Cause robots are awesome! (Grins widely, then remembers he's supposed to be annoyed). Can we MOVE ON now? This is getting boring!
A big TV and robot toys sound fun! So, they were happy for a while. But then, what happened? What did the farmer start to think?

(Crosses arms, scowling). He got... (searches for a word) ...greedy! (Spits out the word with disdain). He wanted MORE! (Voice gets louder). He's so dumb! (Shakes head). He should have just been happy with the golden egg! (Thinking hard) He thought... he thought he could get ALL the eggs at once! He's SOOOOOOOOOO stupid! (Starts to draw a very angry-looking dinosaur on his hand with the crayon).
You're right, he was greedy. And what did he *do* because he was greedy? What silly thing did he do?

(Scribbles harder on his hand, making the dinosaur look even angrier). He... he cut the goose open! (Looks up, eyes wide with a mix of disgust and morbid fascination). He thought all the golden eggs were *inside*! (Shakes head again, even more vehemently). What a moron! (Uses another "big" word he's probably heard adults use). He's dumber than a... a rock! (Points at a rock near the window).
And what did he find when he cut the goose open?

(Makes a grossed-out face). Blood and guts! (Shudders dramatically). Yuck! No golden eggs! (Rolls eyes again). Just... (searches for another complex word) ... viscera! (Looks pleased with himself for using such a big word, even though he probably doesn't fully understand what it means). Serves him right!
You're right, serves him right! So, now he didn't have the goose anymore. What happened to the farmer and his wife after that?

(Smirks slightly, clearly enjoying the farmer's misfortune). They got poor! (Voice is almost gleeful). They lost all their money! No more big TV! No more robots! (Suddenly looks a little thoughtful). Maybe... maybe they learned a lesson? (Quickly shakes head, dismissing the thought). Nah! Probably just whined about it! (Starts tapping the crayon on the desk impatiently again). Can I REALLY draw dinosaurs now? This story is dumb!

They did get poor. They lost their source of golden eggs.

So, the farmer acted without thinking. He wanted more and more, and in the end, he lost everything. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, or the moral of the story?

(Glares at you, like the question is an insult to his intelligence). The moral is... (thinks hard, tapping the crayon) ...don't be greedy! (Says it like it's the most obvious thing in the world). If you have something good, just... keep it! (Shrugs). Don't be like that stupid farmer and ruin everything! (Pauses, then adds, a little quieter). Also... don't cut open animals! (Looks down at the dinosaur drawing on his hand). That's just... mean. (Looks up again, trying to regain his usual bravado). But mostly, don't be greedy! Now, can I PLEASE draw a T-Rex eating that stupid farmer?! (Points dramatically out the window, as if the farmer is actually there).

You got it! Don't be greedy, and think about what might happen *before* you do something silly. The story is teaching us to think before we act. If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realised that cutting open the goose was a very bad idea.

Great job! You really understood the story. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Who bought the well?
(Confidently) The farmer did! He wanted water for his farm. I would have just dug my own well. That neighbor sounds *really* dumb! Did he think the farmer wouldn't need water? (Rolls eyes)

You are right! The farmer bought the well.

Why do you think the neighbor was dumb? What did he do that wasn't very smart?

(Leans forward, eager to explain) Because! He sold the *well*! (Points dramatically with a crayon) That means everything in it! It's like...like selling someone a cookie jar but saying they can't have the cookies! (Thinks hard, tapping crayon on desk) Or selling me my toy car but saying I can't drive it! It's so not fair! (Crosses arms, a little aggressively) He was trying to trick the farmer and get money for nothing. Grown-ups are sometimes silly. Was he trying to be mean?

Those are great examples! Yes, the neighbor was trying to trick the farmer.

Where did the farmer go when the neighbour didn't let him take water?

(Jumps in his seat) He went to the emperor! Duh! (Points to the sky) He went to the *highest* person! If someone stole my favorite red crayon I would tell the PRINCIPAL! Did the emperor have a cool crown? I bet he did! Did the neighbor get in big trouble? He deserved it! (Starts drawing a picture of an emperor with a very large, pointy crown.)

Yes, he went to the emperor! Good job! The emperor listened to both of them.

What did the emperor's helper (the courtier) ask the neighbor?

(Stops drawing to think, chewing on the end of his crayon) Hmmm... (Furrows brow, concentrating) I think... I think he asked him why he wasn't letting the farmer use the water. (Voice gets louder and more confident) And the neighbor said he only sold the well, not the water! What a silly rule! Did the courtier laugh at him? I would have laughed. (Giggles) That neighbor was probably sweating and nervous. I wouldn't be nervous, I'd just tell the truth!

You're right! The courtier asked him about the water.

What did the courtier tell the neighbor to do?

(Smirks, remembering) Oh! Oh! I know! He said he had to either move ALL the water out RIGHT AWAY or pay the farmer rent for the water! (Claps hands together, excited) That was a super smart trick! He was, like, turning the neighbor's own trick against him! (Starts drawing again, adding a tiny figure of the neighbor looking sad next to the majestic emperor.) Did the neighbor cry? He should have!

That's right! The courtier was very clever.

What happened in the end?

(Barely looks up from his drawing of the sad neighbor, focused on coloring in the details) The neighbor said sorry! (Adds tear drops to the drawing) He knew he was caught! And then he went home. (Shrugs, like it's obvious) Serves him right! (Looks up, eyes shining) Did the farmer get all the water he needed then? Was he happy? He deserved to be happy! He bought the WELL!

Yes, the neighbor apologized and went home. He realized his trick didn't work. The farmer probably got his water and was happy.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or lesson?

(Stops drawing completely, thinking hard. Pushes the crayon box away.) Hmmm... (Looks away, tapping his foot) It's about... about being fair? (Looks back, a little unsure) Like, you shouldn't trick people just to get more stuff? (Gets more confident) And you should always share, even if you don't want to? No, wait... it's about... if you try to be sneaky and trick someone, it will probably backfire on you! (Grins, pleased with himself) Because sneaky people are usually not that smart, like that neighbor! Is that right?

You're very close! It's about being honest and fair, and not trying to trick people. The story shows us that when you try to cheat someone, it usually doesn't work out for you in the end.

We can say that cheating will get you nowhere. Can you say that?

(Repeats loudly and clearly, puffing out his chest) Cheating will get you NOWHERE! (Pauses, then adds with a mischievous grin) Unless you're playing a game... then maybe! (Winks) But not with important stuff like wells and water! That's serious! Can we read another story now? One with dragons maybe?

That's a great point. In games, we know there are rules, but in real life, cheating can hurt people.

Yes, we can read another story later. For now, do you think you understood "The Farmer and the Well?"

(Nods vigorously, bouncing in his seat) Yes! I totally understood it! The neighbor was dumb, the farmer was smart to go to the emperor, and cheating is bad! (Raises hand) I even drew a picture about it! See? (Proudly shows off his drawing of the emperor, the sad neighbor, and the well.) I'm ready for the dragon story whenever you are! (Taps foot impatiently)
That's a wonderful picture, and you explained the story very well. You clearly understood the story and the moral. <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Now, let's talk about it a little.

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets a little, but sits up straight) It was okay. (Pauses) At first, the elephant was... um... (Thinking, taps fingers on the desk) He was lonely! Because nobody wanted to be his friend. They were all, like, "No! You're too big! You can't swing!" (Rolls eyes) Silly monkey! He should have just let the elephant try! He might be good at swinging! (Confidently) And the rabbit's burrow was just too small! That's not the elephant's fault! (Looks away, a little annoyed)

You're exactly right! He was lonely.

Why did the monkey say no? And the rabbit?

(Scoffs) I already said! (Crosses arms) The monkey said no 'cause the elephant couldn't swing in the trees. (Points finger) Which is, like, a dumb reason! Elephants are way bigger than monkeys, so of course, they can't swing!

(Huffs) And the rabbit... the rabbit said no 'cause the elephant was too big to fit in the burrow. It's obvious! Do you even read the story? (Raises an eyebrow) It said it RIGHT there!

I did read the story! I just wanted to hear you explain it. You're doing a great job remembering everything.

So, how did the elephant feel after everyone said no?

(Taps foot impatiently) Well, duh! If everyone said NO to ME, I would be... (Thinks for a second, tilting head) ...Sad! (Looks down for a second, then quickly back up, confidently) But the elephant didn't stay sad for long, did he? 'Cause he was brave and saved everyone from the tiger! (Puffs out chest a little) He's a good elephant! Even if the other animals were mean to him at first.
He *was* very brave! What happened with the tiger?

(Eyes widen, excited) The tiger was being a big bully! He was trying to eat everyone! (Makes a growling noise) RAWR! But the elephant... (Voice gets louder) The elephant told him to stop! But the tiger was all like, "Get out of my way, you big dumbo!" (Scoffs) So the elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect) ... KICKED him! (Pumps fist in the air) He kicked the tiger so hard, the tiger ran away! (Grinning proudly) The elephant saved the day!
He sure did! What happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?

(Smirks) They were all, like, "Oh! Elephant! You're the BEST! You saved us!" (Rolls eyes) They only liked him AFTER he kicked the tiger! (Thinks for a second) I guess they realized he was strong and could protect them. (Shrugs) But it's still not nice that they said no in the first place. (Frowns slightly, then brightens) But at least they were friends in the end!

That's right! They *did* become friends in the end.

So, why do you think the animals wanted to be friends with the elephant *after* he helped them? What did they learn?

(Strokes chin thoughtfully) Hmmm... (Taps fingers on desk) I think they learned that... (Pauses) ...being big isn't always bad! And maybe... (Looks up at the teacher, considering) ...they learned that you shouldn't judge someone just because they're different. (Confident again) Even if they can't swing in trees or fit in your tiny rabbit hole! (Giggles) They learned that the elephant was brave and strong, even if he's not good at hopping like a frog! (Nods decisively) They were wrong about him!
You got it! So, what do you think is the big lesson we can learn from this story? What does it teach us about friends?

(Stares intensely, thinking hard) Okay, okay... The big lesson... (Paces in the seat) Don't be mean to people just because they're different! (Points finger) And maybe... (Looks down, then back up) ...friends don't have to be exactly the same to help each other. (Confident again) Like, a little rabbit can't kick a tiger, but an elephant can! So even if someone can't do what *you* can do, they might be good at other stuff! (Smiles proudly) And you should be nice to everyone, even if they're bigger than you!

That's a wonderful way to put it! It sounds like you really understood the story. Friends can be different sizes, and good at different things.

So, if someone asked you what this story is about, what would you tell them?

(Stands up straight, ready to present) I would say it's about a lonely elephant who wants friends, but everyone is mean to him at first! (Voice gets louder and more excited) But then, he saves them all from a tiger, and they realize he's a good friend after all! It's about how you shouldn't judge people by what they look like or what they can't do! (Sits back down, satisfied) And that even if people are mean to you at first, you can still be brave and show them how awesome you are! (Grins)
That was a fantastic explanation! You really understood the story and what it was trying to teach us. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

Okay! That was a good story! Now, let's talk about it.

What did the girl in the story feel?

(Fidgets in seat, glances around the room, then back at the teacher, speaking quickly)

She was, like, SO frustrated! (Rolls eyes). I knew that already. It said it right at the beginning! Why did she even ask her dad? It's obvious life isn't fair! (Crosses arms).
You're right! She *was* frustrated! But why do you think she asked her dad for help *even though* she felt that way? Maybe she hoped he could make it better? What do you think?

(Scoffs, leans back in chair)

Make it better? (Raises eyebrows, looking disbelieving). How could *he* make it better? Life *is* just frustrating! Maybe she's not very smart... (Taps fingers on desk). Or maybe she just wanted him to, like, magically fix everything with a spell or something. But duh, that's not gonna happen. (Looks out the window, losing interest). I'd figure it out myself if I were her. I bet *I* could come up with something better than asking my dad.
Okay, okay! So you think she could have figured it out herself. Maybe! But her dad *did* try to help, right? What did he ask her to get?

(Sighs dramatically, clearly impatient)

Ugh, fine. (Thinks for a second, tapping foot). He asked her for... an egg... and a potato... and... (snaps fingers) ...tea leaves! I remember! See? I *was* listening. (Looks away, a little proud, but tries to hide it). But what's that GOT to do with anything? It sounds like he was making breakfast or something! (Looks back at the teacher, waiting for an explanation).

You're right! Egg, potato, and tea leaves. Good job remembering!

Now, what did he *do* with them? He didn't make breakfast, did he? He did something with water... what was it?

(Sits up a little straighter, thinking hard)

He... he boiled them! (Confidently) He boiled the egg and the potato and the tea leaves in water! In, like, different pots! (Raises hand, waving it a bit). I know this stuff! (Frowns slightly). But I still don't get what the big deal is. Boiling stuff is, like, super easy. My mom does it all the time.
You are absolutely right! He boiled them in separate pots. And what happened to the egg *after* it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Thinking, a slight furrow in the brow)

Well, the story said... (Pauses, searching for the right words) ... it got all... hard! (Looks up, eager to show understanding). Yeah! It was soft before, and then it was hard! (Beats a fist lightly on the desk for emphasis). But, like, so what? Eggs get hard when you boil them. Everyone knows that. (Arms crossed again, losing interest.) Is this supposed to be some kind of trick question?

Not a trick! You're doing great. Yes, the egg got hard.

Now, what about the potato? What happened to *it* when it was boiled?

(Lets out a groan)

Ugh, the potato! (Thinks for a moment, tapping a finger on the chin). It was...hard before. And then... (Snaps fingers) ...it got soft! Like squishy! (Makes a disgusted face). Yuck. So, big deal. Hard potato gets soft in hot water. I could have figured that out. This story is taking forever! (Looks at the clock).

You're remembering everything perfectly! So the egg was soft and became hard, and the potato was hard and became soft.

Now the tea. What happened to the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Rolls eyes, clearly annoyed)

Okay, okay, I get it! (Voice dripping with sarcasm). The tea leaves... they didn't get hard *or* soft! (Pauses for effect). They... (Thinks harder, trying to remember the exact wording) ... they changed the water! (Beams, pleased with own memory). They made it... tea! (Shrugs dismissively). Happy now? Can we be done? I wanna go draw.

Yes! You are exactly right! The tea changed the water. The egg changed, the potato changed, *and* the tea changed the water!

Now, the story said the boiling water was like... something. What was it like? Think hard.

(Leans back, thinking, then scoffs)

Ugh, I don't know! Some, like, grown-up word I don't even care about. Adversity? Is that it? (Wrinkles nose). Stupid word. Sounds like something yucky you have to eat! (Looks away, bored). I just wanna draw a picture of a dragon. (Mumbles) This story is dumb.

"Adversity" *is* a big word! It means something hard or difficult that happens to you. Like a problem or a challenge. So, the boiling water was like a hard time, or a challenge.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same "adversity" – the boiling water. But did they all react the same way?

(Stares blankly at the teacher, then sighs dramatically)

Noooo! (Said with heavy emphasis). The egg got hard. The potato got soft. And the tea... changed the water! (Rolls eyes). I already said that, like, a million times! Why do you keep asking the same questions? (Pouts, crossing arms tightly). This is boring! I already know everything.

Okay! You're right, you *do* know everything that happened in the story!

So, the dad showed his daughter that even though they all faced the same hot water, they all changed in different ways. The egg became hard, the potato became soft, and the tea changed the water.

So, what do *you* think the dad was trying to teach his daughter about how *she* should act when things get hard? Think about the egg, the potato, and the tea.

(Taps foot impatiently. Stares intensely at the teacher for a long time before answering. Then, blurts out.)

(Sighs) Okay, fine! (Grumbling) So, like, the dad wants her to be... I don't know... strong like the egg? (Thinks for a moment). Or... maybe he wants her to be... nice and squishy like the potato? (Looks at the teacher, a flicker of genuine curiosity in eyes, but quickly tries to hide it). Is that it? Am I done now? (Starts gathering belongings, eager to leave). This is SO long.

You're getting *really* close!

The tea changed the water. It didn't just become hard or soft. It made the *whole* situation different. So, what do you think the dad wanted the girl to learn about how *she* could deal with hard times, like the tea? What could *she* change? Could she change the *hard time* itself?

(Stares at the desk, doodling with a pencil. Suddenly looks up, an idea sparking in eyes).

So... (Thinking out loud, a little faster now). The tea didn't just get squished or hard... it made the water all... tea-y! (Giggles). So maybe... maybe he wants her to... to... not just let the hard times change her... but to CHANGE the hard times! (Looks at the teacher, almost excited). Like... make the bad stuff into something... good! Like... make lemonade when life gives you lemons? (Beams, proud of figuring it out, but then quickly scowls again, trying to play it cool). I knew it all along! (Packs up belongings with extra force, eager to move on). Can I go now? Dragon time!

YES! That's it! You got it!

He wanted her to see that even when things are hard, she can choose how to react. She can choose to become hard, or soft, OR she can change the situation itself, like the tea! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a good story.

Now, let's talk about it. Who were the main people in the story?

(Eyes light up, leaning forward eagerly)

Yes, you're exactly right! Good job! The older brother, the younger brother, and the magical tree.

Now, tell me, what did the older brother do in the forest?

"Enterprising"! That's a big word! You're very smart!

Okay, so he found the talking tree. What did the tree offer him if he didn't cut it down?

You're right, he was greedy. And what happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Giggles a little, a hint of mischievousness)

A "needle-y nightmare"! I like how you said that!

So, the older brother was hurt. Who helped him?

(Sighs, a little bored now)

The younger brother, *obviously*. (shifts in seat) He had to pull out all the needles. I bet that took forever! He was probably all like, "Ouch! Ouch! This hurts!" (mimics pulling a needle) But he did it anyway. He's not mean like the older brother.

That's right! The younger brother helped him, even though the older brother was mean to him.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother stay the same?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow)

Hmm... (taps chin) He said sorry! The older brother said he was sorry for being mean! He finally learned his lesson! (brightens up) And then… and then… the tree gave them *more* golden apples! Because they were being nice! So, being nice is better than being mean! (nods emphatically) I knew that already!

You got it! The older brother learned to be kind, and the tree gave them more golden apples!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks away, thinking deeply, using fingers to count something only I can see)

Okay, okay... (stutters a little) It's about... it's about being nice. (looks back confidently) If you're mean and greedy, you get needles! Ouch! But if you're nice, and say you're sorry, you get golden apples! (grins, pleased with myself) So, be nice! And don't chop down talking trees! Because that's just rude! (tilts head, a little puzzled) I wonder if the apples tasted like apple juice?

(Smiling) You're absolutely right! Being nice is very important.

The story teaches us that when we are kind, good things happen. Kindness is rewarded. Being mean and greedy, like the older brother at first, doesn't make us happy.

Do you think you understand the story and what it's trying to teach us?

(Jumps up and down a little, excited)

Yes! Yes! I understand! Be nice, not mean! Golden apples, not needles! (pauses, thinking) Can we read another story now? Maybe one with a dragon? Or a spaceship? Or maybe a story about... about... (eyes widen) ...a giant talking cookie! That would be so cool!

Yes, you understand! You did a wonderful job today! Kindness will always be rewarded.

We can definitely read another story later. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! It's called "The Golden Touch."

First, can you tell me who the main character in the story is?

(Looks away, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... King Midas! (Confidently) He's the MOST important! He got a wish! And it was a SUPER cool wish! (Runs hands excitedly) Everything he touched turned to... GOLD! Yeah! (Taps foot impatiently)
Yes, King Midas! That's right. And what did he wish for? What did he want to happen?

It was horrible! How do you think King Midas felt THEN? After his daughter turned to gold?

You're exactly right. He felt terrible. He realized his wish was a mistake. Now, why do you think the story tells us all this? What do you think we're supposed to learn from King Midas's mistake? What's the BIG idea of the story?

You got it! The story shows us that wanting too much, being greedy, can lead to bad things. King Midas wanted too much gold, and it made him very unhappy. He lost his food and almost more importantly he lost his daughter. So, the story teaches us that it's important to be happy with what we have.

You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay! That was a great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently) Why are you asking me such easy questions? I want to learn something *new*! Did you see how HIGH he jumped? I bet *I* could jump higher! (Stands up and attempts a jump, nearly knocking over my chair.)

(Chuckles) Wow, you are full of energy! Yes, the fox was hungry. You're right, that *is* easy.

Okay, new question. What did the fox see that he wanted?

(Sits back down with a huff, kicking the leg of the desk) Grapes! (Points emphatically) Big, purple, juicy grapes! He wanted *those*! Everyone wants grapes! Are we going to talk about something else now? This is boring! (Starts fidgeting with a pencil, tapping it loudly on the desk.) I know all this already! Why can't we talk about something hard?!

(Looks away, scowling. Fidgets more with the pencil, nearly snapping it.) No! (Snaps the pencil in half. Looks down at the broken pieces, then back up at the teacher, defiant) He couldn't reach them! (Tosses the broken pencil pieces onto the table and folds my arms again, slumping in the chair.) Are you going to ask me *that* question now?

(Takes the broken pencil pieces and sets them aside.) You're right, he didn't get the grapes. He wasn't tall enough, even when he jumped.

(Smiles reassuringly) That's a very good question. It's good to not give up! But sometimes, things are hard to get.

Why do you think the fox said the grapes were sour? Do you *really* think he thought they were sour?

(Stares intensely, narrowing eyes) He said that because... because he was mad! (Pushes self up in the chair and points a finger accusingly) He *lied*! He wanted them really, *really* bad! (Looks down at hands, picking at nails, voice lowers) He probably felt...stupid. And...and sad. (Looks up quickly, voice louder again) But that's still dumb! He should have kept trying! (Taps foot rapidly, then bites lip) Did *you* ever want something you couldn't get?

(Nods gently) Yes, sometimes I want things that are hard to get. It can be frustrating!

So, the fox was probably feeling sad and maybe a little embarrassed that he couldn't get the grapes. And he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad.

Now, this is the important question: What do you think we can learn from this story? Why do you think someone wrote it down for us to read? What is the story *trying* to teach us?

(Thinking, pokes at the table with a finger, making small circles.) Hmm... (Frowns) Okay, okay... (Looks up, suddenly excited, pointing a finger in the air) It's teaching us that... that... (Stuttering slightly) ...that giving up is BAD! And... and that foxes are liars! (Shakes head, confused) But... but I still don't get it. Why didn't he just try HARDER? Or ask someone for help? (Voice rising, getting agitated) It doesn't make any sense! (Crosses arms tightly again and slouches back in the chair, scowling.) And if the grapes WERE sour, then why did he even WANT them in the first place?! (Frustrated grunt.)

You're so close! Giving up *can* be bad, but sometimes, even when we try our hardest, we still can't get what we want.

Think about it this way: Sometimes, things are hard to get. And it's easy to say we didn't *really* want them anyway. The story is teaching us something about *that* feeling.

What if the story is trying to tell us that it's okay if you can't get what you want?

(Confused, tilts head.) Okay... (Taps chin, thinking) But... but that's still dumb! It's not okay to not get what you want! You just have to... (Furrowed brow, struggling) ...to work harder! Or be smarter! Or... (Voice gets quieter, more uncertain) ...or maybe... maybe sometimes, even if you *do* work harder, you *still* can't get it? (Looks down at hands, picking at nails again) And then... then what are you supposed to do? Are you supposed to just say you didn't want it anyway, even if you *really* did? (Looks up, eyes wide and anxious) Is *that* what I'm supposed to do?

(Nods slowly) The story isn't saying you *shouldn't* try hard. You *should*! But sometimes, even when you try your best, you still can't get something.

The fox couldn't get the grapes. So, instead of feeling bad, he said they were sour. He pretended he didn't want them anyway.

The story is trying to teach us that it's easy to *pretend* we don't want things we can't have. It's saying, don't be like the fox! It's okay to be sad or disappointed, but don't pretend you didn't want it. And don't say bad things about it just because you can't have it.

It also teaches us to remember that not everything comes easily. What do you think of that?

(Looks up, thinking hard. Fidgets with clothes) So... so it's like... it's like if I wanted a REALLY big cookie, but there were no big cookies left, and I said I didn't even *like* cookies, just so I wouldn't feel sad that I didn't get one? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) Is that what the fox did? Except with grapes?

(Pause. A slow dawning of understanding) So... it's better to just be sad that there are no big cookies... and maybe ask if there will be big cookies tomorrow? Instead of saying cookies are yucky and pretending I don't like them?

(Brightens a little) Okay... I think I get it now! That fox *was* being a baby! I wouldn't do that! I would ask for a bigger cookie tomorrow! (Confidence returns) Or... or bake my *own* giant cookie! Yeah!

(Beams) Exactly! You got it!

It's better to be honest about what you want and how you feel, even if you can't have it right away. And you're right, maybe tomorrow there will be a big cookie, or maybe you can bake your own!

So, what is the story teaching us? Try to say it in your own words. What's the big lesson?

(Stands up tall, puffing chest out, but still fidgeting with hands behind back.) It's teaching us... (Pauses for dramatic effect, then speaks loudly and clearly) ...that it's dumb to be like the fox! (Sits down, suddenly shy, but a small smile plays on lips.) And... and don't say the grapes are sour if they're not! Because that's just... that's just lying. (Looks up, a bit nervous) Did I get it right? Can we be done now? I'm hungry! Are there cookies?

(Grinning) You got it exactly right! You understand the story perfectly. It's okay to want things, it's important to try your best, and it's always better to be honest about how you feel. Great job today! <finish>

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot? What happened to the rose?

And yes, you are right! The rose started to die because it got very dry and she didn't have water. What about the cactus? What was the cactus doing?

So, the rose is dying, and the cactus is helping others. What did the rose *do* then? Did she keep being mean, or did she do something different?

(Wrinkles nose, thinking hard) (Taps chin) Hmmm... (Sighs loudly) She... (Eyes widen) She asked the cactus for water! (Gasps) She had to! Or she would... (Makes a dying sound) ...ffffft! So, let's think about the whole story. The rose was pretty but mean, and the cactus looked different but was kind. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it about being pretty? Or being kind?
