(Looks at the teacher suspiciously) Unless... unless you're saying something *important*, like I do. (Fidgets nervously) Am I being noisy? (Bites lip)

(Smiling reassuringly) You're doing great! You're not being too noisy at all. You're explaining the story really well. So, if you were going to tell someone the lesson of the story, what would you say? What's the most important thing to remember from "The Wise Old Owl?"

(Stands up straight, puffing out my chest) Okay! (Takes a deep breath) The most important thing is... (pauses for dramatic effect) ... is to use your EARS and your EYES more than your MOUTH! (Points to each in turn) Watch and listen, and THEN you can talk... (lowers voice conspiratorially) ... if you have something *really* smart to say. Otherwise, just... be like an owl! (Strikes a goofy owl pose, then sits down abruptly, looking anxious again) Was that... okay? Did I say it right?
That was perfect! You said it exactly right. Watch and listen more than you talk. That's what makes you wise. <finish>
Okay, let's talk about "The Golden Egg"! You just read the story. What was the goose doing every day?

(Bounces in my seat, almost falls off, then rights myself) A golden egg! The goose was laying a golden egg! Every! Single! Day! (Runs hands through hair, then stares intently at the teacher) I knew it was gonna be a golden egg story! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, barely containing my excitement). It's obvious!
That's right! A golden egg every day. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Stands up straight and tall) He... he... (frowns, taps foot impatiently). Ugh! This is boring! I know the answer! He sold it! Duh! (Crosses arms and looks away, then back at the teacher, raising an eyebrow). Like, what else would he do with a GOLDEN egg? Eat it? (Giggles loudly, then suddenly stops, looking serious).
He did sell it! You're right. And what did the farmer and his wife do with the money?

(Paces back and forth in front of my desk) Money, money, money! (Stops pacing and points at the teacher) They... they used it to buy stuff! Like... like candy! And... and toys! (Shrugs shoulders and rolls eyes) I don't know! Regular stuff! It's not like they bought a rocket ship or anything! (Turns away and mumbles) This story is so slow...
They bought things they needed. They lived comfortably. Were they happy at first?

(Scoffs and kicks at the rug) Happy? HA! (Stares intently at the teacher, leaning forward) Of course, they were happy! They had a GOLDEN EGG every day! I'd be happy! I'd buy, like, a hundred robots! (Sits down heavily in my chair) But... but then...(frowns) Then they got... (struggles to find the word) ...dumb.
Dumb is a good word for it. What made them "dumb"? What did they want that they didn't have?

(Eyes widen, and I tap my pencil rapidly on the desk) More! They wanted... MORE GOLDEN EGGS! (Slams fist on the desk, making the pencil jump) Like, ALL the golden eggs! At once! (Leans in conspiratorially) They were super greedy! It's so obvious! (Looks around nervously, then back at the teacher) It's like... like if I had one cookie, I'd want a whole JAR of cookies! (Grins mischievously). Is there candy in this story? I want candy.
You're right, they were greedy. So, what did the farmer do to get more eggs?

(Stands up again, agitated) Ugh! This is the gross part! (Pulls a face and shudders) He... he cut open the goose! (Makes cutting motions with hands, then quickly hides them behind back) He was soooooo stupid! (Looks away, then back at the teacher, voice getting louder) Why would he do that?! That was the dumbest idea EVER! (Sits down abruptly, nearly knocking over my chair).
He did cut open the goose. And what did he find inside?

(Wrinkles nose in disgust) Blech! (Waves hand in front of face) Blood and guts! Yucky! (Stares at the teacher with wide, disbelieving eyes) No golden eggs! Zero! Zip! Nada! He ruined everything! (Starts to bite fingernails, then stops abruptly) Serves him right! He was a greedy, goose-cutting... (searches for a word) ...doofus!
He found nothing. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that?

(Taps foot impatiently and sighs dramatically) They got poor! (Rolls eyes) No more golden eggs, no more money, no more fun! (Leans back in chair, arms crossed) They were probably super sad and hungry and had to eat, like, vegetables. (Shudders). That's what happens when you're greedy! (Looks pointedly at the teacher).
That's right. They became poor. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?

(Stands up, paces again, even faster this time) The lesson is... the lesson is... (Stops pacing abruptly and points finger at the teacher) DON'T BE GREEDY! (Sits back down, looking proud of myself) And don't cut open animals! That's also a good lesson! (Frowns slightly) Unless you're a doctor, maybe? But definitely not geese! (Looks around the room) Can we be done now? I'm bored! I want to draw a picture of a robot eating a golden egg. Can I? Please?
Those are good lessons! But there's another way to say it. It's about thinking before you do something. Did the farmer think before he cut open the goose?

(Tilts head to the side, considering this for a whole two seconds) Nope! (Shakes head vigorously) He just wanted more! He was all, "Gimme, gimme, gimme!" (Makes grabby hands) He didn't even think about the goose! Or the eggs! Or anything! (Sighs loudly). He was just... (searches for the right word, then snaps fingers) Impulsive! He was a super impulsive, greedy, goose-chopping... (trails off, then grins) ...dodo bird! (Giggles and claps hands together). Can I draw now? Pleeeease?
Yes, he was impulsive! So, the story teaches us to think before we act. Do you understand?

(Nods head enthusiastically, but looks longingly at my crayons) Yeah, yeah, think before you act. Don't be a greedy dodo bird. Got it! Can I PLEASE draw now? I'm gonna draw a super cool robot guarding a golden egg from a greedy... uh... (struggles to find a good word) ...dragon! Yeah, a greedy dragon! (Bounces in seat impatiently) Can I, can I, can I?
Okay, you understand the story and its lesson. You can draw now! <finish>

Okay! You've read the story of the farmer and the well. Good job!

First question: Who bought the well?

(Eyes dart around the room, foot tapping impatiently. I blurt out)

The *farmer* bought the well! (Points finger accusingly, even though there's no one to accuse). It was a trick! A stupid trick! He should have known! (Crosses arms, looking annoyed). He bought the well, duh! What kind of question is that? (Looks away, muttering) Easy-peasy. The farmer! I knew that!

You're right! The farmer bought the well.

Now, who did he buy it *from*? Do you remember?

(Rolls eyes, tapping foot faster)

The *neighbor*! (Voice dripping with disdain). Ugh! That sneaky, mean... (Catches self, then huffs). He sold the well, and then tried to be all tricky! (Puffs out cheeks) I knew it was the neighbor! I pay attention! (Looks around the room again, fidgeting with my hands) What's the next question? I already know all this stuff.

Okay, okay! You *are* paying attention! Good job!

So, the farmer bought the well from the neighbour. Then what happened? What was the problem?

(Scoffs, leaning forward, speaking loudly and quickly)

The problem was the MEAN neighbor wouldn't let the farmer USE the well! He said he only sold the hole, not the WATER! Can you believe that? (Eyes widen, hands fly up in exasperation) It's so OBVIOUS the farmer needed the water! He bought the well to water his FARM! (Stands up abruptly, then sits back down, bouncing my leg) I would have been SO mad! SOOO mad!

You're right, that IS pretty mean!

So, what did the farmer do because he was so mad? Where did he go?

(Paces in seat, muttering to myself) Mad... mad... Emperor... Emperor... (Suddenly, I stop pacing, stand up straight, and announce loudly)

He went to the EMPEROR! (Points dramatically at the ceiling). He went to get JUSTICE! The neighbor was being SO unfair! He deserved to get in trouble! (Sits down with a thump, looking pleased with myself). The emperor is SMART! He knows what's right!
Yes! He went to the Emperor. And what did the Emperor's helper, the courtier, ask the neighbour? What did the courtier want to know?

(Frowns, chewing on my lip. Starts tapping fingers on the desk. Stutters a little)

Umm... umm... (looks down at my hands) The courtier... he asked... he asked about the... water! (Voice getting louder and more confident) He asked if the neighbor SOLD the WATER! Because the neighbor was being tricky about it! (Nods head emphatically). The courtier was trying to TRICK the neighbor BACK! Because the neighbor was a big... (stops myself, remembering to be good-ish) a big MEANIE!

You're doing great! You remembered what the courtier asked about.

And what did the courtier tell the neighbor he had to do? What were the neighbor's choices?

(Stands up and starts pacing again, muttering under breath) Choices... rent... remove... choices... rent... remove...(Suddenly stops, face lights up, and shouts)

PAY RENT or REMOVE the WATER! (Pumps fist in the air) That's what he said! He had to pay rent to the farmer for the water or take it all away RIGHT NOW! (Sits down abruptly, bouncing my knee again) That was a SMART trick! Serves him right! He was trying to be all sneaky! (Glares at an imaginary neighbor)

Exactly! He had to pay rent or remove the water.

And what happened after that? What did the neighbour do?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in seat)

Ugh, fine. The neighbor said sorry. (Rolls eyes). He realized his stupid trick didn't work! He got caught! (Makes a "caught you" gesture with my hands). Then he went home. (Mumbles under breath) Probably grumbling the whole way. He deserved it! (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt). It wasn't fair to trick the farmer like that. The end. Can I go play now? This story is boring!

Okay, almost time to play.

So, the neighbour tried to trick the farmer, but it didn't work. He had to say sorry. Do you think it's a good idea to try to trick people? What happens if you try to trick someone?

(Crosses arms, scowls)

NO! It's NOT good to trick people! (Voice rising). Like the neighbor! He was being a BIG JERK! If you trick people, they get MAD! (Points finger again). And then you get in TROUBLE! The neighbor almost had to pay rent! He learned his lesson! (Scoffs). But probably not really. Some people NEVER learn! (Looks away, muttering) Stupid tricksters...

You're right! It's not good to trick people.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, the lesson, that the story wants us to learn?

(Taps chin, thinking for a whole two seconds, then blurts out)

Don't be a JERK like the neighbor! (Stands up, agitated). Be FAIR! Share the water! (Waves hands wildly). And... and if you ARE a jerk... you'll get CAUGHT! (Points accusingly at an imaginary jerk). The emperor will get you! (Sits down with a huff). Is that good enough? Can I PLEASE go play now? This story is making me ANXIOUS!

That *is* good! You're right! If you try to trick people and be unfair, you'll get caught and it won't work out for you in the end.

So, we can say that this story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere. It's better to be honest and fair.

You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, why was the elephant lonely at the beginning?

(Shrugs, fidgeting with my shoelaces) Uh... yeah, it was okay. (Looks away) He was... uh... lonely? Because... (Stuttering) Because... nobody wanted to be his friend! (Crosses arms, a little impatiently) They all said no! He couldn't swing or hop or... fit. It was in the story! (Taps foot) I remember.

That's right! You remembered! Nobody wanted to be his friend.

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant? What could the monkey do that the elephant couldn't?

(Scoffs) Duh! (Rolls eyes) The monkey could swing! The elephant's too big and... and... clumsy! He can't swing in trees. (Points a finger) It's obvious! The monkey said so. (Taps foot faster, getting a little annoyed) Are we done yet?

You're doing great! You're remembering all the details.

So, the monkey couldn't be friends with the elephant because the elephant couldn't swing. What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

(Sighs loudly) Ugh, are you serious? (Makes a face) The rabbit... the rabbit's hole! The elephant's too big to fit in the rabbit's burrow! (Throws hands up in the air) It's so easy! He'd crush it! I want to read another story now. This one's boring. (Starts to get up from the chair)

Just one more question about this part, okay? You are doing so well!

So the monkey said no because of the swinging, and the rabbit said no because of the burrow. What about the frog? What could the frog do that the elephant couldn't?

(Sits back down with a thump, muttering) Fine. One more. (Glares) The frog? Jump! The elephant can't jump! He's too... (searches for the right word, then shrugs) ... heavy! (Pulls a face) Frogs jump. Elephants... stomp. (Stands up suddenly) Okay, done! I'm going to draw now! (Starts walking away)

Okay, okay! Just wait one more minute!

So, all the animals said no to the elephant. Then, the next day, something happened in the forest. What happened? What were the animals doing?

(Stops walking, turns around, arms crossed, looking impatient) They were running! (Voice rising) A tiger was chasing them! (Eyes widen slightly, a hint of excitement) It was... scary! (Pauses) But the elephant saved them! (Taps foot, waiting for the next question.)
Yes! You're exactly right. The tiger was chasing them, and the elephant saved them. How did the elephant save them? What did he do to the tiger?

(Grins, a little proud) He... he kicked him! (Pumps a fist) Right in the... (hesitates) ... the butt! (Giggles, then quickly composes self) The tiger ran away! (Looks around the room quickly, then back at the teacher) Nobody messes with the elephant! He's big and strong! (Bounces on the balls of feet, eager to move on.) Now can I *please* draw?

He sure did! He kicked the tiger and scared it away.

Now, after the elephant scared the tiger away, what did the other animals think about the elephant? Did they still think he was too big and clumsy?

(Thinking, taps chin with a finger) Uh... (Shrugs) No? (Looks up at the ceiling, then back down) They... (Stuttering) ... they liked him then! (Confidently) Because he saved them! He wasn't too big anymore! He was... (searches for a word) ... perfect! They wanted to be his friends then. (Smirks, pleased with figuring it out). Finally! Can I *please* go now?

Yes! You got it! They thought he was perfect.

So, at the beginning of the story, the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant because he was too big. But at the end, they *did* want to be his friend. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? Can friends only be the same size and do the same things?

(Frowns, confused) Huh? (Scratches head) I don't know! (Voice rising in frustration) It's just a story! With an elephant and a tiger! And running! (Looks down at the floor, kicking at an imaginary stone) Friends... (Mumbles) ...I don't know about friends. (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide) Can I *really* go now? I'm getting a headache.
Think about it this way: The monkey was good at swinging, the rabbit was good at hiding, and the frog was good at jumping. The elephant was good at... what was the elephant good at?

(Sighs dramatically, clearly annoyed) Ugh! (Crosses arms and glares at the teacher) He was good at... (pauses, thinking hard, then a lightbulb goes off) ...kicking tigers! (Grins triumphantly) He was strong! (Looks away, muttering under breath) ...I could kick a tiger... maybe... (Snaps back to attention, bouncing on toes) So? What's that got to do with anything? Can I go *now*?

Exactly! He was strong! So, even though he couldn't swing or hop, he was good at something else. And that something else helped everyone.

Does that give you an idea about what the story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends be good at different things?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) So... (Stuttering) ...so, like... the monkey's good at swinging, and the rabbit's good at hiding, and the elephant's good at... (Looks up, a little less aggressively) ...saving everyone? (Pauses) ...So, friends don't all have to be the same? (Shrugs) I guess... (Mumbles) ...if you say so... (Looks longingly toward the art supplies) Can I PLEASE go now? I think I get it... sort of.
You *almost* have it! So if friends don't have to be the same, does it matter if they are different sizes or shapes?

(Forces self to think about it one more time) Okay, okay, fine! (Taps foot impatiently) If... if the elephant saved everyone even though he was big... then... (Eyes widen slightly, a hint of understanding dawning) ...then it doesn't matter if they're different! (Puffs out chest, finally understanding) The elephant was different, but he was still a good friend! (Lets out a big breath, relieved) I get it! (Grinning broadly) Now can I *PLEASE* go draw a picture of the elephant kicking the tiger? Pretty please?

Yes! You got it! Friends can be different shapes and sizes, and they can be good at different things! The important thing is that they care about each other.

Now you can *definitely* go draw that picture! You did a great job! <finish>

Okay! Hi there! That was a good story, wasn't it?

So, tell me, what did the girl in the story feel?

(Bounces leg, eyes wide) Hi! Yeah, the story was… okay. (Frowns slightly) She felt… frustrated! (Points finger) Because life is, like, hard! Duh! (Runs hands through hair nervously) It said so right in the first line! I listen *really* carefully! (Puffs out chest) Did you hear me say *frustrated*? That's a big word! I know lots of big words! (Starts to say something else but stops abruptly, looking away).

Wow! "Frustrated" *is* a big word! Good job!

Why do you think she was frustrated? What makes life hard, do you think?

(Taps foot impatiently) Hmph. (Crosses arms) Because… because things don’t go the way you want! (Voice rising) Like when… when Billy takes my red crayon! (Face gets red) And Mrs. Davis says we have to share! (Scoffs) That’s NOT fair! (Looks at the floor, kicking it slightly). Sharing is hard! And… and sometimes… (Stutters) …sometimes I don't get picked for the game! (Voice cracks slightly, then quickly reverts to being louder) And it’s ALWAYS someone ELSE'S fault! (Points vaguely towards the window)

Okay, I understand. So, it sounds like the girl in the story felt like things weren't fair too.

Now, what did her father do to help her? What things did he use?

(Snaps fingers) I know! He used... he used... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) He used... (Eyes dart back and forth) things! (Frustrated grunt) Wait! I know! (Beams proudly) He used an egg! (Holds up one finger) And... and a potato! (Holds up another finger) And... uh... (Tilts head, chewing on lip) ...green stuff? (Shrugs) Like... salad? No! (Slaps forehead) Tea leaves! (Jumps up and down a little) See? I remember! He put them in… in water! That was boiling! Like a volcano! (Makes explosion sound). He tricked them! (Grins mischievously).

(Chuckles) You got it! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves. And you remembered the boiling water!

Now, what happened to each of those things after they were in the hot water? Tell me about the egg first.

(Stands up, paces back and forth) The egg… the egg was… (Stops pacing, scrunches up nose) It was yucky at first! All… wiggly! (Shudders) But then… (Snaps fingers again) Then it got… (Voice gets louder) HARD! (Punches the air for emphasis). Like a rock! You could bounce it! (Makes bouncing motion with hand). Before, it was… squishy. (Makes squishing motion with hand) Now it's strong! I like strong! (Flexes bicep, then giggles). The hot water made it tough! (Smirks).

Excellent! The egg became hard.

And what about the potato? What happened to that after it was in the hot water?

(Sits down abruptly, crossing arms again) The potato… (Rolls eyes) That one's boring. It was hard, right? Like… like a rock too! But… (Uncrosses arms and leans forward conspiratorially) But the water tricked it! It got all… (Makes a limp hand gesture) …soggy! And… and… (Looks disgusted) …mushy! (Shakes head) Yuck! I don't like mushy potatoes. (Wrinkles nose). Hard stuff is better! The potato got WEAK! (Says the word "weak" with disdain).

You're right! The potato got soft and mushy. It was hard to begin with, but the hot water made it weak.

Now, what about those tea leaves? What did they do in the hot water? This one is a little trickier.

(Taps chin thoughtfully, then throws hands up in the air) Tea leaves? (Scoffs) They're just leaves! They... they didn't do anything! (Looks around as if expecting a different answer). You can't eat them! They're gross! (Makes gagging noise). I don't like tea! It tastes like dirt! (Frowns and sticks out tongue). (Pauses, thinking) Wait... (Snaps fingers) They made the water brown! (Grins triumphantly) They changed the water! (Points finger at the teacher) The water was plain, but then it was… tea water! (Jumps up again and starts to run in a circle). I got it! I got it!

That's right! The tea leaves changed the water itself!

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Now, think about the story. The hot water is like when things get hard in life, right? Like when Billy takes your crayon.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves are like us. We can be like the egg, the potato, or the tea.

What do you think the father was trying to teach his daughter about how *she* could be when things get hard?

(Stops running in circles and stands still, looking confused) Huh? (Scratches head) Like… when Billy takes my crayon? (Frowns) So… you want me to be like… food? (Looks suspicious) That's weird! (Pauses, thinking hard, biting lip) The egg got strong… so maybe I should be strong? (Flexes bicep again) But… (Voice gets quieter) …being strong is hard! (Looks down at shoes). The potato got mushy… I don’t wanna be mushy! (Shudders). And the tea… (Eyes widen) The tea changed the WATER! (Snaps fingers) Maybe… maybe I should change things! Like… like tell Billy to get his OWN crayon! (Voice gets louder and more confident). Yeah! (Pumps fist in the air) I should be like the tea! Change the water! (Beams proudly). Is that right? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, bouncing on the balls of feet).

That's a *great* way to think about it! The tea changed the water.

So, if the hot water is like hard times, and we can choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea... what do you think the big idea, or the *moral*, of the story is? What's the story trying to teach us?

(Paces again, muttering to self) Moral... moral... (Stops suddenly, eyes wide) Oh! Oh! I know! (Points finger dramatically) When bad stuff happens, you can be strong like an egg, or mushy like a potato… (Makes a disgusted face) …or you can change things! Like the tea! (Puffs out chest) You can… (Voice gets louder) …make the water BETTER! (Grins). So… so the moral is… be tea! (Jumps up and down). Change the world! (Strikes a superhero pose). That's what I should do when Billy takes my crayon! I should change things! I should… (Starts to say something else, then stops, looking suddenly anxious) But… but what if Billy gets mad? (Frowns, looking at the floor).

That's a fantastic understanding of the story! You're exactly right about the tea changing things, and about us having choices when things get tough. It is about what we choose to do. We can choose how to respond.

Being like the tea doesn't always mean changing the whole world all at once. Sometimes, it just means changing how *you* deal with a situation. Maybe talking to Billy is changing the water a little bit. Or maybe, it's telling Mrs. Davis. What do you think? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of The Needle Tree! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?

(Bounces foot impatiently, fidgeting with crayon) Yeah, yeah, it was okay. (Rolls eyes)

He... (Thinking, taps chin) He was... chopping wood! Duh! For the market! (Speaks quickly, practically yelling) He was gonna sell it and get money! (Looks away, uninterested)

That's right! He was chopping wood to sell.

And what did he find one day while he was chopping wood? What was special about it?

(Sighs dramatically, picks at a loose thread on clothes) Ugh, this is boring. (Looks up suddenly, points finger) A tree! A talking tree! (Voice raises in excitement) It was magical! It said, "Don't cut me down!" (Makes a face, like imitating the tree poorly) And it gave him... (Counts on fingers) ... golden apples! But not enough! (Crosses arms, glares) It should've given him, like, a MILLION golden apples! Then he wouldn't have been so... so...(Struggles to find the word) ...stingy!

You remembered all of that! Good job.

Why do you think the older brother felt like it wasn't enough apples? What kind of person was he?

(Stands up abruptly, starts pacing) Because he's GREEDY! (Stomps foot) He always wants more! More, more, MORE! He's a… (Searches for the right word, scowls) …a selfish meanie! (Sits down hard, arms crossed again) He didn't even say "Thank you!" He just wanted MORE apples! I would have said thank you… but I still would have wanted more. (Mutters under breath) But I would have said thank you first!
Okay, so you think he was greedy. What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway, even after the tree gave him golden apples?

(Eyes widen, leans forward eagerly) The needles! The tree got him! (Claps hands together) HA! Serves him right! It showered him with needles! Ouch! Ouch! Ouch! (Pretends to be poked by needles, flinching and swatting at the air) He was probably crying! (Snickers) Good! He deserved it! Maybe that'll teach him not to be so... (Forgets the word) so... TAKE-TAKE-TAKEY! (Points accusingly at an imaginary older brother)
He did get a shower of needles! What happened after he was covered in needles? Who helped him?

(Sighs loudly, slumps in chair) Ugh, now comes the boring part. (Reluctantly) His... (Grimaces) ...his little brother. (Rolls eyes) The nice one. He took out all the needles. Boooooring. He should have just left him there! (Folds arms, looks away) I bet the older brother still didn't say thank you! He probably just complained that it hurt!
Well, he *did* finally say sorry to his little brother. What happened *after* he apologized? Do you remember?

(Eyes narrow, suspicious) He did? He said sorry? (Scoffs) I bet he didn't mean it! He was probably just saying it 'cause he hurt real bad! (Taps foot impatiently) Okay, okay... (Sighs) The tree gave them MORE golden apples! (Voice is flat and uninterested) See? He still won in the end! It's not fair! The tree should have given the apples to the *nice* brother.
Why do you think the tree gave them more golden apples after the older brother said sorry? What changed?

(Frowns, thinking hard) Uhhh... (Picks at fingernails) ... 'Cause the tree is... is... (Struggles to articulate) ...stupid? (Looks up, defiant) I dunno! Maybe the tree felt sorry for him 'cause of the needles! (Shrugs) Or maybe the tree is just a big pushover! It should have learned its lesson and not given him anything! (Crosses arms, muttering) That's what *I* would have done!

Okay, those are some interesting ideas. But let's think about it a little more. The tree saw the older brother being mean *at first*. And then, it saw him say sorry.

What do you think the tree learned when it saw the older brother apologize? What did it see different *then* compared to *before*?

(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair) Ugh, fine. (Thinking, taps chin) Maybe... maybe the tree thought the older brother was... was gonna be nice now? (Voice is hesitant) Like... he learned his lesson? (Looks doubtful) But I still don't think he really meant it! He was probably just trying to get more apples! (Eyes narrow) He's tricking the tree! That's what's happening! He's a... a tricky trickster! And the tree is falling for it! (Shakes head in disapproval) The tree is so dumb!

So you think the tree *hoped* the older brother had learned to be nice? Even if you don't believe it, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about being nice and being mean? Which brother got rewarded in the end?

(Glares, but then looks down at shoes, scuffing them on the floor) It's trying to teach us... (Mumbles) ...that being nice is good? (Looks up, defiant) But it's not fair! 'Cause the mean brother still got apples! So, like, it's teaching us that being mean is okay if you say sorry at the end! (Shakes head) That's dumb! (Pauses) The *older* brother got rewarded, I guess. But the little brother did all the work! He should have gotten ALL the apples! (Pouts) The story is wrong!

Even though the older brother got more apples in the end, do you think he would have gotten *any* if he hadn't apologized and been helped by his younger brother? Who made it possible for the older brother to get the reward?

(Thinks for a long time, chewing on lip) Hmm... (Shrugs) No, I guess not. He would have been all stuck with needles and no apples. (Reluctantly) The little brother helped him... (Grimaces) ...so he could get the apples. But he STILL doesn't deserve them! (Looks away, muttering) It's still not fair... the little brother should have kept all the apples for himself. He's the nice one! And he did all the work!

So, even though it might not seem completely fair, the story shows us that being kind, like the younger brother, can lead to good things, even for people who weren't kind to you. And being greedy and mean, like the older brother, only led to pain until he changed his ways.

What do you think the story is trying to tell us about how we should treat each other? Remember what happened to each brother in the story.

(Sighs dramatically, slumps further down in chair) It's trying to say... (Grumbling) ...be nice or else you get needles? (Looks up, defiant) But I still think the older brother got away with it! He was mean, he got apples, he said sorry (maybe), and he got MORE apples! Where's the punishment? (Crosses arms, sulking) The story should have ended with the little brother taking all the apples and leaving the older brother with the needles! THAT would have taught him a lesson! And THAT would have been a good story! (Nods head firmly)

Okay, I understand you think the older brother should have been punished more. But think about this: the story shows that even someone who is mean can change. And when he *did* change, things got better.

So, what's the *main* thing the story wants us to learn about being kind and being mean? What gets rewarded in the end?

(Sighs heavily, rolls eyes) Ugh, fine, fine, FINE! (Grumbling) It wants us to learn that... (Struggles to say it) ...being kind is better than being mean? (Looks doubtful) Even if being mean sometimes gets you stuff too? (Frowns) And... (Reluctantly) ...that people can change, even if they're really, really mean? (Looks away, scuffing shoes again) But I still think the little brother should have gotten all the apples! (Muttering) It's his fault he's so nice... people always take advantage of nice people... (Looks up suddenly, defensive) But *I* wouldn't! I mean... maybe I would... but only a little bit!

You're getting it! The story shows that kindness can be rewarded. Even though the older brother was mean at first, when he showed kindness by apologizing, he was rewarded too. It's not always easy to be kind, especially when someone has been mean to you, but the story teaches us that it's a good thing to try for.

So, what's the big lesson of the story? What do we learn about kindness in the end?

(Sighs, picks at a loose thread) The big lesson is... (Reluctantly) ...that kindness is good, even if it's hard? And that... (Grimaces) ...even mean people can be good sometimes? (Looks up, challenging) But it doesn't mean they deserve all the apples! (Stands up abruptly) Can I go now? This story is boring, and I want to draw! I want to draw a picture of the little brother with ALL the golden apples, and the older brother with just needles! (Grabs crayons, ready to leave)
Okay! I think you understand the story and its lesson very well. You understand that kindness will always be rewarded in the end! Now, you can go draw your picture.<finish>
Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! What did you think of it? Did you like it?

(Bounces in my seat, then runs a little ahead of the teacher, before skipping back) Yeah! I liked it! King Midas got GOLD! (Claps hands) I would want that too! But... (frowns slightly) He couldn't eat! That's silly. He should have wished for... (thinking hard, tapping my chin) a GOLDEN... um... GOLDEN CAKE! Yeah!
(Chuckles) A golden cake! That sounds...interesting! Okay, so let's talk about the story a bit. Who gave King Midas the golden touch?
(Stares blankly for a second, then answers confidently) Dionysus! The... the wine guy! (Puffs out chest a little) I knew that!
You sure did! And why did Dionysus give Midas a wish?
(Shrugs, looks away) He helped a... a... (Sticks tongue out, struggling to remember) ... a satyr! Yeah! (Nods head vigorously) He was nice to the satyr. That's why! (Taps foot impatiently)
That's right! Midas was kind, so Dionysus wanted to reward him. Now, what was the wish Midas asked for?
(Eyes widen, practically shouting) EVERYTHING he TOUCHED turned to GOLD! (Grabs a nearby pencil and pretends to turn it golden) See! GOLD! GOLD! GOLD! (Throws the pencil down carelessly)
(Smiling) You remembered! Was Dionysus happy about that wish? Did he think it was a good idea?

(Wrinkles nose) Nope! (Shakes head firmly) He said... said... (Struggles for the words, then gives up) He didn't WANT him to do it! He knew it was... was... BAD! (Crosses arms, impatient) Why are you asking so many questions? I know the story!
(Laughs gently) I know you do! I just want to make sure you understand everything. So, Dionysus warned him. But Midas still wanted the golden touch. At first, was Midas happy with his wish?
(Nods head rapidly) YES! SUPER happy! (Mimics turning everything into gold with exaggerated movements) Chair! GOLD! Rock! GOLD! Tree! GOLD! (Giggles) Everything was GOLD! (Stops abruptly)
He was excited at first. But what happened after a while? What was the first problem Midas had with his golden touch?

(Frowns, kicks at the floor) He... he got hungry! (Makes a face) And when he tried to eat his... his... (Snaps fingers) FOOD... it turned into GOLD! Yuck! (Shudders dramatically) I don't want to eat GOLD!
Exactly! He couldn't eat. Then what happened? Who came to see him?
(Sighs dramatically) His... (grumbles) ... DAUGHTER! (Rolls eyes slightly, then perks up a bit) And she turned to GOLD too! Uh oh!
Uh oh, indeed! How did Midas feel about his golden touch THEN?

(Frowns deeply, looks down at hands) He felt... (mumbles) ... sad. (Looks up, defiant) He didn't WANT her to be gold! It was a... a... MISTAKE! He didn't like the gold anymore. (Crosses arms again, stubbornly) Is that the end?
That's a big part of the end. So, Midas wanted all that gold, but it made him very unhappy. What do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big lesson?

(Stares blankly for a long moment, then shrugs) Um... don't be greedy? (Looks at the teacher, waiting for confirmation) Or... or... don't ask for stupid wishes! (Taps foot, impatient) Can I go play now?
(Smiling) "Don't be greedy" is a great start! Why do you think it's important not to be greedy? What happened to Midas because he was so greedy for gold?

(Sighs loudly) Because... (Struggles, looking around the room for inspiration) ...because he couldn't eat his... his yummy dinner! And... (voice drops) ...his daughter turned into a statue. (Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) That's bad. (Looks up suddenly, a little brighter) So... it's better to have yummy dinner and a daughter who... who hugs you! Than just... gold! Can I PLEASE go play now? I UNDERSTAND.

(Nods encouragingly) You're exactly right! It's better to have the things that really matter, like family and food, than just a lot of gold. Wanting too much can make you lose the things you already have and that are important. So, the story teaches us that being too greedy can lead to sad things. You understood the story really well! <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, tell me, who was the main character in our story?
(Looks away, fidgeting) Uh, the... the fox! (Confidently) He was trying to get the grapes! They were, like, super high up. I would've gotten them, easy!

That's right! The fox was the main character. And you're very confident, I like that!

So, the fox wanted the grapes. What did he do to try and get them?
(Scoffs) He jumped! Duh! (Rolls eyes) He jumped, like, a million times! But he's not very good at jumping, I guess. I can jump way higher than a stupid fox. (Crosses arms) He should have asked *me*!
You're right, he did jump! And you think you can jump higher! That's awesome! But did his jumping work? Did he get the grapes?

(Taps foot impatiently) Noooo! (Louder) He didn't get the stupid grapes! That's why the story is about him being dumb! (Points finger) He should have built something to stand on, like a tower. Then he could have gotten them. Everyone knows that.
Okay, so he didn't get the grapes. He tried and tried, but he failed. What did he say about the grapes *after* he couldn't reach them?

(Sighs dramatically) (Looks up at the ceiling, bored) He said... uh... he said they were sour. Like, yucky! (Wrinkles nose) But that's just because he couldn't get them! He's just being a big baby about it. Sour grapes? Pfft! I bet they were the best grapes *ever*! Maybe they were even purple! I like purple.
Yes! He said they were sour. Why do you think he said that? Was he telling the truth, or was he just saying that to make himself feel better?

(Scowls) To make himself feel better, obviously! He's just a liar! (Raises voice) He wanted those grapes so badly, and then he says they're sour? That's just dumb! I wouldn't do that. I'd keep trying until I GOT them! Or... or I'd find someone else to get them for me! (Taps chin thoughtfully)

So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted. He tried really hard, but he just couldn't do it. And then he said he didn't even want it anyway.

Does that remind you of anything else? Have you ever wanted something really badly, but couldn't get it?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! Never! I *always* get what I want! (Pauses, thinking) Except... except that one time... (Mumbles) ...with the blue crayon... (Looks away, embarrassed) But that's different! (Gets defensive) I *could* have gotten it if I wanted to! But I didn't really need it! Blue is a boring color anyway! (Crosses arms again)

Okay, well, sometimes we can't get what we want. Even if we try really, really hard. So, what do you think we can learn from the story of the fox and the grapes? What's the big idea the story is trying to tell us?

(Sighs loudly) (Pokes at the table) I don't know! That it's stupid to want grapes? (Shrugs) That foxes are bad jumpers? (Looks up, challenging) That *I'm* a better jumper than a fox? I think the story is dumb. (Mumbles) I want to go play now. Can I go play? This is boring.

(Smiling gently) I know it can be tough to think about. The story wants us to understand that sometimes, we might not get what we want, even when we try our best. And it's easy to say we didn't want it anyway. But what do you think the story is trying to teach us about not getting what we want? Is it okay for the fox to call the grapes sour?

(Scoffs) No! It's not okay! He's being a baby! (Glares) If *I* couldn't get something, I would try harder! Or... or I'd make a plan! Like, build a tower! Or find a ladder! Or... (Taps chin) ...or train a squirrel to get it for me! (Smirks) That would be a good plan. Way better than just saying they're sour. So, no, it's not okay! He's a quitter!

You're right! It's not okay to just give up and say you didn't want it anyway. The story is trying to teach us that it's important to try our best. And even if we don't get what we want, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it in the first place or call it sour, or hate it. We should accept that sometimes things are hard. The grapes didn't come easy to the fox.

So, what do you think is the lesson we learn? What do you think the story wants us to know?

(Grumbling) That foxes are bad at getting grapes? (Pauses) Okay, okay! (Rolls eyes) That we should... uh... we should try really hard, and if we still can't get it, we shouldn't be a big, whiny baby about it and call it sour. We should just... (Shrugs) ...try something else. Or... or get someone else to help! (Smiles slyly) Yeah, that's what I would do. Train a squirrel. So, can I go play now? I learned the lesson! I promise! (Starts to get up)

You got it! It's about not giving up easily and not hating things just because you can't have them. It’s also about accepting that some things take hard work! Nothing comes easy. You understood the story! Great job!<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of The Proud Rose! That was a fun one.

Now, tell me, who are the main characters in the story?

(Stands up straighter, hand shooting in the air) Me! Me! I know!

The main characters are...are a rose (points to the floor like there's a rose) and a... a spiky cactus! (Puffs out chest confidently) I knew that! (Sits down abruptly, already bored with the question).

(Smiling encouragingly) That's right! You got it! Good job!

Now, what did the rose like to do to the cactus? Remember what the story said?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) The rose? She was, like, totally mean! (Crosses arms) She... she said the cactus was ugly and stuff! (Makes a face). Everyone else tried to be nice to the cactus but the rose was too busy looking at herself. It was dumb. (Taps foot impatiently). I would never do that.

You're right, the rose *was* being mean. And it's good that you wouldn't do that!

Why do you think the rose was being mean to the cactus? What did the rose think about herself?

(Thinking hard, taps chin) Uh... 'cause she thought she was, like, the prettiest? (Looks away, then back, confidently) She was all, "Look at me! I'm so beautiful!" (Mimics a haughty voice, then giggles) But she was just a flower! The cactus was way cooler. It gave water to birds! (Points finger accusingly) The rose didn't share anything! She was dumb. (Shrugs shoulders).

Okay, so the rose thought she was the prettiest and that made her think she was better than the cactus. Right?

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Eyes widen, leans forward slightly) I know this! I know!

(Points excitedly) She started to...to... wither! (Makes a drooping gesture with hand). Yeah! She was all dry and sad 'cause there was no water! (Smirks a little) Serves her right for being mean! (Shrugs again).
You got it! The rose started to wither. Why do you think the rose started to wither, but the cactus was okay?

(Sighs, fidgets) Ugh, this is easy! (Rolls eyes). Because... because the cactus had water inside! (Taps side of head) The story said the cactus was a water source! For the birds! (Looks around the room, distracted). So, duh, the rose didn't have any and she got all... wrinkly. (Makes a disgusted face). Can we be done now? (Starts looking at the door).

You're doing great! Just a little bit more.

So, the cactus had water and the rose didn't. What did the rose do then? Did she stay all wrinkly?

(Sighs dramatically) Fine. (Looks back, reluctantly). She... she asked the cactus for water! (Makes a face like she's eating something gross) Can you believe it? After being so mean! (Taps foot impatiently). She should have just stayed wrinkly.
Okay! So, she asked the cactus for water. And what did the cactus do? Did the cactus say no?

(Shrugs, picks at imaginary lint on pants) The cactus... the cactus gave her water. (Looks up, surprised) It was nice! (Frowns) Even though the rose was super mean. (Glares at an imaginary rose). It's kinda dumb that the cactus helped her. I wouldn't have! (Crosses arms again).

You're right, the cactus was very nice! Even after the rose was mean.

So, the rose *looked* beautiful, but she wasn't very nice, right? And the cactus *looked* prickly, but he was helpful and kind.

What do you think we can learn from this story?

(Sighs heavily, staring at the ceiling) Ugh, are we doing morals now? (Scoffs). It probably means... (pauses, thinking for a moment, then shrugs) ... don't be mean? (Looks away, then back, unsure). Or... or maybe even if someone's mean to you, you should still be nice? (Frowns, confused) I don't know! (Throws hands up in the air) This is boring! Can I go play now?

You're so close! Think about how the rose judged the cactus because of how he *looked*. But the cactus was good on the *inside*. What does that tell you? Should we judge people based on how they look?

(Eyes light up, stands up straighter) Oh! (Snaps fingers) I get it! (Points an accusing finger towards the door) It means... it means you shouldn't just look at the outside! The rose *looked* pretty, but she was mean! The cactus *looked* prickly, but he was nice! (Smiles proudly) So...so it's about what's on the *inside* that matters! (Sits down, satisfied) Finally! Can I go now? (Already halfway out of the chair).

Yes! Exactly! We shouldn't judge people just by how they look. It's what's inside that counts! The cactus was kind even though he looked different.

You understood the story really well! Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Let's talk about it.

First, who is the main person in the story?
(Stands up straight, pointing a finger in the air) Molly! (Confidently) Molly the milk... milk... (Sticks out tongue, trying to remember) Milk...maid! Yeah! She's the main person!

Excellent! You got it! Molly the milkmaid.

What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Starts pacing back and forth) She was gonna... (Stops abruptly, tapping my foot impatiently) Sell it! (Looks away, then back, like I'm stating the obvious) Duh! Sell it at the... (Thinks for a second, snapping my fingers) Market! She was going to sell the milk at the market! (Runs a few steps ahead, then comes back) Then she was gonna buy... (pauses) a chicken!
Yes, that's right! She was going to sell the milk at the market. And she *wanted* to buy a chicken. Why did she want to buy a chicken?

(Scoffs and crosses my arms) Because... because chickens lay eggs! (Rolls my eyes slightly) And eggs are... are... (Paces again, then stops, pointing) MORE MONEY! She could get more money for eggs! (Taps my foot faster) It's... it's easy!
Exactly! More money! So, she was thinking about the chicken and the eggs and the money. What happened while she was thinking about all of that?

(Sighs dramatically, like this is taking too long) Ugh! This is SO boring. (Looks at my shoes, then back up) She was skipping! And the milk... the milk... (Clenches my fists) it spilled! (Voice gets louder) ALL OF IT! The stupid milk! (Frowns)
Yes! The milk spilled. And why did it spill? What was she doing that made it spill?

(Looks away, clearly annoyed) I already said! She was skipping! (Taps my foot even faster) I don't wanna talk about the stupid milk spilling anymore! It's... (Thinks for a moment, trying to find a better word) ... dumb!

Okay, okay. No more talk about the "stupid milk" for now. Because she was skipping and thinking about the chicken, the milk spilled.

So, what happened to Molly's plan to buy a chicken?

(Arms crossed, looking stubborn) She couldn't buy it! (Looks away, then back, like daring you to argue) Because all the milk was gone! (Huffs) No milk, no money. No money, no chicken! It's... (Thinks for a split second) ...obvious!
You're right, it *is* obvious. She couldn't buy the chicken. So, what did Molly's mother say to her at the end of the story? Do you remember?

(Squeezes my eyes shut, trying to remember) Something about... (Opens eyes, looking impatient) Something about chickens! (Throws my hands up in the air) I don't remember the EXACT words! But it was about chickens! (Taps foot really fast now)

That's okay! You don't have to remember the exact words. It was something like "Don't count your chickens before they hatch."

What do you think that means?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes) Means don't... (Struggles to find the right words, looks away, then back) Don't... get... happy... about the chicken... before you... have the chicken? (Looks at you expectantly, waiting to see if I'm right)

You're getting close! It means don't get happy about something *before* it *actually* happens. Molly was happy about the chicken and the eggs before she even *had* the chicken.

Can you think of another time when it might be a bad idea to count your chickens before they hatch?

(Taps my chin, thinking for a very brief moment. Then suddenly gets an idea and becomes very excited, running a few steps ahead.) I know! I know! If I... (Comes back, speaking quickly) If I say I'm gonna win the race at recess... (Points at myself proudly) ...before the race even STARTS... and then I LOSE! (Frowns briefly, then shrugs) Then I look stupid! (Looks away, then back, confidently) So, don't count the winning before you win it! (Grins)

That's a perfect example! You understand. Don't be sure of something good happening until it really *does* happen.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What does the story try to teach us?

(Crosses my arms again, looking like this is a waste of time) Ugh. It means... (Sighs) It means don't be... (Thinks for a second, tapping my foot) ...Don't be all happy and excited about stuff... that hasn't... happened... yet! (Looks away, then back, impatiently) Is that right? I wanna go play now!
Yes! That's exactly right! Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. You understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay, [Student's Name], that was a lovely reading of "A Wise Old Owl"!

Now, tell me, what did the owl do every day?
(Confidently) He watched stuff! (Looks away) Uh...things happening around his tree. (Taps foot impatiently) People talked too, I think.
That's right! He watched things happening around his tree. And you said people talked. Did he talk a lot himself?
(Scoffs) No! (Rolls eyes) The story said he talked LESS. The more he saw, the less he talked. It's right there! (Points vaguely at the book)
Good job remembering! Why do you think he talked less the more he saw? What was he doing when he wasn't talking?

(Thinking, tapping chin) Hmmm... He was listening! (Confidently) Listening is important! You learn more when you listen than when you talk, duh! (Starts to fidget, eager to move on) Can we do something else now? I know all about it!
You're getting there! You're right, he was listening. And what did he learn by listening and watching? What happened to the owl because of all the listening and watching?

(Sighs dramatically) He got... (thinking, wrinkles nose) ...wiser! (Confidently) He became a WISE old owl! Because he saw everything and heard everything! (Stands up and stretches) That's why the story is called "A Wise Old Owl"! Can I go play now?

Yes! You're exactly right! He became wise because he watched and listened. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What can *we* learn from the wise old owl? Maybe not to be noisy all the time? What do you think?

(Crosses arms, looking away) I don't know! (Sticks out tongue slightly) It's just a story about an owl. (Shrugs) I guess... (mumbling) ...maybe you should listen sometimes? (Louder, dismissively) But I already KNOW everything, so I don't need to listen! (Starts walking towards the door) Can I go now? I finished!
You're so close! If you listen, you learn. And what happens when you learn a lot? Think about the owl. He listened and learned, and he became... what? What kind of owl was he?

(Stops at the door, sighs loudly) (Confidently) A wise owl! (Rolls eyes again) Ugh, fine. (Muttering) So, if *I* listen... I'll be wise too? (Turns back slightly, impatient) But I already said I know everything! This is boring. Can I PLEASE go?

(Smiling) Think of it this way: Maybe you know a lot, but there's always something new to learn! Just like the owl kept learning new things every day. So the story is telling us to listen and watch, and maybe talk a little less, so we can learn and become wiser. So, what's the story about?

(Taps foot impatiently) (Grumbling) Listening... and learning... (Brightens up, speaking quickly) So you can be smart! Like me! Okay, okay! The story is about listening and learning so you can be super smart and wise! Now can I *please* go? I'm REALLY good at listening already. (Starts to run toward the door) Bye!
You got it! The story is about listening and watching, and talking less so you can learn and become wiser. You did a great job understanding the story, [Student's Name]! Now you can go play! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

What kind of egg did the goose lay?

(Sits up straight, tapping foot impatiently)

A golden egg! Duh! (Rolls eyes) It said it right there in the title, "The Golden Egg!" Were you even listening? (Confidently) I know how to read, you know. A golden egg! One. Every. Day.
(Smiling calmly) Yes, you're right! A golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Scoffs) He sold it! (Crosses arms) What else would he do with it? Eat it? That's gross. He sold the golden egg and got money. It's obvious! (Taps foot faster, looking around the room) I knew that!
You're absolutely right! He sold it and got money. And how did that make the farmer and his wife feel?

(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on his shirt)

Uh... happy? (Shrugs) The story said they enjoyed a comfortable life. Comfortable means happy, right? (Glares back, daring the teacher to disagree) I'm pretty sure.
Yes, comfortable can mean happy! They were happy because they had enough. But then, something changed. What did the farmer start to think?

(Sighs loudly, drumming fingers on the desk)

He got greedy! (Raises hand suddenly) Can I go to the bathroom? I *knew* he was gonna get greedy! He wanted *more* eggs! Stupid farmer. He should have been happy with one. (Stands up halfway, waiting impatiently)

(Chuckles softly) We'll go to the bathroom after we finish talking about the story, okay?

You're right, the farmer got greedy. He wanted more. What did he *do* because he was greedy?

(Sits back down with a thump, muttering under his breath)

(Glares at the teacher) He... he cut open the goose! (Wrinkles nose in disgust) Blech! That's so... yucky! He wanted all the eggs at once, but there weren't any! Just... guts! (Turns head away slightly) That was a dumb idea! I would *never* do that!
Yes, it was a very bad idea. And what happened *after* he cut open the goose? What was his life like then?

(Looks down at his hands, picking at his fingernails)

He was... poor? (Scowls) The story said he became poorer. Because he didn't have any more golden eggs. (Taps foot again, louder now) So, no more money. He was dumb! (Looks up, defiant) He should have just been happy with what he had! I know that!

You're exactly right! He should have been happy with what he had. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the farmer and his goose? Think about what happened when he got greedy.

(Thinking hard, squints eyes)

(Grumbling) Hmmm... Don't be greedy? (Looks up, uncertain for a split second) Is that it? If you're greedy, you'll mess everything up? (Taps desk impatiently) Just be happy with what you have! (Confidently) Yeah! That's it! Don't cut open your goose! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Am I right? And can I *finally* go to the bathroom now?

You're very close! It's not *just* about being greedy, it's about thinking carefully before you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen *after* he cut open the goose. He acted quickly without thinking.

So, what's another way to say that? What's the lesson about thinking first?

(Crosses arms again, looking annoyed)

Ugh, more thinking? (Rolls eyes) Okay, okay... (Taps fingers on his arm rapidly, deep in thought)

Think... before... you... (Snaps fingers) Act! Think before you act! If you don't think, you might do something stupid like cut open a goose and then you'll be poor! (Grins triumphantly) Is *that* right? Can I PLEASE go now? (Starts bouncing leg impatiently)
Yes! "Think before you act." That's the lesson. The farmer didn't think, and he lost everything. You understood the story perfectly! <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story!

Now, tell me, who bought the well?

(Bounces in my seat, practically vibrating with energy)

The farmer did! (Points a finger emphatically) He bought it from his... his neighbor! (Looks away, thinking hard) Yeah, the neighbor sold him the well! But... but he was being tricky!

You're right! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

And you're also right, the neighbor *was* being tricky. What did the neighbor say about the water in the well?

(Stands up suddenly, pacing in front of my pretend desk)

He said... (scrunches up my nose in disgust) he said he SOLD the well, but he didn't sell the WATER! (Throws my hands up in the air) Can you believe that? That's so dumb! (Arms crossed). He thought he was SO smart! (Voice dripping with sarcasm). So, he didn't let the farmer to take water out of it.

Yes, that's exactly what happened! The neighbor thought he was very clever.

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water?

(Sits back down with a thump, leaning forward eagerly)

The farmer... (eyes widen) The farmer went to the... the Emperor! (Points upwards dramatically). He went to get JUSTICE! (Beats a fist on the table for emphasis, a confident tone in my voice). The farmer is SMART! I would have done the same.

You are right! The farmer *was* smart to go to the Emperor.

What happened when the farmer told the Emperor about the well? What did the Emperor's helper (courtier) say to the neighbor?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently)

The courtier... (taps chin thoughtfully, but speaks quickly) He said the neighbor had to either LET the farmer use the water... (Looks directly at you, a smug look on my face). See? He got him! That's what he gets for being so tricky! It was a super smart plan. (Proudly)

You explained that perfectly! The courtier *was* very clever!

What did the neighbor do when he heard the courtier's plan? Did he still think he was so smart?

(Scoffs and rolls my eyes, demonstrating my low agreeableness. My high Conscientiousness is still present in my explanation.)

Pfft! (Crosses my arms again) No way! He was all like... (puts on a whiny voice, exaggerating) "Oh, I'm sorry! I was wrong!" (Returns to normal voice, dripping with disdain) He totally apologized! Because he knew he was beat! (Sticks my tongue out) He wasn't so smart THEN, was he? (Confidence is beaming and very proud of my answer)

That's right! He realized his trick didn't work.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, or the moral of the story? Why do you think the neighbour apologised?

(Frowns, but tries to use logic to answer the question)

Ummm... (stares at the ceiling, thinking). It's about... (scratches my head) It's about not being tricky and trying to cheat people! (Points a finger again) Because you'll get caught! (Taps foot impatiently, wanting to be finished.)

The neighbour apologised because he didn't want to pay rent for the water! (Confidently) That's too much money! He realised that the farmer will still win. (Looking to the teacher for affirmation)

You got it! Trying to cheat someone doesn't work, does it? It only makes things worse! So the neighbour realised that he wouldn't win, and that he would have to pay the farmer to keep water in the well.

We can say that the moral of the story is: Cheating will get you nowhere.

Okay, great job reading the story of the elephant and his friends! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

(Thinking) Hmmm… (Taps chin) Because… (Suddenly sits up straight) Because he was strong! And big! And he could kick mean tigers! (Confident) He could protect them! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs dramatically) Ugh, is this like, a trick question? (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) It's, like, about being friends even if you're different. (Glares slightly) They thought being the same was important. (Taps fingers on the table impatiently) Like, you have to be able to swing or jump or fit in a hole. (Raises eyebrows) But that's dumb! (Jumps up and down excitedly) Different! Friends can be different! (Grins widely) Even if they can't swing or jump or fit in tiny holes! Yes! Friends can be any shape or size! The important thing is being a good friend. You understood the story really well! <finish>

Okay! That's a great story, isn't it?

Now, can you tell me in your own words what the girl did when she was feeling frustrated?

(Fidgets in my seat, tapping my foot) Yeah, it was... okay. (looks away, then blurts out quickly) She was sad, right? And she went to her dad because she was... (pauses, thinking hard) ...frustrated! Like when I can't finish my puzzle, and Timmy *always* finishes first! (crosses arms defensively) So, she went to her dad.

That's right! She went to her dad because she was frustrated, just like when you can't finish your puzzle. Good job remembering that word!

What did her dad ask her to get?

(Scoffs) Easy peasy! (confidently) He wanted an egg, a potato, and... and those green leafy things for tea! (points finger) Tea leaves! Like the kind my grandma uses! But hers smell yucky. (wrinkles nose)

Excellent! You remembered everything!

Now, what did her dad do with those things? He didn't make a snack, did he?

(Raises hand impatiently) No! He boiled them! In water. Three different pots. (rolls eyes) Like, duh! Everyone knows that. (taps fingers on desk impatiently) He was showing her something. Something about... (struggles to remember, thinking hard) ... adversity! (Sticks tongue out slightly in concentration)

You're doing great! He boiled them in water. And you even remembered the word "adversity"! That's a big word!

After he boiled them, what was different about the egg? What did it feel like?

(Pushes chair back slightly) It was... (pauses, thinking) ...hard! (emphasizes the word "hard" with a small fist pump) Before, it was all wobbly and soft, like when you try to hold it, and it feels weird. But then, after the water, it was all tough and... and hard! (scowls) Like Timmy when he won't share his crayons!

Good description! The egg was soft before and hard after.

What about the potato? What was it like *after* being boiled?

(Sighs dramatically) Ugh, the potato. (picks at a loose thread on shirt) It was the opposite! It was... (makes a mushing motion with hands) ...squishy! All soft and mushy. Yuck! (shudders slightly) I like my potatoes fried, not mushy! (glares at the thought of mushy potatoes)

Exactly! The potato was hard before and soft after.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Taps foot impatiently) They didn't get hard or soft! (rolls eyes) They changed the water! The water got all brown and smelly, and it tasted like... (makes a gagging noise) ...tea! (crosses arms) They made the *water* different. Not themselves. So, that's different!

That's a very important point! The tea leaves changed the water itself. They didn't just become hard or soft.

Now, this is the important part. The dad wasn't just making a weird soup, right? He was trying to teach his daughter something about being frustrated.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same problem: the boiling water. But they each reacted differently. Can you see what he was trying to show her?

(Squirms in seat, thinking hard) Umm... (looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) ...the egg... got strong? And the potato got... (makes a face) ...weak? And the tea... (snaps fingers) ...changed things! (frowns) But I don't get it. What does that mean? (leans forward, slightly confused) Is it like... like sometimes being strong is good, and sometimes it's bad? And sometimes... sometimes you gotta change things? (looks genuinely puzzled)

You're getting so close! You're right, the egg got strong, the potato got weak, and the tea changed things.

Think about *why* the girl was frustrated in the first place. She was having a hard time, right? Life felt difficult.

The boiling water is like those hard times. The egg, potato, and tea leaves show us different ways to react when things get tough. So, if the hard times came to your door what would you do?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping a pencil against the desk) So... (looks down at hands, then back up) If I was like the egg, I'd get tough? (frowns) But being tough isn't always good, like when Timmy is being tough and won't share! (pauses) And if I was the potato, I'd get all mushy and sad? (shudders) I don't wanna be a mushy potato!

(eyes widen slightly) Wait a minute! (sits up straighter) What if I was like the tea leaves? (taps pencil excitedly) Then I could change things! I could make the water... better! (grins slightly) Like... like if Timmy won't share, I could... I could ask Miss Lily to help us share! (beams proudly) Is that it?

Yes! That's it! You've got it!

The dad wanted his daughter to see that when things get tough, *we* get to choose how we react. We can become hard, like the egg. We can become soft, like the potato. Or, we can change the situation, like the tea leaves.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What did the dad want his daughter to learn about dealing with hard times?

(Pushes chair back again, confidently) He wanted her to be like the tea! (points finger emphatically) To change things! Not just get hard or mushy! (stands up, pacing slightly) If something's bothering you, you gotta do something about it! Don't just sit there and be a potato! (smirks triumphantly) I get it now! So, the story is about... changing things when stuff is hard! (sits back down, satisfied)

That's right! You figured it out! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be strong, weak, or change the situation. The choice is ours!

You did a wonderful job understanding the story! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, tell me, who are the main people in the story?

(Stands up straight and taps my foot impatiently)

There were two brothers! Duh! (rolls eyes) One was a BIG meanie, and the other was...well, not as mean. And there was a tree! A magic tree! It gave them...uh... shiny things! I know that! (crosses arms and looks away, already bored) I'm super good at reading!

Yes, you are a good reader! You remembered the brothers and the magic tree.

Tell me more about the brothers. Which one was the meanie? What did he do?

(Sighs dramatically)

He sounds like the kind of guy who pushes people! (nods head confidently)

Okay! So, the older brother was mean to the younger brother. He chopped wood to sell.

What happened when the older brother met the magic tree? What did the tree say?

(Shifts weight from one foot to the other, looking around the room)

The tree... uh... the tree... (taps chin, then snaps fingers) It said... "Don't cut me down!" (says this loudly and proudly) And it said... it gave him... something... shiny! (concentrates hard) Was it... was it stickers? No... no stickers. (eyes widen, remembering) GOLDEN APPLES! (says this very loudly, like he's won something) He got golden apples! But he wanted MORE! (scoffs) Greedy!

Yes! The tree said, "Don't cut me down!" and gave him golden apples. You're doing great!

Why did the older brother want more apples?

(Looks at the teacher with a puzzled expression)

Because... (thinking) ... he's the older brother! (shrugs) Older brothers ALWAYS want more! They think they're SOOO special! (rolls eyes again) He probably thought he deserved all the golden apples in the whole wide world! And he probably wanted to keep them all for himself and not share with his little brother! (nods head firmly, convinced of his answer) He was being totally unfair!
You think he wanted to keep them all for himself and not share. What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Eyes light up with excitement, momentarily forgetting his disinterest)

The tree got MAD! (punches the air) It didn't give him more apples! It gave him... (pauses for dramatic effect)... NEEDLES! (says this with exaggerated emphasis) Like, a bazillion needles! All over him! (mimics being poked all over with needles and makes a pained face) Ouch! Serves him right! (crosses arms again, a smug look on his face)

Yes! The tree gave him needles! That doesn't sound very nice.

What happened after the needles? Who helped him?

(Lets out a loud sigh)

Ugh... (reluctantly) the little brother. (mumbles) He helped him. He pulled out all the needles... (makes a face) that sounds boring and kinda gross. He probably cried about it too, 'cause he's the little brother! (taps foot impatiently, eager to move on to a different part of the story)

The little brother helped him by pulling out the needles.

What happened *after* the little brother helped him? Did the older brother say anything?

(Wrinkles his nose, trying to remember, but is clearly uninterested)

He said... he said... (Stares blankly) I don't remember. Did he say thank you? (Raises an eyebrow skeptically) Probably not. He's too mean to say thank you! Maybe he said, "Hurry up and pull out the needles, you slowpoke!" Yeah, that's probably what he said! (Nods emphatically)
He did say something important. Think hard. Maybe he said he was sorry?

(Eyes widen slightly, surprised by the suggestion)

Sorry? (scoffs) Him? Saying sorry? Nah! Mean people NEVER say sorry! (pauses, considering) Okay... maybe... MAYBE... he said sorry. (says it very quietly, almost like a question) But only because he was covered in needles and it hurt really bad! And he probably didn't mean it! He was just trying to get the little brother to pull out the needles faster! (nods firmly, convinced he's figured it out) He's still a big meanie!

He *did* say sorry. And the story says he meant it.

What happened *after* the older brother said he was sorry? What did the tree do?

(Gapes at the teacher in disbelief)

The tree... GAVE them... MORE golden apples?! (voice dripping with sarcasm) Are you KIDDING me?! That is SOOO unfair! He was a big meanie and he gets MORE?! (throws hands up in the air in exasperation) That's the dumbest thing EVER! The tree should have just turned him into a toad! (mutters under his breath) Stupid tree... stupid story...
The tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother said sorry. Why do you think the tree did that? What changed?

(Glares at the teacher, clearly not happy about having to think about this anymore)

Because... (grudgingly) ...because... the older brother said sorry. But I still don't think he MEANT it! (pauses, thinking harder) Maybe the tree is just really, really stupid! Or... or maybe it just wanted to see if he was REALLY sorry. Like a test! (nods slowly, starting to warm to this idea) Yeah! It was a test! And if he's mean again, the tree should turn him into a toad for REAL! (crosses arms, satisfied with this conclusion)

It was a test in a way. And the tree saw that the older brother was *really* sorry, and that the younger brother was kind and helpful.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Sighs deeply and slouches in his chair)

Ugh... (Stares at the ceiling) That if you're a big meanie, you get needles, and then if you say sorry (even if you don't mean it!), you get MORE golden apples?! (Voice rising in indignation) That's a TERRIBLE lesson!

(Pauses, and, after a long silence, looks at the teacher with a hint of thoughtfulness)

...Unless... (frowns, trying to figure it out)... unless it's saying that even mean people can... can change? And... and maybe being nice is better than being mean, even if you get more golden apples at the end? (Shrugs) But I still think turning him into a toad would have been a better lesson! Can I go now?

You're getting close! It's about how being kind is better than being mean. And what happens when you're kind.

Think about the younger brother. He was kind, even when the older brother was mean. What did the younger brother get in the end?

(His eyes dart around the room, avoiding eye contact.)

He got... he got... (Mumbles) He got stuck pulling out needles! That's what he got! And maybe... maybe he got some golden apples too. (Looks up, a flicker of something that might be guilt crossing his face.) But mostly, he got to be the one who wasn't covered in needles... So, maybe that's a good thing? (Shrugs again, then immediately pushes back, adopting his usual defiant stance.) But still! Toads! Shoulda been toads! (Crosses his arms and stares stubbornly ahead.)

He helped his brother, and then they *both* got golden apples. The tree gave them more because the older brother was sorry and the younger brother was kind. So, even though the younger brother had to pull out needles, his kindness was rewarded.

The story is trying to tell us that being kind is a good thing, and that it can lead to good things happening to you. Kindness will always be rewarded. Does that make sense?

(Squints skeptically at the teacher, clearly still not entirely convinced)

I guess... (mumbles) ...if you say so. But... (a hint of a mischievous glint in his eyes) ...what if you're REALLY good at being mean and you NEVER get caught? Do you STILL get golden apples then? (Leans forward expectantly, waiting for an answer) I'm just asking! For a friend! (Giggles slightly, then quickly composes himself.)

That's a good question! This story is about what *should* happen. It shows us that when we are kind, good things often come back to us. It doesn't always happen right away, but it's still important to be kind. Because being kind also makes *you* feel good inside!

Do you understand the story and what it's trying to teach us now?

(Sighs dramatically, but there's a slight softening in his expression)

Okay, okay... (reluctantly) ...I guess so. Be nice... get golden apples... maybe don't turn people into toads (even if they deserve it!)... (mutters under his breath) ...blah, blah, blah...

(Then, looking up with a slightly mischievous glint in his eyes)

So, does this mean I get a golden apple for listening to the story? (Grins, showing a missing tooth) Just kidding! (But his eyes are still hopeful.) Can I go play now?
You did a great job listening to the story and answering my questions! You really thought hard about it. Yes, you can go play now! <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read about King Midas. Can you tell me one thing that happened in the story?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking down) Uh… he… uh… turned things to gold? (Looks up quickly, then back down)

Yes! That's right. He turned things to gold.

How did he get that power? Do you remember?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) Dionysus… gave it to him. (Pause) For… for helping a… satyr? (Looks at the teacher questioningly)

Great job! Yes, Dionysus gave him the golden touch because Midas helped a satyr.

Was Midas happy when he first got the golden touch?
(Nods slowly) Yeah. (Pause) He… uh… touched everything! (Rolls my eyes a little) Stupi… silly.

He *was* very excited at first!

What happened *after* he touched everything? He got hungry, right? What happened when he tried to eat?
(Sighs, looking away) It turned to gold. (Pause) So he couldn't eat. (Frowns) I would never wish for that. (Mumbles under my breath, "Dumbest wish ever.")

So, he couldn't eat. Was he still happy then?

(Shakes head quickly) No! (Looks at the teacher with wide eyes) He was… uh… sad. And… and… (Stutters) m-mad! 'Cause he was hungry! And everything was gold! (Crosses my arms) He should have wished for candy.

Candy *would* have been a better wish!

What was the *worst* thing that happened because of the golden touch? What about his daughter?

(Looks down at my shoes, scuffing them on the floor) … His daughter… (Voice cracks, eyes start to water) She… turned into gold, too! (Sniffs, wipes nose with sleeve) That's… that's the dumbest thing ever! (Glares at the table)

(Looks up, furrowing brow) It was… (Thinking hard, chews on lip) … a curse! (Nods emphatically) A really, really bad curse! He didn't like it anymore. (Asks abruptly) Can we read a different story now? This one is… is… making me (Shivers, pulls my arms closer to my body)
