You said it was a curse. Why was it a curse? What did Midas learn?

(Sighs loudly, fidgeting again) Uh… he learned… (Thinking, taps fingers on the table) That… that gold isn't everything? (Looks at the teacher, then quickly away) And… (Mumbles) … that hugging is more important. (Almost inaudible) But he was too dumb to know that before.

You're getting it! Gold isn't everything.

So, why did Midas wish for the golden touch in the first place? What did he want?

(Rolls eyes) He wanted… (Pause) … to be rich! (Scowls) Stupid king. Didn't he know it's better to have friends and… and… (Trails off) … not turn your daughter into a statue? (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes) Can we *please* be done now? My tummy hurts. (Clutches stomach dramatically)

Okay, almost finished! You're doing so well.

He wanted to be rich. And what happened because he only cared about being rich? He lost things that were much more important.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Grumbling) The big idea is… (Sighs) …don't be greedy? (Looks up at the ceiling, thinking, then back at the teacher) And… and be careful what you wish for. (Pause) Because you might turn your daughter into a gold statue. (Looks away, shivers again) Can we *please* be done now?

Yes! You got it! Don't be greedy. Wanting too much can make you lose the things that are *really* important. That's the big idea.

You understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Looks away, fidgeting with my pencil)

Uh… food.
That's right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

Grapes… Big, purple… juicy… grapes. (Stuttering slightly) They looked really good.
They did look good! So, what did the fox try to do?

(Sighs heavily, almost like a groan)

He... jumped. (Short pause) Tried to get them.
He did! He jumped and tried to get them. Did he get the grapes?
…No. (Looks down at desk, nervously tapping pencil)
No, he didn't. He kept jumping. What happened then? Did he keep trying forever?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

Gave up. (Mumbles) Stupid grapes.
He did give up! And what did he say about the grapes after he gave up?

(Eyes narrow slightly, a flicker of defiance)

Said… they were sour. (Confidently) Probably rotten anyway. I bet they had bugs.
He said they were sour! Why do you think he said that, even though he really wanted them before?

(Thinking, chewing on the end of my pencil)

Because… (Starts to sound anxious) …he couldn’t… get them. (Voice cracks slightly) So… he said they were bad. (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression)
That's a good idea! Yes he said that because he couldn't get them. Do you think he *really* thought they were sour? Or was he just trying to feel better about not getting them?

(Taps pencil rapidly on the desk, voice trembling slightly)

… I don’t know! (Suddenly louder, almost a whine) Maybe they WERE sour! How do *I* know?! (Then quieter, almost a mumble) …It’s not fair…

It's okay! It's a tricky question. Think about it this way: He really wanted them at first, right? He jumped and jumped. So, if he *really* thought they were sour all along, would he have tried so hard?

(Eyes widen slightly, a glimmer of understanding, but still anxious)

…No… (Thinking) …He wouldn’t have tried so hard if he thought they were yucky. So… he was just… pretending? (Frowns, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) That’s… dumb.
Pretending to himself, maybe. Why do you think he would pretend that they were sour? What did he get by pretending?

(Thinks hard, pushing hair out of my face, a rare moment of focus)

…(Slowly) …Made him feel… less bad? (Looks up, a flicker of a question in my eyes) If he said they were sour… it’s not his fault he didn’t get them. It’s the grapes' fault for being… gross. (A tiny smirk, like I’ve figured something out)

Exactly! It made him feel better. So, the story is about a fox who wanted something, couldn't get it, and then said he didn't want it anyway.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the message of the story? It's called the moral.

(Starts to bite fingernails, looking increasingly uncomfortable with the question)

Uh… (Hesitates) …Don't want grapes? (Looks pleadingly at the teacher) Is that right? I don’t know. It’s… confusing. (Voice rising slightly)

It *is* a bit confusing! It's not really about grapes. It's about *wanting* something you can't have. The fox wanted the grapes, right? But he couldn't get them. So, he pretended he didn't want them.

Does that make you think about wanting something you can’t have?

(Folds arms, scowling)

…Like that toy car… the red one… at the store. (Muttering) Mom said no. It’s not fair. (Suddenly gets a determined look) I bet it’s broken anyway. Probably doesn’t even work. (Glares at the teacher)
Ah, I see! So that's like the fox and the grapes. Now, is it true that the red car is broken? Or are you just saying that to feel better?

(Eyes dart around the room, avoiding direct eye contact. Voice is quiet and almost a whisper)

…I don’t know. (Shrugs, then a sudden burst of frustration) Maybe! Maybe it IS broken! It probably is! (Starts to fidget again, picking at clothes) Why are you asking so many questions?

I'm asking because the story can help us understand how we feel when we can't get something we want. The story is trying to teach us that, is it okay to hate something just because you cannot have it?

(Thinks for a moment, head tilted to one side, still avoiding eye contact, but a glimmer of understanding in their eyes)

…No… (Quietly) …It’s not really the *thing’s* fault. It's… just… I couldn't get it. (Sighs, sounding a little less anxious) So… it’s not okay to say it’s bad just because I’m… sad.

You got it! It's not the *thing's* fault. So, the story teaches us two things. First, nothing comes easy. The fox had to work hard to try and get the grapes, right? The second thing is, we shouldn't hate something just because we can't have it.

So, what's the moral of the story, in your own words? What did you learn from the fox and the grapes?

(Looks down at desk, tracing patterns on the wood with a finger. Takes a deep breath, sounding slightly less anxious and a bit more thoughtful)

…(Slowly, carefully) …Sometimes… you can’t get what you want. And… (Hesitates) …it’s okay to be sad… but… (Looks up briefly, then back down) …but you shouldn’t… say it’s bad… just because… you couldn’t get it. (Quietly) …And you should try hard first.

That's a great way to put it! You really understood the story and its message. The fox gave up and then blamed the grapes. You understand that it's important to try hard and not just give up, and it's not fair to hate something just because you can't have it.

Do you have any other questions about the story? <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story, "The Proud Rose"!

You just read it, right? What was the rose like at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looks down at my desk) Uh… mean? (pauses) The rose… it said mean things. (Stares intensely at a spot on the desk, trying to remember exactly what it said, then looks up at the teacher, anxious) It said… uh… (thinking, bites lip) …it said the cactus was… ugly. (Voice cracks slightly)

That's right! The rose thought the cactus was ugly and said mean things about it.

How did the other plants feel about the rose being mean?

(Looks away, shuffling feet) They… didn't like it. (pauses, frowning) They tried to… (searching for the right word, struggling) …stop her? I think? (looks back at the teacher, nervously) But the rose… (hesitates, then blurts out) …didn't care! (crosses arms defensively)

You're doing great! Yes, the other plants didn't like it and tried to stop the rose, but she didn't care. She only cared about how pretty she was.

Then, what happened during the hot summer? What did the rose need?

(Anxious look returns, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Uh… it got… hot. (stuttering) R-really hot. (Eyes widen slightly) The rose… (voice barely a whisper) …it needed water. (Looks down again, drawing circles on the desk with my finger)
Yes, it got really, really hot, and the rose needed water. What was happening to the rose because it didn't have any water?

(Frown deepens, chews on the end of the pencil) It… (hesitates) …it was dying? (Looks up at the teacher, nervous, seeking confirmation) Withering? (Uses a slightly more complex word, but still unsure) Like… shrinking and… and not being pretty anymore. (Voice gets quieter)

"Withering" is a great word! Yes, the rose was withering, shrinking, and not being pretty anymore because she didn't have any water.

Now, what was the cactus doing during that hot summer? Remember, the birds were involved.

(Thinking hard, taps pencil against desk) The cactus… (eyes light up with a sudden idea, but still hesitant) …it had water? (Looks at the teacher questioningly, then continues more confidently) For the birds! (pauses) Little sparrows… they drank from it. (A small smile appears, then fades quickly)

That's right! The cactus was helping the birds by giving them water.

So, the rose is withering and needs water, and the cactus is helping the birds. What does the rose do next?
(Sighs, avoids eye contact) She… (struggles, clenching fists) …she asks the cactus for water. (Mumbles the last part, ashamed)
Yes, she asks the cactus for water. After being so mean, she had to ask for help. What does the cactus do?

(Looks up quickly, surprised, then back down) Uh… (long pause, thinking deeply) …the cactus… (hesitates, confused) …it helps her? (Frowns) Even though… even though she was mean? (Raises an eyebrow, thinking beyond the given information) Why? (Confused and anxious)
That's right! The cactus helps her, even though she was mean. Why do *you* think the cactus helped the rose? It's okay if you're not sure, just tell me what you think.

(Pushes the pencil away, lost in thought, voice barely audible) I… I don't know. (Shrugs, then a sudden idea flashes across face) Maybe… (searches for the right word) …maybe it's just… nice? (Wrinkles nose) But… that doesn't make sense. (Looks at the teacher, frustrated) Why be nice to someone who's mean? It's… illogical. (Uses another complex word, emphasizing the lack of logic)

It can be confusing when someone is nice even when others are mean, you're right!

Think about it this way: Did the cactus *have* water to give?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking) Uh… yeah. (pauses, considering) It had water for the birds, so… it had extra? (Tilts head, a flicker of understanding) So… it could share? (Still seems unsure, but less anxious)

Exactly! The cactus *could* share. The cactus wasn't worried about being pretty like the rose, it was worried about helping others.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big message?

(Sighs, looks down at hands, picking at a fingernail) Uh… (struggles, then blurts out) Don't be mean? (Forces eye contact, then quickly looks away, feeling nervous) Or… (searching for a deeper meaning, biting lip) …or… even if someone is mean to you… (hesitates) …you should still help them? (Voice is quiet, questioning) But… (frowns again) …that's still not… (searching for the right word) …efficient. (Uses a complex word, but still feels uneasy and illogical. Crosses arms tightly) It's like… a waste of water! (Voice rises slightly in frustration)

You're thinking very hard about this! You're right, it's not just about "don't be mean." There's something more.

Think about what the rose did *before* she needed water. What did she judge about the cactus?

(Glares at the desk, remembering) She said it was… ugly! (Voice is sharp, resentful) She… she only cared about how pretty she was. (Paces the idea) So… (a new thought dawns, but remains uncertain) …so maybe… (struggles to articulate) …maybe it's about… judging people? (Looks up at the teacher, nervous) Like… not judging people based on how they look? (Voice cracks) Because… because everyone needs help sometimes? (A hint of vulnerability shows through the usual defensiveness, then the look is quickly masked) But it's STILL not efficient! (Arms remain crossed defensively.)

You got it! That's a very important lesson. Never judge someone according to how they look. You never know when you might need their help, or when they might have something important to offer. The rose only cared about looks, but the cactus was able to help others even though it didn't look as pretty.

So, the message of the story is "Never judge someone according to how they look." Do you think you understand the story now? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Milkmaid and Her Pail."

First, tell me: What was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking at the floor) Uh... sell it? (pause) At the... the market?

Yes! That's right. She was going to sell it at the market.

Now, what did Molly start thinking about *while* she was going to the market? What was in her head?

(Looks up quickly, then down again. Stuttering) She... she thought about... (long pause, thinking) ...buying... things? Like... fancy things? (Looks at the teacher with a furrowed brow) With the... money?

Yes! She was thinking about buying things. Good job!

What was the FIRST thing she wanted to buy? Do you remember? It was something alive...
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard, tapping my foot) A... a chicken? (Looks up at the teacher, a little anxious) Is that... is that right? It's... for the eggs, right?
That's exactly right! A chicken. And why did she want the chicken?

(Looks away, shrugging slightly) To... get eggs. (Pause) And then... more money? (Frowns, thinking beyond the given information) Could she sell the chicken later too? Like, when it's old? (Looks back at the teacher, curious)

Those are great thoughts! Selling the chicken later *is* a possibility, but the story focuses on the eggs. So, she wants the chicken for the eggs, and then more money.

Now, what happened *because* she was thinking about the chicken and the money? What did she do?

(Voice gets quieter, looking down at my shoes) She... she skipped. (Pause. More quietly) And... the milk... spilled. All of it. (Looks up, a little anxious) Does that... does that mean she was... silly? Because she... she lost all the milk?

Yes, the milk spilled because she skipped.

Do you think it was a good idea to start planning all those things *before* she even sold the milk? Why or why not?

(Crosses my arms, a little defensively) No! (Pause, thinking) Because... (uses a complex word) ...hypothetically, if you don't have the money *yet*, you shouldn't, like, already spend it! (Looks at the teacher, a bit defiant) That's just... logical. (Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt) The chicken wasn't even *real* yet!

Wow, you used a big word like "hypothetically"! That's fantastic! You're right. The chicken wasn't even real yet.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson we can learn from Molly? What did her mother tell her?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling my eyes a little) Ugh, her *mom*. (Pause, thinking) Something about... not counting... chickens? (Looks at the teacher, a bit unsure) Before they... hatch? It's... a stupid saying. (Frowns) I mean, it makes sense, but... it's still a stupid saying. (Fidgets again, feeling anxious) Does that make sense? I'm... I'm not sure I'm explaining it right.

That makes perfect sense! It *is* a bit of a silly saying, but you understand what it means.

So, putting it in your own words, what does "Don't count your chickens before they hatch" *mean*? What's the big idea?

(Taps my fingers on the desk, deep in thought) It means... (Long pause, thinking beyond the obvious) ...don't make plans based on things that haven't happened yet. (Looks up, a little proud) Like... like hoping you'll get a good grade on a test *before* you even study! (Frowns again) Or... or promising to buy your friend a toy with money you *might* get for your birthday. (Bites my lip, suddenly anxious) Is that... is that a good example? (Looks at the teacher, nervous) Am I... am I doing okay?

Those are *excellent* examples! You're doing great!

You understand that it's about not making plans based on things that *might* happen, but haven't happened yet.

So, can you tell me the moral of the story? What did Molly learn?

(Sighs again, but this time a little less dramatically) She learned... not to be... stupid? (Looks at the teacher, a little defiant) I mean, she shouldn't have skipped! She should have been careful with the milk! (Pause, thinking a bit deeper) Maybe... maybe she learned to be more... patient? (Looks down, mumbling) And... and not to be so... greedy. (Looks up quickly, a little flustered) But... but it's still kind of a dumb story. (Crosses my arms again, a little defensive)

You're right, she should have been more careful. And being patient is a great way to put it. It's about waiting until you *actually* have something before you start planning what to do with it.

A simple way to say the moral is: Do not depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

Do you think you understand the story now? Do you think you could explain it to someone else?

(Nods slowly, looking a bit less anxious) I... I think so. (Pause) I could tell them about Molly and the milk. (Shrugs) And the chicken. And... and that you shouldn't count your chickens. (Looks up, a bit mischievous) Unless... unless you *know* they're going to hatch. (Grins slightly) But... then it wouldn't be a very good story, would it? (Looks away, tapping fingers)
That's right! It wouldn't be much of a story then! You understand the story and its meaning very well. You did a great job! <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the wise old owl.

What did the owl like to do every day?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with my hands) He... uh... (thinking hard) He watched stuff. (shrugs) Near the tree.

That's right! He watched stuff near the tree. Good job!

What kind of things did he see?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking) People... talking... (hesitates) Sharing... stories. (looks away, a little anxious)

Yes! He saw people talking and sharing stories.

Did the owl talk a lot?
...No. (looks at the teacher, then quickly down again)

That's right. He didn't talk a lot. The story says he spoke *less*.

So, he watched a lot, and he didn't talk a lot. What happened to the owl because of that?
(Frowns slightly, chewing on lip) He got... (struggles with the word) Wi... Wi... Wiser? (looks up at the teacher, questioningly) ...Is that right?

That's *exactly* right! He got wiser.

Why do you think watching and listening made him wiser?
(Scoffs, crossing arms) 'Cause... (pauses, thinking hard, then blurts out) ...'Cause he learned things! (rolls eyes slightly, like it's obvious). People are always saying stuff.

That's a great reason! He learned things. He heard lots of stories and saw lots of things happening.

Do you think if he talked all the time, he would have learned as much? Why or why not?
(Shakes head, looks skeptical) ...Uh, no. (stares intently at my shoes) 'Cause... if you talk, you can't hear. (thinks for a moment, then adds, a little smugly) ...Duh.

(Smiling) "Duh" indeed! If you're talking, you're not listening and learning.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it good to talk all the time, or is it good to listen and watch sometimes too?

(Fidgets, avoiding eye contact) It's... better to... (long pause, sigh) ...listen. (mutters under breath) ...sometimes... (looks up suddenly, eyes wide with a thought) Wait! Does that mean I should listen more in *your* class? (a hint of a challenge in my voice)

(Chuckles softly) Well, listening in class is *always* a good idea! But yes, the story wants us to remember that we can learn a lot by watching and listening.

So, a short way to say what the owl teaches us is: Talk less and watch more. Can you say that?
(Grumbling) ...Talk less... watch more. (Stares blankly ahead, then a flicker of a smile plays on my lips) ...That's kinda... smart. (Looks away again, suddenly embarrassed.) Can I draw now?

Yes, that is kinda smart! You did a great job understanding the story of the wise old owl. You figured out that watching and listening can help you learn and become wiser. You really understood the story. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story about the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. First, what kind of animal laid the golden egg?

(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers)

Uh... a goose. (Short answer, hesitant) A golden goose. (More confident this time, but still quiet)
That's right! A goose. And what was special about the eggs the goose laid?

(Furrows brow, thinking hard. Looks up at the ceiling)

They... they were gold. (Short, factual answer) Like... real gold. (Adds detail, but still unsure) Shiny. (More detail, fidgeting with the edge of my shirt)
Shiny and gold! Very good. What did the farmer do with the golden eggs?

(Sighs, looks away)

Selled them. (Short answer, avoids eye contact) For... money. (Hesitates, anxious)
Yes, he sold them! And because he sold them for money, what happened to the farmer and his wife? Were they poor, or something else?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

They... they got rich. (Short answer, but complex word usage) They had... lots of money. (Adds detail, cautiously) But... (Stops, looks worried)
But...? What happened after they got lots of money? What did the farmer want then?

(Voice trembling slightly, pulling at a loose thread on my sweater)

He... he wanted more. (Short answer, anxious tone) He was... greedy. (Complex word, but said nervously) He wanted... all the gold. (Looks down at my shoes, avoiding eye contact) It was... stupid. (Muttering to myself, showing disapproval) Why couldn't he just... (Trails off, frustrated)
You're right, he was greedy. He wanted more and more. What did he *do* because he was greedy? What did he do to the goose?

(Eyes widen, voice barely a whisper, face flushed)

He... he cut it open. (Very short answer, horrified) He... he killed it. (Looking down, shoulders slumped, close to tears) To get... all the gold. (Shakes head slowly, mumbling) That's... that's really dumb. (Expressing opinion, still upset)
Yes, he did. And what did he find when he cut the goose open? Was there lots of gold inside?

(Sniffles, wiping nose with sleeve. Dramatic shift in mood from frustrated to sad and anxious.)

No! (Sharp, sudden answer.) Just... blood. (Short, blunt answer.) And... and gross stuff. (Wrinkles nose in disgust.) No gold. (Miserable tone.) He was... so stupid. (Still focused on the farmer's foolishness.) He lost... everything. (Whispers, feeling defeated)

He lost everything, you're right. So, at the beginning of the story, the farmer had a goose that gave him golden eggs. He was doing pretty well. Then, he got greedy and cut open the goose. What happened to him after that? Did he get richer or poorer?

(Looks up, thinking, but still a bit teary-eyed)

Poorer. (Short, quiet answer.) 'Cause... no more eggs. (Adds reasoning.) No more... gold. (Voice cracks slightly.) He was... dumber than dirt. (Expressing strong opinion, reverting back to frustration, a coping mechanism for the sadness)

Poorer, that's right. So, the farmer acted quickly without thinking. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What is the story trying to tell us? Should we act quickly without thinking, or should we do something else?

(Furrows brow, thinking deeply. Uses complex reasoning.)

It means... (Pauses, searching for the right words.) ...if you're already... happy... (Hesitates, anxious about getting it wrong.) ...with what you have... (More confident now.) ...don't be... greedy. (Emphasizes the word.) Or you'll... lose it all. (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe.) It's... about being... content. (Uses a complex word, pleased with self.) ...and not being a dummy like the farmer! (Returns to being judgmental and blunt in frustration.)

That's a great way to put it! Being content with what you have is very important. It's also about thinking before you do something, isn't it? If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realised he was making a mistake. So, we can say the story teaches us to think before we act. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, still anxious but also relieved.)

Yeah. (Short answer.) Think... before you do stuff. (Restates the lesson in simpler terms.) So you don't... mess things up. (Adds detail, connects it to the story.) ...like the farmer. (Adds a final jab at the farmer, feeling a bit better now.)
Exactly! You understood the story and what it teaches us very well. The story teaches us to think before we act, so we don't mess things up. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! It was called "The Farmer and the Well."

First, tell me, who are the people in the story?
(Fidgets with my hands, avoids eye contact) Uh… the farmer… and… the neighbor… and… (looks up at the ceiling) the… emperor? And… (hesitates) the… the court… guy?

Yes! You got them all. The farmer, the neighbor, the emperor, and the courtier.

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well?
(Looks down at my shoes, nervous) Water… his… farm. (Swallows hard) He wanted to… get water… from the well. Is that… is that right? (Anxious expression)

That's exactly right! He wanted to water his farm.

So, he bought the well. But what happened after he bought it? Did the neighbor let him use it?

(Scoffs, rolls my eyes slightly) No! (Arms crossed defensively) The neighbor… he was… being mean. He said… (struggles to remember) he said he only sold the… the *well*, not the… the water inside. (Frustrated) It doesn't even make sense!
You're right, that *doesn't* make sense! Why do you think it doesn't make sense?

(Thinks hard, tapping my fingers on the table) Because… (pauses) if you sell a well… doesn't that mean… (wrinkles my nose) all of it? Like, the hole… and… and everything inside? (Looks up, a little confused) It's… stupid. He's being… (searches for the word) illogical.
"Illogical" is a big word! Good job! It *is* illogical. So, what did the farmer do because the neighbor was being illogical? Where did he go?
(Shifts in my seat, sighs) He… he went to the… (struggles) um… the emperor. (Mumbles) He wanted… justice. (Looks away, disinterested)
Yes, he went to the emperor for justice! And what did the emperor's courtier ask the neighbor?

(Frowns, thinking hard) He… (hesitates) He asked him… why… why he wouldn't let the farmer use the water? And… (snaps fingers) if the water wasn't part of the deal… then… then the neighbor had to… pay… rent! (Looks at the teacher, a hint of a smirk) Or take the water away… somehow.
You got it! So, what happened to the neighbor in the end? Was he happy?

(Shakes head dismissively) No! (Raises voice slightly) He was tricked! The courtier… outsmarted him. (A small, almost mean, smile plays on my lips) He had to… apologize. He was… probably… (searching for a word) humiliated.
"Humiliated" is a good word! He probably was. So, the neighbor tried to trick the farmer, but what happened to the neighbor instead?
(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He… got tricked back. (Mumbles) Serves him right. (Looks back up, a bit more defiant) He was being… dishonest. I don't like dishonest people.
You're right, he was being dishonest. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the main idea or the lesson we can learn from it?

(Thinks for a long moment, chewing on my lip) … (Pauses) … Uh… (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in my eyes) Don't be… a jerk? (Frowns slightly) If you try to… cheat people… it might… backfire? Is that… is that what it means? (Anxious)

That's very close! It's about being honest. If you try to cheat someone, like the neighbor did, it will come back to hurt you. Cheating doesn't work in the end.

So, what's the moral of the story? Something like, "Honesty is the best policy," but using what *we* talked about.

(Stares blankly for a second, then a flicker of annoyance crosses my face) … Uh… (Sighs dramatically) If you try to… pull a fast one… you’ll just… get pulled faster on? (Looks up, challenging the teacher) Is that… good enough? I don’t wanna do this anymore.
Haha! That's a very creative way to put it! It means the same thing. Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, what was the elephant doing at the beginning of the story?
(Fidgets with my hands, looking down) Uh... he... he was... (long pause) ...looking for... friends.
That's right! He was looking for friends. And where was he looking? Do you remember?
(Looks up quickly, then down again) In the... the... forest? (Voice shaky)

Yes! He was looking in the forest. So, the elephant was looking for friends in the forest.

Now, the story tells us about some animals that the elephant met. Can you remember *one* of the animals that the elephant asked to be his friend?
(Bites lip, thinking hard. Wrinkles forehead) The... monkey. (Whispers)

Good job! Yes, the monkey!

Why didn't the monkey want to be friends with the elephant? What did the monkey say?
(Looks away, shuffling feet) He... couldn't... (Stuttering) ...swing... in the trees. (Anxious expression)

That's exactly right! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

So, the monkey didn't want to be friends because the elephant was too big to swing. Do you remember any *other* animals who didn't want to be the elephant's friend?
(Thinking, tapping fingers on the desk nervously) ...Uh... the rabbit? (Voice barely audible)

Yes, the rabbit!

And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Looks down, mumbling) ...Too big... for the burrow... (Anxious)

You're doing great! Yes, the rabbit said the elephant was too big for the burrow.

So, the monkey and the rabbit didn't want to be friends because the elephant was too big. Did any other animal say no?
(Thinks hard, eyes darting around the room) ...The frog? (Raises hand to mouth, chewing on fingernail)

The frog! You remembered!

And what did the frog say? Why didn't *he* want to be friends with the elephant?
(Looks down, voice barely a whisper) ...Couldn't... jump? (Shoulders slump)

Perfect! The frog couldn't jump.

So, lots of animals said no to the elephant. How do you think the elephant felt?
(Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Sad? (Voice small and hesitant) ...Maybe... lonely? (Looks up quickly, then back down)

Yes, I think he probably felt very sad and lonely.

Now, the story changes a bit. What happened the next day in the forest?
Yes! The animals were running. Why were they running? Do you remember?
(Eyes widen slightly, a flicker of understanding) ...Tiger? ...Tiger attacking? (Whispers)
That's right! The tiger was attacking. And what did the elephant do?
(Straightens up a little, a hint of excitement in my voice) He... he kicked the tiger! (Quickly looks down again, as if embarrassed by the outburst)

He did! He kicked the tiger and scared it away!

What happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?
(Thinking hard, tapping fingers on the desk) ...They... liked him? (Looks up, confused) ...Because he... saved them? (Worried expression)

Yes! They liked him because he saved them.

Why do you think they liked him *then*, even though they didn't like him before? What changed?

(Frowns, thinking deeply. Pushes hair behind ear) ...He was... big? (Confused) ...But... good big? (Eyes widen slightly) Before they only cared he wasn't good at... swinging or jumping... but then... he was good at... (struggles to find the word) ...protecting! (Looks up at the teacher, searching for approval)

That's a *really* good way to put it! You're exactly right. Before, they only thought about what he *couldn't* do. Then, they saw what he *could* do.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size or shape?
(Fidgets, nervous again) ...Uh... no? (Looks down, then up quickly) Friends... can be... different? (Hesitates) ...It's not just about swinging? (Looks at the teacher expectantly)

You got it! It's *not* just about swinging!

The story shows us that friends don't have to be the same size or shape, or good at the same things. What's important is being a good friend and helping each other. So, friends can be any shape or size. That is the lesson from the story. Do you understand?
(Nods slowly, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Yeah... (Whispers) ...I think so. (Looks away, anxious) But, um... (hesitates) ...can we read another story now? (Voice is very quiet)

Yes, we can definitely read another story soon. But before we do, let's just think for one more minute about "Elephant and Friends."

Can you tell me, in your own words, what the story is about? Just a short version.

(Sighs softly, looking down at my hands) ...Elephant... wants friends... (Long pause) ...Animals say no... (Frowns) ...Tiger comes... (Brightens slightly) ...Elephant helps... (Voice trails off) ...Then they are friends. (Looks up quickly, then back down. Nervous) ...Is that okay?

That's perfect! You told me the whole story in a few sentences. You remembered the important parts.

And what did you learn from the story? What's the big idea it teaches us?
(Bites lip, thinking hard. Wrinkles forehead) ...Don't... just look at the outside? (Confused) ...See what people... can do? (Looks up anxiously) ...Is that right? (Fidgets with hands)

Yes! That's *absolutely* right! Don't just look at the outside. See what people can do. And remember, friends can be different sizes and shapes.

You understood the story really well! Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks".

First, can you tell me: What three things did the father ask his daughter to bring?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looking down at my desk) Uh… (clears throat) A…a potato… (pauses, thinking hard) and an egg. (Looks up quickly, then back down) And tea… leaves. Was that right? (Anxious tone)
Yes! That's exactly right! Good job remembering. Now, what did the father do with the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves?

(Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) He… he boiled them. (Stuttering slightly) In… in water. Why did he do that? (Frowns, confused. Raises hand slightly, then puts it back down.) I don't get it. It seems… illogical. (Complex word used confidently, but tone remains anxious.)

You're right, he boiled them in water. It might seem a little strange!

What happened to the *egg* after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

(Wrinkles nose, thinking hard) No… (pauses) It… it got hard. (Looks up at the teacher, a flicker of understanding in my eyes. Tone is still hesitant) But… eggs are already kind of hard… on the outside. So, I don’t… (trails off, confused again) (Sighs softly). This isn't making sense. What does boiling an egg have to do with… anything? (Voice gets louder and slightly more aggressive as frustration builds)
Okay, you're right, eggs *do* have a shell that's already hard. But think about what's *inside* the shell. What was the egg like *inside* before it was boiled? Was it hard or soft?

(Eyes widen slightly, thinking. Bites lip) Oh! (Voice slightly higher pitched with realization) It was… runny. And… and now it’s not runny! It’s… solid. (Confidently) So… the soft became hard! (Frowns again, picking at the thread again) Still… what does it *mean*? (Annoyed tone). This is taking too long. (Dramatic shift in mood; impatient)
You got it! The soft became hard. Now, what about the potato? What was the potato like before it was boiled, and what was it like after?

(Glares at the desk, thinking) The potato... (pauses, struggling) It was… hard. (Voice quiet, hesitant) And after… it was… mushy. (Looks up, a question forming) So, the hard became soft? Like… the opposite of the egg? (Looks away again, tapping foot nervously). Uh...Is that important? (Anxious)

Yes, you're exactly right! The hard potato became soft. So, we have the egg that got hard and the potato that got soft.

Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Rolls eyes slightly) They didn’t get hard or soft. (Scoffs) They're just… tea leaves. (Thinks for a moment, then a look of confusion crosses face) Wait… they… they changed the water. You're getting so close! You're right, the egg is like someone who gets stronger when things are hard. And the potato is like someone who gets weaker.

And you're also right that the tea changes everything. The tea doesn't just get hard or soft, it changes the water itself!

So, what do you think the father was trying to teach his daughter about problems? Is there only one way to deal with them?

(Sighs deeply, still twisting hands) So… there are… different ways to… to deal with problems? (Voice quiet, hesitant). Not everyone… gets stronger. And not everyone… gets weaker. (Frowns again, confused) But… how do you *do* that? How do you be like the tea leaves? (Asks a question to the teacher). What if I’m just… a potato? (Anxious and insecure)

That's a very good question! Sometimes it's hard to be like the tea leaves. But the important thing is that we have a choice. We can choose to be like the egg, the potato, *or* the tea leaves.

So, what's the big idea, the lesson, of the story? What do you think the father wanted his daughter to understand about dealing with hard times?

(Taps fingers on the desk, deep in thought. Chews on the end of the pencil) Uh… (hesitates) That… that problems… uh… change people? (Looks up, anxious for approval) But… (frowns) …you can… choose… how they change you? (Struggles to articulate, but there’s growing confidence in voice). You can… try to be strong… even if it's hard. And… maybe… (eyes widen again) …maybe you can… even… make things better for everyone? (Looks hopeful, a glimmer of optimism in eyes).

So, to put it all together: The story is about how we get to decide what we do when problems come our way. We decide how to respond to difficult situations.

So, he saw lots of things, and then he spoke less. Why do you think seeing things made him speak less? What do you think he was doing when he wasn't speaking?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot nervously. Bites my lip.)

...Uh... (long pause) ...Listen? Maybe? ...Don't know.

Listening is a great idea! He was listening and watching.

So, he watched and listened. Did the story say that the owl learned anything from watching and listening?

(Looks at my hands, picking at a fingernail.)

...Wise...? (Mumbles) Got... wiser?

Yes! He got wiser!

So, the owl watched, listened, and got wiser. Do you think watching and listening helped him get wiser *because* he spoke less? What do you think?

(Frowns, squints my eyes, looks confused.)

...(Long pause) ...Don't... get it. (Looks away, sighs dramatically). This is... hard.

It *is* a little tricky! Let's try this:

Imagine you are watching your friends play. You are not talking, just watching. What do you learn by just watching?

(Thinking, tapping my pencil on the desk. Still avoiding eye contact.)

...How to... play the game? (Shrugs) ...Maybe... who's good at it.

Yes! Exactly! You learn how to play, and who is good. You learn by watching!

So, the owl learned by watching and listening. Do you think he could have learned as much if he was talking all the time?

(Shakes head quickly, but keeps eyes down.)

...No. ...Talking... not... learning.

You got it! Talking *and* not listening and watching is not learning. So the owl was quiet, watched and listened, and learned.

What do you think is the big idea, or the lesson, of the story?

(Looks up briefly, then back down. Voice is very quiet.)

...Watching... (stutters) ...and... listening... makes... you... wise? (Pulls at my sleeve, looking anxious.) Is that... right?

That's very close! And yes, you're right, watching and listening helps you learn and become wise. It's like the story is telling us to pay attention and not talk all the time.

Can you think of a short way to say that? What's the lesson the owl taught us?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot faster. Bites my lip again.)

...Uh... (Long pause) ...Listen... more... talk... less? (Whispers it, almost like a question.)
Yes! That's a perfect way to say it! Listen more, talk less! Or, talk less and be more observant. You got it! The wise owl teaches us that we can learn a lot by watching and listening. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Goose and the Golden Egg."

First, can you tell me who the story is about?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Um... a farmer... and... a goose.
That's right! A farmer and a goose. And what was special about the goose?
Yes! The goose laid golden eggs. What did the farmer do with those eggs?
He did! He sold them. And what happened because he sold the golden eggs?
Yes, they had money! Did they have a lot of money or a little bit of money?

(Hesitates, picking at a loose thread on my shirt)

...Enough?
Enough, that's a good word! They had enough. Were they happy at first?

(Looks up quickly, then down again. Speaks very quietly)

...Yeah...
Okay. Now, what did the farmer want *later*? He wasn't happy with just one egg a day. What did he want?
More! He wanted more. So, what did he DO to get more? This is the part where he made a big mistake.

(Stares blankly, avoiding eye contact, voice barely a whisper)

...Cut...the goose?
Yes, he cut the goose! Why did he cut the goose? What did he *think* would happen?

(Scoffs, a bit louder now, but still looking down)

...Stupid... thought there were... more eggs... inside.
He thought there were more eggs inside! And what did he find inside the goose?

(Wrinkles nose in disgust)

...Blood... and... guts. Gross.
Yes, blood and guts. Was he able to get more golden eggs that way?

(Rolls eyes slightly, a quick, almost imperceptible movement)

...No. (pauses) Uh...duh.
Right! So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? Did they get richer or poorer?

(Taps foot impatiently)

...Poorer. (pauses) Can I go now?
Almost! Just one more question. The farmer wasn't happy with what he had and he acted quickly without thinking. Was that a good idea? What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Grumbling, looking out the window)

...Don't be greedy? (pauses) It's boring.

"Don't be greedy" is a good start! It's also about thinking before you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose. He just wanted more, more, more! So, maybe the story is trying to tell us to... think before we...?

(Sighs loudly, staring at the floor)

...Act? ...Whatever. Can I go now?

Think before we act! That's it! The farmer didn't think, and he lost everything. So, remember the story of the golden egg. It's important to think about what will happen *before* you do something, okay?

<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well. Now, let's talk about it a little bit.

First, who bought the well?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh...the...the farmer.
Yes! The farmer bought the well. And who did he buy it from?
(Hesitates, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Neighbor.
That's right! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor. Now, after the farmer bought the well, what problem did he have? Could he use the well?
No, he couldn't. Why couldn't he use the well, even though he bought it? What did the neighbor say?
(Stares at the floor, scowling a little) ...Said...said he only sold the well... not the water.
Exactly! He said he only sold the well, not the water. Was that a very nice thing for the neighbor to do?
No, it wasn't! So, what did the farmer do when the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water? Where did he go?
(Looks up quickly, then back down, voice trembling slightly) ...Emperor. Went to the...the emperor.
Yes, he went to the Emperor! Good job remembering that! Why did he go to the Emperor? What did he want?
Justice! That's a big word! What do you think "justice" means in this story? What did the farmer want the Emperor to do?
(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) ...Make...make the neighbor...fair? (Looks up, a flicker of hope in my eyes) Is that right?
That's a great way to put it! Yes, he wanted the Emperor to make the neighbor be fair. And what did the Emperor's helper, the courtier, tell the neighbor to do?
(Taps my foot nervously, picking at my fingernails) ...Pay rent...or...or take the water...away.
Yes! Pay rent for the water, or take it all away right now! Why do you think the courtier said that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbor?
(Glares at the table, voice rising slightly) ...Stupid neighbor! He tricked the farmer! (Pause, struggling to articulate) ...Courtier...showed him...his trick...didn't work.
You're getting it! The courtier showed him that his trick didn't work. So, what happened in the end? What did the neighbor do?
(Sighs, slouches in my chair) ...Apologized. Then...went home. (Mumbles) ...Should have known better.
He did apologize and go home! He realized he was wrong. Now, thinking about the whole story, what do you think it teaches us? What's the big idea of the story? Is it good to trick people?
(Shakes my head vigorously) No! ...Don't trick people! (Looks up, a little more confidently) ...It's...not fair. And...you'll get caught.
You're absolutely right! It's not fair, and you'll get caught. So, what's the lesson we can learn from The Farmer and the Well? What happens if you try to cheat someone?
(Looks down again, thinking, then speaks in a low voice) ...You'll...get in trouble. And...and it's wrong. (Suddenly, a bit louder, almost defiant) ...Shouldn't be greedy!

You've got it! Cheating and being greedy doesn't work out in the end. It might seem like a good idea at first, like the neighbor thought, but it always leads to trouble. So, we can say the story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story really well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends." Now, let's talk about it.

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands) He felt... uh... lonely.
That's right! He felt lonely. And what did he want to find?
Yes! He wanted to find friends. So, he went around asking the other animals. What happened when he asked the monkey?
The monkey said no! Why did the monkey say no? Do you remember?
(Thinking, brow furrowed) ...Too... big? (Looks up briefly, then back down) Can't... swing.
You got it! The monkey said the elephant was too big to swing. What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
Yes! The elephant was too big to fit in the rabbit's burrow. And the frog?
The elephant couldn't jump like the frog. So, how did the elephant feel after all the animals said no?
I bet he was sad. Now, something changed the next day. What happened in the forest the next day?
(Eyes widen slightly) ...Tiger! (Looks up quickly, then back down) Run!
That's right! The tiger was chasing everyone. What did the elephant do?
...Kicked. (Looks down, a tiny smirk appears for a second, then disappears)
He did! He kicked the tiger! Why did he do that?
Exactly! The tiger was being bad and scaring everyone. So the elephant helped. What happened *after* the elephant scared away the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?
...Friends. (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on shirt) Perfect... size.
They wanted to be his friend! Why did they think he was the "perfect size" then, but not before?
(Thinking hard, chewing on lip) ...Protect? (Looks up briefly, then back down, nervously tapping foot)
Yes! He could protect them! So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us?
(Fidgets, avoids eye contact completely) ...Uh... (Long pause) ...Don't... know.

Think about it. The monkey, rabbit, and frog all wanted friends who were like them. But the elephant was different. And in the end, being different was what made him a good friend. What does that tell you?
(Brow furrowed, looking down, thinking) ...Different... good? (Mumbles the words like a question, unsure)
Different *can* be good! The story shows us that friends don't have to be exactly the same. Can friends be different sizes?
Can friends be good at different things?
So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about what makes a good friend? Can they be any shape or size?
(Looks down, pauses for a long time, then speaks very softly) ...Help... each other? Even... if... different? (Looks up quickly, then down again)

Yes! That's a great way to put it! Friends can help each other, even if they are different. The story is telling us that friends can be any shape or size, and that what's *inside* is what really matters. <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

Now, can you tell me in your own words, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looking down at my desk)

Uh...frustrated. (Short answer, avoids eye contact)

...Life... hard. (Sticking to simple words, anxious tone)

Yes, you're right! She was frustrated. She thought life was hard.

And what did she do when she felt that way? Who did she talk to?

Good job! She asked her father for help.

And what did her father ask her to get? What things did he need?

(Thinking, tapping pencil on desk)

...Egg... (Pause)

...Potato... (Another pause)

...Tea... (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)

...Leaves. (Short, simple words)

Perfect! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves.

Then what did her father do with those things? He put them in... what?

Yes! He put them in boiling water. Three different pots.

What happened to the *egg* after it was in the hot water? Was it the same?

(Frowns, looks down at hands)

...Hard.

...Was soft... (Confused look, sticking to given info)

You're right! It became hard. The soft egg became hard.

What about the *potato*? What happened to the hard potato?

(Looks up at the ceiling, thinking hard)

...Uh... Soft? (Hesitates, unsure)

...Now... (trails off)

Yes! The hard potato became soft.

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Confused, looks at the teacher with a slight frown)

...Uh... (long pause)

...Changed...water? (Tilts head, sticking to simple words and what was directly stated)

That's right! The tea leaves changed the water. They didn't become hard or soft, they changed the water itself.

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water.

Do you think the hot water was like a hard time, a problem?

(Fidgets again, pulls at sleeve)

...Maybe... (Mumbles, unsure)

...Don't know. (Avoids eye contact, anxious)

It's okay! Think about it. Sometimes things in life get hard, right? Just like the hot water.

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea, they all faced the same hard thing - the hot water. But did they all react the same way?

Yes! Different!

The egg, the potato, and the tea all reacted differently to the same problem.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about hard times?

(Long pause, looks around the room, anxious)

...Uh... (Stuttering)

...Hard... times... (Confused look)

...Don't know... (Mumbles, nearly inaudible)

It's a tricky question!

Think about the girl at the beginning. She thought life was hard. The story shows us that when things get hard, *we* can change, just like the egg, the potato, or even the water.

Do you think *we* get to choose how we react when things are hard?

(Shrugs, looking down at the desk, picks at a loose thread.)

...Maybe... (Unsure, mumbled)

...Too hard... (Voice barely audible, feeling overwhelmed)

It *can* be hard. But the story shows us we have a choice!

The potato was hard, but it became soft. It changed. The egg was soft, but it became hard. It also changed. And the tea? It changed the *water* itself!

So, when something bad happens, do *we* have to stay the same, or can *we* change?

(Long pause, thinking hard, brow furrowed)

...Can...change? (Questioning tone, still unsure)

...Like...tea? (Trying to connect to the story, using simple words)

Exactly! Like the tea! The tea changed the water. It made the water... different.

So, the story is telling us that when bad things happen, we can decide how we will be. We can decide how to react.

Does that make a little more sense?

(Nods slowly, still looking down, but a bit less tense)

...Uh... (Pause)

...Little bit. (Small voice, but more confident than before)

Great! So the story wants us to know that *we* get to choose. Even when things are hard. *We* decide how to react.

So, what is the moral of the story?

(Starts tapping pencil again, a little more rhythmically this time. Still avoids eye contact, but seems slightly less anxious.)

...Choose...how... (Pause, thinking hard)

...React... (Barely audible)

...(Mumbles) Hard times...

You're getting very close! You choose how to react in hard times.

So, the story is telling us that *we* decide how *we* respond to difficult situations. Can you say that back to me?

(Takes a deep breath, still looking down, but a little more clearly)

...We... decide... how... we... respond... (Hesitates)

...Hard... situations. (Quietly, but enunciates each word)

Perfect! That's exactly it! We decide how to respond to difficult situations.

You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Can you tell me, what did the older brother do for work?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... (pauses, thinking hard) He... uh... chopped... wood.
That's right! He chopped wood. And what did he do with the wood?
Good job! He sold it. Where did he sell the wood?
Yes! He sold it at the market. Now, tell me, what did the tree offer the older brother if he didn't cut it down?

(Looks up quickly, then back down)

...Apples... Golden...
Golden apples! That's right. Did the older brother like the golden apples?

(Hesitates, picking at a loose thread on my sleeve)

...Not enough...
Not enough! He was greedy. What happened when he tried to cut the tree anyway?

(Eyes widen a little, voice barely a whisper)

Needles... (shivers)
Needles! Lots of needles. Who helped him?

(Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor)

...Brother... Younger...
Yes, his younger brother! Was the younger brother mean like the older brother?
No, he wasn't. What did the younger brother do?

(Thinking hard, bites lip)

...Pulled out... needles... (almost inaudible)
He pulled out the needles! He was very kind. What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? What did the older brother say?

(Looks up briefly, then down again, anxious)

...Sorry... (mumbles)
He said sorry! Why do you think he said sorry?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact, voice barely audible)

...Bad... to brother...
Yes! He was bad to his brother. He wasn't kind. And what happened after he said sorry? What did the tree do?
More golden apples! Why do you think the tree gave them more apples *after* the older brother said sorry?

(Confused, looks at teacher briefly, then back down)

...Uh... I don't know...(shrugs)
Think about it: The older brother was mean, and the tree gave him *some* apples. Then he was kind, and the tree gave him *more* apples. What does that tell you about being kind?

(Stares at the floor, thinking very hard)

...Kind... good...? (voice trails off)

Can... can you say it again?
Sure! The older brother was mean, and the tree gave him *some* apples. Then he was kind, and the tree gave him *more* apples. What does that tell you about being kind? What happens when you are kind?

(Stares intensely at the floor, concentrating)

...If you're... nice... (pauses, searching for the right words)... good things... happen...?

Is that right? (Looks up, anxious for confirmation)

That's right! If you are kind, good things happen. Being kind is rewarded. And being greedy or mean... well, the needles show what happens then, don't they? So, what's the big idea, the lesson, of the whole story? What does the story try to teach us?

(Fidgets with hands, avoids eye contact, voice hesitant)

...Be... nice...? (Quietly) ...Or get needles...?

(Smiling gently)

Be nice! And you'll get good things, like more golden apples. The story teaches us that kindness will always be rewarded. You were very clever figuring that out! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was King Midas and his golden touch.

First, can you tell me: Who gave King Midas the golden touch?
Uh... (looks down, fidgets with fingers) Dionysus.

That's right! Dionysus gave him the golden touch.

Now, why did Dionysus give Midas a wish?
(Shrugs) He... uh... did a good deed. (avoiding eye contact)
You're almost there! Who did Midas help? It was a creature...

Yes! Midas helped a Satyr. Good job! So, because he helped the Satyr, Dionysus gave him a wish.

What did Midas wish for?

Everything he touched turned to gold! That's right.

At first, was Midas happy with his wish?
He was happy at first! Why was he happy at first? What did he do?
(Sticks to given information, using simple words) He... touched... things. Gold.
Yes! He touched things and they turned to gold. Was that good for him in the end?
No, it wasn't. Why wasn't it good for him? What happened?

Yes! He couldn't eat the food, and his daughter turned to gold. Oh no!

How do you think Midas felt then?
Sad is a good word. Maybe... more than sad? Think about it. He couldn't eat. He turned his daughter into gold. How do you think he felt?

Bad is good too. He felt bad. Really, really bad.

So, Midas wished for everything to turn to gold. He was happy at first, then he was very unhappy. Why did he become so unhappy? What was the problem with his wish?
(Looks down, thinking logically) He couldn't... eat. And... (pauses) ... hug his daughter. 'Cause... gold.
Exactly! He couldn't eat, and he couldn't hug his daughter. Gold is nice, but is it more important than food or hugs?
No. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What did Midas want too much of?
(Sticks to given information) Gold. Too much... gold.
Yes, he wanted too much gold. And what happened when he wanted too much?

He lost important things! He lost his food, and he almost lost his daughter forever!

So, if you want too much of something, even something that seems good, what might happen?
...(Stares blankly, avoids asking questions) ... Bad things.
Bad things might happen. You might lose things that are more important. So maybe wanting too much... is not so good? What word can we use for wanting too much? It starts with a "g"...
Yes! Greed! Wanting too much is called greed. And what happened to Midas because of his greed?
He became sad, and lost important things. So, what can we learn from the story of King Midas?
...(Long pause, looks at the teacher briefly then down again)... Don't be... greedy?
That's right! Don't be greedy! Because greed can lead to bad things. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the fox and the grapes! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Now, let's think about what happened. First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
(Looks away, fidgets with my pencil) Uh…food.
Yes! The fox was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?
Grapes! Big, juicy, purple grapes. Did the fox get the grapes easily?
…No. (Looks down at my desk, avoiding eye contact)
No, he didn't. What did he do to try to get them?
(Thinks hard, tapping pencil on the desk) Jumped. He…jumped.
He jumped! He jumped as high as he could! Did jumping work? Did he get the grapes?
No. He kept trying, but he couldn't reach them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes?
He went home. And what did he say about the grapes *before* he went home? What did he think about the grapes when he left?

Yes! He said they were sour. Even though he really wanted them at the beginning, and tried so hard to get them. Why do you think the fox said the grapes were sour? Do you think he *really* thought they were sour?
(Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) …Dunno.

Think about it. He wanted the grapes really badly. He jumped and jumped. But he couldn't get them. So, he walked away and said they were sour. Do you think he was maybe…a little bit sad or disappointed that he couldn't get them?
Okay. So, maybe he was a little disappointed. Do you think saying the grapes were sour made him feel a little better about not getting them?
(Thinking, pencil tapping speeds up) …Uh…maybe. (Mumbles) They were too high anyway.

Exactly! "They were too high anyway." He's trying to make himself feel better about not getting something he wanted.

Now, imagine you really want a toy, but you can't have it. What would you do? Would you say you didn't want the toy anyway?
(Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) …Yeah. I…I wouldn't want it. (Mumbles even quieter) It's…stupid anyway.

(Nods understandingly) It's okay to feel like that sometimes. The fox felt like that too.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? Is it easy to get everything you want?

No. Sometimes, no matter how hard we try, we can't get what we want. And what did the fox do when he couldn't get the grapes? He said they were sour. He pretended he didn't want them anymore.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about things we can't have? Should we say they are sour anyway?<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story, [Student's Name]! That was "The Proud Rose."

Now, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in our story?
(Looks down, fiddling with my pencil) Uh... the rose... and the cactus.

That's right! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me... what did the rose think about the cactus? Did she like the way he looked?
(Shrugs, staring at the desk) No. She... she didn't like him.
You're right! She didn't like him. Why didn't she like him? What did the story say about how the rose felt?
(Thinking, tapping the pencil on the desk) She... (pauses) ...she thought she was prettier.
Yes! She thought she was prettier. And what did she do because she thought she was prettier? How did she treat the cactus?
(Looks away, a slight frown) She... was mean.

Exactly! She was mean. She insulted him.

Now, something happened in the desert, didn't it? Something that made things hard for everyone. What was it?
That's it! No water. What happened to the rose when there was no water?
She did wither. She started to die. What happened to the cactus? Did he wither too?
He did! How did he have water? Remember what the story said? Who was using the cactus?
(Thinking hard, biting lip slightly) The... the birds?

Yes! The sparrows! The cactus was helping the sparrows.

So, the rose is dying, and the cactus is helping the birds. What does the rose do then?
(Looks down again) She... asks for water.
She does! And does the cactus give her water? Even after she was mean to him?

Yes, he does. He's kind.

So, the rose was pretty, but she was mean. The cactus maybe wasn't as pretty, but he was kind and helpful. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?
(Frowns, sticking to simple words) Uh... be nice?
Being nice is very important! And why should we be nice, even to people who might look different or who we don't think are as "pretty" as us? What did the rose learn about the cactus?
(Looks at the teacher with a blank stare) ...I don't know.

Okay, let's think about it this way. The rose *thought* she was better than the cactus because of how she looked. But in the end, who had the water? Who was able to help others? Who was actually stronger in the desert?
(Thinks for a moment, tapping the pencil) The cactus...
Yes! The cactus. So, is it a good idea to judge people just by how they look?

No! Because looks can be deceiving. The rose *looked* beautiful, but she wasn't very kind or helpful at first. The cactus *looked* different, but he was strong and kind and helpful.

So, what could we say is the lesson of the story? What does the story teach us about judging others?
(Sticks to given information, repeats) Don't... judge... by how they look.

Perfect! Don't judge someone by how they look. That's the big idea of the story. The cactus might not have been as pretty as the rose, but he was the one who was truly strong and helpful. And the rose learned that being pretty on the outside isn't as important as being kind on the inside. You understood the story really well. <finish>
Okay! So, you just read the story of Molly the Milkmaid. What did Molly do for work?
(Confidently) Milk the cows. Sell milk at market.
Great job! What did Molly start thinking about while walking to the market?
(Thinking) Uh... (Sticks to simple words) Money. Spend money.
Yes! She was thinking about spending her money. What did she want to buy first?
(Looks away, avoids asking questions, short answer) Chicken.
A chicken! And why did she want to buy a chicken?
Exactly! She wanted more money. What happened while she was thinking about all this?
Yes, the milk spilled! How do you think Molly felt when the milk spilled?
(Encouraging, not dismissive) Even if Molly doesn't care, it's still worth thinking about how *we* would feel! Would you be happy or sad if you spilled all your milk?
(Well-organized and logic thinking) No milk. No money. (Sticks to given information)
Good job! So, Molly went home with no milk and no money. What did her mother say to her?
(Confidently, sticking to simple words) Don't... count... chicken... hatch.
Perfect! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means? It's okay if you don't know for sure.
(Thinking, avoids asking questions) ...Means... wait? (Sticks to simple words)
Wait... for what? Wait for the chickens?
(Well-organized and logic thinking, sticking to given information) Wait... for eggs. Then... count.

You're getting close! It means don't *plan* on something good happening until you *know* it will happen. Molly was planning to get rich with the chicken's eggs, but she didn't even *have* the chicken yet!

So, what do you think is the lesson of the story? What did Molly learn?
(Confidently, sticking to simple words) Don't... plan... too early.
That's a great way to put it! Don't plan too early, before you're sure. So, if you are saving up for a toy, should you spend the money before you actually *have* enough?
Why not? What would happen if you spent it too early?
(Sticking to simple words, logic thinking) No toy. No money.
Exactly! You learned the lesson of the story. Do not depend on something until you are sure it will happen. You did a great job explaining the story! <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! You read the story of the Wise Old Owl so well.

Now, tell me, what did the old owl like to do every day?

(Looks down at the book, rereading the first line silently. Thinking hard.)

He... he watched stuff. (Points at the picture of the owl in the book.) Around... his tree.

Did he watch a little bit, or a lot? The story says he watched "every day."

...A lot.
Right! He watched a lot. And what did he do *besides* watching? Did he only watch?
