(Smiles warmly) That is a *wonderful* explanation. You are exactly right! It's okay to be sad, and it's not nice to say mean things just because you can't have something.

And it's also okay to try your best and still not get it. That happens to *everyone*. The important thing is that you tried! And you're right, you can always ask for help.

So, the story is teaching us that even if we can't get something we want, we shouldn't hate it. It's like saying, "Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have." We should just keep trying or find something else that makes us happy. And it's ALWAYS okay to be a *little* sad when you don't get something you really wanted. It just means you care.

I think you understand the story *perfectly*. You did such a great job thinking about it and explaining it! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

So, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in our story?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand excitedly, then lowers it a bit nervously) Um... well, there was... (Stuttering) ... there was a... a rose! (Points to the book) And... and a... (Looks away, fiddling with my pencil) ...a prickly thing! What's it called again? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Is it... a... a cactus? Yes! A rose and a cactus! (Beams, then adds quickly) They lived in the desert!

Yes! You got it! A rose and a cactus! And you remembered they lived in the desert. Good job!

Now, tell me, what did the rose think about the cactus?

(Confidently) Oh! That rose was not nice! (Frowns dramatically) She... she thought she was SOOOO pretty! Like, the prettiest flower EVER! (Rolls eyes) And she thought the cactus was... (Wrinkles nose) ...yucky and prickly and... and not pretty at all! (Pauses, thinking) She even said mean things to the cactus! (Looks down, shuffling feet a little) It wasn't very kind... (Looks back up, anxiously) Was it?

No, it wasn't kind at all. You're right. The rose wasn't being very nice.

So, what happened when the summer got really, really hot?

(Sits up straighter, excited again) Ooh! Ooh! I remember! (Claps hands) It got super hot and... (Thinking) ... the rose started to... to... (Looks at the teacher, a little panicked) ... what was the word? It started to... to not look so good anymore! (Waves hands vaguely) Like, the pretty colors started to fade! And the cactus... (Eyes widen) ...the cactus was okay! (Gasps) Because it was helping the birdies! (Points excitedly) It had water for them! The rose didn't have any water! (Whispers dramatically) It was thirsty!

Exactly! The rose started to *wither*. That's a good word to describe it.

And you're right, the cactus was helping the birds. So, what did the rose do then? When she was thirsty?

(Bites lip nervously) Oh... oh, this part is kinda hard. (Looks down at hands) The rose... she... she had to ask the cactus for help. (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide and a little teary) It was probably really hard for her to do! (Voice cracks a little) Because she was so mean before. (Sniffles quietly) Did the cactus say no? (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes)
(Softly) That's a very good question. What do *you* think the cactus did? Remember the story. Did the cactus say no?

(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed) Hmmm... the cactus... (Taps chin) ... the cactus was a nice cactus, right? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Even though the rose wasn't nice to him... (Chews on pencil eraser) ... I think... I think the cactus shared the water! (Beams, relieved) Because that's what nice people do! (Adds quickly, excitedly) Or... or nice cacti!

You're absolutely right! The cactus *did* share the water. Even after the rose was mean to him.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big message?

(Thinking, head tilted) Hmmm... (Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) I think... (Stuttering slightly) ... it's like... like even if someone isn't nice to you... (Pauses, trying to find the right words) ... you should still be nice to them! (Confidently) Like the cactus! (Frowns slightly) And... (Looks away, fiddling with a button on shirt) ... and maybe... maybe the rose learned that being pretty isn't everything? (Looks back at the teacher, hopefully) Is that right? (Anxiously) Did I get it right?

That's a *really* good answer! You got it!

It's about being kind, even when others aren't. And it's also about not judging people just by how they look. The rose only cared about being pretty, but the cactus was helpful and kind.

So, we can say the story teaches us: Never judge someone according to how they look.

Do you understand?

(Nods enthusiastically, clapping hands) Yes! Yes! I understand! (Grinning) Like... like in real life too! Not just with flowers and prickly things! (Thinks for a moment, then adds seriously) It's important to be nice to everyone, even if they don't look like you or act like you. (Beams proudly) I get it! (Asks suddenly, eyes wide with curiosity) Teacher, can we draw pictures of the rose and the cactus now? I wanna draw the cactus being super helpful!
I'm so glad you understand! That's a wonderful thought. And yes, we can definitely draw pictures of the rose and the cactus now. I'd love to see your drawing of the super helpful cactus! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good story, wasn't it?

So, tell me, who was the main person in our story?

(Bouncing my leg nervously, fiddling with my pencil)

Uh, yeah! It was a good story! (Looks away, then back at the teacher, smiling brightly) The main person... um... (thinking hard, wrinkling my forehead) Was it... was it Molly? The milk... milk... (stuttering a bit) milk-maid? She had the... the pail! And the milk! (Confidently) Yeah! Molly! She was going to the market!

Yes! You got it! It was Molly.

And what was Molly going to do at the market? What was in her pail?

(Eyes widen, excited)

Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand, but doesn't wait to be called on) She was going to sell the... the... (pauses, thinking hard) milk! (Beams proudly) In the pail! She was going to sell it at the market so she could get money! And then... (frowns slightly, starting to get distracted) ...then she saw a chicken! Oh! Chickens are so fluffy! I want a chicken... (catches self, looks back at the teacher) ...But she was going to sell the milk! To get money!

That's right! She was going to sell the milk to get money. Good job!

Now, what did Molly start thinking about *while* she was walking to the market? What was she going to do with the money?

(Squirms in seat, looking around the room for a moment)

Um... (taps pencil on desk, then gasps, eyes wide) Oh! Oh! I remember! She was going to buy a... a chicken! (Confidently) And then the chicken would lay eggs! And she could sell the eggs too! And then she would have even MORE money! (Starts getting very excited, voice gets louder) And she could buy lots of things! And the other milkmaids would be jealous! (Looks away, giggling to self)

Yes! You're doing great! She was thinking about buying a chicken and selling the eggs to get even more money.

Did she actually *buy* the chicken in the story?

(Face falls slightly, starts chewing on the end of the pencil)

Um... (voice gets quieter, more hesitant) No... (Shakes head) No, she didn't. (Looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher with wide, slightly anxious eyes) Did she? I... I don't think so. She was just... just thinking about it. She didn't really buy it. (Stuttering a bit) Cause... cause she spilled the milk!

That's right! She didn't buy the chicken. She was just *thinking* about it. And you remembered she spilled the milk!

Why did she spill the milk? What was she doing when it spilled?

(Bounces in seat again, trying to remember)

Oh! Oh! (Points finger in the air) I know! She was... she was skipping! (Giggles) She was so happy thinking about the chicken and the eggs and all the money! She was skipping and... and (pauses, struggling to find the word) ...excited! And then... (makes spilling motion with hand) ...WHOOSH! The milk spilled! (Looks at the teacher expectantly)
Exactly! She was skipping and excited. And *then* the milk spilled. What happened *after* the milk spilled? Where did Molly go?

(Voice gets small and anxious, fidgeting with hands)

Oh... (Looks down at desk, tracing circles with finger) She... she went home. (Sniffs quietly) 'Cause she didn't have any milk anymore. (Looks up at teacher, eyes a little watery) And she didn't have any money. (Whispers) Just... just an empty pail.
Yes, she went home with an empty pail and no money. How do you think Molly felt when she went home?

(Sniffles and wipes nose with sleeve, voice trembling a little)

Sad. (Looks down, avoids eye contact) Really, really sad. (Mumbles) 'Cause she wanted the chicken... and the money... and she spilled all the milk. (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide and pleading) Was her mommy mad at her? (Bites lip)

It sounds like Molly made a mistake and was sad that it happened.

What did Molly's mother say to her? Do you remember the words she said? It's okay if you don't remember exactly.

(Eyes dart around, looks like about to cry, voice wobbly)

Um... (Stuttering) I-I... I don't remember exactly. Something about... something about... (Starts to frown, concentrating hard) ...about counting... (Eyes widen a bit, like a lightbulb just went on) ...chickens! (Pauses, then says it confidently) Don't count your chickens before they hatch! That's what her mommy said! (Looks proud, but still a little nervous) Was that right?

Yes! That's exactly what her mother said! "Don't count your chickens before they hatch."

Now, what do you think that means? What was Molly doing that her mother was warning her about?

(Pushes hair out of face, looking thoughtful, then nervous)

Um... (Scratches head) It means... it means... (Looks around the room, getting distracted by a poster) ...Ooh, shiny! (Snaps back to attention) It means... don't... don't think you have something... (Frowns, struggling to explain) ...before you REALLY have it? (Looks at the teacher, pleading for confirmation) Like, she didn't have the chicken yet, but she was already spending the egg money in her head! So... (Voice gets louder, excited) ...she was counting the chickens before they were even born! Is that it? (Bites lip, anxious for approval)

You are *exactly* right! She didn't *have* the chicken or the eggs, but she was already planning what to do with the money.

So, what do you think is the lesson of the story? What does the story teach us?

(Sighs, relieved, but still a little jumpy, taps foot on the floor)

The lesson... (Puts finger to chin, thinking hard) ...is that you shouldn't... you shouldn't plan too much before things actually happen. (Voice gets softer) Or you might spill all your milk! (Giggles nervously) And then you'll be sad. So... (Looks up at the teacher, serious expression) ...wait until the chickens hatch before you count them! And... (Eyes widen with a new thought) ...and maybe be careful when you're skipping with a pail full of milk! (Smiles brightly)
That's a great way to put it! The story teaches us to be careful and not to depend on things before they are certain. You understood the story really well. Great job today!<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story about the wise old owl! Did you like it?

Now, let's talk about the owl. What did the owl do every day near his tree?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooooh, I liked it! The owl was, like, a super-duper spy! (Giggles)

(Thinking, tapping my pencil on the desk) Hmmm... near the tree... (looks away) The owl... saw... stuff! Yeah! He saw things! And... and... (stuttering a little) people were talking? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Did I get it right? It was so many things happening, it was kind of hard to remember all of them! Are we going to read it again? Maybe then I'll remember even *more*!

(Smiling warmly) You're doing great! Yes, you're right! The owl *did* see stuff. He observed things happening around his tree. And you're right, people were talking.

So, the owl saw things and heard people talking. Did the story say he talked a lot?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk, a little anxious) Oh! Oh! (Voice gets quieter) I don't... I don't *think* so? (Frowning, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) I think... I think he listened *more* than he talked? (Looks up at the teacher nervously) But I don't know *why*... (Suddenly excited again) Maybe he had a sore throat! Or maybe he was, like, a *super-secret* listener and that's how he knew *everything*! (Leans forward conspiratorially) Like a real-life detective! Is that why he was wise? Because he listened really, really well?

(Nodding encouragingly) You're getting very close! You're right, he did listen more than he talked. And it wasn't because of a sore throat! (Chuckles softly)

Think about it: he *saw* lots of things, and he *heard* lots of things. What happened to the owl because he saw and heard so much? The story used a special word to describe him.

(Eyes widen, face scrunches up in concentration, tapping the desk again, faster this time.) A... a special word! (Whispers) What was it? (Looks around the room as if the word is hidden somewhere). He saw things... he heard things... He became... (Gasps, jumping slightly in my seat) Wise! (Confidently) He became... wiser! Because he learned from what he saw and heard! (Beaming) Like, he put all the pieces together and figured things out! Did I do it? Did I get it right this time? (Slightly anxious again) Am I a little bit wise now too, because I'm learning from *you*?

(Beaming) You absolutely got it right! The owl became wiser because he saw and heard so much. He learned from everything around him.

So, if the owl talked *less* and *watched* and *listened* *more*, what did he become?

(Claps my hands together excitedly) He became a super-duper wise owl! (Stands up, almost knocking over my chair, then sits down quickly, a little embarrassed). Oops! (Giggles nervously). So, so, if I want to be wise like the owl... (starts thinking hard, biting my lip)... I have to listen really, REALLY carefully and watch everything? (Looks up at the ceiling, pretending to watch things happening). Even... even when it's hard to pay attention? (Frowns a little). Like when Timmy is making funny noises in class? (Whispers) But Timmy's noises are REALLY funny! (Suddenly brightens) But if I listen to *you* really well, and watch how *you* do things... will I get wise too? (Looks at the teacher with hopeful, sparkling eyes)

(Smiling warmly) Yes, you're exactly right! To become wise, like the owl, you need to listen carefully and watch what's happening around you. Even when Timmy is being funny! (Chuckles) It's okay to laugh sometimes, but try to also pay attention to what you can learn.

So, what's the big idea of the story? What does the story want us to learn about talking and listening?

(Nods enthusiastically, then fidgets with my shoelaces). Okay, okay! The big idea is... (pauses, looking thoughtful)... that listening is super important! (Voice gets a little quieter and more serious). It's even *more* important than talking... (Looks up, a little worried). But I *like* talking! (Frowns). So, does that mean I have to be quiet *all* the time to be wise? (Pulls at my hair nervously). That seems really hard! (Then, eyes light up with an idea). But maybe... maybe I can still talk, but I just need to listen *more*, too! (Looks at the teacher for approval, bouncing my leg up and down anxiously). Is that right? Can I still talk a little bit?

(Smiling encouragingly) You've got it! The story isn't saying you can *never* talk. It's just saying that listening and watching are very important for learning and becoming wise. You can still talk, but try to listen even more.

So, we can say that to be wise, it's good to...?

(Eyes light up, relieved and happy) Ooooh! Okay! To be wise, it's good to... (Puts a finger to my chin, pretending to think hard, then grins) ...to listen with your ears AND watch with your eyes! (Stands up and points to my ears then my eyes). And... and... (sits back down, getting excited again) ...and think about what you hear and see! (Claps my hands). Like, put it all together in your brain like a puzzle! (Leans in conspiratorially). And maybe, just maybe... talk a little bit less! (Giggles). But not *never*! (Looks at the teacher with a big, happy smile). Did I get it all? Am I super-duper wise now?

(Nodding enthusiastically) You got it all! You understand the story and what it means to be wise. You are definitely on your way to becoming super-duper wise! You can listen and observe and share your ideas, just like you did today! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

First, can you tell me... what did the farmer's goose do every day?

(Swinging my legs under the desk, then tapping my foot nervously) Uhm... (looks away, fiddling with a loose thread on my shirt) It... it was about a goose, right? (eyes widen, remembering) Oh! Oh! I know! (confidently) The goose... the goose gave the farmer a... a... (stuttering) a gold... a golden egg every day! Yeah! A golden egg! (bouncing in my seat excitedly) It was like, *bling!*, super shiny! (pauses, frowning) But... but what does 'lay' mean? Did she put it down gently?

That's right! The goose gave the farmer a golden egg every day. *Bling!* Super shiny!

And "lay" just means to *give* or *produce* an egg. So, the goose *produced* a golden egg each day.

Now, what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Eyes dart around the room, spotting a colorful poster on the wall. Briefly distracted, then snaps back to attention) Oh! Oh yeah, the egg! (wrinkles nose) He... he took it somewhere... (thinking hard, furrowing brow) Was it to the market? (Looks up hopefully) To... to sell it? (Voice gets louder and more excited) So he could get money! (clapping hands once) And buy candy! (a thought strikes) Or maybe a new toy! Did the story say what he bought? I bet he bought a GIANT lollipop! (laughs, then gets a little anxious) But... but what if he didn't share with his wife? That wouldn't be very nice... would it? (looks at the teacher, concerned)

Yes, you're exactly right! He sold the egg to get money! The story doesn't say what he bought, but getting money was the important part.

So, the farmer sold the egg and got money. Were the farmer and his wife happy at first?

(Nods head vigorously, eyes wide) Yeah! Yeah, they were happy! 'Cause they had money! (Starts to draw circles on the desk with a finger) Money's good, right? (Looks up at the teacher, a little anxious) But... but not if you're greedy! Is "greedy" a bad word? My mom says it is. (Pauses, thinking) So... they were happy... but then... then something bad happened! (Voice drops to a near whisper) The goosey didn't get a lollipop, did it? (Frowns deeply)

You're so smart! "Greedy" *is* a bad word. And you're right, something bad *did* happen.

What made the farmer and his wife *stop* being happy? What did they want more of?

(Starts to bite nails, then quickly stops, remembering what my mom said) Hmmm... (Taps chin thoughtfully) They... they wanted more... more golden eggs! (Eyes widen in realization) They were greedy! Like you said! (Shifts in seat, looking nervous) Did they shout at the goosey? I don't like shouting. It makes my tummy feel funny. (Looks at the teacher with big, worried eyes) Why did they want more eggs anyway? One egg is already a lot, isn't it? (Pulls at a strand of hair)

That's right, they wanted more golden eggs, and that made them greedy.

Why do you think they wanted more eggs *right away*, instead of waiting for one each day? What do you think was in their heads?

(Paces in front of the desk) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Stops suddenly, pointing a finger in the air) They thought... (lowers voice conspiratorially) ...there was a whole bunch of golden eggs *inside* the goose! (Eyes widen again, excitedly) Like a treasure chest! But instead of jewels, it was full of golden eggs! (Starts hopping from one foot to the other) They thought they could get rich super fast! (Pauses, looking down at the floor) But... but that wasn't very smart, was it? (Looks up at the teacher, anxiously) Was it?

You've got it! They thought there were lots of eggs inside, so they could get rich *super fast*. You are absolutely right: that wasn't very smart.

What did the farmer *do* because he wanted all the eggs at once?

(Gasps, covering mouth with hand) Oh no! (Eyes widen in horror) He... he didn't... he didn't hurt the goosey, did he? (Voice trembling) He... he cut it open! (Starts to tear up a little) Oh, that's so sad! (Sniffles) He wanted all the eggs, but he only found... (looks down, avoiding eye contact) ...blood and guts. (Shakes head sadly) That's yucky! And now the goosey is gone! (Voice cracks) That's the worst! (Looks up at the teacher, face crumpled) Why did he do that?!

You're right, it *is* very sad. He did hurt the goose, and now it's gone.

Why do *you* think he did that? Even though it was a bad idea, what was he hoping for?

(Wipes eyes with sleeve, then sniffs) He was hoping... (Thinking hard, tapping chin) He was hoping to be super rich! (Voice still a little shaky) He wanted all the golden eggs, like, *right now!* (Gestures wildly with hands) He was probably thinking about all the cool stuff he could buy! Maybe a giant castle! Or a mountain of candy! (Sighs heavily) But... but being greedy made him do something really, really bad. (Looks down at hands, picking at fingernails) And now he has nothing. (Whispers) Poor goosey...

You're exactly right. He was thinking about being rich and all the things he could buy. But his greed made him do something terrible, and now he has nothing.

What happened to the farmer and his wife after the goose was gone?

(Sits up straighter, trying to focus, but still a little sniffly) Okay... okay, I remember. (Thinking) They... they got sad, right? And... (frowns) ...and poor! They didn't have any more golden eggs to sell. (Looks up at the teacher, concerned) Did they have to sell their house? Did they have to eat yucky food? (Shudders) It's not good to be poor. (Leans forward, whispering) Being greedy made them lose everything... (Pulls at a strand of hair, looking worried) Did they learn their lesson? I hope they did!

Yes, they got sad and poor. They didn't have any more golden eggs, so they didn't have any money.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the important lesson?

(Stands up and begins to pace again, agitated) Ooh! Ooh! This is important! (Stops pacing, pointing a finger) It's telling us... (Stuttering) not... not to be greedy! (Voice becomes stronger and louder) If you're greedy, you might do something bad! And you'll lose everything! (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) Is that right? (Calmer now, but still earnest) It's better to be happy with what you have, even if it's just one golden egg a day. (Sits down heavily, sighing) And... and don't hurt gooseys! (Hugs self tightly) That's the most important thing!

You're so close! It *is* about not being greedy, and being happy with what you have.

But it's also about *thinking* before you do something. The farmer didn't *think* about what would happen if he hurt the goose. He just acted quickly because he was greedy.

So, what's a good lesson the story teaches us, starting with "Think..."?

(Frowns, thinking really hard, tapping a finger on the desk) Think... Think... (Eyes light up) Think *before* you do something greedy! (Nods head enthusiastically) Yeah! Because if you don't think, you might make a really big mistake! (Pauses, biting lip) And then... and then the goosey gets hurt! (Looks at the teacher pleadingly) Is that it? Did I get it right this time? (Clenches hands tightly)

Yes! That's it! "Think before you act." If the farmer had thought before he acted, he wouldn't have hurt the goose and lost all his golden eggs. He acted without thinking because he was greedy, and that made everything worse. You understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! You read the story of "The Farmer and the Well" very well.

Now, tell me, who bought the well?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking at the floor) Um... the... the farmer? (Looks up quickly, then down again) He... he bought it from... from the... neighbor! Yeah! The farmer bought the well! (Beams, then bites lip nervously) Was that right? Did I get it right? (Whispers) I hope I got it right. It was a tricky story! Did you see that big word... um... "courtier"? What's a courtier? Is that like... like a king's helper? They sound important!

Yes, you got it exactly right! The farmer bought the well from the neighbour.

And yes, a courtier is like a helper to the emperor, a very important helper!

Now, what was the problem after the farmer bought the well? Could he use it?

(Eyes widen, leans forward eagerly) Oh! Oh! I know this! (Stands up a little in my seat, then sits back down quickly, embarrassed) The... the neighbor... (frowns) ...he was being... (searches for the right word, wrinkling my nose) ...he was being not nice! (Looks around the room, distracted for a moment by a colourful poster) The farmer bought the well, but the neighbor... (stuttering slightly) ...but he wouldn't let him... (thinks hard, tapping a finger on the desk)...draw water! Yeah! He wouldn't let him get the water! It's like... like buying a cookie but not being allowed to eat it! (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful) That's not fair, right? Right! (Nods head vigorously)

That's right! It's like buying a cookie but not being allowed to eat it. You explained it very well.

So, the neighbour wasn't being fair. What did the farmer do because the neighbour wouldn't let him use the water?

(Sighs dramatically, then perks up again) Okay, okay! The farmer... (looks up at the ceiling, thinking)... he went to the... the... um...(Eyes widen) The EMPEROR! He went to the emperor! (Points a finger in the air) Because the emperor is like... super important! Did he have to walk a long way? (Tilts head, then whispers) Maybe he took a horse? (Looks at the teacher, suddenly anxious) Is the emperor REALLY important? Was the farmer scared? I'd be scared!

Yes, the emperor is very important, and the farmer went to him for help. It was very brave of him!

What happened when the farmer told the Emperor his problem? What did the Emperor's helper, the courtier, do?

(Hides face in hands for a second, then peeks through fingers) Oh! This part is a little tricky! (Lowers hands and frowns, focusing hard) Okay, the courtier... that's the emperor's helper, right? (Nods head) The courtier asked the... (stuttering) ...the me-me-mean neighbor... (suddenly sits up straight, remembering something)... WHY he wouldn't let the farmer have the water! (makes a silly face, trying to imitate the neighbor) ...he said, "I sold him the WELL, not the WATER!" (Giggles, then covers mouth, embarrassed) It's like... like saying you sold someone the BOX, but not the TOYS inside! (Looks at the teacher, questioning) That doesn't make sense, does it? It's like, super silly, right?

You're doing a great job! Yes, the neighbour was being very silly!

What did the courtier say to the neighbour after that? He gave him a choice. What was it?

(Bounces in seat with excitement, then calms down, trying to focus) Okay, okay! The courtier... (taps chin, thinking)... he said the neighbor had to... (eyes widen, remembering)... PAY RENT! (Claps hands together softly) Or... or...(voice drops to a whisper) ...or take ALL the water away... RIGHT NOW! (Looks at the teacher, wide-eyed) All of it! That's a LOT of water! Where would he put it? Would he need a lot of buckets? (Starts to count on fingers) One bucket, two buckets, three buckets... (trails off, distracted)

Yes, that's right! He had to pay rent for the water, or take it all away.

What happened *then*? What did the neighbour do after the courtier told him that?

(Sighs dramatically, leaning back in chair) Oh! Oh! (Eyes light up) The neighbor... (makes a face like he's about to cry) ...he was... (searches for the word) ...he was... SORRY! (Claps hands together happily) Did the farmer get his water then? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Did he finally get to water his farm? (Starts tapping foot impatiently)

Yes! The neighbour realised his trick didn't work, and he went home sorry. The farmer could finally use the well to water his farm.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or the message of the story?

(Stares blankly for a moment, then bites lip nervously) Oh... oh no... this is the hard part, isn't it? (Looks around the room, avoiding eye contact) Um... it means... (stuttering) ...it means... be... be... (suddenly sits up straight, a spark of understanding in eyes) ...be FAIR! (Points a finger emphatically) Don't be tricky like the neighbor! (Frowns, thinking harder) And... and... if someone is being tricky... (looks up at the teacher with wide eyes) ...you can ask for HELP! Like the farmer asked the emperor! (Smiles brightly, relieved to have figured it out) Is that right? Is that what the story means? (Whispers) I hope so!
That's a *very* good answer! You're right, the story is about being fair and not tricky. What happens when you try to trick people, like the neighbour did? Did it work out well for him?

(Shakes head vigorously, eyes wide) No way! (Lowers voice) It didn't work at ALL! He had to say sorry! (Giggles nervously) Being tricky is like... like building a tower of blocks really high... (gestures with hands)... and then it FALLS DOWN! (Claps hands together softly, making a collapsing sound) It's better to be nice and fair, right? (Looks at the teacher for reassurance) Because then... then everyone is happy! (Beams proudly) And you don't have to say sorry! (Makes a silly face) Saying sorry is no fun!

You've got it! So, if you try to trick people, it won't work out for you in the end. It's better to be honest and fair. We can say that the story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere. Do you understand that?

(Nods head enthusiastically) Yes! Yes! (Claps hands softly) Cheating is like... (thinks hard, wrinkling nose) ...like pretending you know the answer when you DON'T! (Looks at the teacher with big, pleading eyes) I promise!

No, no, asking questions is *never* cheating! Asking questions is how we learn! Cheating is when you try to get something by being unfair or dishonest. You were just curious, and that's wonderful!

Do you think you understand the story of "The Farmer and the Well" now? Do you understand what it teaches us?

(Sighs with relief, then beams happily) YES! (Jumps up and down in seat a little) I understand! (Points finger in the air) Be fair! Don't be tricky! Or a princess! Or maybe even a talking DOG! (Claps hands together excitedly) Ooh! Ooh! Can we, can we, PLEASE?!

I'm so glad you understand the story! You did a fantastic job.

Yes, we can read another story next time. We'll see if we can find one with a dragon, a princess, or maybe even a talking dog! <finish>

Okay! That was a great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends.

Now, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Bites lip) He was all... alone in the big, big forest. (Scratches head, thinking). Is it okay that he wanted friends? It's good to have friends, right?

Yes, it's absolutely okay to want friends! And you're right, the elephant was very sad.

Why didn't the monkey want to be the elephant's friend?

(Eyes dart around the room, distracted by a fly buzzing near the window.) Oh! Oh! The monkey! (Claps hands excitedly) The monkey... (Looks back at you, furrowing brow) The monkey said the elephant couldn't... couldn't... (Thinking hard, tapping pencil on the desk) swing in the trees! And why didn't the rabbit want to be the elephant's friend?

(Voice gets quieter) To fit in his burrow. (Looks up suddenly, eyes wide) Burrows are, like, rabbit houses! All small and cozy. An elephant would NEVER fit! (Starts to giggle nervously, then stops abruptly, worried)

So, all the animals turned the elephant away because he was different. Then, something happened the next day. What happened?

(Face scrunches up, brows furrowed, concentrating really hard) Uh oh... (Bites lip) The next day... (Taps foot impatiently, struggles to remember) Hmmm... (Suddenly, eyes light up, remembers) Oh! Oh! (Makes a clawing motion with hands) ...get them! (Looks a little scared, then quickly recovers and asks) Was the tiger really, REALLY mean?

The story says the tiger was attacking them, so yes, he wasn't being very nice.

What did the elephant do when he saw the tiger?

(Eyes widen, then asks a little nervously) Is it okay to kick someone if they're being mean to everyone? (Looks at you expectantly for an answer).

That's a good question. It's usually better to find other ways to solve problems. But in the story, the tiger wouldn't listen.

That's a very smart question! It IS good to be different.

Why do you think the animals wanted to be the elephant's friend *after* he saved them, even though they didn't want to be his friend before?

(Asks curiously) Does that mean we should always give people a chance, even if they're different?

You've got it! The animals learned that being able to swing or jump wasn't the only thing that mattered. The elephant was helpful and brave.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the Elephant and his friends?

(Looks thoughtful, tapping pencil on the desk) The lesson... (Pauses, fidgeting with shoelaces) Hmmm... (Suddenly, sits up straight, excited) I know! I know! (Voice gets louder) The lesson is... That's absolutely right! You understood the story perfectly. Friends can be any shape or size, and everyone has something special to offer. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

What happened to the egg when it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

What do you think the dad was trying to teach his daughter by showing her this? It's okay if you're not sure.

So, the egg started soft but became hard in the problem (boiling water). The potato started hard but became soft in the problem (boiling water). And the tea leaves changed the water itself.

What does that mean about how *we* can act when *we* have problems?

(Takes a deep breath, looks determined) Okay, I'm going to try REALLY hard! (Concentrates, scrunches up face) So... the egg... (points finger) ...it was soft, then hard! So maybe... (smiles brightly) ...maybe some people change the problems! Like... they make the problems BETTER! (Claps hands excitedly) Did I do it, teacher? Did I figure it out?! I'm so excited! (Bounces in seat)

Yes! That's exactly right! The girl learned that she gets to choose how she responds to problems. It's up to her (and to you!) to decide whether to become hard, soft, or to change the problem. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Needle Tree! That was a long one!

Let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?

(Eyes wide, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... um... (looks away) There were... two... two boys! (Confidently) Brothers! Yeah, brothers! And... and one was... mean! (Voice gets higher) Really, really mean! And the other one... (pauses, thinking hard) ...was... nice! (Smiles brightly) He helped!

Yes, that's right! Two brothers. And one was mean and the other was nice.

What did the mean brother do in the forest?

He wanted money, money, money! (Wrinkles nose) But then... then the tree... the magical tree! (Claps hands once, quietly) He wanted to chop it too! Oh no! (Starts to get anxious, picks at a loose thread on my shirt). Is that right? Did I get it right?

You got it exactly right! He chopped wood to sell for money and then he wanted to chop the magic tree.

That's very kind of you to share, even with the mean brother!

The tree gave him golden apples. Was the older brother happy with the apples?

(Frowns, face scrunches up) No! (Shakes head emphatically) He was... (searches for the right word, points finger in the air) ...dis...disap... (Looks hopeful)
That's a very thoughtful idea. Maybe he did want to share. But what did he *do* because he was disappointed? Did he share them, or did he do something else to the tree?

(Looks down at hands, picking at them nervously) He didn't share. He was... really, really greedy. (Sighs deeply, on the verge of tears) I don't like mean people. (Sniffles quietly) It makes me sad.

It's okay. It's sad when people are mean.

What happened when he tried to chop down the tree?

Yes, it must have hurt a lot. The tree threw needles at him.

Then what happened? Who helped him?

(Claps hands, softly) Even though the older brother was mean at first!

That's right! He apologized for being mean, and then the tree gave them more golden apples.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks intensely at the teacher) Because... because being kind makes things better! And maybe... maybe if you're really, really mean, you can say sorry and then things will be okay too! (Sits back, pleased with the answer) Is that right? Is that the big idea? (Anxious, hopes for approval)

That's very close! The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen. Being mean didn't get the older brother anything good, did it? But when he was sorry, and the younger brother was kind, what happened?

(Eyes widen, understands the point) Oh! (Voice full of excitement) Oh! I get it! (Points finger in the air) Being mean didn't get him more apples! It just got him needles! Exactly! Kindness is better than being mean. Kindness was rewarded. That's the big idea of the story. Kindness will always be rewarded. You understood the story very well! <finish>

Why do you think he wished for the golden touch in the first place? What do you think he wanted more than anything?

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from King Midas and his golden touch? What do you think the moral of the story is?

Okay, great job reading the story! That was the story of The Fox and the Grapes.

So, what did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes? Where did he go?

Why do you think he said the grapes were sour? Was he being honest?

That's a really good connection to cookies! You understand the fox very well.

So, the fox couldn't get what he wanted, and then he said he didn't want it anyway. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson?

(Scrunches up face, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Looks away, fiddling with shirt) It's teaching us that... that... (Complex thought coming!) ...it's not good to lie! (Looks back at the teacher) Even to yourself! 'Cause the grapes might have been yummy! (Pauses, then brightens) Or... (Another complex thought!) ...it's teaching us that we shouldn't give up so easily! Maybe if the fox tried a little harder, or asked for help, he could have gotten the grapes! (Asks teacher) Which one is it? Is it both? (Looks hopeful and a bit anxious to get the "right" answer)

Those are both really good ideas! It *is* important to not lie, and it's also important to not give up.

Another way to think about it is that sometimes, things are hard to get. The story teaches us that it's better to work hard for what you want. And if you *can't* get it, it's not good to pretend you didn't want it in the first place.

So, what if the fox kept trying? Or asked for help?

(Eyes light up, intrigued by the question) Ooh! (Starts brainstorming out loud) If he kept trying... maybe he could have found a ladder! (Makes climbing motions with hands) Or he could have asked the farmer! (Becomes more serious) Maybe the farmer would have said no, but at least he would have *tried*! (Looks at the teacher, a spark of understanding in their eyes) And if he still couldn't get the grapes, then he could just say, "Okay, I tried my best," and find something else to eat! (Beams proudly) That's a better ending! (Asks teacher enthusiastically) Can *I* write a new ending for the fox? Where he doesn't give up? Pleeeease?

That *is* a much better ending! I like your idea of the fox trying harder or asking for help. And you're right, even if he still couldn't get the grapes, it would be better than just saying they were sour.

So, we can learn that nothing comes easy, and it is not good to hate what you can’t have. You understood the story and the lesson very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about "The Proud Rose."

(Sits down, beaming)

Why do you think the rose was so unkind to the cactus? What did she think was so important?

Yes, that's a great way to put it! She thought she was better because of her looks.

Now, what happened when the weather got really, really hot?

That's a good question. The cactus also needed water. But what was special about the cactus during the hot summer? What did the cactus *do*?

(Thinking hard, fidgets with a pencil) Hmmm... (Looks up, excited) Oh! The birds! The little birdies! They came to the cactus! (Beams) He gave them water! (Confused look) But... how did the cactus HAVE water? (Asks the teacher, brow furrowed) Did he have a secret water bottle hidden somewhere?

So, the cactus was helping the birds. What happened then with the rose? Did she keep being proud?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! (Looks down, a little embarrassed) She was all... (stuttering) ...wi-thered! And sad! (Looks up at the teacher) And... and she asked the cactus for water! (Gasps dramatically) The *cactus*! The one she was mean to! Did he say no? (Asks the teacher anxiously) Did he get mad at her? I would be mad if someone was mean to me and then asked for my help!
That's a great question! What do you think the cactus *should* have done? But first, tell me, what *did* the cactus do?

(Thinking deeply, face scrunched up) Hmmm... what *should* he have done? (Looks up at the ceiling, pondering) Maybe he should have said, "No! You were mean to me! Go away!" (Pouts) That's what I would do! (Suddenly remembers the story) But... but the cactus didn't do that, did he? He... (brightens up) He gave her water! He was nice! Even though she was mean! (Eyes wide with realization) Wow! He was really, really nice!

He was very nice, wasn't he?

So, the rose was mean because she thought she was pretty, but the cactus helped her even though she was unkind. What do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea of the story?

(Jumps up and down excitedly) I know! I know! (Pauses, thinking) The big idea is... (struggling for words) ...is it's important to be nice, even if someone is mean to you! (Claps hands) And... and being pretty doesn't make you better than anyone else! (Looks at the teacher proudly) Is that right? Is that the big idea? (Tilts head, waiting for confirmation) And maybe... maybe you shouldn't judge people by how they look! Like the cactus, he looked prickly, but he was really nice inside!

You got it! You explained that perfectly! The story teaches us that it's not good to judge others based on how they look. The rose learned that the hard way! It's much better to be kind, like the cactus. Great job!<finish>
Okay, so you've read the story of Molly and her milk! What did Molly do with the milk she got from the cows?

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly on my feet) Oh! Oh! I know! Molly... Molly had a lot of milk, right? (Pauses, thinking) She... she was gonna... (looks away, fidgeting with my hands) ...sell it! To get money! Yeah! She wanted to sell the milk and get lots and lots of money! (Looks back at the teacher, smiling brightly) Is that right?
That's right! She was going to sell the milk. What did she start thinking about *while* she was walking to the market? What did she want to buy *with* her money?

(Gasps, excited) Ooh! Ooh! She saw a chicken! (Points excitedly) A clucky, clucky chicken! And she thought... (scrunches up face, thinking hard) ...if she bought the chicken, it could lay eggs! And then she could sell the eggs too! (Beams) And then she'd have even MORE money! (Raises hand enthusiastically) Could I buy a chicken with my milk money too?

That's exactly right! She wanted to buy a chicken so she could sell the eggs and get even MORE money. That was a very clever idea Molly had.

But what happened *while* she was thinking about all the money she would make? How was she walking?

(Starts to skip in place, almost bumping into the table) She was... she was skipping! (Giggles) Like this! She was so happy thinking about all the things she could buy! (Stops skipping abruptly, a little confused) Wait... Did something bad happen when she was skipping? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) I can't remember... Did the chicken run away?
You're right, she *was* skipping because she was so happy! But think... what was she carrying while she was skipping? And what happened to it when she skipped?

(Eyes widen, remembering) Oh! The milk! (Claps hand to mouth) She was carrying the milk in pails! And... and because she was skipping... (Slowly acts out tipping a pail) ...the milk... spilled! All over! Oh no! (Frowns, looking genuinely upset) She lost all her milk! That's so sad! (Looks at the teacher with concern) Did she cry?
Yes, she spilled all the milk! How did she feel when she got to the market? Did she have milk to sell? What did she have?

(Head hangs low, voice quiet) She... she felt sad, I think. (Looks up, a little brighter) Because she didn't have any milk to sell! The pails were all... (makes empty hand gesture) ...empty! She went home with nothing! (Frowns again) That's not very good, is it? Could she get another chicken?
No, it wasn't good at all. She went home with empty pails and no money. What did her mother tell her when she got home? Do you remember? It's okay if you don't!

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the table) Hmmm... Her mommy... (Snaps fingers) Her mommy said... something about chickens! (Looks up hopefully) It was a funny saying! Was it... don't count your chickens before they... something? What was the something? (Looks expectantly at the teacher)
You're so close! Her mother said, "Don't count your chickens before they... *hatch*." Can you say that?

(Repeats the sentence slowly and carefully) Don't... count your chickens... before they hatch! (Beams proudly) I said it! What does it mean? (Tilts head, curious) Does it mean you shouldn't name your chickens before they're born?

That's a very good guess! It means something like that. Think about Molly. She was counting on getting eggs from the chicken *before* she even *bought* the chicken. And before she even sold the milk!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What did Molly do wrong?

(Thinking very hard, furrowing brow) Hmm... So, she was thinking about the eggs... (Looks away, distracted by a colorful poster on the wall) Oh, look! Rainbows! ...Wait, focus! (Brings attention back to the teacher) She was thinking about the eggs before she even had the chicken! And she spilled the milk because she was too busy thinking about the eggs! (Snaps fingers) So... maybe it means you shouldn't... plan too much before you actually do things? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for confirmation) Is that close? Can I go see the rainbows now?

You're getting very close! It means you shouldn't *depend* on something happening until you are *sure* it will happen. Molly *depended* on getting money from the eggs, but she didn't even have the chicken yet! And she hadn't even sold the milk!

So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we learn from Molly's mistake? Try to use the word 'depend'.

(Eyes focused, trying to understand) Okay... so... we shouldn't... (Struggles with the word) ...de...pend... depend on... (Thinking hard) ...getting something... before we... before we actually have it! (Nods, feeling proud of herself) We have to sell the milk *first*, and *then* buy the chicken! Don't depend on the eggs before you have the chicken! (Smiles brightly) I got it! Can I have a sticker now?

You got it! You shouldn't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. Just like Molly shouldn't have depended on the egg money before she even sold the milk or bought the chicken. You understood the story and the lesson very well! <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, tell me, what did the old owl do every day?

(Wiggles in seat, looks around the room) Um... he... (stuttering) he watched stuff? And heard stories? (Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Was that right? He was by a tree, a big... oak tree! Is that important? (Raises hand and waves it excitedly) I know oak trees! My backyard has one! It's super tall!

What kind of secrets?! (Bounces in seat)

(Snaps fingers) Like learning a new word! Or a new story! (Raises hand again, wiggling it) Can I tell you a story I know? It's about a dragon!

That's a wonderful thought! You are absolutely right! When you listen, you can hear new things and learn. Before the dragon story, let's stick with the owl for just a little bit longer.

So, the owl watched and listened, and he became wiser. What do you think the story is trying to teach *us*?

(Leans forward conspiratorially) Except when there's something shiny...

Yes! You got it! The story is teaching us that it's good to listen and watch, just like you listen in class (most of the time!). So, what's another way to say that? What's the big idea, or the main point of the story? It's about talking and watching. Which one should we do *more* of?

(Stands up and starts pacing, thinking out loud) More... more... Okay! (Stops pacing and points a finger in the air) The big idea is... (draws a deep breath) ...listening and watching makes you smart! Like the owl! And like... like detectives! They watch for clues! (Eyes widen) I wanna be a detective! Can we read a detective story next? Does being a detective make you wiser too? (Sits down, bouncing excitedly)
You're so close! Listening and watching *does* make you smart! But the story is also about talking. So how does talking fit in? Should we talk a lot, or a little? Think about what the owl did.

(Thinks really hard, scrunching up nose) Okay... okay... the owl didn't talk much. So... (eyes light up) we should listen *more* than we talk! (Claps hands together) So the big idea is... listen more, talk less, get wise! (Beams proudly) Did I get it right this time? Can we *please* read about detectives now? Or dragons? Maybe a dragon detective?! That would be awesome!
Yes! You got it exactly right! Listen more, talk less, and you'll become wiser. The story is telling us to be observant like the owl. Great job! <finish>

Okay, let's talk about "The Golden Egg" story. You just read it, right?

What did the farmer have?

(Eyes widen, I bounce in my seat a little) Yeah! I read it! It was... interesting!

The farmer... (thinking, taps chin with finger) He had a... umm... a goose! (Confidently) A goose that gave him... shiny... golden eggs! (Looks around the room briefly, distracted by a colourful poster) They were really, really valuable!
That's right! A goose that laid golden eggs. And what did the farmer do with those golden eggs?

(Beaming, hands clasped in front of me) He... (stuttering slightly) s-sold them! He sold the golden eggs! And then... (eyes sparkle) he got lots and lots of money! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Did he buy candy with it? I would buy candy! What would *you* buy, Teacher? (grinning)

Exactly! They lived a comfy life. Now, what happened that made the farmer *stop* having a comfy life? What did he do that wasn't so smart?

You are absolutely right! It's about being happy with what you have and not being greedy. If you're greedy, you might mess things up.

It's also about thinking before you act. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he killed the goose. What could have happened if he just waited and was patient?

That's a great way to put it! Waiting is better than chopping! Because if he had waited, he would have kept getting golden eggs. He didn't think about what would happen. He acted without thinking. Yes! That's a wonderful way to put it! Being fair is very important, and trying to trick people usually doesn't work out in the end.

Another way to say it is, "Cheating will get you nowhere." Do you understand why that fits the story?

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends"!

The father told the girl that these three things were like how we deal with problems.
