(Sniffles, wiping my nose with the back of my hand. I still avoid eye contact, staring at my shoes.)

(Barely audible) I... I don't know. (Shakes my head slightly.)

(After a long pause, I speak a little louder, but still hesitant) Maybe... maybe she could be like... the egg? (Looks up quickly, then down again.) Be... be strong? Even when things are bad? (Looks doubtful) But... being hard seems... not nice.

(Another pause) Or... or she could be like the potato? (Frowns) Be... soft? But... being soft seems... weak. (Kicks my feet under the desk) It's confusing! Which one is the good one? (Looks up at the teacher, pleadingly)

That's a very good question! It's not about which one is "good" or "bad." It's about choosing how *you* want to be when things get tough.

The egg changed itself to become hard. The potato changed itself to become soft. The tea changed the water.

They all reacted to the same problem, but they all changed in different ways.

Does that give you a clue about what the story is trying to teach us?

(My eyes widen a little, and I stop fidgeting as much. I'm still a little nervous, but the tears have stopped.)

(Thinking out loud) So... so it's not about being hard or soft... it's about... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...about changing? (Looks at the teacher, uncertain)

(A small smile starts to form) Like... like the tea! The tea didn't get hard or soft. It changed the *water*! It made something new! (Gets a bit more excited, starting to bounce my leg again.) So... so maybe the story is about... about how we can change things... even when things are hard?

(Looks at the teacher, almost hopeful) Can we be like the tea and change the water?

Yes! You are getting very close!

We can be like the tea and change the water. The water is like the situation, and we can change it, just like the tea did.

So, the story is about how we can choose how we react to problems. We can choose to become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or change the situation like the tea.

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to tell us? What's the big idea, the lesson?

(I sit up straighter, and my voice is a little stronger now.)

(With a thoughtful expression) So... so the story is saying... that when things are hard... (pauses, looking around the room) ...we can choose... (slowly) ...how we want to be.

(I smile a little bit, finally understanding.) We can choose to be strong, like the egg. Or... or we can choose to be... to be kind, even when things are bad, like the potato.

(I pause, thinking about the tea.) Or... or we can choose to... (eyes light up) ...to make things better! Like the tea! We can change the water, and make things better for everyone!

(Looks at the teacher, with a newfound confidence) So... the story is about choosing! Choosing how we want to be when we have problems! (Beams, proud of myself) I got it! I really got it!

Yes! You got it! That's exactly right!

We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be strong, kind, or try to make things better. It's our choice!

You did such a great job figuring that out. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

Okay, fantastic! You've finished reading "The Needle Tree." That was a good story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. Who are the main people in the story?

(Bouncing in my seat, a little too eagerly) Yes! Yes, it was a good story! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Uhm... (Stuttering a little) There were... two... two brothers! (Confidently) One was... mean! And the other one... was... nice! (Fidgets with my hands, avoids eye contact) Are... are there any more? Did I... did I get it right?

You got it! Two brothers. One mean, one nice. Perfect!

What did the mean brother do in the forest?

(Eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) Oh! Oh! (Starts to get out of my seat) He went to... to chop... chop wood! (Sits back down, a little deflated) For... for the market! He wanted to sell it! (Looks around, distracted by something shiny on the desk) Uhm... what was I saying? (Looks back at the teacher, nervously)
You were doing great! He chopped wood to sell at the market. And then what did he find? Something special! Do you remember?

(Gasps, remembers) Oh! (Starts to get excited again, bouncing slightly) He found a... a... (Frowns, struggling) A... magical... (Whispers) tree! (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) Is... is that right? It was a magical tree, right? (Pulls at my sleeve)
Yes! A magical tree! You remembered! What did the tree ask the mean brother?

(Wrinkles nose, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Looks down at my shoes) The tree... the tree didn't want to be... (Voice trails off) ...cut down! (Looks up, suddenly remembers) It... it said it would give him... (Eyes widen) ...golden apples! Shiny golden apples! (Claps hands together)
Shiny golden apples! That's right! Did the mean brother like the apples?

(Frowns, remembering the mean brother's reaction) No! (Shakes head vigorously) He was... (Searches for the right word) ...disap... disap... (Looks at the teacher, pleadingly) He wasn't happy! He wanted... more! (Crosses arms, mimicking the mean brother) He was greedy! (Gets a worried look on my face) Is... is it bad to be greedy?
Good job using that word, "greedy"! And yes, being greedy isn't usually a good thing. What happened when the mean brother got greedy and tried to cut down the tree anyway?

(Gasps, eyes wide with a little bit of fear) Oh no! (Hides face for a second, then peeks out) The tree... the tree got mad! (Voice trembles) And it... and it gave him... (Whispers) ...needles! So many needles! (Shivers) It must have hurt so much! (Looks up at the teacher, anxiously) Did... did it really hurt?
It sounds like it hurt a lot! What happened after he was covered in needles? Who came to help him?

(Sniffles, remembering the sad part) Uhm... (Looks down, tracing patterns on the carpet with my shoe) His... his brother... the nice brother... (Voice cracks) He... he came and... and took all the needles out! (Looks up, tears welling in my eyes) It... it was so nice of him! Even though his brother was... was mean! (Wipes eyes with sleeve)
That was very kind of him, wasn't it? Why do you think the nice brother helped him even though the mean brother wasn't very nice?

(Sniffles again, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Looks at the teacher, confused) Because... because he was his... his brother? (Shrugs shoulders) Brothers are supposed to... to help each other? (Looks down, worried) Even if they're... mean? (Anxious tone) I'm not always nice to my sister... does that mean I'm a bad brother?

It's normal to not always be perfectly nice. The important thing is that you *try* to be kind.

So, the nice brother helped the mean brother. What happened *after* the nice brother helped him? Did the mean brother stay mean?

(Looks up, relieved) No! (Shakes head, more confidently) He said... he said sorry! (Smiles a little) He said he wouldn't be mean anymore! (Pauses, thinking) And then... and then the tree gave them... more golden apples! (Claps hands softly, happy) Because... because the mean brother was nice now! (Looks at the teacher, with a hopeful expression) Does that mean the tree forgave him?
Yes, it does seem like the tree forgave him. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson?

(Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, biting my lip nervously) Uhm... (Struggles to find the words) That... that being mean... is... is bad? (Looks at the teacher, searching for approval) And... and that saying sorry... is... good? (Frowns, like I'm missing something) And... and that even if someone is mean to you... you should still... still help them? (Looks down, twiddling my thumbs) Is... is that it? I don't really know...
You're on the right track! Think about what happened *because* the nice brother was kind, and because the mean brother said sorry. What did they get?

(Eyes light up) Oh! Oh! (Bounces in my seat) They got... more golden apples! (Thinks for a moment, brow furrowed) So... so being kind and saying sorry... (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious again) ...makes good things happen? Like... like golden apples? (Tilts head, confused)
Exactly! Being kind and saying sorry made good things happen. So, what could we say is the lesson of the story in one sentence? What does the story tell us about kindness?

(Stares blankly, overwhelmed) Uhm... (Starts to fidget, picking at my fingernails) One... one sentence? (Looks at the teacher, pleadingly) That's... that's too hard! (Voice gets shaky) I don't... I don't know! (Tears well up again) Can... can you help me?

Okay, okay, don't worry! Let's think about it this way: What happens when you *are* kind? Does something good usually happen? The story showed us that when you are kind, you get rewarded. So, how can we say that in a short sentence?

(Sniffles, wipes eyes) Okay... (Thinking very hard, concentrating) If... if you're kind... (Pauses, struggling) ...good things... happen... to you? (Looks at the teacher, anxiously) Is... is that right?
That's very close! How about this: Kindness... is rewarded. Kindness means you get something good back. Does that make sense?

(Eyes widen, a little light bulb goes on) Kindness... (Repeats slowly) ...is... re...warded! (Smiles, understanding) Like... like the golden apples! (Claps hands softly, relieved) I get it! (Bounces in my seat) Kindness is rewarded! Yay!
You got it! "Kindness is rewarded" is the lesson of the story! You worked so hard to understand that. I'm very proud of you! <finish>

Okay, [Student's Name], you just finished reading "The Golden Touch"! That was quite a story, wasn't it?

Can you tell me, who was the main character in the story?

(Wiggles in seat, looks around the room) Uh... (points finger up in the air excitedly) Midas! King Midas! He was the...the one who... (trails off, looking at the teacher expectantly). He was the main one! (Confidently)

Yes! You got it! King Midas was the main character.

Now, what did King Midas wish for?

(Eyes widen, bounces knees) Oh! Oh! I know! He wished... he wished... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard) ...for...everything... (voice trails off, looks at hands)...to be gold! (Looks up at teacher brightly) Everything he touched! To be...shiny! (Beams proudly)

Excellent! You remembered that perfectly. He wished for everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, tell me, at first, did King Midas like his golden touch?

(Nods head vigorously, almost falling off chair) Yes! Yes! He liked it! He was happy! (Claps hands together) He touched everything! (Starts to reach out to touch the teacher's pen, then stops, giggling). Shiny! Gold! Everywhere! (Confidently) He was... uh... (scratches head)... he was happy! At first! (Looks at teacher for approval)

You're right! He *was* happy at first. He thought it was a wonderful thing.

But... did he *stay* happy? What happened after he touched lots of things?

(Frowns slightly, looks down at shoes) Uh... (stuttering) He... he got... um... (looks back up, a little worried) He got... hungry! (voice gets quieter) And... and his... food turned to gold! (Eyes widen again, this time with a bit of fear) He couldn't eat! (Shakes head slowly) That's... that's not good. (Looks at teacher, wanting reassurance)

That's right! He got hungry, and his food turned to gold. He couldn't eat!

And what else happened that made him sad? Think about his daughter.

(Gasps, covers mouth with hand) Oh no! (Eyes start to water a little) His daughter! (Voice cracks) She...she hugged him! (Looks down, fiddling with fingers) And she turned...into gold too! (Looks up at the teacher, voice small) That's...that's very sad. (Sniffles quietly)

Yes, it was very sad. His daughter turned to gold.

So, [Student's Name], did the golden touch make King Midas happy in the end?

(Shakes head vehemently, sniffling) No! (Wipes eyes with back of hand) It made him... sad! (Frowns deeply) He couldn't eat, and his daughter... was gold! (Looks away, thinking) It wasn't a good wish. (Confidently) He was wrong to want it!

You're absolutely right. It wasn't a good wish, and he was wrong to want it.

Why do you think he was wrong to want it? What made him make that wish in the first place?

(Shrugs, looks at the ceiling) Uh... (Thinking hard) Because... because gold is... (searches for the right word)... shiny! (Beams, proud of finding a word) And... and he wanted lots of shiny things! (Frowns again) But shiny things... are not as good as... (looks at the teacher, seeking help)... food! And... and hugs! (Confidently) He didn't think about that! He just wanted shiny! (Nods head, satisfied with explanation)

That's a great answer! He just wanted shiny things, and he didn't think about what was truly important, like food and hugs from his daughter.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea or lesson it teaches us?

(Wiggles in seat, looks around again, distracted) Uh... (Points finger up in the air) Don't wish for too much gold? (Giggles) (Looks at teacher expectantly) Or... (Thinking hard) Or... maybe... shiny things aren't the most important things? (Looks down at shoes, then back up, confidently) Maybe... being happy with what you have is better! Yeah! That's it! Being happy! (Beams proudly)

That's a wonderful lesson to learn from the story! Being happy with what you have is very important. The story shows us that wanting too much, or being too greedy, can actually make you unhappy. Do you know what the word 'Greed' means?

(Tilts head, looks puzzled) Greed? (Looks at teacher expectantly, hoping for an explanation) Is that like... wanting all the candy? (Eyes widen) Even if other people don't get any? (Looks worried) Is it... is it bad? (Voice is softer, a little unsure)

Yes, that's a great way to understand it! Greed is like wanting all the candy, even if it means others don't get any. It's wanting more and more and more, and never being satisfied. And yes, it can be bad, because, as we saw in the story, it can make you unhappy and even hurt the people you love.

So, can you tell me in your own words what the story of King Midas teaches us about greed?

(Nods head slowly, thinking hard. Then, a flash of understanding) Okay! Okay! I get it! (Becomes more confident) King Midas was greedy! He wanted ALL the gold! (Holds hands out wide). But then... he couldn't eat! And his daughter... (voice gets quiet) So... being greedy... is bad! (Looks at teacher seriously) Because it makes you sad and... and you might lose the things you really love! (Nods head decisively) Yeah! Greed is not good! (Beams, proud of understanding)

You got it! That's exactly right! King Midas was greedy, and it made him very unhappy. He lost the things he loved most. So, the story teaches us that greed leads to unhappiness. You understood that so well!

I think you've really understood the story of the Golden Touch and what it means. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Fox and the Grapes."

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Smiling brightly, but fidgeting with my hands)

Um... the fox? He was... (looks away, scratching my head) looking for... um... yummy things! Like... (stuttering) things to eat! Yes! He was hungry and wanted... food!
Yes! You got it! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

(Eyes widen, excited)

Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Jumping up and down a little bit) He found... grapes! Big, purple, juicy grapes! (Uses hands to show how big the grapes were) They looked SO good! (Looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Were they Concord grapes? My mom buys those sometimes... they're really... (Teacher gently redirects my attention) Oh! Sorry! Grapes! Lots of grapes!
Yes, lots of grapes! They looked very yummy. So, what did the fox try to do?

(Confidently)

He wanted to EAT them! (Sticks tongue out like I'm trying to reach something) He jumped and jumped and jumped! (Starts miming jumping really high, almost bumping into the desk) He wanted those grapes SO bad!
You're right! He jumped and jumped. Did he get the grapes?

(Frowning, then quickly perking up)

Um... (looks down at my shoes, kicking them slightly) no? He... he couldn't reach! (Voice gets softer) He tried really hard, but... (looks back up, smiling again) the grapes were too high! Were they REALLY high? Like, higher than a house? (leans forward, curious)
They were high enough that the fox couldn't reach them no matter how hard he tried. So, what did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin)

After? Hmm... He... (looks around the room again, then back at the teacher) Did he ask the farmer for help? No... (shaking head) He... he went home! Yeah! He went home! (Confidently) Because he was tired from all the jumping!
He did go home! And what did he say about the grapes *as* he was going home? Do you remember?

(Eyes widen, remembering something)

Oh! Oh! (Snapping fingers) He said... he said they were... (Stuttering slightly) sour! Yeah! He said the grapes were sour anyway! (Looks pleased with myself) They weren't even good grapes! He didn't WANT them anymore!
That's right! He said they were sour. Now, why do you think he said that? The story says they looked big and juicy.

(Tilts head, thinking)

(Looks away, distracted by the window for a second)

Hmm... Why did he say that? (Thinking really hard) Was he... was he sad he couldn't get them? (Looks back at the teacher, hopefully) But he didn't want to *say* he was sad, so he said they were yucky instead? So it wouldn't matter that he couldn't reach them?

That's a really good idea! He *was* probably sad. So, he said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad.

Do you think that was a good thing to do?

(Shrugs shoulders)

I don't know... (Looks down at my hands, picking at my nails) Maybe? (Looks back up, smiling again) If he didn't want to be sad, then it was good! But... (Thinking again, furrowing brow) But maybe it would be better to just say you're sad? I don't know! (Gestures with hands, confused)

That's a very thoughtful answer. Sometimes it's hard to know what to do.

This story teaches us that it's okay to be sad when we can't get something we want. And it also teaches us something else: Sometimes, if we can't have something, we shouldn't just pretend we didn't want it in the first place. The fox couldn't get the grapes, so he said they were sour.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking hard, almost sticking my tongue out)

(Looks at the teacher, then back down at my hands)

Um... that... (Stuttering slightly) it's okay to want things? Even if you can't get them? And... (Looks back up, more confidently) and don't say mean things about the grapes just because you're mad! Because... maybe they WERE yummy! (Smiles brightly) The story is telling us to be honest!

You're getting very close! The story is about being honest, and it's also about trying your best. The fox tried his best to get the grapes, but he couldn't. The story wants us to remember that not everything is easy to get. And if we can't have something, we shouldn't pretend it's bad just to make ourselves feel better.

Can you tell me in your own words what the story is about?

(Giggles a little, then gets serious)

Okay! (Takes a deep breath) The story is about a fox who wanted grapes! (Uses hands to show big, round grapes) But he couldn't reach them! (Makes a sad face) And then he said they were sour! (Makes a yucky face) But... but maybe they weren't! (Looks thoughtful) So the story is telling us to... to try hard! And... (Gets distracted by a buzzing fly near the window) Is that a fly? It's a BIG fly!

(After a pause, teacher gently redirects my attention)

Oh! Sorry! (Focuses back on the teacher) So the story is telling us to try hard and... and be honest even if we don't get the grapes!
Yes! That's a great way to say it. Try hard, and be honest, even if you don't get what you want. Nothing comes easy, and don't hate what you can't have. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

So, tell me, who are the main characters in our story?
(Eyes light up, beaming a big smile) Ooh! Ooh! I know! It's... it's the rose! (Points finger excitedly) And... and the cactus! (Wiggles in seat) The pretty rose and the... the other one.

Yes! The rose and the cactus. You remembered perfectly.

Now, can you tell me, what was the rose like at the start of the story? Was she nice?

(Starts to run around, but quickly comes back, smiling brightly) The rose? (Stands still, but can't stop wiggling). Nooo! (Shakes head emphatically) She wasn't nice! She... she was... (pauses, looks around the room, then back at the teacher, beaming) ...mean! To the cactus! (Confidently) She said mean things because she thought she was pretty! (Jumps up and down) I wouldn't say mean things!

You're right! She *was* mean. She thought she was better than the cactus because she was pretty.

What did the rose *do* that made her mean? What did she say to the cactus?

(Eyes dart around, looking at posters on the wall, then back at the teacher) Hmmm... (Scrunches up nose, trying to remember). She... she said... (Stutters slightly) I... I don't remember the *exact* words. But she said... (Voice gets high-pitched and a little sassy) "You're ugly and I'm pretty!" (Giggles and covers mouth with hand) Something like that! She thought she was the prettiest!

That's a *very* good way to put it! The rose thought she was the prettiest and the cactus was ugly.

Now, what happened when the summer got really hot? What was the problem?

(Eagerly) Ooh! Ooh! (Waves hand excitedly). I know! It got super hot! (Wipes forehead dramatically). And there was NO water! (Eyes widen) The rose... the rose started to get all droopy! (Slumps shoulders to demonstrate). Like this! (Stands up straight again, beaming). Because she didn't have any water!

Exactly! The rose needed water.

And what about the cactus? Did the cactus need water? What was happening with the cactus?

(Looks around, fiddling with fingers) The cactus... (Thinks hard, chewing on lip) Oh! The cactus... (Beams suddenly) He had water! For the birdies! (Points to the window) The birdies came and drank from him! (Wiggles excitedly) He was helping them! (Confidently) I like to help people too!

That's right! The cactus was helping the birds. The cactus had water, even when it was hot.

So, the rose is droopy and needs water, and the cactus has water for the birds. What happens next? What does the rose do?

(Bounces up and down, almost unable to contain excitement) Ooh! Ooh! She asks the cactus! (Gasps dramatically) She asks him for water! Even though she was mean to him before! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, beaming)

Yes! She asks the cactus for water!

And does the cactus give her water?

(Nods head super fast and enthusiastically) YES! (Claps hands). The cactus is nice! He gives her water! (Beams proudly) Even though she wasn't nice to him! He's a good cactus! (Looks at teacher expectantly) Is that right?

That's absolutely right! The cactus *was* very nice. He helped the rose, even after she was mean to him.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the rose and the cactus? Think about how the rose acted at the beginning and how the cactus acted.

(Looks down at shoes, then back at the teacher, chewing on lip) Hmmm... (Thinking hard). It's... it's about... (Looks around, distracted by a noise in the hallway, then refocuses) ...being nice! (Eyes light up) Even if someone is mean to you! The cactus was still nice! (Beams proudly) And... and... (Pauses, trying to find the words) ...and maybe... don't be mean like the rose! (Giggles nervously) Is that it?

That's a *very* good start! Being nice is definitely important. And you're right, we shouldn't be mean like the rose.

But there's a little bit more to it. Why was the rose mean to the cactus in the first place? What did she think about the cactus?

(Eyes light up, points finger) Ooh! Ooh! Because she thought she was prettier! (Slight pause) She thought she was better than the cactus. (Thinks for a second) So... so it's also about... not thinking you're better than other people? (Looks at the teacher, seeking approval) Because everyone needs help sometimes! Even the pretty rose needed help!

You're getting *so* close! You're exactly right - everyone needs help sometimes. And the rose thought she was better because she thought she *looked* better.

So, what's the lesson about judging people based on how they look?

(Looks down, wiggles toes in shoes, then looks back up, beaming) Ooh! Ooh! (Claps hands once) It's about... not judging! (Confidently) Don't judge people by how they look! (Points a finger for emphasis) Because even if they don't look pretty like a rose, they can still be nice and helpful, like the cactus! (Smiles proudly) And... and looks don't matter as much as being kind! Is that right?
YES! That's perfect! Don't judge people by how they look. It's much better to be kind like the cactus! You understood the story so well. <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! So, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Wriggles in seat, looks around the room) Um, (stuttering) she was gonna, like, sell it? At the... the place where people buy stuff? (Looks at teacher with big, hopeful eyes). The market! Yeah, the market!
Yes, that's right! She was going to sell it at the market. And what did she start thinking about *while* she was going to the market?

(Eyes light up, leans forward eagerly) Ooooh, I know! I know! She was thinking about all the stuff she was gonna buy! (Starts bouncing leg excitedly). Like... like a chicken! And then... and then she could sell the chicken's... uh... (trails off, looking confused) what do chickens make again? (Looks expectantly at the teacher).
Good job remembering the chicken! What do chickens give us that we can eat? Think about what you might have for breakfast.

(Gasps, face brightens) Eggs! Yeah, eggs! She was gonna sell the eggs! And then she'd have even MORE money! (Beams proudly at the teacher) And then, and then, she was gonna make all the other milkmaids jealous! (Giggles, then quickly covers mouth with hand, a little embarrassed).
That's right! She had big plans. So, what happened to the milk while she was thinking about all of that?

(Starts to fidget, picks at a loose thread on clothes) Um... (looks away, thinking hard) I... I think she was... skipping? (Voice gets quieter) And then... (eyes widen with sudden realization) Oh no! Did she... did she spill it? (Looks back at the teacher with a worried expression). All of it?
Yes, she was skipping, and she spilled the milk. What did she have left when she got to the market?

(Sighs dramatically, slumps back in chair) Nothing! (Voice is sad). She had... (counts on fingers, then looks up miserably) Zero! Just an empty bucket. (Looks at teacher with a small frown). That's not very good, is it?
No, it wasn't very good. How do you think Molly felt when she had no milk and no money?

(Pouts, thinking) Sad! (Nods emphatically). Really, really sad. 'Cause she wanted all those things, and she spilled everything! (Looks at the teacher with wide, sympathetic eyes) I would be sad too! (Suddenly perks up) But maybe she can get more milk tomorrow! (Smiles brightly).
That's a good thought. Now, what did her mother say to her when she got home?

(Concentrates, chewing on lip) Hmmm... her mom said... (face scrunches up in thought) it was something about... (snaps fingers) chickens! Yeah! Something about not... not counting the chickens... (trails off again, looking frustrated) until... until they... (eyes widen) hatch! (Beams proudly) I remembered!
You did remember! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means? Why did her mother say that?

(Tilts head to the side, considering) Hmmm... (taps chin thoughtfully). It means... (pauses, looking at the ceiling) ...don't, like... don't get excited about something... (looks back at the teacher) before it happens? (Voice is hesitant) Like, don't buy the chicken in your head until you *actually* have the money from the milk? Is that right? (Looks at the teacher hopefully).
You're getting very close! It means don't depend on something good happening until you are sure it *will* happen. Was Molly sure she would get the chicken and the eggs?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! (Looks determined). She was just thinking about it in her head! (Points to head). She didn't even have the money yet! (Voice gets louder with enthusiasm). So, she shouldn't have been all happy and skipping! She should have been careful with the milk! (Nods sagely).
Exactly! So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we learn from Molly's mistake?

(Eyes dart around the room, then settle on the teacher) We should... (takes a deep breath) ...we should be careful! (Nods firmly). And not get too excited about things that might not happen! (Looks thoughtful). We should, like... wait until the chickens hatch before we start counting them! (Grins proudly, pleased with self). And maybe... maybe not skip so much when we're carrying milk! (Giggles).
You got it! That's a great way to put it. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, [User's Name], that was a great reading! Now, let's talk about the owl.

What did the old owl like to do every day?

(Wiggles in seat, eyes darting around the room) Uh... the owl... (looks away) ...saw things? Like... around his tree? (Confidently) Yeah! He saw things! A lot of things! And people talked! (Beams at the teacher, waiting for approval)
Yes! You're exactly right. He saw things happening around his tree. And what else did he do? You said it! What did the people do?

(Eyes widen, excited) They talked! (Points at the teacher) Like we're talking now! They told... (Stuttering) ...sto... sto... stories! (Looks down at hands, fidgeting) Were they good stories? I like stories! (Looks up hopefully)
That's right! They told stories. The story doesn't say if they were good stories or not. But the owl *heard* them. Now, did the owl talk a lot?
(Bursts out) NO! (Looks surprised at own loudness, then giggles) He didn't talk a lot! He... he listened! (Pulls on sleeve) Was he a quiet owl? I'm not very quiet. (Grins)
He was a very quiet owl! And because he watched and listened, what happened to the owl? The story tells us.

(Thinking, brow furrowed) He... (Looks around the room again, distracted by a colourful poster) ... he saw more things? And heard more stories? (Shrugs) I don't know! (Confidently) Maybe he saw a squirrel! Squirrels are funny!
He did see more things and hear more stories! And that helped him to become something. The story uses a special word. What did he become? Was he silly? Was he grumpy?

(Shakes head vigorously) Not silly! Not grumpy! (Thinking hard, taps chin) Was he... (Eyes light up) ...wise! (Beams) He was a wise owl! Because he listened! Did listening make him wise? Is that like when I listen to you reading? (Points at the book excitedly)

Yes! Listening made him wise. Just like listening to stories helps you learn things. So, the owl watched and listened more than he talked. And that made him wise.

So, what do you think we can learn from the wise old owl? What's the story trying to tell us?

(Bounces in seat, eager to answer) We should listen! (Points to ears) And... and... (Struggling) ...watch? Like the owl? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) If we listen and watch, we can be wise too! Can I be wise like the owl? Will I know lots of things if I listen to all the stories? (Giggles) Maybe I'll know everything!

You've got it! Listening and watching can help us learn lots of things and become wise.

Now, the owl didn't talk much. He listened. So, maybe another way to say the lesson is... try to talk less and... what? What should we do *more* of?

(Jumps up and down slightly) Listen! (Points at the teacher again) We should listen more! I'm good at talking! But I can try to listen more too! (Suddenly remembers something) Oh! Can we read another story now? Maybe one with a puppy! (Looks hopeful)
You are right! We should listen more and talk less. And watching is important too. You understood the story of the wise old owl very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg!

So, tell me, what kind of animal laid the golden egg?

(Bouncing in my seat, excited)

A goose! (Points finger up in the air confidently) It was a golden... a golden egg...laying goose! (Looks at teacher, beaming) The farmer got the egg every day! (Starts to get out of my seat, ready to talk about the farmer)

That's right! A golden egg-laying goose.

And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?

(Starts fiddling with my pencil, losing focus a little bit)

He... (looks away, thinking)... he did something with it. (Stutters) It was... it was shiny! He... (eyes light up again, remembering) He sold it! (Points at the teacher again, enthusiastically) He sold the golden egg! And then he had money! (Almost stands up, wiggling with excitement)

Yes! He sold it and had money.

Did the farmer and his wife need a lot of money at the beginning?

(Starts drawing little doodles on my paper, not really paying attention)

Umm... (pauses, thinking) No... (Looks at the teacher, trying to remember) They... they had a little bit of money. (Sounds unsure) But they wanted... (eyes widen with sudden excitement) MORE! They wanted a BIG pile of money! (Stands up halfway again, then sits back down, realizing I shouldn't)

You're right! They wanted more. They were doing okay, right? But they wanted to be richer.

What did the farmer decide to do to get more golden eggs?

(Starts tapping my foot under the table, getting restless)

He... (pauses, looking at the ceiling)... He did something... (starts to whisper) something not nice... (looks at the teacher, a little worried) He wanted all the eggs... RIGHT NOW! (Voice gets louder again, excited) So he... (hesitates, then blurts out) He cut the goose! (covers mouth with hand, eyes wide).
Yes, he cut the goose. Why did he do that? What did he think he would find?

(Pushes my chair back a little bit, making a small screech, a bit distracted by the sound)

He thought... (starts to trace the outline of my hand on the paper) He thought there were lots of eggs! (Looks up, excited) Like... like a treasure chest, full of golden eggs! (Starts humming quietly to myself) He wanted to be super rich! (Forgets the question for a second, then remembers) Oh! That's why he cut the goose!
Okay, and what *did* he find when he cut the goose?

(Swings my legs under the table, losing focus again)

He... (Stares at the teacher blankly for a second) Hmmm... He found... (Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) Something yucky! (Wrinkles my nose in disgust) Not... not gold. (Looks up at the teacher again) It was... blood! (Makes a face) And... and guts! (Shudders dramatically). He didn't find any eggs!

That's right. He found blood and guts. No golden eggs.

So, after he cut the goose, did he get richer or poorer?

(Stands up completely this time, then quickly sits back down when I remember the rules)

Poorer! (Shouts the answer loudly) Much poorer! (Leans forward eagerly) Because... because he didn't have any golden eggs anymore! The goose was... was gone! (Looks sad for a second) So, he couldn't sell any more eggs! No more money! (Starts drumming on the desk with my fingers).

Exactly! He got poorer.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What is the story trying to teach us? Think about the farmer.

(Rocks back and forth in my chair, thinking hard)

Ummm... (Sticks my tongue out a little, concentrating) It's... it's about... (Eyes widen, remembering something) Being greedy! (Points at the teacher) The farmer was greedy! He wanted too much! (Voice gets louder) And then he got nothing! (Starts to draw circles on my paper again) So... so we shouldn't be greedy! (Looks up, smiling proudly).

That's a big part of it! It's definitely about being greedy.

But it's also about *thinking* before you *do* something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut the goose. He just wanted more, more, more!

So, what could the farmer have done differently? What should he have thought about?

(Starts to spin my pencil on the desk, a little distracted)

He should have... (pauses, thinking) ...been happy with the one egg! (Looks at the teacher, surprised at my own answer) Yeah! He should have been happy! (Snaps my fingers) And... and he should have thanked the goose! (Beams with excitement) Instead of... (makes a cutting motion with my hand, then shudders) ...that! (Looks at the teacher, expecting praise)

That's excellent! You're exactly right. He should have been happy with what he had and thought about what would happen *before* he did something silly.

So, the story teaches us to think before we act. If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realised he was making a mistake.

Can you tell me in your own words what the story of the Golden Egg is about and what it teaches us?

(Bounces up and down in my seat again, ready to talk more)

Okay! Okay! The story is about a farmer and a goose! (Points enthusiastically) And the goose laid a golden egg! (Holds up one finger) And the farmer sold it! (Pretends to put money in my pocket) But the farmer was greedy! (Frowns dramatically) And he wanted more eggs! (Makes grabbing motion) So he cut the goose! (Gasps) And he found yucky stuff! (Wrinkles nose) And then he was poor! (Looks sad for a second) So the story teaches us to be happy with what we have! (Beams again) And not to be greedy! (Nods head seriously) And to think before we cut a goose! (Giggles)

Wonderful! You understood the story perfectly and you explained the lesson very well. You know that the moral of the story is 'Think before you act', and what happens if we don't think before we act. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Now, let's talk about it. Who bought something in the story?

(Smiling brightly) The farmer! The farmer did! He bought... he bought the well! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, grinning). He wanted water for his farm! It was a big well, I think. (Starts to wiggle in my seat, barely able to contain my excitement). Is there a picture of the farm? (My voice trails off as I think about the picture).

Yes, the farmer bought the well! Good job.

Why did the farmer buy the well? You said it!

(Beaming) Because...because he needed water! (Confidently) For his farm! The farm needed water to grow all the yummy stuff! (Taps fingers on the table, then blurts out) Like tomatoes! And...and carrots! Do you like carrots, Teacher? My mom makes them in soup! (Starts to stand up a little, then quickly sits back down, remembering I should stay in my seat).

That's right! He needed water for his farm to grow yummy things like tomatoes and carrots!

Now, after the farmer bought the well, what happened? Did he get to use the water?

(Frowning slightly, thinking hard) Um... (looks away, distracted by a colorful poster on the wall for a moment) He bought the well... but... (stuttering slightly) but the neighbor... the neighbor was being mean! He didn't... he didn't let the farmer get the water! (My voice gets louder and more excited again) That's not fair! If you buy a well, you should get the water, right? Right?
You are absolutely right! It wasn't fair. Why do you think the neighbor didn't let the farmer use the water?

(Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Hmmm... (Looks down at my shoes, then back up at the teacher) Because... because he was tricky! (Confidently) He thought he was super smart! He thought he could keep the water even though the farmer bought the well! (Stands up a bit, then catches myself and sits back down) He was trying to trick the farmer! Was that a good trick, Teacher? (Looks expectantly, eager for approval). I don't think so.

You're right, it wasn't a good trick. It was a *bad* trick.

So, the farmer couldn't get water. What did he do then? Where did he go?

(Eyes widen, remembering the exciting part) He went to the emperor! (Bounces in my seat) The emperor is like the super-important boss person! He went to tell him about the mean neighbor! (Leans forward, whispering) He went to get justice! That means... that means... (struggling to explain) ...to make things fair again! (Looks to the teacher for confirmation, beaming). The emperor has a really cool crown, right? (Wiggles fingers in the air, imitating a crown).

Yes! The emperor is a very important person, and you're right, the farmer went to him to make things fair again.

What did the emperor's helper (the courtier) do to help the farmer? What did he ask the neighbor?

(Thinking, head tilted) The courtier...the courtier talked to the neighbor! (Pauses, trying to remember) He asked... he asked... (Struggles to recall the details, getting distracted by my shoelaces) He asked about the well! (Suddenly remembers with a burst of excitement) He asked if the neighbor sold the water too! Did he? Did he sell the water? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for a quick answer so I can keep talking).

Good remembering! You are right, the courtier asked about the water.

What did the *neighbor* say about the water? Did he say he sold it, or not?

(Eyes widen again, remembering the sneaky part) He said... he said he *didn't* sell the water! (Makes a surprised face) He said he only sold the well, not the water inside! He thought he was so clever! (Shakes my head, disapprovingly) That's still not fair! If you sell a well, you should sell the water too, right? (Looks at the teacher for agreement, eager to continue the story). The neighbor was being super tricky!

He was trying to be tricky!

What did the courtier say *back* to the neighbor then? This is the clever part!

(Eyes dart around the room, thinking hard. Then, a huge grin spreads across my face). Oh! Oh! I know! (Bounces in my seat) The courtier said... he said the neighbor had to... had to pay rent! (Confidently) For the water! Or... or take all the water away RIGHT AWAY! (Claps my hands together) That was so smart! The neighbor didn't want to pay rent or take the water away, so he knew he was caught! He was so silly! (Stands up a little again, then quickly sits down, giggling).

That *was* clever!

So what happened to the neighbor in the end?

(Smiling, remembering the ending) He... he said he was sorry! (Looks away, then back at the teacher) He knew he messed up! He said he wouldn't be mean anymore. And... (pauses, tapping my fingers) and he went home! (Beaming) The farmer got his water, right? Did the farmer grow lots of tomatoes and carrots? (Eagerly awaits the answer, ready to imagine all the delicious food).

Yes, the farmer could finally use the well!

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What did we learn from the farmer and the tricky neighbor?

(Thinking hard, frowns slightly) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, distracted by a buzzing fly for a moment, then focuses back on the teacher) It... it teaches us that... (Struggling to find the words) ...that it's not good to be tricky! (Confidently) You should be fair! (Adds quickly) And... and if someone is being mean, you should ask for help! Like the farmer did! He went to the emperor! (Beaming) Is that right, Teacher? Is that what the story means? I think it's a good story! (Starts to wiggle again, excited to move on to something else). Can we read another story now? About a dragon, maybe?

You're very close! The story shows us that being tricky or cheating doesn't work out in the end. The neighbor *thought* he was being clever, but it backfired on him.

So, we can say the story teaches us that... cheating will get you nowhere.

Do you understand?

(Nods enthusiastically) Yes! (Confidently) Cheating is bad! Like when you peek at someone's paper during a test! (Eyes widen) Is that cheating, Teacher? (Leans in conspiratorially) I saw someone do that once! (Immediately sits back, remembering to stay on topic) So, yeah! Cheating doesn't work. The neighbor was cheating the farmer, and he got in trouble! (Beams) I understand! Can we draw a picture of the farmer now? Or maybe the emperor's crown! It must be so sparkly! (Starts to reach for a crayon).
Okay, you understood the story and what it means! Great job today. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story, little one! That was "Elephant and Friends."

Now, can you tell me... why was the elephant lonely at the beginning?

(Wiggles in my seat, looking around the room) Um... (thinking) because... because nobody wanted to be his friend! (Confidently) He was all by himself! He wanted someone to play with, but... (looks away, distracted by a colorful poster) ...but the monkey wouldn't, and the rabbit wouldn't, and the frog... (Stops talking and stares at the poster).

That's right! He was all alone.

Why didn't the monkey want to be his friend? What was the reason the monkey gave?

(Snaps back to attention, almost jumping in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! (Raises hand excitedly) The monkey... the monkey said the elephant couldn't... couldn't swing in the trees! (Stands up a little in excitement) He said, "You're too big to swing!" (Sits back down, beaming.) The elephant was too big!

Excellent! You remembered that very well.

And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Starts to fidget with my shoelaces) The rabbit... (pauses, thinking hard) The rabbit... hmm... (Looks up, then back at my shoelaces) Oh! The rabbit said he was too... too big to fit in the burrow! (Confidently) He couldn't fit in the rabbit's house! The elephant was too big again! (Giggles)

You are doing a super job! Yes, the elephant was too big for the burrow.

So, the monkey said he was too big to swing, and the rabbit said he was too big for the burrow. How did the elephant probably feel when he heard all of this?

(Pulls on my sleeve) Um... (Thinking) Maybe... maybe sad? (Looks up at the teacher for approval) He wanted friends, but nobody wanted to play with him 'cause he was too big! (My voice gets quieter) Maybe he felt... lonely. Like at the beginning of the story! (Looks down at my hands)

Yes, you are exactly right! He probably felt very sad and lonely. Good job using those feelings words.

Now, something interesting happened the next day. What happened in the forest that made all the animals scared?

(Eyes widen, sits up straight, forgets about the shoelaces) Oh! Oh! A tiger! (Voice gets louder) A big, scary tiger was chasing everyone! (Starts to get out of my seat a little) They were all running away and screaming! The tiger was going to get them! (Looks at the teacher, excited)
That's right! A scary tiger was chasing them. And who stopped the tiger?

(Confidently) The elephant did! (Points enthusiastically) The elephant stopped the tiger! He... he asked him to stop, but the tiger was mean! So... (pauses, remembering) ...so the elephant kicked him! (Makes a kicking motion with my foot under the desk) He scared the tiger away!

Yes! The elephant scared the tiger away! He was very brave.

So, after the elephant saved everyone, did the other animals *still* think he was too big to be their friend?

(Shakes head vigorously) No! No way! (Sits up even straighter) They... they all wanted to be his friend then! (Beams) They realised he was... he was the perfect size! Because he saved them from the tiger! (Claps my hands once, quietly)
The perfect size! Why do you think they thought he was the perfect size *then*, but not before?

(Scrunches up my nose, thinking hard) Because... (pauses) ...because he was strong! (Voice gets louder, more excited) He was big and strong enough to kick the tiger away! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) He wasn't just big, he was... helpful! He helped them! (Nods head confidently)

That's a great answer!

So, the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog all thought the elephant was too big before. They only wanted friends who were like them. But then they learned something important. What do you think they learned? What's the story trying to teach us?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk) Um... (Looks around, then back at the teacher) I think... (pauses, thinking) ...I think it's saying that... that even if someone is different, they can still be a good friend. (Looks down at my hands, then back up at the teacher) And... and maybe being different is good! 'Cause the elephant was big, and that's what helped him scare the tiger away! (Smiles shyly) Is that right?

That is absolutely right! You understood the story perfectly.

The story is teaching us that friends can be different shapes and sizes. Being different isn't a bad thing. The elephant was big, and that's what made him a great friend in the end!

So, can a friend be tall or short?

(Nods enthusiastically) Yes! Tall or short! Or... or skinny or chubby! (Giggles) It doesn't matter! As long as they are nice and can help you! (Looks at the teacher with a big smile, pleased with myself)

Exactly! You got it! It doesn't matter what size or shape someone is. What matters is how they treat you and if they are a good person (or animal!).

You did a wonderful job with this story! You really understood it. <finish>
Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, can you tell me who was in the story?

(Smiling brightly, bouncing slightly in my seat) Yes! It was a good story! Um... (looks away, tapping my foot) There was a girl... and her... (counts on fingers) one, two... her father! That's it! A girl and her father! (grinning proudly)
Great job! You remembered them both. Now, what was the girl feeling in the beginning of the story? Was she happy or sad?

(Eyes widen, hands go up in the air a little) Oh! She was... she wasn't happy! (pauses, biting lip) She was... (starts to run forward in the chair, then catches myself and sits back) She was... Frus... Frustra... (thinking hard, brow furrowed) Frustrated! Yes! She was frustrated! Because of... (shrugs) ...life! (beams, pleased with myself)
Frustrated is a big word! Good job! So, she was frustrated with life. What did she do because she was frustrated?

(Jumps up and down a little) Oh! Oh! I know! She... she asked her father! (sits down quickly, but wiggles in place) She said, "Daddy, Daddy! I'm... I'm... frustrated!" (pauses, then speaks louder and faster) And she wanted help! (looks at teacher expectantly) Was I right? Am I right? (bounces again)
You are absolutely right! She asked her father for advice. Now, what did her father ask her to get? It was some food...

(Claps hands together) Oh! I remember! I remember the food! (Stands up straight and starts listing on my fingers) He said get an... an egg! And a... (thinking, looking around the room) ... a potato! Yes! And... (snaps fingers) ...tea! Tea leaves! (sits down with a thump, beaming) He got yummy food!
You got them all right! Egg, potato, and tea leaves. What did her father do with the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves?

(Sways back and forth a little) Hmmm... (eyes dart around the room, distracted for a moment by a colorful poster) He... (comes back to the question) He put them in... in... (stuttering) wa...wa...water! He put them in hot water! (looks pleased with myself) To...to cook them!
Yes! He put them in hot water. And what happened to the egg after it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Shakes head vigorously) No! No way! The egg was... (thinking hard, sticking tongue out a little) ...it was soft before! And then... (eyes widen) ...it got HARD! Like a rock! (makes a fist and pretends to punch the air, then giggles)
Good! The soft egg became hard. What about the potato? Was it hard or soft before the water? What happened to it?

(Puts hand up eagerly) I know! I know! The potato was... (pauses dramatically) ...HARD! (stretches arms out wide) Like... like a rock too! But then... (leans forward conspiratorially) ...it got... squishy! (squeezes hands together) It got soft! (grins)
Exactly! The hard potato got soft. Now, what about the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?

(Scrunches up nose) The tea leaves... (taps chin thoughtfully) They didn't get hard or soft! (looks up suddenly, eyes bright) They changed the water! The water got... (searches for the word) ...tea-colored! And it smelled good! (nods head confidently)
That's right! The tea leaves changed the water itself. Now, the father told his daughter that the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves were like...like what?

(Starts to fidget, looking around the room again) Like... (stuttering) like... like... (eyes focus back on the teacher) Oh! (snaps fingers) Like when... when things are bad! (frowns slightly) Like when things are... (searches for the word) ...hard! (nods slowly) Like when *Adversity Knocks*! (beams, proud to remember the title)
Yes! They are like when things are hard, when *Adversity Knocks*. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all faced the same hot water, the same hard time. But did they all react the same way?

(Shakes head quickly) Nope! Not the same! (holds up three fingers) The egg got hard! (makes a hard fist) The potato got soft! (makes a squishy face) And the tea... (twirls finger in the air) ...changed the water! (looks at the teacher expectantly)
Exactly! So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about when *Adversity Knocks*? What can we learn from the egg, the potato, and the tea?

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead) Hmmm... (looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) Maybe... maybe when things are hard... (pauses) ...we can be like the egg and get stronger! (puffs out chest) Or... or we can be like the potato and... and be soft! (shrugs) Or... (eyes light up) ...we can be like the tea and change things! (claps hands together) We can change the problem! Is that right? (leans forward eagerly) What do *you* think?

You are so close! It's not about changing the problem exactly. It's about how *we* change. The egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. So, when things are hard, we can choose to be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. We get to choose! What do you think the story wants us to learn about that?

(Thinking really hard, biting lip) Ohhhhh... (eyes widen slowly) So... so it's not about the *problem* changing... it's about *us* changing! (nods head slowly) So... when things are hard... we can choose how we... we... (searches for the word) ...act! (smiles brightly) We can choose to be strong like the egg! Or... or... (pauses) Or maybe... sometimes it's okay to be soft like the potato! And... (gasps) ...maybe sometimes we can... can change things around us, like the tea! (beams proudly) Is that it? Did I get it now? (bounces in seat, practically vibrating with excitement)
Yes! You got it! We get to decide how we respond when things get difficult. We decide how to be! That's a big idea. You did a great job understanding the story. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! That was a great story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, what was the older brother doing in the forest?

(Beaming, eyes wide) Yeah, it was a *really* cool story! (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, bouncing slightly)

He was... he was getting wood! (Confidently) To sell at the market! For money! (Points finger in the air) Because he's the older brother, so he has to, um... (trails off, starts fidgeting with a pencil on the desk) ...get the wood. (Looks away, mumbling) It's... it's important.

That's right! He was chopping wood to sell it. Good job!

Now, what did he find in the forest? Something special. Do you remember?

(Eyes light up) Oh! Oh! I know! I know! (Raises hand excitedly, almost knocking over the pencil)

He found a... a tree! (Confidently) But not just any tree! A... a *magic* tree! (Voice drops to a whisper) It could talk! And it... (Stops, frowning slightly) ...it had... something... what was it? (Looks down at the desk, tapping a finger)

(Looks back up, smiling brightly) Oh! Golden apples! The tree promised him golden apples if he didn't chop it down! (Bounces in seat again)

Yes! You got it! He found a magic tree that promised him golden apples.

Did the older brother share the golden apples with his younger brother?

(Head tilts, brow furrows) Hmm... (Starts tapping foot, looks around the room again)

He... (pauses, chewing on lip) ...I don't think so? (Confidently) He was kinda... (searches for the right word) ...not nice! (Frowns) He wanted *more* apples! He wasn't happy with just... (counts on fingers) ...one, two, three... (stops counting) ...a few! He wanted *all* of them! (Slightly louder, more animated)

You're exactly right! He wasn't happy and he wasn't very nice.

What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?

(Eyes widen, leans forward in seat, excited again)

Ooooh! This part was cool! (Claps hands softly) The tree... the tree... (pauses dramatically) ...it gave him needles! (Points finger) Lots and lots of sharp, pokey needles! They stuck all over him! He was lying on the ground! (Giggles a little) Because he was naughty!

Yes! He was covered in needles!

Who helped him get the needles out?

(Straightens up, very eager to answer)

His brother! (Points to self, like he's the younger brother) The *younger* brother! He's nice! He helped him! He took all the needles out, even though the older brother was mean! (Looks proud of the younger brother in the story)

That's right! The younger brother was very kind.

What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? Did the older brother stay mean?

(Thinking hard, scratches head)

Ummm... (Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher)

No! (Confidently) He said sorry! He said he wouldn't be mean anymore! He... he learned his lesson! (Smiles brightly) And then... (Eyes widen again, remembering the exciting part) ...and then the tree gave them *more* golden apples! Because the older brother was nice now! (Claps hands again, softly)

Exactly! The older brother apologized.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the important thing to learn from this story? Think about how the brothers acted.

(Squints, thinking hard. Taps foot again, looking around the room for something interesting.)

Ummm... (Mumbles) ...important thing...

(Brightens up suddenly, pointing a finger) It's... it's about being nice! (Confidently) The older brother was mean, and he got needles! But the younger brother was nice, and he helped! So... (pause for emphasis) ...be nice to your brother! (Smiles, pleased with the answer) And... and maybe you'll get golden apples! (Giggles)
You're on the right track! It *is* about being nice. What happened *because* the younger brother was nice?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping a pencil on the desk)

Because he was nice... (Looks up, a little uncertain) ...the older brother said sorry? And... (Eyes widen, realizing something) ...and *that's* why they got more golden apples! (Beams, excited by the discovery)

So, being nice makes other people be nice back! (Nods head emphatically) And then everyone gets golden apples! (Laughs) It's like magic!

Yes! Being nice can make other people nice back. It's like the story is saying that when you are kind, good things can happen.

So, what do we call that? What's the big idea that being kind can bring good things? What's the story trying to teach us in one sentence?

(Stares intently at the teacher, brow furrowed in concentration, fidgeting in the seat)

One... sentence? (Looks around the room, seemingly searching for the right words written on the walls)

(Fidgets in my seat, anxiously looking down at my hands)

(Voice trails off, unsure) ... Did he say he had to pay for it? Or take it away? (Asks the teacher, hoping for a hint) It's... it's hard to remember all of it! (Sighs heavily)

... (Very quietly) Because... because the neighbor was being... greedy? (Looks at the teacher, then looks down again, picking at my fingernails) If he paid for the water... it would cost him a lot! (Sits up a little straighter, but still fiddling with my hands)

... (Hesitates) ...He... he said sorry? (Looks at the teacher, searching for approval) ... Because he knew he was being... (ponders for a moment, searching for the right word) ... sneaky? Yes! He apologized and went home. He realized his trick didn't work. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson of the story?

(Takes a deep breath, looking thoughtful. Pulls at my collar, feeling a little warm)

... (Stutters) ...Uh... maybe... (Long pause, struggling to put the thought into words) ... maybe it's about... being... fair? (Looks up at the teacher, then looks away again, feeling self-conscious) And... and not trying to trick people? (Frowns a little, thinking harder) Is that right? It's... it's hard to say for sure... (Voice trails off, feeling anxious again)

(Shakes head slowly, looking down at my hands)

Okay, great job reading the story of the Elephant and Friends! That was a good story.

Now, can you tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... (pauses) sad? (Quietly) Because...because nobody wanted to play with him. (Looks away, nervously) He... he wanted friends. (Sniffs a little)
That's right! He was sad because he wanted friends. And why didn't the other animals want to be his friend at first?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Hmmm... (long pause) (Looks at the teacher, then back down) The... the monkey... (Stutters) couldn't... couldn't... he couldn't climb trees like the monkey? (Voice gets softer) And the rabbit... was it... too big for the rabbit's house? (Eyes widening slightly) They said no... because he was different? (Looks up at the teacher, a little anxious) Is that right?

Yes, that's exactly right! The monkey said he couldn't climb trees, and the rabbit said he was too big for its burrow. They didn't want to be friends because he was different.

So, how did the elephant help the other animals later in the story?

(Eyes widen slightly, a little more engaged now) Uh... (Pauses, trying to remember) The tiger! (Frowns, biting my lip) The tiger was... was being mean! (Looks at the teacher, a little worried) And the elephant... (Voice gets a bit louder, more excited) He... he kicked the tiger! (Giggles nervously) And then the tiger ran away! (Looks down again, shyly) He... he saved them.

Yes! He did save them. He kicked the tiger away.

And after the elephant saved them, what did the other animals think about him then?

(Thinking, tapping my foot nervously) Uh... (Looks up, a little hesitant) They... they liked him? (Eyes widen, a little surprised) Because he was... strong? (Confidently, but still a bit shy) They wanted to be his friend then! Because... because he saved them! He wasn't too big or anything anymore. (Smiles faintly)
That's right! They wanted to be his friend after he saved them. Why do you think they changed their minds? What did they learn?

(Frowns, thinking really hard) Hmmm... (Scratches my head) (Looks up, eyes widening a little) Maybe... maybe they learned that... that being different isn't bad? (Confused look) That even if you can't swing in trees or fit in a hole... (Voice trails off, then perks up a little) ...you can still be a good friend? (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) And... and maybe they learned that being strong and helpful is important too? (Bites lip, worried I got it wrong)

You are so close! They learned that even though the elephant was different, he was still a good friend and he could help them in a way they couldn't help themselves. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be the same size and do the same things?

(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) (Quietly) No... (Looks up, thinking) I... I don't think so. (More confidently) Because... because the elephant couldn't do the same things as the monkey or the rabbit. But... but he was still a good friend! (Smiles a little) So... so friends don't have to be exactly the same. (Pauses, thinking deeper) Maybe... maybe it's good to have different friends? (Looks at the teacher, a little proud) Because then you can all help each other in different ways! Like... like the elephant and the other animals! (Beams, then gets a little nervous again) Is that... is that what it means?

Yes! That's it! You got it. The story teaches us that friends can be any shape or size, and they don't have to be exactly the same. Different friends can help each other in different ways.

So, what is the moral of the story? What is the big lesson it teaches us?

(Thinking really hard, tapping my pencil on the desk) (Stutters a bit) Uh... um... (Looks up, a little anxious) (Quietly) To... to be nice to everyone? Even if they're different? (Voice gets a little louder) And... and that everyone is good at something! (Looks down again, tracing shapes on the desk with my finger) Even if they're big... or can't climb trees... or can't fit in holes... (Suddenly looks up, eyes wide) They might be able to kick tigers! (Giggles nervously, then gets serious again) So... so be nice and... and don't judge people by how they look? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is... is that the moral?
Yes, that is a *very* good moral! You've understood the story very well. Another way to put it is: friends can be any shape or size. You were right! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

First, tell me, what things did the father put in the boiling water?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... um... (Stutters) A... a potato? And... and an egg? (Looks up quickly, then down again) And... tea... leaves? (Voice barely a whisper)

Yes! That's exactly right! A potato, an egg, and tea leaves. Good job!

Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the hot water? Was it the same, or did it change?
(Bites lip, looking anxious) It... it changed? (Eyes dart around the room) It... it got... hard? (Whispers) I think...

You're doing great! Yes, the soft egg got hard.

And what about the potato? What happened to it in the hot water?
(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) The potato... (Pause) ...uh... (Looks at teacher with wide, unsure eyes) It got... soft? (Voice questioning) Was it soft?

Yes! You got it! The hard potato got soft.

And what did the tea leaves do to the water?

(Eyes widen slightly, a glimmer of understanding) The... the tea... (Looks away, then back, a little more confidently) It... it changed the water! (Almost smiles, then gets nervous again) It made it... tea? Is that right?

That's right! The tea changed the water into tea. Good job remembering everything!

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea leaves all went into the same hot water, but they all changed in different ways. Why do you think the father showed his daughter this? What was he trying to teach her?

(Chews on pencil eraser, looking very worried) Uh... (Long pause, eyes glazed over) I... I don't know. (Voice cracking slightly) Was it... was it about being... strong? (Looks at the teacher hopefully, but nervously) Like the egg? (Starts to tear up a little) This is hard...

It *is* a little hard, but you're doing so well! Don't worry.

It *is* about being strong, but it's also about more than that. Think about it this way: The hot water is like something bad happening, like a problem or a challenge. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves are like different people.

Did the hot water change for each of the objects?
(Sniffles, wiping eyes with sleeve) No... (Sniffs again) The water... it was the same for all of them... (Looks down at hands, picking at a loose thread)

Exactly! The water was the same. So, the problem was the same for the egg, the potato, and the tea. But they all reacted differently.

The egg became hard. The potato became soft. And the tea...it changed the water itself.

What do you think the father wanted his daughter to learn about how *she* could react when something bad happens?

(Thinking hard, tapping foot nervously) Uh... (Looks up, then down again) That... that she could... choose? (Voice barely audible) Like... like be strong like the egg... or... or soft like the potato... or... (Eyes widen slightly) ...or change things? Like the tea? (Looks at the teacher, a little less anxious now, a faint glimmer of understanding in their eyes) Could she... could she pick what to be?

Yes! You got it! She could pick! When something hard happens, we get to choose how we react. We can become hard, like the egg. We can become soft, like the potato. Or we can even change the situation, like the tea.

The story wants us to know that we decide how to respond to difficult situations. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, looking thoughtful) (Almost smiles, but then looks worried again) So... so if something bad happens... (Swallows hard) ...I don't *have* to be... scared? (Looks at the teacher, pleadingly) I can... I can try to be like the tea? And... and change it? (Voice hopeful) Even if it's... really hard?

Yes! Exactly! It might be hard, but you get to choose. You don't *have* to be scared. You can try to be like the tea and change things. You can decide how you want to react. And that's a very powerful thing to know.

You understood the story and the moral really well. I'm very proud of you! <finish>
Okay! Hi there! That was a good job reading the story. It's called "The Needle Tree". Can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?

Did the older brother like the golden apples?

(Gasps, eyes wide and a little scared) Uh... (Voice shaky) The... the tree... it... it... hurt him! (Clenches hands into fists) It... it poked him! Lots and lots! (Looks down, voice barely a whisper) With... with the needles...

(Looks up, sniffing a little) He... he felt... (Pauses, thinking hard) ...hurty? And... and maybe... (Whispers) ...sad? 'Cause... 'cause he was... bad? (Looks down again, avoiding eye contact) I... I don't know for sure...

(Looks down, shuffling feet) Uh... (Quietly) He... he said... sorry? (Looks up, hopeful) Did he say sorry? I... I think he did. 'Cause... 'cause he was... mean before. (Pulls a face) Being mean is... is not good.

He did say sorry! He apologized for being mean.

What happened after he said sorry? What did the tree do?

(Eyes widen, a small gasp) Oh! Oh! The... the tree... (Claps hands softly) It... it gave them... more apples! (Looks up, excited) 'Cause... 'cause they were... nice now? Was it... happy? Did it like that they were nice? (Tilts head, curious)

(Looks down, tapping fingers on legs nervously) Uh... (Thinking hard) ...Because... because the mean brother... was not mean anymore? I don't want to get it wrong... (Voice trails off)
That's a very good reason! The tree liked that he said sorry and wasn't mean anymore. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Looks down, drawing circles on the floor with a shoe) Hmmm... (Bites lip) Uh... (Long pause) Maybe... maybe that... being mean... is bad? (Looks up, nervous) And... and saying sorry... is good? (Fidgets with hands) And... and if you're nice... maybe... maybe good things... will happen? (Looks at you, pleadingly) Is... is that... okay?

That's a *great* idea! It's like the story is telling us that if you are kind, good things can happen. So, kindness gets rewarded.

Can you say that? Kindness will always be rewarded.

(Looks down, whispers) Kindness... (Looks up, takes a deep breath) Kindness... will... be... re...warded? (Frowns) Re...warded is a... hard word. (Looks at you, a little anxious) Can... can I just say... good things will happen if I'm nice? Is that... is that the same? (Hopes for approval)
Yes! Saying "good things will happen if I'm nice" is the same. That's what the story teaches us. You did a very good job figuring that out! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Touch."

First, can you tell me, who was King Midas?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a bit)

Uh… (pauses) … King… Midas… was a… king? (Looks up quickly, then down again) He… he lived in… Greece?

Yes! You got it. He was a king who lived in Greece.

Now, what did King Midas do that made the god Dionysus happy?

(Thinking hard, scrunching up my nose)

He… he helped… uh… (looks up at the teacher, eyes wide) … a Satyr? (Looks down again, tracing a pattern on the desk with my finger) He was… nice to him?

Exactly! He helped a Satyr. And because he was so kind, Dionysus offered him a wish.

What did King Midas wish for?

(Eyes light up a little, but still hesitant)

He… (pauses, thinking)... he wished for… everything he touched… (looks at the teacher, then back down)… to turn to… gold? (Says it like a question, unsure) Everything!

Yes! That's right. He wished everything he touched would turn to gold.

How did he feel when Dionysus gave him the golden touch? Was he happy or sad?

(Confidently) Happy! (Smiling slightly) Very happy! (Pauses) He thought it was… awesome! He touched… (starts to look around the room, then stops himself) … lots of stuff! (Looks down again, a small frown forming)
