(Thinking, tapping a finger on the desk)

Um… (pauses) Food? (Looks up, questioning) And… and stuff in his… palace? Like… chairs? (Frowns a little)

Yes, food and chairs! Good job.

But what happened when he tried to eat the food? What was the problem?

(Eyes widen a bit, remembering)

Uh… (hesitates) … it turned to… gold? (Looks at the teacher, worried) He couldn’t… eat it? (Stomach rumbles)

That's right! He couldn't eat it. Gold isn't very tasty, is it?

So, he couldn't eat. Was there anything else that went wrong with his wish?

(Thinking hard, chewing on the inside of my cheek)

…His… daughter? (Looks up at the teacher, voice small) She… she hugged him? And… and she turned into… gold too? (Looks down at my lap, fiddling with my hands) Is that… is that right?

Yes, that's exactly right. His daughter hugged him and she turned to gold.

How do you think King Midas felt when that happened? Was he still happy about his golden touch?

(Shakes head slowly, looking down)

…No… (voice barely a whisper). He was… sad? (Looks up, a little confused) Really, really sad. He didn’t want her to… to be gold. (Frowns) He didn’t want the gold anymore.

That's right. He was very sad. He realised the golden touch wasn't such a good thing after all.

Why do you think he wished for the golden touch in the first place? What did he want?

(Thinking, tilting my head)

He… (pauses) … he wanted to be… rich? (Looks up, unsure) He liked gold? Shiny things? (Looks down again) He… he didn’t think about… about the other stuff. (Frowns deeply)

He did want to be rich. He really, really liked gold.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea we should remember from "The Golden Touch?" Think about what King Midas wanted and what happened to him in the end.

(Thinking really hard, almost closing my eyes)

…That… (long pause)… that wanting too much… (opens eyes, looks up at the teacher) …isn’t always… good? (Looks down again, tracing patterns on the desk) That… that some things are more important than… gold? Like… (hesitates) …like people? (Voice is very soft)

Yes! You're getting it! Wanting too much isn't always good. And some things, like people, are much more important than gold.

So, if someone is always wanting more and more, even when they have enough, what might happen to them?

(Looks up, thinking)

…They might… (pauses) …forget about… the things they already have? (Looks down again, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) And… and make people… sad? (Voice is quiet)

Yes, they might forget about the things they already have and maybe even make people sad. King Midas loved gold so much, he forgot what was really important.

So, the story teaches us to be careful about being too greedy. If you are too greedy, it can lead to bad things happening. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher)

…Yeah… (pauses) …It makes sense. (A small smile appears) So… so it’s better to be… thankful for what I have? (Looks down, then back up at the teacher, a little brighter) Even if it’s not… gold?
Exactly! It's much better to be thankful for what you have. Even if it's not gold. You understood the story really well and you figured out the lesson all by yourself! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

Now, can you tell me, what did the fox want?
(Looks down, fidgets with my fingers) Uh... grapes? (Looks up quickly, then down again) Big... purple... grapes.
That's right! He wanted the big, purple grapes. And how did he try to get them?
(Thinking hard, taps foot on the floor) He... uh... jumped? (Looks up, hopeful) He jumped really... high?
Yes! He jumped really high. Did he get the grapes?
(Shakes head) ... Uh... no. (Looks away, a little embarrassed)
No, he didn't. He jumped and jumped, but he couldn't reach them. What did the fox do *after* he couldn't get the grapes?
(Thinking, brow furrowed) He... went... home? (Looks up, questioningly) ...Said... something...?
Yes! He went home and said something. Can you remember what he said about the grapes?
(Eyes widen a little, trying to remember) ... Uh... they were... sour? (Looks at teacher for confirmation) Were they sour? I don't... (Starts to drift off, looking at the pictures on the wall)

He *said* they were sour. But do you think the story *really* thinks they were sour? Maybe they were really yummy?

Why do you think he *said* they were sour?

(Snaps back to attention) Oh! (Thinking, chews on lip) Maybe... (pauses, looks at teacher) ... he was sad he couldn't get them? (Frowns slightly) Is that... a big word? Frus...frustra... frustrated? Because he couldn't get the... the juicy grapes! (Looks proud for a moment, then fidgets again)

That's a GREAT word! Frustrated. Yes, he was probably feeling frustrated! And maybe a little sad.

So, he couldn't get what he wanted. And then he *said* he didn't want it anyway. Why would he do that? What was he trying to do?

(Ponders, looking at the ceiling) Hmmm... (Looks back at the teacher) Was he trying to... to trick himself? Like... like when I don't get the blue crayon, and I say I wanted the green one all along? (Tilts head, waiting for an answer)

That's a *really* good example! Yes, maybe he was trying to trick himself.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it a good idea to say we don't want something just because we can't get it?

(Shakes head slowly) ...Uh...no. (Thinking) Because... then you don't get to be sad about really wanting it? And maybe you could find a way to get it later? Like... like get a ladder! (Eyes light up with the idea) Could the fox get a ladder?

That's a very clever idea! Maybe the fox *could* find a way to get them later!

So, if you *really* want something, should you give up right away if it's hard to get?
(Frowns, concentrating) ...No. (Looks down at hands) ...Keep trying? Or... or ask for help? (Looks up hopefully) Is that what I'm supposed to learn?

Yes, that's a big part of it! And sometimes, even if you try your best, you *still* can't get what you want. Then, it's important to remember that it's okay to be sad, but it's not good to pretend you didn't want it in the first place.

So, what's a good way to say what the story teaches us? Something like... "If you can't get something..." What would you say next?

(Thinking hard, taps a finger on the desk) If you can't get something... (pauses) ...don't say you didn't want it, but... (looks up, a little confused) ...but it's okay to be sad? And try again later? Or... ask for help! (Smiles shyly) Did I do good?

You did AMAZING! You figured out the story and what it means!

A good way to say it is: Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have.

You really thought hard about the fox and the grapes, and you learned a lot. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! It was about a rose and a cactus.

First, can you tell me, what did the rose think about itself?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a bit) Uh... (clears throat) The rose... (thinking) ... thought it was... pretty? (Looks up at the teacher with a small, polite smile)

(Hesitates, looks away) ... Uh... not pretty? (Looks back, tilting head) Was it... mean to the cactus? (eyes widen slightly, like asking a question)

(Scrunches up my nose, thinking hard) ... Because... (pauses, searching for the right words) ... it... thought it was better? (looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping for confirmation) Was it... because the rose was proud? Like the title?

Yes, you're exactly right! The rose was very proud and thought it was better than the cactus.

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot?
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering the story) Uh... (stuttering) ...the... the water... it went away? And the rose... (looks down, tracing a pattern on the desk with a finger) ...got thirsty?
Yes! The water went away and the rose got very thirsty. What about the cactus? How was the cactus doing?

(Thinking, tapping a finger on my chin) The cactus... (eyes light up) ...it helped the birds! (Looks at the teacher, excited) It gave them water! ... (pauses, thoughtfully) ...Because it had water inside? How does a cactus keep water inside?

But what happened when the rose got thirsty and saw the cactus helping the birds?
(Looks down, a little sad) ... The rose... asked for water? (Looks back up, hopefully) Did the cactus give the rose water?
Yes! The cactus gave the rose water. Even after the rose was mean. Why do you think the cactus did that?

(Thinking hard, wrinkling my forehead) ... Because... (searching for the words) ...it was... nice? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Was it... being kind, even when the rose wasn't kind to it? Is that... what friends do?

So, the rose *looked* pretty, but it wasn't very nice. The cactus maybe didn't *look* as pretty, but it was very kind and helpful. What do you think we can learn from this story?

You are so close! The story shows us that we shouldn't only look at what's on the outside. The rose was pretty, but it wasn't kind. The cactus wasn't as flashy, but it was helpful and kind.

So, what's a good way to treat everyone, even if they look different than you?

Exactly! We should be nice and helpful to everyone, no matter what they look like. We shouldn't judge them based on how they look.

So, what's the lesson of the story in your own words?

(Looks down, trying to put it all together. Takes a deep breath.) ... Um... (pauses) ... It's... (more confidently) ... it's good to be kind and helpful... more than just pretty... (Looks up at the teacher, a little proud of myself) And... and don't be mean to people... even if they're different. (Smiles shyly) Is that... is that okay?
That's perfect! You understood the story really well. We should never judge someone just by how they look. It's what's inside that matters. <finish>
Okay! So, you just read "The Milkmaid and Her Pail." What was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... she was... uh... going to... (pauses, thinking) ...sell it? At the market? I think.

(Looks up, eyes widening a little) She was... uh... (thinking hard, tapping my chin) She was thinking about... (pauses, unsure) ...buying a chicken? And eggs? I think she said something like that. I think she was buying something with the money, but the money wasn't even hers yet.
Good job! She was thinking about buying a chicken. Why did she want to buy a chicken?

(Looks away, distracted by something shiny on my desk) Uh... (Stutters) ...Because she... (pauses, trying to remember) ...more money? (Looks back at the teacher, tilting my head) Could she get more money from eggs? Is that what the story meant?
Yes! She thought she could get more money from the eggs. So, she was planning what she would do with money she didn't have yet, right? What happened to the milk in the end?

(Nods slowly, understanding dawning) ...Oh! Yeah. She didn't have the money yet. (Frowns a little, remembering) ...She spilled it! (Looks down again, tracing patterns on the desk with my finger) All of it. Uh... because she was skipping.
Exactly! She spilled it because she was skipping and thinking about the chicken. So, did she get to buy the chicken?

(Shakes head slowly, looking at the teacher with wide eyes) ...No. (Quietly) She didn't have any milk to sell, so she didn't get any money. (Thinks for a moment, a question forming) ...Why did her mom say that thing about chickens hatching? What did that mean?
That's a great question! Her mom said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means about making plans? Think about what happened to Molly.

(Looks at the teacher hopefully) Because Molly thought she had all that chicken money, but she didn't... 'cause she spilled the milk?

You're getting it! Yes! It means don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. Molly was depending on the chicken money before she even sold the milk. So, what is the moral of the story? <finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, can you tell me, what did the old owl do every day?

(Looks up, a little more confident)

So, what's the main idea of the story? What can we learn from the wise old owl?

...That... (Pauses) ...that listening... and... and watching... (Confidently) ...makes you... wiser! (Smiles a little) Like me... learning from Mrs. Davis!

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a little sad, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. What did the farmer have?
(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... (Hesitates) a...goose? A goose that... (thinking) uh...laid eggs? (Looks up at the teacher, hopefully)
Yes! He had a goose that laid eggs. What kind of eggs did it lay? Were they normal eggs?
(Eyes widen a little, then look off to the side, thinking) Not normal... uh... They were... (pauses, searching for the word) Gold! (Confidently) Golden eggs! Like... real gold!
That's right! Golden eggs. And what did the farmer do with those golden eggs?
(Shrugs, looking down again) He... uh... (Thinking) Sold them? (Looks up, a little unsure) To get... money?
Yes, he sold them! And because he sold them, did he have lots of money or not much money?
(Looks up, thinking hard) He had... uh... (pauses) Lots! (eyes widen) Because they were gold! So... lots of money. (Nods, a little more sure of myself)
Exactly! He had lots of money. Were he and his wife happy at first?
(Nods slowly) Uh-huh. (Thinking) They... they lived... (searching for the word) comfortably? Because... of the gold eggs. (Looks at the teacher, questioning)
Yes, comfortably! That's a good word. So, they were happy. Then what happened? What did the farmer start to think about?
(Frowns, looking down at the table) He... got... (pauses) Greedy? (Looks up, unsure) He wanted... more? Than one egg? A day? (Asks the teacher questioningly) Is that right?
That's right! He got greedy. He wanted more than one egg a day. Why do you think he wanted more?

(Thinking, wrinkling my forehead) Because... he wanted to be... richer? (pauses) And he... he thought...(eyes widen) I know! (confidently) He thought maybe... inside the goose... were... (searching for the word) lots more gold eggs! Right?
Yes! That's what he thought. He thought there were lots more golden eggs inside the goose. So, what did he do?
(Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor) He... (pauses, voice gets quiet) He cut... the goose? (Looks up at the teacher, worried) Is that... is that what happened?
Yes, he cut open the goose. And what did he find?
(Frown deepens, looks away, voice barely a whisper) Blood... and guts... (Shakes head a little) No gold eggs... just... yuck. (Looks back at the teacher with a sad expression)
That's right. Just blood and guts. No golden eggs. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that?

(Thinking, bites lip) They... (pauses) Got poorer? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Because... no more gold eggs... to sell? (Looks down again, fiddling with fingers) Did they learn something? About... (searching for the word) being greedy?
Yes, they got poorer because they had no more golden eggs to sell. And yes, they probably learned something about being greedy. What do you think they learned?

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the table) That... (pauses) Being greedy... isn't good? (Looks up, a little confused) Because... (eyes widen) ...if you're greedy, you might... lose everything? Even the goose? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Is that... the lesson?
You're getting very close! It's not just about being greedy not being good, but what you do *because* you are greedy. So what's the lesson here? What could the farmer have done differently?

(Thinking, looks up at the ceiling) He could have... (pauses, searching for the right words) ...been happy with... the one egg? (Frowns) And... not been greedy? (Looks back at the teacher) So... the lesson is... (eyes light up) ...be happy with what you have? And don't try to... (searching for the word) ...take too much? Or you might lose it all? (Looks proud of myself) Is that it?

That's very good! It's about being happy with what you have, but it's also about something else. It's about thinking about what might happen *before* you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he cut open the goose. He just acted. So, the lesson is to... what?

(Thinking, rubs chin) To... (pauses) ...think before you... (searching for the word) act? (Looks at the teacher, a little hesitant) So you don't... (eyes widen) ...mess things up? And lose everything? (Nods slowly, understanding dawning) So... think first, then act?
Yes! "Think before you act." That's the important lesson. The farmer didn't think, and he lost everything. You understood the story and the lesson very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

Now, can you tell me, who did the farmer buy something from?
Umm... (looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) ... the... the neighbor?
Yes! The farmer bought something from the neighbor. What did he buy? Can you remember? Look back at the story if you need to!
(Peers at the book, tracing the words with my finger)... Uh... (pauses) ... a well? (looks up at the teacher hopefully)
Yes! He bought a well! So, the farmer bought a well from his neighbor. Now, after he bought the well, could the farmer use it?
(Thinking, furrowing my brow) ... No... (hesitates) ... I don't... I don't think so.
You're right! He couldn't. Why couldn't he use the well, even though he bought it? What did the neighbor say?
(Squints at the book again, pointing) The neighbor... said... (stutters) ... he... he sold the well... but not... not the water! (looks up, a little confused) ... Is that... is that even allowed?
That's exactly what the neighbor said! Good job finding that in the story. And that's a good question! Do *you* think that's allowed? If you sell someone a well, should they be able to use the water?

(Thinking hard, tapping my pencil on the desk) ... Hmmm... Well, if you buy a well... (pauses) ... doesn't that mean you can get the water too? Otherwise, what's the point of buying the well? (looks at the teacher with a questioning expression, tilting my head)
That's a very smart way to think about it! What do you think the farmer thought? What did he do because he couldn't get water from the well?

(Looks down at my hands, tracing patterns on the desk) ... He... he got sad? (looks up, unsure) ... And then he went to... the... the big boss man? The emperor? (confidently) He asked the emperor for help!
Yes! He went to the emperor for help. And what did the emperor's helper, the courtier, ask the neighbor?

(Thinking, eyes widening) ... Oh! ... The courtier... he asked the neighbor... (searches memory) ... if he didn't want the farmer to use the water... then he had to... (pauses, struggling) ... pay for the water! (beams, proud of remembering) Or... or take it all away!
Excellent! You remembered perfectly. So, what happened then? What did the neighbor do when the courtier said that?
(Smiling slightly) ... He... uh... he said sorry. (shrugs) And then he went home. (pauses) ... Was he being mean? Is that why he had to say sorry?

You're exactly right! He was being mean. He was trying to trick the farmer, wasn't he? He wanted to get money for the well and *still* keep the water.

So, the neighbor tried to trick the farmer. Did his trick work?
(Shakes head confidently) Nope! His trick didn't work! Because the emperor was smart! (thinking) ... Or the courtier was smart!
They were both very smart! So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What lesson can we learn from the farmer and the well? Think about the neighbor and his trick.

(Thinking hard, chewing on the end of my pencil) ... Hmmm... (eyes light up) ... Maybe... maybe it's saying that... that you shouldn't be greedy? And you shouldn't try to trick people, because you'll get caught? (looks at the teacher, a little proud) Is that right?

That's a *fantastic* answer! You're absolutely right. It's like saying, if you try to cheat someone, it won't work out for you in the end. Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story really well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me, how did the elephant feel at the start of the story?

(Looks down, shuffling my feet)

Uh... (Hesitates) ... sad? Because... uh... nobody wanted to play with him. He was... lonely. (Looks up quickly, then back down)
Yes, you're exactly right! He was sad and lonely. Why do you think the other animals didn't want to be his friend at first? What did they say?

(Thinking, tapping my fingers on the desk)

The monkey... (Looks up, then down again) ...said he was too big to swing. And the rabbit... uh... (Stuttering) ...the rabbit said... he couldn't fit in the... burrow? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look)

... Was that right?
Yes, that's perfect! The monkey couldn't swing with him and the rabbit's burrow was too small. And what did the frog say? Do you remember?

(Squints, trying to remember)

The frog... (Pauses) ... um... something about... jumping? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for help) He couldn't... jump with the elephant?

... Can you remind me?

You're so close! The frog said the *elephant* couldn't jump. The elephant couldn't jump like the frog.

So, all the animals turned the elephant away because he was different. Right? What happened the next day in the forest?

(Nods slowly)

...Uh... (Thinking hard) ... The tiger! The tiger was... (Looks up, eyes widening slightly) ...scaring everyone! They were all running.

...Was the tiger being mean?
Yes, the tiger *was* being mean! And everyone was scared. What did the elephant do when he saw the tiger?

(Sits up a little straighter, remembering)

He... (Hesitates) ... kicked him! (Looks down, then back up, a little proud) He kicked the tiger away!

...Did he hurt the tiger bad? I don't like hurting people... or animals.

That's a very kind thought! The story doesn't say the elephant hurt the tiger *bad*. He just scared him away so he wouldn't scare the other animals. He protected everyone.

What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel about the elephant then?

(Thinking)

...Uh... (Pauses) ...They liked him? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Because... he saved them?

...Did they want to be his friend then?
Yes! You got it. They *did* want to be his friend then. Why do you think they changed their minds? What made them like the elephant *after* he scared the tiger?

(Looks down, tracing a pattern on the desk with a finger)

...Because... (Thinks hard) ...he was brave? And... (Looks up, a little spark in the eyes) ...he was big enough to... protect them!

...So being big wasn't bad anymore?
Exactly! Being big wasn't bad anymore. It was actually helpful! So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Frowns, thinking really hard. Pushes hair behind ear)

...Uh... (Long pause) ...That... (Looks up at the ceiling, searching for the right words) ... that being different... isn't... (Looks back at the teacher) ... bad? And... (Squints eyes) ... that sometimes... the things that make you different... are the things that... (Big breath) ... help people?

...Is that right? That's a hard question!

That's a *fantastic* answer! You are absolutely right. Sometimes the things that make you different are the things that make you special and helpful.

So, if someone is good at swinging, or good at jumping, or fits in a small space, those are good things. And if someone is big and strong and brave, those are good things too.

This story teaches us that friends can be different sizes and shapes, and that's okay! Sometimes, those differences are what make them good friends.

Does that make sense?<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

First, tell me, what did the girl feel at the beginning of the story?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with my hands) she was, um... frustrated? (peeks up at the teacher) She told her dad she was frustrated with... life. (trails off)

Yes! She was frustrated. Good job!

And what did her father ask her to bring him? Can you remember those things?
(Thinking hard, bites lip) ...A potato? (eyes widen a little) And an egg? (pauses, looks around the room) And... uh... tea... leaves? (sounds like a question)

Yes! Potato, egg, and tea leaves! You got them all.

What did he do with those things?
(Looks down at my hands again) He... put them in... (pauses) ...water? (Eyes dart up to the teacher, then quickly back down) Boiling water? (quietly)

Boiling water! You're doing great! He put each thing in its own pot of boiling water.

Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the boiling water? Was it the same?
(Stares at the table, thinking. Then, a small spark of understanding) It got... hard? (looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) It was soft, and then it was... hard?

Yes! The soft egg became hard. Good remembering!

And what about the potato? What happened to *it* in the boiling water?
(Thinking hard, brows furrowed) The potato... uh... (long pause) ...it was hard... and then... (looks up at the teacher, then back down) ...softer?

Yes! The hard potato became soft!

And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?

(Confused) Uh... (scratches head) They... they didn't get hard or soft. (Looks up, a little worried) They... changed the water? (Sounds unsure) The water got... tea-y? (Looks hopefully at the teacher)

Yes! The tea leaves changed the water. They made the water different. The water wasn't just water anymore! It had the flavor and color of the tea.

Okay, so the egg changed, the potato changed, and the water changed because of the tea. Now, the story said this was like... adversity. Do you know what adversity means? It's like when things are hard or difficult.

So, the *hard* things are like adversity. How can the egg, potato and tea help us understand adversity? Which one is like you when things get hard?

(Thinking hard, eyes darting around. Bites lip.) Adversity... is... hard things? (Looks at the teacher, then back down at my hands. Fidgets.)

Uh... (long pause) ...I don't... know. (voice barely above a whisper) Which one is like me? I... uh... don't know. (Shrugs a little) Can you... tell me more? (Looks up at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes.)

Okay, let's think about it a little differently. Remember the girl was frustrated with life. Life felt hard to her.

The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves *all* faced the *same* hard thing: the boiling water. But did they all react the same way?

(Thinking, forehead furrowed) No... (pauses) The egg got hard... the potato got soft... and the tea... changed the water. (Looks up, a flicker of understanding) They did... different things? (Quietly)

Yes! They all reacted differently to the same problem, the boiling water.

The story says *we* can react in different ways when things are hard too. We can be like the egg and get hard. We can be like the potato and get soft. Or we can be like the tea and change the water.

Which one do you *want* to be like when things get hard?

(Long pause. Stares at the floor, thinking very hard. Finally, looks up, a little shyly.) I... (hesitates) I want to be like the... tea? (Voice is quiet, but more confident than before) Because it changed the water... and made it... better? (Looks at the teacher, hoping for approval.)
That's a great answer! Why do you think being like the tea is better? What does it mean to "change the water" when things are hard?

(Thinking, chews on the inside of my cheek) Uh... (long pause) Changing the water... means... (Looks up, a sudden flash of understanding) ...making things better even when it's hard? (Eyes widen slightly, surprised at my own answer) Like... like if someone is mean to me, I can still be nice back? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is that... right?

That *is* right! Being like the tea means that even when things are hard, you can still change the situation for the better. You can choose how you react and maybe even make things better for yourself and others.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about hard times?

(Looks thoughtful, still a little unsure, but more confident) That... (pauses) ...that hard times... (Looks up at the teacher, then back down, twisting my hands in my lap) ...that hard times can change us? (Looks up again, a little pleadingly) But we can choose how we change? (Whispers) And we can choose to be like the tea?

Exactly! You got it! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. We can choose to be like the egg, the potato, *or* the tea. The story wants us to think about being like the tea and changing things for the better.

You did a wonderful job understanding the story. I think you really understand the message now! <finish>

That's absolutely right! He felt bad for being mean. And what happened *after* he apologized? What did the tree do then?
(Eyes light up a bit) Oh! Oh! The tree gave them... MORE apples! (smiles slightly) Golden ones! (looks at the teacher, pleased with remembering) Because he was... nice? (questions the teacher)

(Frowns, thinking really hard. Looks up at the ceiling for a moment) ... Um... (hesitates) ... Don't be greedy? (looks back at the teacher, unsure) And... and be nice to your brother? (a little more confident)

(Thinking, taps a finger on the desk) ... Good things happen? (looks up, searching the teacher's face for approval) The tree... gave them apples! So... if you're nice, you get... (searches for the right word) ... rewarded? Is that right? It's a big word... but is that what happened?

"Rewarded" is a perfect word! You are absolutely right. Being kind can bring good things. So, we can say that kindness gets rewarded. Kindness will always be rewarded! Did you like the story? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story!

He wanted lots and lots of gold. And that's what made him forget about other important things, like eating and hugging his daughter.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea of the story?

(Thinking hard, tapping foot nervously) ... (long pause) ... Maybe... maybe gold isn't... the most important thing? (Looks up at the teacher hesitantly) ... Maybe... maybe love... and food... are more important? (Voice barely audible) I... I don't know... (Looks down again, fiddling with pencil)

Exactly! Because he was so greedy, he lost the things that were truly important: his daughter and even his ability to eat.

So the story is trying to tell us that being too greedy can lead to bad things happening. It can lead to your downfall. You understood that very well. <finish>

Do you think the grapes *really* were sour? Or was he just saying that because he couldn't reach them?
(Fidgeting with my fingers, looking down) Uh... (long pause) Maybe...he...just said it? (Whispers) 'Cause... (trails off, doesn't finish the sentence. Starts to tear up a little). It was...hard.

It *was* hard! It was hard to jump and not get the grapes. It's okay to be a little sad when things are hard.

So, he said they were sour because he couldn't get them. He pretended he didn't *want* them anymore.

Have you ever wanted something really badly, but you couldn't get it?
(Sniffles quietly, wipes eyes with the back of my hand) (Nods head slowly, avoiding eye contact). Uh...yeah. (Voice barely a whisper) Like...the red crayon. (Looks like I'm about to cry).

Oh, the red crayon! I remember. And someone else was using it, right?

Did you say you didn't want the red crayon, even though you really did?
(Nods, tears welling up again) Uh-huh. (Whispers) Said...blue was better. (Looks down, ashamed).

Okay. See? You did something like the fox!

The fox couldn't get the grapes, so he said they were sour. You couldn't get the red crayon, so you said blue was better.

Do you think that was *really* true? Was blue *really* better at that moment?
(Shakes head very slightly, still looking down, tears dripping) ...No. (Sniffles) Red...was...for the firetruck. (Voice cracks again)

Red *was* for the firetruck! You really wanted that red crayon.

So, the fox pretended he didn't want the grapes because he couldn't have them. What do you think we can learn from this story? It's a lesson about trying hard and what to do when things are difficult.

(Wipes eyes again, takes a shaky breath) Uh... (Long pause, thinking hard, biting my lip) ...If...can't get it... (Struggles to find the words) ...it's okay to be sad? (Looks up at the teacher for the first time, eyes red and watery, but hopeful).

Yes, it *is* okay to be sad! It's okay to be sad when you can't get something you want. But what about saying you didn't want it anyway? Was that the best thing to do? What else could the fox have done?
(Looks down again, thinking) ...Uh... (long pause) ...try...again? (Voice hesitant). Or... ask for help? (Looks up quickly, then down again, nervously). Maybe... grapes were too high for him.

Those are great ideas! He could have tried again, or asked for help. Maybe the grapes were too high.

So, the story teaches us that things don't always come easy. And it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it. It's better to keep trying, or ask for help, or just accept that you can't have it *right now*. Maybe later you can get it.

Can you try to say that lesson in your own words? What does the story teach us?

(Fidgets with hands, takes a deep breath) Uh... (looks up, tries to make eye contact but fails, looking at the teacher's chin) Story...says... (Struggles) ...Sometimes...things are... hard. (Whispers) It's okay to be sad...but... (Forces myself to look up a bit more, a small, determined frown on my face) ...try...or... ask. Don't... say don't want it... if you do. (Looks down again, exhausted but a little proud).

That's excellent! You explained it perfectly. The story teaches us that nothing comes easy, and it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it. It's better to try, ask for help, or accept it. You understood the story really well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good effort!

Now, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting)

Uh… (long pause) … the… uh… rose… (another pause) … and the… cactus?

Yes! That's right! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what did the rose think about the cactus? Was she nice?

(Looks away, nervously twisting a button on my shirt)

… Uh… No? (pause) She… she wasn't very nice. She… she said… bad things… about the… cactus. (voice barely above a whisper)

That's right! She wasn't nice.

What kind of things did the rose say to the cactus? Do you remember?

(Shakes head slowly, eyes wide)

I… I don't… exactly… remember. (Stuttering) S-something about… about the cactus not… not being pretty? (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression) It was mean…

Yes, it *was* mean! You are right. The rose thought the cactus wasn't pretty.

Now, what happened when the summer got really, really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Frowns, thinking hard. Bites lip)

The… the rose… (pause) … she got… thirsty? (Looks up at the teacher with a questioning look, hoping for confirmation) She… she started to… to… wither? (Voice cracks slightly) I… I think…

Yes, you are doing great. The rose got very thirsty and started to wither.

And what about the cactus? What was the cactus doing during the hot summer?

(Looks down again, playing with my fingers. Voice is very quiet)

The… the cactus… (pause) … he… he gave water to… to the birds? (Looks up quickly, then back down, feeling nervous) The… the sparrows?

Yes! The cactus was giving water to the sparrows.

So, the rose is thirsty and withering, and the cactus is helping the birds. What did the rose *then* do? What did she ask the cactus?

(Hesitates, picking at a loose thread on my pants)

…She… she asked for… water? (Looks up, biting lip) From the… cactus? (Whispers) Because she was… thirsty…

Yes! That's right! The rose asked the cactus for water.

And did the cactus give her water?

(Looks at the teacher, eyes wide with a little bit of hope.)

…Yes? (Pause, voice barely audible) …He did? (Quietly) Because he was… nice?

Yes! The cactus *did* give her water. Even after the rose was mean to him.

So, what does this story tell us? Was the rose right to judge the cactus for how he looked?

(Shakes head slowly, avoids eye contact)

…No… (Pause) …It's… it's not… nice to… to be mean… (Looks down, almost inaudible) …Even if… someone looks… different.
That's it! You're getting it. So, what do you think is the lesson of the story? What does the story want us to learn?

(Thinking very hard, furrowing brow)

…Um… (Long pause) …That… that being… nice… is… is better than being… pretty? (Looks up at the teacher, anxious, waiting for approval) …And… and you should… should help… people… even if they… they weren't nice… to you? (Voice trembling slightly) I… I don't know…

You're so close! You're absolutely right that being nice is important and that we should help others.

Think about *why* the rose was mean. She thought she was better because she thought she was prettier. But in the end, who was really helpful and kind?

So, what's the lesson about judging people based on how they look?

(Looks down at desk, tracing shapes with a finger. Voice is very quiet)

…That… that you… shouldn't? (Pause) …Because… because what's inside… is… is more important… than what's outside? (Looks up, eyes filled with a hint of understanding but still nervous) …Like… the cactus… he looked… prickly… but he was… kind…

Yes! That's exactly right! We shouldn't judge people just by how they look. The cactus looked different, but he was kind and helpful. The rose was pretty, but she was mean.

So, the story teaches us to never judge someone according to how they look. It's what's inside that counts! You understood the story so well! <finish>

Okay! Hi there! That was a good reading!

Now, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... sell it? (Whispers) At the market?

Yes! That's right. She was going to sell it at the market. Good job!

What did Molly start thinking about while she was walking?

(Bites lip, looks away)

...Uh... (Long pause) The... the money? (Voice trembling slightly)
Yes! She was thinking about the money. What did she want to buy with the money? Do you remember?

(Eyes widen a little, then quickly dart back down. Stuttering)

A... a... (Pause, then barely audible) chicken?
A chicken! Yes! And what did she hope the chicken would do?

(Shuffles feet, pulls at sleeve)

Lay... eggs? (Looks up quickly, then down again, nervous)
Yes! Lay eggs! And what would she do with the eggs?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed. Avoids eye contact)

Sell... them? (Whispers) For more... money? Uh...

Yes! She would sell them for more money! You're doing great!

So, she was thinking about all the things she could buy. What happened while she was thinking and skipping?

(Face scrunches up, anxious)

...Uh... (Voice barely there) The... the milk... (Gestures vaguely with hands) It... spilled? (Looks up quickly, then down again, worried)

The milk spilled! That's right! All the milk spilled. Oh no!

What happened to Molly then? Did she get to buy the chicken?

(Shakes head slightly, still looking down)

...No... (Sniffles quietly) ...Empty... pails... (Voice very small)

Empty pails. You got it!

Did her mom say anything to her? What did her mom tell her?

(Clenches hands together, looks up with a worried expression)

...Uh... (Long pause, tears welling up) I... I don't... remember... (Voice cracking)

It's okay. It's okay if you don't remember exactly. Her mom said something like "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

Do you know what that means? It's okay if you don't! We can figure it out together. Why do you think she said that?

(Wipes eyes with the back of hand, looks down again, sniffling)

...Uh... (Mumbles) ...Don't... be... happy... too early...? (Quietly) ...'Cause... maybe... it won't... happen...?

Yes! That's very good! Don't be happy too early because it might not happen.

Molly was counting on the chicken eggs before she even *had* the chicken!

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?

(Takes a deep breath, tries to focus, but still looks anxious)

...Uh... (Fidgets with fingers) ...Don't... dream... too much...? (Whispers) ...Before... you... do it...? (Looks up, pleadingly)

Yes! That's a great way to put it. Don't dream *too* much before you *do* it. It's good to have dreams, but Molly was planning on things that weren't real yet.

Maybe another way to say it is: Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen.

Do you understand that?

(Nods slowly, looking down, but a little less anxious. A small, almost imperceptible smile appears)

...Uh-huh... (Whispers) ...Don't... depend... (Mouths the words silently, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe.)
Great! You got it! You understood the story and its lesson. Well done!<finish>
Okay, great job reading the story! Now, can you tell me, what did the old owl do every day?
(Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers) Uh… (pauses) He… he watched things? (Stuttering) Things… around the tree?
Yes! That's right! He watched things around the tree. And what else did he do? The story mentioned something else he did with his ears.
(Eyes widen slightly, a nervous habit) Uh… (long pause, looking at the ceiling) Did he… listen? (Whispers) Uh… to people talking? (Looks away quickly)
Yes! He listened to people talking! So, he watched with his eyes and listened with his ears. Now, did the owl talk a lot?
(Shakes head slowly, avoids eye contact) … No… (Quietly) Not a lot.
That's right. He didn't talk a lot. What happened to the owl as he watched and listened more and more? Did he get taller? Did he grow more feathers? What did the story say?
(Thinking hard, biting lip) Uh… (Frowns, confused) I… I don’t know. (Looks down at shoes) Did… did he learn stuff? (Whispers) Did he get… wiser? (Voice trails off)

You got it! He got wiser! He learned things by watching and listening. So, the owl watched and listened a lot, and he didn't talk a lot. And that made him wise.

Why do you think watching and listening made him wise? What did he learn from watching and listening?
(Looks up, then quickly down again, anxious) Uh… (Shrugs, a little defeated) … I don’t know… (Mumbles) He… he heard stories? (Looks up, pleadingly) Can you… can you tell me?
He did hear stories! And he saw things happening. Imagine you are watching children play in the playground. What could you learn just by watching them?
(Thinking hard, face scrunched up) Uh… (Pause) I… I could see… see if they… they were sharing? (Hesitantly) Or… or being mean? (Looks up quickly, then back down) Is that… is that right?

That's a great answer! You could see if they were sharing or being mean. So, you learn about how people act, right? The owl learned about lots of things by watching and listening. He didn't need to talk all the time to learn.

Now, think about this: if you are always talking, are you listening?

(Eyes widen, understanding dawns a little) … Uh… No? (Thinks for a moment, looking thoughtful) ‘Cause… ‘cause you’re… you’re talking! (Giggles nervously, then becomes quiet again) So… the owl… he listened more?

Yes, the owl listened more. And because he listened more, he learned more, and he became wiser. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it better to talk all the time, or listen and watch sometimes?

(Looks down, shuffling feet) … Listen and… and watch? (Voice barely audible) Because… (struggling to find the words) … because you can… can learn stuff? (Looks up briefly, then down again) Is… is that okay?

That's perfect! Yes, listening and watching helps you learn stuff. So, the story is telling us that it's good to listen and watch, and maybe not talk *so* much. It's good to be observant.

So, can you tell me in your own words, what is the story "The Wise Old Owl" about?

(Takes a deep breath, still nervous but trying) The… the owl… he… he watched… and listened… (Pauses, looks down) … and he… he got… (Concentrates intensely) … wiser! (Looks up, fleetingly, a tiny smile) Because… because he… learned… from watching and listening… (Mumbles) … not… not talking all the time… (Looks away again) … Is that… is that it?
That's it exactly! You explained it perfectly! The owl watched and listened, and he learned and became wiser because he wasn't always talking. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! It was a bit sad, wasn't it?

First, tell me: what did the farmer have?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... he had... uh... (stuttering) a... a goose?
Yes! He had a goose. And what was special about that goose?
(Looks up quickly, then back down) ... Uh... it laid... (long pause) ... uh... a... (whispers) golden egg?
That's right! It laid a golden egg. And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
Yes, he sold it! And what happened when he sold the golden eggs? Did they have lots of food?
Uh-huh! They had lots of food and a comfortable life. So, were they happy at first?
(Looks away, pulling at a loose thread on my shirt) ... 'Cause they had... uh... (long pause) ... food? (Voice barely audible)

Because they had food! And a nice life! So, the goose gave them a good thing.

Now, what did the farmer want *more* of?
(Thinking hard, biting my lip) ... More... eggs? (Looks up, anxious)
More golden eggs, yes! He wanted *more* golden eggs. And what did he *do* to try and get more?
(Voice trembling slightly) ... He... (swallows hard) ... he cut... the goose? (Looks down at my hands, wringing them together)
Yes, he cut the goose. And what happened then? Did he get more golden eggs?
(Shakes head slowly, tears welling up in my eyes) ... No... just... (whispers) ... blood. (Looks close to crying)
(Softly) That's right. Just blood. So, did he get what he wanted? Did he get more golden eggs?
(Sniffles, wiping eyes with the back of my hand) ... No... (Shakes head again) ... He lost... the goose. (Voice cracking)
He lost the goose. And what happened to him and his wife after that? Were they happy then?
(Shakes head vigorously, more tears spilling) ... No! They were... (sobs softly) ... poor. (Hides face in hands)

(Pauses to give the student a moment to compose themselves) They became poor. The goose was giving them something good, and they lost it because they wanted too much, too quickly.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? Is it good to be greedy?

(Sniffling, peeks out from behind my hands) ... (Whispers) ... No. (Shakes head again, voice shaky) ... 'Cause... you might... lose... everything. (Looks up, eyes red and watery) ... It's... it's sad.

It *is* sad. It's sad because they weren't happy with what they had. They wanted more and ended up with nothing.

So, what could the farmer have done differently?
(Thinks for a long time, chewing on my lip) ... Uh... (shrugs weakly) ... Be... (stutters) ... b-be happy with... with one egg? (Looks up, hoping for approval)

Yes! Be happy with one egg! He should have been patient.

So, the story teaches us to be careful and think about what might happen *before* we do something. It teaches us to think before we act. Can you say that? Think before you act.
(Wipes eyes again, takes a deep breath) ... (Quietly) ... Think... before... I act. (Looks at the teacher, a little bit of confidence returning)
Good! Think before you act. That's a very important lesson. And it sounds like you understand the story and what it's trying to teach us. <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story!

First, can you tell me: Who bought the well?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... the... the farmer? (Stuttering) He... he bought it. (Looks away)

Yes, that's right! The farmer bought the well.

And who did he buy it *from*?

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip)

...uh... the... neighbor? (Quietly) I... I think so.

You got it! The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

Now, what did the farmer want to do with the well? Why did he buy it?

(Nervously picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

...To... to water... (pauses, looks up briefly) ...the... farm? (Voice barely audible)

Yes! To water his farm. That's exactly right!

But could he use the well? What did the neighbor say?

(Eyes widening slightly, voice trembling)

...The... the neighbor... (Long pause, almost whispering) ...said... no? (Looks down again, anxious) He... he said he only sold the well... not the... water.

That's right! The neighbor was being tricky.

Do you think that was a nice thing for the neighbor to do?

No, it wasn't nice.

What did the farmer do then? He couldn't water his farm.

(Takes a deep breath, fidgeting intensifies)

...Went to... the... (Struggles with the word) ...Em... Emperor? (Looks up, a flicker of hope in my eyes, but quickly looks down again)

Yes! He went to the Emperor. Good job!

Why do you think he went to the Emperor?

(Shrugs, voice soft and hesitant)

...To... to get help? (Looks up, then quickly down again, nervous about being wrong) ...Because... the neighbor... was being... (Trails off, unable to find the word) ...mean?

Being mean is a good way to put it. He went to the Emperor because he thought the neighbor was being unfair.

What did the Emperor's helper (the courtier) say to the neighbor?

(Pulls at my sleeves, voice barely above a whisper)

...The... the... courtier... (Long pause, eyes darting around the room) ...said... pay... rent? (Sounds like a question, unsure and anxious) Or... take the water... away? (Frowns, confused)

Yes! The courtier said the neighbor had to either pay rent for the water *in* the well, or take the water *out* of the well right away.

Why do you think the courtier said that?

(Confused, looks down at my hands)

...I... I don't... (Shakes head slightly, overwhelmed) ...know... (Mumbles) ...It's... hard... (Close to tears)

It's okay. It is a bit tricky.

Think about it this way: The neighbor said he only sold the well, not the water. So, if the water is still *his*, what is it doing in *someone else's* well?

(Eyes widen slightly, a glimmer of understanding)

...Oh... (Whispers) ...It's... like... he's... using... the farmer's well... to keep his water? (Looks up, a little less anxious, searching for confirmation)

Yes! Exactly! He's using the farmer's well to store his water. And if he's using the farmer's well, he should pay for it, right?

So, what happened to the neighbor after the courtier spoke to him?

(Relieved that I understood, but still hesitant)

...He... he... said... sorry? (Looks down, a little smile playing on my lips) And... and went home? (Quietly)

Yes! He said sorry and went home.

Why do you think he said sorry?

(Sticks to simple words)

...Because... he... was... wrong? (Looks at you briefly, then back down) He... he tried to trick... the farmer? (Voice small)

Yes! He tried to trick the farmer, and it didn't work.

So, what do you think this story teaches us? What's the big lesson?

(Fidgets with my hands again, looking increasingly anxious)

...Uh... (Long pause, avoids eye contact completely) ...Don't... trick... people? (Barely audible, with a lot of hesitation) ...It's... not... nice? (Voice cracking slightly, on the verge of tears)

You're very close! It's definitely not nice to trick people.

The story shows us that trying to trick people doesn't work out in the end. The neighbor tried to cheat the farmer, but he got caught.

So, we can say the story teaches us that... what happens if you try to cheat?

(Sniffles, wiping my eyes with the back of my hand)

...You... get... (Struggles to find the word) ...caught? (Looks up, teary-eyed, seeking reassurance) ...And... it's... bad? (Voice trembling)
Yes, you might get caught, and it's definitely bad. Trying to cheat will get you nowhere. It's better to be honest and fair. Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, still a little teary, but a bit calmer)

...Yes... (Quietly) ...I... understand... (Looks down at my hands again, relieved the questioning is over) Thank you, teacher. (A small, polite gesture)
You're welcome! I'm glad you understand the story now. You did a great job thinking about it! <finish>

Okay! That was a great job reading, [Student's Name]! That's a fun story, isn't it?

Let's talk about it. First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
Yes, sad! Why was the elephant sad?
(shrugs, avoids eye contact) ...uh... no friends? ... (long pause)
That's right! He didn't have any friends. And why didn't he have any friends? What did the other animals say?
(Stares blankly for a few moments, then looks around the room) ... The... the monkey...(pauses, chewing on lip) ...said...can't swing...(mumbles) in trees. (looks away, nervously)
Good job! The monkey said he couldn't swing in the trees. What about the rabbit? What did the rabbit say?
(long pause, looking at the floor)... uh... too big? (voice barely audible) ... to fit... (another long pause)... burrow...(eyes widen slightly, then looks back down)
Yes, the rabbit said he was too big to fit in the burrow! And the frog? Do you remember what the frog said?
(starts to bounce leg nervously) ... (whispers) ... Jump? ... Can't jump? (looks up quickly, then down again) ... uh... I don't know.

You're doing great! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump. So, all the animals said "no" because the elephant couldn't do what *they* could do.

Then, what happened the next day? What were the animals doing?

(eyes dart around the room, fiddling with clothes) Running! (voice a little louder, but still hesitant) ... Running from... (swallows hard) ... tiger! (suddenly looks very scared, pulls knees up to chest)
Yes, they were running from the tiger! And who stopped the tiger?
(points finger hesitantly) ... Elephant? ...(looks at you for confirmation, eyes wide) The elephant stopped... the tiger? (voice questioning)
The elephant did! How did the elephant stop the tiger?
(thinking hard, furrowing brow) ... Kicked? (looks up, anxious) ... Kicked the tiger... away? Is that right? (voice trembling slightly)
That's right! The elephant kicked the tiger away. Then, what did the other animals think about the elephant *after* he helped them?
(a small, relieved sigh escapes) ...Good friend? (looks at you pleadingly) ... Perfect size... to be friend? (voice barely a whisper) ... Uh... they liked him then.

Yes! They liked him then. So, at first, they didn't want to be friends because the elephant was different. But then, they realized he could help them in a special way.

What do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size or be able to do certain things?

(fidgets with hands again, looking down) ... Uh... (long pause) ... No? (looks up briefly, then back down) ... Size... not matter? (mumbles) ... Help... matters? (shrugs, looking confused) ... I don't know... (voice gets quieter) It's... confusing.

It's okay if it's confusing! Let's think about it this way: the monkey was small and could climb, the rabbit was small and could burrow. The elephant was big and strong.

Did being big and strong help the other animals?
(eyes widen slightly, a flicker of understanding) ... Yes! (but still hesitant) ... Helped with... tiger! Because... big and strong... scared tiger away. (voice gains a little confidence)
Exactly! So, does it matter if your friend is big or small, or if they can climb trees or jump high? What *really* matters?

(Stares intently, thinking hard, and then answers hesitantly) Being... helpful? (looks for reassurance)... and... kind? ( a small smile, barely noticeable, appears then disappears as anxiety returns) ... Uh... I think so?

You got it! Being helpful and kind matters most. The story shows us that friends can be different sizes and shapes and still be good friends. A good friend is someone who helps you and is kind to you, no matter what!

So, what's the lesson of the story? Friends can be any... what?

(Eyes downcast, fidgeting, mumbling)...Any...size? (looks up quickly, then back down again, a small tremor in voice) Any...shape? (barely audible) ... And... help each other? (a question more to himself) ... Uh... I think... I think that's it. (seems relieved the questioning is ending)
Yes! Friends can be any shape or size! They don't have to be exactly like you. What's important is that they are kind and helpful. You understood the story very well. <finish>
Okay! That was a good story, right? Now, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

(Looks down at my shoes, fiddling with my hands) Uh... (Stutters) she... she brought a... a potato? (Looks up quickly, then back down) And... uh... an egg. And... something else. (Thinking, bites lip)
You got it! You remembered the potato and the egg! What was that "something else"? Think about what you like to drink. Did it color the water?
(Eyes widen a little, remembering) ...Tea? (Whispers) Tea leaves?
Yes! Tea leaves! Great job! Now, what did her father do with the potato, the egg, and the tea leaves?
(Looks away, shuffling my feet) He... uh... (Long pause, looks at the teacher nervously) ...cooked them? ... In water? (Voice barely audible)
You're right! He cooked them in water. He boiled them. Now, after they were boiled, what happened to the *egg*? Was it the same as before?
(Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with my shoe) ...Uh... (Hesitates) ...It changed? (Looks up, anxious) I... I think it got... hard?
Yes! It got hard. The soft egg became hard. What about the potato? What happened to *it* after it was boiled?
(Thinking hard, frowning) ...The potato... (Looks at the teacher, worried) ...Um... Did it... did it get soft? (Whispers)
You got it! The hard potato got soft. And what about the tea leaves? What did *they* do to the water?
(Sticks to simple words) ...Changed it? (Looks down again, avoiding eye contact) The... the water... it's different now. (Mumbles)

Yes! The tea changed the water. So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water.

The story says the girl was frustrated, which means she wasn't happy and things were difficult for her. The boiling water can be like those difficult times.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about those difficult times?

(Frowns, looking confused) ...Uh... (Long pause, nervously picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Things change? (Looks up quickly, then back down, anxiously) ...Is that... is that right? I don't... I don't really know. (Whispers)

Things *do* change! That's part of it. The egg, the potato, and the water all changed. But *why* did they change? They each reacted to the hot water differently.

The egg, it was soft, but it became hard. The potato, it was hard, but it became soft. And the tea, it changed the water itself!

Can you think about what that means for *us* when things get hard?

(Thinking hard, eyes darting around the room, nibbling on my lip) ...Uh... (Stammers) ...So... like... if things are hard... (Looks at the teacher with wide, nervous eyes) ...We can... we can be like... like the potato? ...And get... get soft? (Whispers) ...Or... or like the egg... and get hard?
Yes! You're getting it! We can be like the potato and get soft, or like the egg and get hard. And what about the tea? What did *it* do?

(Frowns, concentrating, sticking out my tongue a little) ...The tea... (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in my eyes) ...It... it changed... (Stuttering) ...Everything? Like... like the water? (Looks down again, quieter) ...Can we... can we do that too?

Yes! The tea changed the water itself. It made the water *become* tea.

So, all of them reacted differently. The egg, the potato, and the tea.

Who decided if they would become hard, soft, or change the water? Did someone *else* decide for them?
(Shakes my head slowly, still looking down) ...No... (Whispers) ...They... they decided? (Looks up, a little less anxious, but still hesitant) ...So... so *we*... we get to decide too?

Exactly! We get to decide how we will be when things are hard. We can choose to be like the potato, the egg, or the tea.

So, what do you think is the most important thing this story is trying to teach us?

(Thinking really hard, brow furrowed, chewing on my lip) ...Uh... (Long pause, looks up at the teacher, then quickly down again) ...That... that we can... choose... (Whispers) ...Choose how we... how we act? ...When things are... bad?

Yes! You got it! We decide how to act when things are bad. We decide how to respond to difficult situations. The story is telling us that **we decide how to respond to difficult situations.**

That's a big idea, and you understood it! Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, let's talk about it. Who were the main people in the story?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking down at my shoes)

(My face scrunches up a little, like I'm remembering something unpleasant.)

... No. (Looks away, fiddling with my shirt sleeve) ... Mean.
Yes, he was mean. Okay, so the older brother was mean. Now, what happened when he found the tree? What did the tree offer him?

(Bites my lip, thinking hard. Frowns a little.)

... (Very quiet) Golden... apples? (Looks at the teacher, then quickly looks down again, nervously).
Yes! Golden apples. And did he take them?

... Uh-huh.
Okay! He took the golden apples. But what happened after that? Was he happy?

... No. (Whispers) He... wanted more.

(Eyes widen slightly, looking nervous, and I hunch my shoulders a bit)

... (Very softly) Needles... (I shiver slightly)
Needles! Lots and lots of needles. Ouch! Who helped him get the needles out?

(Looks up at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes, then quickly looks back down at my hands)

... (Almost inaudible) ... His brother?
Yes, his younger brother. Even though the older brother was mean, the younger brother still helped him. What did the older brother say after that?

(Pulls at my shirt collar, looking uncomfortable and red-faced.)

... (Stammering) ... S-sorry? (Looks up at the teacher, then immediately down again, like I'm ashamed)
He said sorry! That's right. And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do then?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow)

... (Quietly) More... apples? (Looking at the teacher questioningly, hoping I'm right)

More apples! That's right! The tree gave them more apples. So, the older brother was mean at first, but then he said sorry, and they got more apples.

What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Was it good to be mean, or good to be helpful?

(Looks down, scuffing my shoe on the floor. Hesitates, then looks up quickly at the teacher with a worried expression.)

... (Whispers) Good to... be nice? (Voice is very quiet and uncertain.)
Good to be nice! Yes! If the older brother kept being mean, do you think they would have gotten more apples?

(Shakes my head slowly, still looking down.)

...No...(Voice is barely audible)

Right. So, being kind, like the younger brother, helped them in the end. The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen.

We can say that "Kindness will always be rewarded". Does that make sense?<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story about King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... everything... uh... (stutters) to turn... to gold?

Yes! That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold.

Now, at first, was King Midas happy with his wish? Why or why not?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) ... Uh... Happy? (thinking) ... 'Cause gold?

Yes, he was happy *because* of the gold! He liked gold!

But did he stay happy? What happened next that made him *unhappy*?
(Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down) ...Food? (pauses) ...and... uh... (mumbles) ...daughter?
Yes! Tell me more about the food. What happened when he tried to eat?
(Sticks out tongue slightly, mimicking disgust) ... Couldn't... uh... (quietly) ...eat it? Turned to... gold. (Looks away again)

Exactly! The food turned to gold! And he couldn't eat it. He must have been very hungry!

Yes, she turned to gold too. How do you think King Midas felt when that happened? Was he still happy about his golden touch?
(Shakes head slightly, eyes still downcast) ... Uh... no. (pause) ...Sad? (Looks up briefly, a little more confidently) He couldn't hug her anymore.

That's right! He was very sad. He couldn't eat, and he couldn't even hug his daughter.

So, King Midas wanted more and more gold. But in the end, did the gold make him happy?
(Shakes head firmly) No. (Looks at the teacher, then quickly away) ...Not happy.
Okay. So he wanted all that gold, but it made him sad. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?
(Looks down, thinking hard. Frowns slightly) ... Uh... (long pause) ...Gold... not... important? (Looks at the teacher with a questioning look)
That's a good start! Gold *isn't* the *most* important thing. What was King Midas thinking about *most* of the time? What did he *really, really* want?
He really, really wanted gold! More than anything else, it seems. He was being very... what do you call someone who always wants more and more? Someone who isn't happy with what they have?
Okay, let's try this. Was King Midas being generous and sharing, or was he keeping all the gold for himself?

Yes! He was keeping it all for himself. He was being... greedy! The story is about how being greedy, wanting too much, can make you unhappy.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about being greedy?
(Looks at the floor, thinking) ...Greedy... (pause) ...Makes you... (struggles) ...sad? (Looks up at the teacher, hoping for confirmation)

Yes! Being greedy can make you sad. It can also make things bad for the people around you, like his daughter. So being greedy leads to unhappiness and sadness. That's the lesson! You understood that! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the fox.

Why was the fox looking around?
Yes, he was looking for food! And what did he find?
That's right! What did the grapes look like? Were they small and green, or big and purple?

(Thinking, bites lip)

…Big… and… purple? (looks at the teacher for confirmation)
Big and purple! And did the fox get the grapes?
No, he didn't. What did he do to try and get them?
He jumped high! He jumped as high as he could! Did he give up quickly, or did he try many times?

(Pauses, looking at the floor, thinking)

…Many times? …(eyes dart up to the teacher briefly)
Many times! And after trying many times, what did he do?

(Looks down, fiddling with a loose thread on shirt)

…Went… home?
He went home. And what did he say about the grapes when he went home?

(Hesitates, chewing on lip)

…Uh… sour? (Looks up at the teacher, unsure)
Sour! He said they were sour. Do you think the grapes *really* were sour?

(Shakes head slowly, looking at the desk)

…No…
Why do you think he said they were sour if they weren't really sour?

(Long pause, looks around the room, avoids eye contact, whispers)

…Don't know… (Shrugs shoulders)
Okay, let's think about it. He wanted the grapes really badly, right? But he couldn't get them. How do you think that made him feel? Maybe sad? Maybe mad?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping a finger on the desk. Looks at the teacher briefly, then down again.)

…Sad? …(Quietly) Maybe.
Maybe sad. So, he was sad he couldn't get the grapes. And then he said they were sour. Do you think maybe he said that to make himself feel better?

(Eyes widen slightly, considering this. Nods slowly, almost imperceptibly.)

…Uh… maybe…

Yes! It's like he was saying, "I didn't *really* want them anyway!" even though he did. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Is it good to say something is bad just because you can't have it?

(Thinks hard, frowning slightly. Looks at the teacher, then back down at hands.)

…No… (softly) Not good.

No, it's not good. The story is trying to tell us that if you can't get something, don't pretend you didn't want it or that it was bad anyway. It also tells us that things don't always come easy. What did the fox need to do to get the grapes?

(Looks down at shoes. Answers quietly)

…Try… hard?
Try hard! And what happened when he didn't try hard enough?

That's right! So, the story teaches us that we should try our best and not give up easily. And if we *still* can't get something, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it. We should just accept it. This story is telling us nothing comes easy and don't hate what you can't have. Do you understand now?

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher with a small, slightly unsure smile.)

…Uh… yeah. (Quietly) I think so.
Great! Can you tell me in your own words what the story is about and what it teaches us?

(Looks down, takes a deep breath. Hesitates.)

…Fox… wanted… grapes… (Stutters slightly) …Couldn't… get them… (Looks up at the teacher, then quickly down again) …Said… they were sour… But… (Pauses, thinking hard) …Shouldn't… say that… (Whispers) …Try hard… (Looks up, hopeful) …Is that right?

That's very good! You got it! The fox wanted the grapes but couldn't reach them, and he said they were sour even though he really wanted them. The story teaches us that we should try hard to get what we want, and if we can't, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it anyway. The story teaches us that nothing comes easy and don't hate what you can't have. You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good effort!

... No. (Looks up, a tiny bit more confident) ... Because the rose... thought it was... pretty?

... Sad? ...For the cactus?

... It... (long pause) ... withered? (Says the word hesitantly, like a question)

Withered! That's a big word! Yes, it withered. It started to dry up and get weak.

Now, who had water that the rose could use?

... The... (pauses, then says more quickly and confidently) ... the cactus!
The cactus! And why did the cactus have water? What was it doing with the water?

... It was... (struggles to find the words) ... giving it... to the... (looks at teacher, pleading for help)

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea, the lesson?

Yes! You got it! We shouldn't judge others just because they look different, or because we think we are better than them. We should be kind to everyone. That's what the story of the Proud Rose teaches us. Never judge someone according to how they look.

Okay, let's talk about the story! You just read "The Milkmaid and Her Pail."

First, who is the main person in the story?
(Looks down at my shoes) ... Uh... Molly? (Shrugs)

That's right! Molly is the milkmaid.

What was Molly going to do with the milk?

Good job! She was going to sell it at the market.

What did Molly start thinking about while she was walking?

Yes! She started dreaming about the things she could buy. What was one of the things she imagined buying?
A chicken! And what would the chicken give her?
Eggs! And what could she do with the eggs?
(Looks down, silent for a long time) ...Uh... (shrugs again) I don't know.
Think about what she was going to do with the milk. What do you think she could do with the eggs?
(Thinking hard, wrinkling forehead) ...Sell them... too? ... (Quietly) Like the milk?
Exactly! She wanted to sell the eggs, just like the milk. So, what happened to the milk in the end?
(Looks down, a little bit embarrassed) ... It... spilled? ... (Mumbles) All of it.
Yes, it all spilled. Why did it spill?
(Looks away, shuffling feet) ...She... was skipping? ... (Quietly) And... not looking?

That's right! She was so busy dreaming about chickens and eggs that she wasn't careful.

So, did Molly get to buy a chicken?
That's right. Empty pail, no chicken. What did her mother say to her?
(Looks down, tracing a pattern on the floor with a shoe) ...Something... about... chickens? (Confused look)
Yes! Her mother said, "Don’t count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means?
(Looks puzzled, then shrugs) ...Uh... (Silent, thinking hard, chewing on lip) I don't know... Is it... about... waiting?

Waiting... that's a good start! It's about waiting and being sure of something *before* you start making plans. Molly was planning on selling the eggs before she even *had* the chicken!

So, what do you think the big lesson of the story is? What should we learn from Molly's mistake?
(Looks down, fiddling with hands. Long pause.) ...Don't... skip? (Looks up quickly, then down again) ...Uh... (Mumbles) ...Don't... count chickens? ...Before they... hatch?
You're so close! It's not just about chickens. It's about *anything* you are hoping for. Should you start spending the money before you *actually* have it?
(Shakes head slowly) ...No... (Thinking, bites lip) Wait... till... you have... the money? (Looks up, a little more confident)

Yes! Wait until you *actually* have the money. Wait until it *really* happens. That's the lesson.

So, what's another way to say "Don't count your chickens until they hatch?" Think about what happened to Molly and the milk.
(Concentrating, forehead furrowed. Whispers to self) ...Milk... spilled... skipping... (Looks up hesitantly) ...Be careful... with... what you have? ...Don't... lose it?

That's a very good way to think about it! It's about being careful and not *depending* on something that *might* happen. You depend on things that are *sure* to happen.

So, if you tell a friend this lesson, what would you tell them? Can you tell me in your own words what this story teaches us?

(Looks down, takes a deep breath. Speaks very quietly) ...Um... Don't... get... too excited... (Shrugs) ...About... things... that... might... not happen? ...Wait... and see? (Looks up briefly, then down again, fiddling with shoes)
That's perfect! You understood the story and what it means. You know not to count your chickens before they hatch! <finish>
