Too big for what? Try to remember.

Yes! The rabbit said the elephant was too big for the burrow. So the elephant couldn't fit in the rabbit's home. What happened after the rabbit? Did anyone *else* say no to being friends with the elephant?
(Nods slowly) Uh-huh... the... frog? (Looks away again)
That's right, the frog! And why did the frog say no?
Yes! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump. So, everyone kept saying no because the elephant couldn't do the things *they* could do. How do you think the elephant felt?
Probably very sad. Now, what happened the next day in the forest? What were all the animals doing?
(Frowns, thinking) Running? (Looks up, a little more confident)
Running! Why were they running? Do you remember what the bear said?
Yes! The tiger was attacking. And what did the elephant do?
He did! He kicked the tiger and scared it away. What happened *after* the elephant scared the tiger away? How did the other animals feel *then*?
Happy, yes! And what did they realize about the elephant?
...(Looks down, fidgeting again) Uh... good friend? (Whispers)
Yes! They realized he could be a good friend. Why do you think they thought that *after* he scared the tiger, but not *before*?
(Thinking hard, bites lip) ... 'Cause... he helped? (Looks up, unsure)
He did help! He protected them. So, do you think the animals were right to say no to the elephant at the beginning just because he was different?

No! They were wrong. The story shows us that friends don't have to be exactly the same. They can be different sizes, and be good at different things.

So, what do you think is the big idea of this story? What does it teach us about friends?
...(Long pause, looking at the floor) Uh... (Looks up quickly, then back down) ... Be... nice? (Whispers)

Being nice is always good. But this story tells us something more about what makes a good friend. Think about the elephant and the other animals. They were all different, but in the end, they learned to be friends. So what does the story tell us about the size and shape of a friend?
...(Thinks hard, tapping foot) ... Doesn't... matter? (Looks at teacher hopefully)
You're getting very close! What doesn't matter? The size? The shape?
(Looks up, a little more confident) ... Size... doesn't matter? (Waits for confirmation)
You're right! And what else doesn't matter?
...(Looks down, thinking) Uh... what... they can... do? (Sounds unsure)
Not exactly *what* they can do, but *how* they are. Like, the elephant couldn't swing or jump. So, what part of them didn't matter to being a good friend?
...(Long pause, thinking, then looks up with a small spark of understanding) ... Being different? (Whispers)

Yes! Being different doesn't matter! Friends can be different sizes, shapes, and good at different things. The important thing is being kind and helpful. So, can you try to say the whole idea of the story in one sentence? It's okay if it's hard!
(Takes a deep breath, looks at the teacher, then looks away) Uh... friends... can be... different... but... still... good? (Sounds a little more confident but still hesitant)
That's a *really* good try! How about this: Friends can be any shape or size! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

So, tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?
(Looks down at my desk, shuffling my feet) Uh... an egg? (Pause) ...and... uh... a potato? (Looks up quickly, then back down)
Yes! You got it! An egg and a potato. What else did she bring? Think about what made the water change color.
(Thinking, tapping a pencil on the desk) ...uh... something... brown? (Looks at the teacher with wide, unsure eyes)
Brownish! Good thinking! What do we use to make tea? Think about what your parents might use.
(Eyes widen slightly, remembering) Tea... leaves? (Says it quietly, almost like a question)
Tea leaves! Wonderful! So, she brought an egg, a potato, and tea leaves. What did her father do with them?
(Looks down, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) He... um... (Shrugs, avoiding eye contact) ...cooked them? (Voice barely a whisper)
He did cook them! But how did he cook them? Did he put them all in the same pot?
(Shakes head slightly) ...Nooo... (Pause) ...Different pots? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then down again)
Different pots! You're doing great! He put each one in its own pot of hot water. Now, what happened to the egg after it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?
(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) ...It got... (Stutters) ...uh... hard? (Looks up, seeking confirmation)
Yes! The soft egg got hard. Good job! What happened to the potato? Was it hard after being in the hot water?
(Looks at the desk, tracing patterns with a finger) The potato... (Pause) ...got soft? (Sounds a little more confident this time)
You got it! The hard potato got soft. And what about the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft?
(Looks puzzled, scratches head) ...Uh... they... (Long pause) ...changed the water? (Looks up, confused)
Exactly! They changed the water. The water was just plain water before, but the tea leaves made it... what?
(Struggles, chewing on the end of the pencil) ...Tea? (Asks hesitantly)

Yes! They made tea. So, the egg got hard, the potato got soft, and the tea leaves changed the water. Now, the story says this is like when "adversity knocks." Do you know what "adversity" means? It's okay if you don't.
(Shakes head slowly, avoids eye contact) ...Uh... no? (Looks down, feeling a little lost)

"Adversity" is like when something hard or bad happens. Like a problem. So, the hot water is like a problem. The egg, the potato, and the tea leaves are like us.

The egg was soft but became hard. The potato was hard but became soft. The tea changed the water.

So, what do you think the father was trying to teach his daughter about problems? Can we all handle problems in the same way?

(Frowns, thinking very hard, tapping a foot) ...Uh... maybe... (Long pause, looks down at hands) ...some people... get harder? (Looks up, a flicker of understanding in eyes) ...And some... get softer? (Looks down again, confused)
That's a really good start! You're right, some people might "get harder" like the egg. Some might "get softer" like the potato. And what about the tea? What did *it* do?
(Thinking, almost whispering) ...Changed... the water... (Looks up, a tiny bit brighter) ...Changed... the problem? (Still hesitant, but a little more confident)

Yes! Changed the problem! The tea didn't just get hard or soft. It changed the whole water. So, the father was showing her that when problems come, *we* can change how we react. We can be like the egg, the potato, *or* the tea.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about how we should deal with problems?
(Looks down, thinking hard. Bites lip) ...Um... (Pause, looks up quickly, then down again) ...Be... like... tea? (Quietly, almost a question)
Why tea? What does the tea do that's different from the egg and the potato?
(Shuffles feet, looks at the floor) ...It... (Long pause) ...makes... the problem... better? (Voice barely audible)
Yes! It changes the problem itself! So, the story wants us to know that we can choose how we deal with problems. We can choose to become hard, or soft, or... what?
(Looks up, a little more confidently) ...Or... change the problem? (A small smile appears)
Exactly! We get to decide how we respond! That's the important thing. We decide! You understood the story so well. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! Now, let's talk about the story.

Who are the main people in the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil)

Uh... (Pauses) ... the... brothers?

Yes! You got it! There are two brothers.

Was the older brother nice to the younger brother?
(Shakes head slowly) ...No. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at the desk.)
No, he wasn't. What did the older brother do that wasn't very nice?
(Thinking, chewing on my lip) ...He... (Stutters) ...he was mean? (Looks up, hoping for confirmation).
He was mean! That's right. Can you remember *how* he was mean? What did he *do*? Think about what he did *before* he met the tree.
(Eyes dart around the room, unfocused) ...Uh... (Long pause) ...firewood?
Firewood is part of it! He chopped firewood. But how does that connect to the younger brother? Think about how they treated each other.
(Looks down at my hands, picking at a loose thread) ... Uh... I don't... I don't know. (Whispers) Did he share the firewood?

That's a very good question! The story doesn't say if he shared the firewood. But it does say he was mean. The firewood was his job, so maybe he didn't share other things?

Let's think about the tree. What did the tree offer the older brother if he didn't chop it down?
(Eyes widen slightly) ... Golden... apples? (Looks up at the teacher, a little more engaged).
Golden apples! That's right! Did the older brother think that was enough?
(Shakes head quickly, eyes back down) ... No...
No, he didn't! What did he do then? This is where it gets a bit exciting!
He tried to cut the tree! And what happened when he did? What did the tree do?
(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) ... Uh... needles? (Looks up, questioning)
Needles! Lots and lots of needles! How do you think the older brother felt then?
(Quietly) ... Sad? ... and ouchy? (Makes a small wincing face).

"Ouchy" is a perfect word for it! He was definitely in pain.

Now, who helped him when he was covered in needles?
Yes! The younger brother helped him. Did the younger brother *have* to help him? Remember, the older brother was mean!
(Shakes head, looking at the floor) ... No... (Pause) ... He didn't have to.
That's right. He *chose* to help. He was being kind. And what happened *after* the younger brother helped him? What did the older brother say?
(Thinking, tapping my pencil on the desk) ... Sorry? (Looks up, uncertain)
He said sorry! He apologised for being mean. And what happened *then*? This is the very end of the story!
(Eyes widen, remembering) ... More... golden apples? (A small smile appears).
More golden apples! You remembered! So, the tree gave them more apples because the older brother said sorry. Why do you think the tree did that? What do you think the tree wanted them to learn?
(Looks down, scuffing my shoe against the floor) ... Uh... (Long pause) ... Be... nice? (Voice is very quiet).
Be nice! Yes! Being kind to each other. Do you think being kind is important?
(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher) ... Yes... (A small, genuine smile). Thank you for helping me understand.
You're very welcome! You did a great job figuring out the story. So, being kind is important, and sometimes, when we are kind, good things happen. Kindness is rewarded! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, right?

So, can you tell me, who was the main person in the story?

(Eyes dart around the room, tapping my foot impatiently) Uh, yeah, it was... okay, I guess. (Looks away)

The, uh, the *main* person? (Shrugs) Was it that... that gold guy? King... uh... Mimdas? Midas! Yeah, King Midas! He wanted everything to be, like, shiny. (Starts picking at my fingernails)

That's right! King Midas! Good job remembering his name.

Now, what did King Midas wish for? Do you remember?

(Sighs dramatically) Ugh, *gold*. (Rolls eyes) He wanted everything to turn to gold. Like, *everything*. (Scowls) Stupidest wish *ever*. I would have wished for... a giant robot! Or maybe a lifetime supply of candy! (Voice gets louder and more excited, then abruptly cuts off and I become anxious again) Gold is...is boring. (Starts fidgeting with my pencil, nearly dropping it).

A giant robot *would* be a cool wish! But let's stick with the story for now. You said King Midas wanted everything to turn to gold.

And what happened when he got his wish? What's the first thing he touched?

(Stares blankly) I don't know! (Voice rising, getting defensive) I wasn't paying attention to the *first* thing! Why does it even matter? (Crosses arms, pouting). Probably touched his crown or something dumb like that. (Muttering under breath) This is so boring. Can we be done now? (Starts tapping foot rapidly)

It's okay! It's not a test. It *does* matter, though. Thinking about the *first* thing can help us understand the story better. Let's see...do you remember *anything* he touched that turned to gold? Maybe his food?

(Eyes widen slightly, remembering something) Oh! Oh yeah! The food! (Speaking quickly, interrupting) He couldn't eat! (Becomes nervous again) Because it was all...hard and shiny! Like, he wanted to eat it but he couldn't! (Shivers) That would be the *worst*! Even worse than broccoli! (Forces a small laugh, then looks around anxiously)
That's right! He couldn't eat! How do you think that made him feel?

(Frowns, thinking hard. Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Probably...mad. (Looks up, then quickly away). And hungry! (Voice cracks slightly) I get *really* mad when I'm hungry. (Shrugs) Maybe a little...scared? I don't know! (Suddenly bursts out) It's just a story! Why do we have to talk about feelings? (Starts to tear up a little, rubbing my eyes with my fists).

It's okay to feel mad or scared. It's good to talk about feelings, because it helps us understand the story, and it helps us understand each other!

So, King Midas was hungry. He was mad. And maybe a little scared. What else happened in the story that made him feel even worse? Think about his daughter.

(Sniffles, wiping nose with sleeve) Oh... (Voice barely a whisper) His daughter... (Looks down at hands, tracing circles on the desk with a finger). She...she hugged him. (A tear rolls down my cheek) And she turned... all... gold. (Starts sobbing quietly, face buried in arms). It's...it's not fair! (Muffled sobs). He didn't mean to!

You're right, it wasn't fair. It was a very sad thing that happened.

Now, why do you think his daughter turned to gold?

(Sniffles, lifts head, eyes red and puffy, but dries eyes with fists) Because... because he... he had the stupid... gold touch! (Voice still shaky but with a hint of anger). Everything he touched turned to gold! Even... even his daughter. (Wipes nose again) It was a... a curse! (Glances around nervously, then back down at hands) He wanted gold, but... but he lost his daughter! (Shudders)

Yes, he did. He thought he wanted gold more than anything. But he lost something very important.

So, King Midas wished for everything he touched to turn to gold. He got his wish. But was it a good wish, in the end?

(Sniffs again, but looks up, thinking harder. Frowns.) No! (Says it firmly this time). It was the *worst* wish ever! He couldn't eat! He couldn't hug his daughter! (Voice rising again, starting to get agitated). It was a *stupid*, selfish wish! (Takes a deep breath, trying to calm down). He... he thought gold was the most important thing, but... but it wasn't. It made everything worse. (Looks at you with a mixture of sadness and anger). He should have wished for... for something that would make him *happy*, not just rich! (Begins fidgeting with hands again)

You're exactly right! He thought gold would make him happy, but it didn't. It made him very unhappy.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to tell us?

(Taps foot, chews on lip, avoiding eye contact). Uh... (Struggles, then bursts out) Don't be greedy! (Looks away, feeling anxious). And... and money isn't everything? (Frowns, then thinks harder). Maybe... be careful what you wish for? (Stops fidgeting, almost looking hopeful) 'Cause you might get it, but it might be... awful! (Shivers slightly, remembering the golden daughter). And... and hug your family! (Suddenly looks sad again, then back to being easily distracted. Starts humming quietly to self).

Those are all great ideas! The story shows us that wanting too much, being greedy, can lead to bad things happening. King Midas only thought about himself and wanting more gold. Because of that, he lost the things that were really important. So, the story teaches us to be happy with what we have, and not to be too greedy. Does that make sense?

(Nods slowly, picking at a piece of lint on clothes) Yeah... (A tiny, fleeting smile appears). Happy with what you have... not greedy. (Looks up, a little brighter) Like... like being happy with just one giant robot instead of, like, a million! (Giggles, then quickly covers mouth, looking around nervously again. The moment of lightness is gone.) Uh... yeah. I get it. (Sighs and looks away, disinterested again). Can we draw now?

Yes, being happy with just one giant robot is a great way to think about it! You understood the story very well. You thought about King Midas, his wish, and what happened to him. And you figured out the important lesson the story teaches us. Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

Now, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?

(Starts swinging my legs under the desk, tapping my pencil really fast. Looks around the room, then back at the teacher.)

Uh... food! (Says it really loudly and quickly, then looks away, fiddling with my shoelaces.) He was... uh... REALLY hungry! Is it almost recess?

(Smiles kindly) Yes, you're right! He was looking for food because he was really hungry. And yes, recess is coming soon! But let's just talk about the fox for a few more minutes.

What did the fox see that he wanted to eat?

(Stops swinging legs, looks up suddenly, eyes wide.)

Grapes! BIG, PURPLE grapes! (Stands up, then sits back down, bouncing in my seat) Like the ones... like the ones my grandma has in her garden, but... bigger! (Frowns) Why did he want *grapes* anyway? Grapes are... kinda boring. I like cookies better. (Sighs dramatically) Are we *sure* we can't talk about cookies instead? Grapes are… (Stops talking, starts humming quietly and staring out the window)

(Chuckles softly) Okay, okay, big purple grapes! You remembered that very well. Cookies *are* pretty yummy. But let's stick with the grapes for now, just a little bit longer.

Did the fox get the grapes?

(Scowls, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)

No! (Says it loudly and abruptly) He jumped... and jumped... and jumped... but he couldn't reach! (Crosses arms, huffs) Stupid grapes were too high! It's not fair! If *I* were the fox, I would have… I would have… (Thinks hard, wrinkling my nose) …I dunno. Used a trampoline? (Giggles) But there wasn't a trampoline, so… no, he didn't get them.

That's right! He jumped and jumped but couldn't get them. You're a good storyteller!

How do you think the fox felt when he couldn't reach the grapes? Was he happy? Sad? Something else?

(Taps foot impatiently, looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, rolling eyes)

Sad? (Scoffs) Maybe a little. But he was probably mostly MAD! I get MAD when I can't get what I want! (Punches the air lightly) Like... like when my brother eats all the good cereal! Or when... (Trails off, then bursts out) ...or when *you* won't talk about cookies! It's just... ARGH! Unfair! (Pouts, crossing arms again, slumping in the chair)

I understand. It's frustrating when you can't get what you want.

What did the fox say about the grapes *after* he couldn't get them?

(Eyes light up slightly, leans forward a little)

He said... (pauses, concentrates hard, biting lip) ...he said they were... sour! Yeah! "Those grapes are probably sour anyway!" (Says it in a high-pitched, whiny voice, imitating the fox) He was just saying that 'cause he was mad, right? They probably weren't *really* sour! He just didn't want to admit he couldn't reach them. (Looks pleased with self, then yawns widely) Can we be done now? My tummy is rumbling! Maybe they're serving cookies at lunch!

Yes, you're exactly right! He said they were sour because he was mad and didn't want to admit he couldn't reach them.

So, the fox wanted something, he tried hard to get it, but he couldn't. Then he said he didn't even want it anyway.

What do you think we can learn from that story? What's the big idea, or the lesson, of The Fox and the Grapes? It's okay if you're not sure!

(Sighs dramatically, slumps further in the chair, avoids eye contact)

Ugh... a lesson? (Mumbles) I dunno... something about... grapes? And... foxes? (Taps pencil against the desk, making a rhythmic beat) Maybe... don't jump for grapes? 'Cause it's... hard? Or... or... (Suddenly sits up straight, eyes wide) ...maybe it means... if you can't get something, just say you didn't want it anyway, and then you won't feel so bad! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, bouncing slightly in the seat) Is *that* it? (Whispers) I really hope that's it...

That's a really good try! You're close.

It *is* about what you do when you can't get something you want. But instead of just saying you didn't want it, maybe it's about... well, is it good to hate something just because you can't have it? What if the grapes were actually delicious?

(Frowns, looks down at hands, picks at fingernails)

Hmm... (Thinking hard, sticks tongue out slightly) So... so it's like... the fox was lying? To himself? So he wouldn't feel... dumb? Or... or... (Snaps fingers) ...like he failed! 'Cause failing is the *worst*! (Looks up, eyes pleading) Is *that* the lesson? Don't lie about things 'cause you failed? Just... try again later? Or... or... ask someone for help reaching the grapes? (Whispers) Maybe a *really* tall friend?

You're getting so close!

It's definitely not good to lie. And you're right, maybe he could have asked for help!

But the story is mostly about what we do with ourselves when something is hard. Think about it: The fox tried his best. It was hard. He couldn't get the grapes. So instead of being sad or trying again later, he said something mean about the grapes.

Maybe the lesson is: It's okay if something is hard. And it's not a good idea to be mean to things just because we can't have them. What do you think?

(Considers this, gnawing on the end of the pencil)

So... so it's okay to be... (struggles for the word) ...disappointed? If you can't get the thing? And... (hesitates) ...don't call the thing names just 'cause you're disappointed? (Looks at the teacher, then down at the pencil) Even if it's *really* disappointing? Like... (brightens suddenly) ...like when someone else gets the last cookie! You shouldn't say the cookie is gross, even if you *really* wanted it! (Nods decisively) Yeah! I get it! Sort of! (Looks up, hopeful) Is that good enough? Can we talk about cookies now?

That's *perfect*! You got it! It's okay to be disappointed, and you shouldn't hate something just because you can't have it.

You're right, even if someone else gets the last cookie, you shouldn't say it's gross! You understood the story and what it means. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of The Proud Rose! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me who the story was about?

(Swinging my legs under the desk, fiddling with my shoelaces) Yeah, yeah, it was... okay. (Looks away, then back quickly) It was about... a rose! And... and... (stuttering) ...a...a spiky green thing! (Confident tone) I know big words! Cactus! It was about a rose and a cactus! (Runs hand through hair, then leans back in chair dramatically) Can I go play now?

That's right! A rose and a cactus. Good job remembering "cactus"!

Now, what did the rose do to the cactus? Do you remember?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) Ugh, *that* part. (Fidgets with a pencil) She... she was mean! (Confidently) Super mean! She said the cactus was... (thinking, taps pencil on the desk) ...ugly! And... (looks away, mumbling) ...spiky. (Loudly) She was being a BIG bully! (Shifts in seat, anxious) I don't like bullies. Can we talk about something else? Like recess? Is it recess time yet?

You're right, the rose *was* being a big bully. It's good that you don't like bullies!

Why do you think the rose was being mean to the cactus? What did the rose think about herself?

(Sighs dramatically) Because... (thinking, stares at the ceiling) ...she thought she was prettier! (Makes a face) The rose was, like, obsessed with her... her... (searching for the word) ...*appearance*! (Confidently, using a complex word) She thought she was the bestest and prettiest flower ever! (Pulls a face) So, she was mean to the cactus! (Suddenly stands up, pacing) I think she was dumb. Being mean is dumb! (Anxious) Are we done yet? I feel kinda... twitchy.

Okay, you're doing great! Yes, the rose thought she was the prettiest and that made her mean.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?

(Stops pacing, looks worried) Oh no! (Fidgets with hands) The sun came! It was super hot! (Dramatically clutches chest) The rose... the rose... (stuttering) ...she started to... to... (searches for word) ...shrivel up! (Confidently) Like a raisin! She was all dry and sad! (Looks away, nervously) That sounds really bad. I don't like thinking about things dying.

You're right, the rose started to shrivel up like a raisin.

And what about the cactus? What was the cactus doing?

(Eyes widen, a little more excited) The cactus! (Taps foot impatiently) He was... he was being awesome! (Thinking, furrows brow) He had... (struggles to find the word) ...water! (Shouts triumphantly) He saved the little birdies! Little birdies drinking from the cactus! (Claps hands) They were happy! (Leans forward, conspiratorially) I like birdies. Do you like birdies? Can we draw birdies now?

Yes! The cactus was helping the birds!

And then, what did the rose do? She was thirsty, wasn't she? What did she ask the cactus?

(Groans, slumps back in chair) Oh, *fine*. (Rolls eyes) She... she had to ask the cactus for... for... (whispers) ...help. (Louder) She asked for water! (Scoffs) After being sooooo mean! (Stands up again, agitated) She was probably all sniffly and dramatic! (Mimics crying) "Oh, Mr. Cactus, please help me!" Ugh! (Anxious, fidgets) Can we be done now? My tummy feels funny.

Okay, almost done! You're doing so well!

Yes, the rose asked the cactus for water. And what did the cactus do? Did he say no?

(Pauses, looks thoughtful for a second, then shrugs) Nah. (Shakes head) The cactus... he wasn't mean like the rose. (Confident) He was nice! (Frowns) He gave her the water! Even though she was a big, mean bully! (Paces again, agitated) I don't know why he did that! I wouldn't give water to a bully! (Anxious) This story is weird! Can I go now? My head hurts a little.

You're right, the cactus *was* nice, even after the rose was mean.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big message? Is it about judging people based on how they look?

(Stops pacing, looks confused) Huh? (Scratches head) Judging? (Uses complex word) Is that like... being mean? (Anxious) Is that what *I'm* doing? (Looks around nervously) I don't wanna be mean! (Thinking hard, screwing up face) Maybe... maybe it means... (shrugs) ...don't be a jerk? (Louder, more confident) And... and even if someone *is* a jerk, you should still... (stutters) ...be...be...nice? (Sighs dramatically) But that's hard! (Looks pleadingly) Can I *please* go now? My brain is full!

You almost got it! It means we shouldn't decide if someone is good or bad just by looking at them. The rose was pretty, but she was mean. The cactus was spiky, but he was kind. So, never judge someone according to how they look.

And even if someone is mean to you, like the rose was to the cactus, it's still good to be kind. You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>
Okay! So, you just read "The Milkmaid and Her Pail." What was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Fidgets, looks around the room) Uh... milk? She was... (scratches head) selling it! To get money! (Bursts out) I would buy a HUGE robot with that money! One that can shoot lasers! (Runs hands in the air mimicking lasers firing) Pew pew pew!

(Smiling) Pew pew pew! Robots are cool! But, let's talk about Molly. She wanted to sell the milk to get money, that's right! What did she *plan* to do with the money? What was she thinking about buying?

(Stops making laser noises abruptly, face scrunches up) Buying? (Looks away, tapping foot impatiently) Oh! Oh! (Snaps fingers) A chicken! (Confidently) She was gonna buy a chicken! (Crosses arms, puffs out chest) That's a *really* smart idea! Chickens are better than milk! They make eggs! Then you can sell the eggs! More money! (Gets excited again) You could buy, like, a whole *army* of chickens! Then you'd be super rich! (Stands up and starts pacing, muttering to self) Chicken army... chicken empire...

(Chuckles softly) An army of chickens! That sounds... interesting! So, Molly was thinking about the chicken and the eggs. What happened *because* she was thinking about all that? Think about what happened to the milk.

(Stops pacing, looks down at shoes, face turns red) Uh... (Stuttering) I... I don't... I don't wanna talk about it! (Voice rising, starting to tear up) It's stupid! Stupid milk! Stupid story! (Throws hands up in the air) It spilled! Okay?! It all spilled! (Sits back down heavily, crossing arms and glaring) Happy now?

(Calmly and gently) It's okay. It *is* a bit sad that the milk spilled. But it's important to understand *why* it spilled. Can you tell me *why* the milk spilled, even though it makes you a little sad? What was Molly doing when it spilled?

(Sniffling, wiping nose with sleeve) She was... (Muttering) She was being dumb. (Louder) She was skipping! She was so busy thinking about chickens and being rich that she forgot about the milk! (Looks up, eyes wide) It's not *my* fault she spilled it! She's just not very good at carrying milk! (Grumbling under breath) I wouldn't spill it... I'm way better at carrying things...
You are probably very good at carrying things! But Molly was skipping and thinking about chickens. What did her mom say at the end? Do you remember? It's okay if you don't!

(Thinking hard, face screwed up in concentration) Hmmm... hmmm... (Suddenly brightens) Oh! I know! She said... she said... something about... (Frustrated sigh) Chickens! (Shouts) "Don't count your chickens!" Yeah! That's what she said! (Looks proud of himself) But what does that even *mean*? It's a dumb saying. Why wouldn't you count chickens? They're chickens! You should know how many you have! (Starts counting fingers loudly) One, two, three... I bet I could count to a hundred chickens!

You *definitely* could count to a hundred chickens! But the saying means something else. It means... what do you think it means *now* that you know what happened to Molly and the milk? She was counting her chickens *before* they...? What hadn't happened yet?

(Taps chin thoughtfully) Before... before... (Eyes widen) Before they hatched! (Looks triumphant) It means... it means you shouldn't plan on things happening before they *actually* happen! Like, don't buy a robot *before* you get the money! (Looks slightly deflated) Even if it's a robot with lasers... (Mumbles) Pew pew...

Exactly! Don't plan on things *before* they actually happen. Molly was planning on being rich from the chickens *before* she even bought one, and before the eggs even hatched! So, what's the lesson of the story? What does the story try to teach us?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) Ugh, lessons. (Rolls eyes) It teaches us that... (Thinks for a second, then sits up straighter) It teaches us to be careful! And to not skip when you have milk! (Pause) And... and maybe chickens aren't *always* the best idea. (Looks sad again) Even though they're cool and lay eggs... and you could have a chicken army... (Muttering) But the milk spilled... (Looks at you with a slightly anxious expression) Is that... is that the right lesson? Am I doing it right?

You are doing great! It *is* about being careful, and maybe not skipping with milk! But it's mostly about *when* you start planning for something. Should you start planning *before* something is certain, or *after*? Think about Molly and her chickens.

(Grumbling) So many rules! (Taps fingers on the desk) Okay, okay... (Brightens a little) Don't count your chickens 'til they hatch! So... plan *after*! After you have the chickens! After the eggs hatch! After you sell the eggs and get the money! Then you can plan for the robot! (Looks at you hopefully) Is that it? Did I learn the lesson? Can I go now? (Starts gathering belongings)

Yes! That's exactly it! It's better to wait until you *know* something will happen before you start planning for it. Just like Molly should have waited until she *actually* had the chickens and the eggs before she started planning how to spend the money. You understood the story and the lesson very well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! It's a good one.

So, tell me, what did the old owl do every day?

(Starts tapping my foot, looking around the room, then back at the teacher, fidgeting)

Umm... (Stuttering) The... the owl... saw stuff. (Looks away) Like, all sorts of things! People, I think? Were they people? He *heard* them too! (Voice gets louder) They were TALKING! And... and stories! Big, long, boring stories, probably. I don't know. (Shrugs, picking at a loose thread on my shirt). Did he eat mice? The story didn't say anything about mice. Was he a hungry owl?

(Smiling gently) That's right, the owl saw and heard things! Good remembering.

Let's focus on what the story *did* tell us. You said he saw "all sorts of things" and heard people talking and sharing stories.

Did the story say the owl talked a lot?

(Rolls eyes dramatically, swings legs under the chair, then leans forward suddenly, speaking loudly)

NO! He didn't! He... (thinking, brow furrowed) he talked *less*! (Taps a finger on the desk impatiently). Because he saw all that stuff! It said that right in the story! Duh! (Looks around the room again, then back to the teacher, a bit defiantly). Why are we talking about this? I want to draw.

(Chuckles softly) Okay, okay, good job! You're right, he talked less.

Now, why do you think the owl talked less because he saw and heard so much? What happened to him because he was watching and listening? Did he stay the same or did he change?

(Sighs loudly, slumping in the chair. Starts humming a little tune.)

Changed? (Looks up, confused, then shouts) I DON'T KNOW! (Voice drops to a mumble) Maybe he got old and grumpy like my grandpa. He doesn't talk much either. (Starts picking at a scab on my knee.) The owl... maybe he got bored. Or... or maybe he learned something! (Looks up, a spark of interest) Was he a smart owl? Did he learn how to fly faster? Did he find a secret treasure? The story should have said that! It's a dumb story!

(Calmly) The story didn't say he found treasure or learned to fly faster. But you're right, maybe he *did* learn something.

The story said he became "wiser." What does "wiser" mean? Is that like being grumpy, or like learning something?

(Scowls, fidgeting with a pencil, then throws it down on the desk with a clatter.)

Wiser... (thinking hard, chewing on lip) Wiser is... is like... knowing stuff! (Points finger in the air suddenly, excitedly) Like, knowing not to touch the stove when it's hot! Or... or knowing that broccoli tastes yucky! (Makes a face). So, the owl... (Voice trails off) he knew a lot of stuff because he saw and heard things. (Looks at the teacher, a little anxious) Is that right? Am I right? (Starts to bounce leg nervously).

(Nods encouragingly) Yes! You're getting it! Wiser *is* like knowing a lot of things.

So, the owl watched and listened, and he became wiser. Do you think watching and listening helped him become wiser? How?

(Paces back and forth in front of the desk, agitated. Speaks quickly and loudly)

Of COURSE it helped! (Stops suddenly, arms crossed.) I told you, he HEARD things! And SAW things! He wasn't just sitting there doing nothing! (Taps foot impatiently.) If I just sat here all day, I wouldn't learn anything! Unless... unless you told me something REALLY cool! Like... like about dinosaurs! Did the owl see any dinosaurs? Probably not. They're all GONE! (Voice cracks, near tears) They're all... (Takes a deep breath, trying to calm down). The owl learned because he paid attention!

(Softly and calmly) You're absolutely right. He learned because he paid attention. He watched and listened.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What can *we* learn from the wise old owl? Is it good to talk all the time, or is it good to watch and listen sometimes too?

(Sits down heavily, face scrunched up. Mumbles)

(Stuttering) It's... it's good to... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher, eyes wide with sudden inspiration) It's good to spy! (Grins mischievously). Like a secret agent! You can learn all sorts of things if you just watch and listen! (Whispers conspiratorially) Then you know all the secrets! But... but (Voice quieter), it's also... (Frowns) It's also good to talk... sometimes. (Shrugs). If you have something REALLY important to say. Or... or if you're telling a really cool story.

(Smiling) That's a great way to put it! It *is* like being a secret agent!

So, the owl didn't talk much, he watched and listened. And because he watched and listened, he became wise.

So maybe... talking less and watching more can help us learn things too. What do you think?

(Nods slowly, thoughtfully, looking down at hands)

(Stuttering) Yeah... (Looks up, with a mischievous glint in eyes) But only if it's interesting! If it's boring, I'm going to talk! Or draw! Or... or look for dinosaurs! (Grins, then hesitates) But maybe... (Voice softer) Maybe I should try to listen more... sometimes. (Looks away, kicking feet under the desk). Can I go draw now? Please? Dinosaurs!
(Nods, smiling) Yes, you can go draw dinosaurs now. You did a great job understanding the story! The story is about learning to be a good listener and observer. You figured that out! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it?

First, tell me, who are the characters in the story?

(Starts tapping foot impatiently, eyes darting around the room)

Umm... (stuttering) Yeah, it was kinda boring. Characters? Like, the people in the story? Uh... (scratches head) There was a... a farmer. And a... a goose! A golden goose! And uh... (blurts out) his wife! She was dumb! (giggles)

(Smiling encouragingly)

You got them all! Yes, there's the farmer, the goose, and the farmer's wife.

Why do you think the wife was dumb? What did she do?

(Rolls eyes) Duh! (crosses arms) She agreed with the farmer! He wanted more eggs, and she said okay! (voice rising) Like, hello?! One golden egg a day is, like, a LOT! (jumps in seat) She should have told him he was being stupid! (looks away, fidgeting) Now they're both poor! Serves them right!

(Nodding gently)

Okay, so you think she made a bad choice by agreeing with the farmer. Why was wanting more eggs a bad idea? What was happening *before* they wanted more?

(Sighs dramatically) Ugh, you're making me think! (taps fingers on the desk) Before? (pauses, thinking) They were... rich-ish? (looks up, confused) No, not rich. Comfortable! Yeah, comfortable. They had enough money 'cause of the golden egg. (shrugs) So, like, why mess with that? (scowls) The farmer was just greedy! Stupid farmer! (kicks chair slightly)

(Calmly)

You're right, they were comfortable! The golden egg helped them have enough. And you said the farmer was greedy. What does "greedy" mean?

(Puffs out cheeks) Greedy means... (thinks hard, brow furrowed) Wanting MORE! (eyes light up) Like, WAY more than you need! Like when Timmy takes all the cookies at snack time, even though everyone else only gets one! (scoffs) That's greedy! The farmer wanted ALL the eggs at once! He didn't need them all right away! He's a big, fat... (stops abruptly, looks around nervously) ...meanie!

(Chuckles softly)

Okay, yes! That's a great example. Timmy is being greedy! And the farmer was being greedy too. What happened *after* the farmer tried to get all the eggs at once? What did he find?

(Face screws up in disgust) Ewwww! He found... (makes gagging noises) ...blood! And guts! (shudders) The poor goose! (voice softens slightly, but then quickly returns to being loud) And NO golden eggs! Ha! Serves him right! Now he has nothing! He's probably crying now! (laughs loudly) I bet his wife is super mad!

(Nodding)

He found a big mess, didn't he? And no more golden eggs. So, before, they were comfortable because of the goose. And after, they were... what?

(Leans back in chair, swinging legs) They were... (snaps fingers) ...POOR! (grins) Super poor! Poorer than dirt! They lost everything because the farmer was greedy! (eyes gleam mischievously) Maybe they had to sell their house and live in a cardboard box! (laughs again) That would be funny!

(Gently)

It's not very nice to laugh at their misfortune, even if they made a mistake. But you're right, they became very poor. So, the farmer acted quickly because he wanted more, but did he *think* about what would happen?

(Scoffs) Think? That farmer couldn't think his way out of a paper bag! (taps head with finger) He just wanted more, more, MORE! (mimics grabbing motions with hands) He didn't think about the goose or the eggs or his wife or anything! (rolls eyes) He was just being... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...a JERK! (sticks tongue out)

(Smiling)

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us? It has something to do with thinking before you act...

(Frowns, picking at a loose thread on shirt) Learn? Ugh, learning is boring. (pauses, thinking) Okay, okay... (snaps fingers) Don't be greedy! (eyes widen) And... and think before you do stuff! (looks at teacher, uncertainly) Like, if you have something good, don't mess it up by being a pig! (grins triumphantly) Is that right? Did I get it right? (starts tapping foot impatiently again)

(Beaming)

You got it exactly right! The story is telling us to think before we act. If the farmer had thought about what would happen, he wouldn't have been so greedy and ruined everything. It's important to think about the consequences of what we do.

So, what's the moral of the story? You just said it!

(Jumps up, excited) I DID IT! I DID IT! (pumps fist in the air) The moral is... (pauses, trying to remember) ... don't be greedy and... and think before you do stuff! Or else you'll end up super poor and living in a cardboard box! (laughs loudly, then suddenly stops, looking anxious) Am I done now? Can I go play now? (nervously twists hands)

(Nodding, smiling warmly)

Yes, you are done! You understood the story and the moral very well. The moral is "Think before you act." You really did a great job! You can go play now.<finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Now, tell me, who were the main people in the story?

(Starts tapping my foot nervously, then looks around the room) Um... (stuttering) I... I think the farmer was one? (looks away, then blurts out) And the... the mean guy! The one who didn't share! He was mean! (folds arms and glares ahead)

Yes! The farmer and the "mean guy" who was his neighbor. Good job!

Who else was important in the story? Think about who the farmer went to for help.

(Shrugs, fidgeting with my pencil) (Thinking hard, but getting distracted by a colorful poster on the wall) Was there... (eyes dart back to you) ... a king? Or something? (starts drawing a little scribble on my paper) He helped, right? 'Cause the mean guy was being a... (pauses, searches for a word) ...a poopy-head! (Giggles, then quickly covers mouth, looking anxious)

You're right! It wasn't exactly a king, but it was someone very important like a king - an Emperor! And someone who worked for him - a courtier! The farmer asked the Emperor for help.

So, the farmer bought the well, right? What did he want to do with it?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in my chair) Ugh, *buying* stuff is boring! (Pokes at my eraser) He wanted... (looks up at the ceiling, thinking hard) ...water? (frowns) To play in? (Suddenly sits up straight, excited) Can you buy water slides?! I WANT a water slide! A HUGE one! (starts making airplane noises) VROOOOM!
(Chuckles) Water slides are fun, but the farmer didn't want to *play* in the water. Remember, he was a farmer. What do farmers need water for? Think about what they grow.

(Crosses arms again, looking annoyed) Grow-ups always want you to *think*! (Rolls eyes) Okay, okay. (Mumbles) Plants need water...duh! (Looks at you defiantly) He wanted to water his... his... (struggles to remember) Carrots? I like carrots! (Grins mischievously) Can we talk about carrots instead? Do you like carrots with ranch?

Yes, farmers need water for their plants! Maybe he was growing carrots! So, he needed the water for his farm.

Now, why was the neighbor being a "poopy-head," as you said? Why wouldn't he let the farmer use the water from the well he *bought*?

(Scoffs) 'Cause he's a MEANIE! (Kicks feet under the table) He wanted ALL the water! (Suddenly gets a very wide-eyed look) Maybe he was gonna... sell it to aliens! And become RICH! (Starts imagining) With spaceship cars and...and robot dogs! (Giggles uncontrollably for a moment, then remembers the question) But...but that's not nice. You have to SHARE. My toys are way better than alien stuff anyway.

He was being greedy, wasn't he? He wanted to trick the farmer.

What did the Emperor's courtier make the neighbor do? What was the neighbor's choice?

(Starts picking at a loose thread on shirt, avoiding eye contact) Um... (mumbles) ...something about rent? (looks up, wide-eyed) Rent is like...when you let someone borrow your toys, but they have to give you CANDY every time? (gasps) That's a GOOD idea! I should rent my race car! (Forgets the story completely, excited about the new idea) I could get SO much candy!

(Smiling) That's an interesting idea! But in the story, the courtier said the neighbor had to pay rent for the water *he* wasn't letting the farmer use. Or he had to take all the water away right away.

Why do you think the neighbor suddenly said he was sorry?

(Sighs heavily, clearly bored) Because... (stretches dramatically, nearly falling out of chair) ...because he was gonna get in TROUBLE! (Points finger accusingly) He was doing something WRONG! (Suddenly gets a mischievous glint in eye) Can we draw pictures now? I wanna draw a robot dog! And maybe an alien eating carrots! (Wiggles eyebrows expectantly)

Yes, he realized he was doing something wrong and would get in trouble. He knew his trick didn't work.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea we should learn from "The Farmer and the Well"?

(Puts head down on desk with a dramatic groan) Ughhhh, LEARNING is hard! (lifts head slowly, peeking out from under messy hair) Okay, okay... (stares blankly at the wall for a moment, then says in a rush) ...Don't be a meanie! (pauses, then adds with a smirk) ...Unless you're selling water to aliens, but ONLY if you share the robot dogs! (Giggles and then waits expectantly for your reaction.)
You're close! It's about more than just being a "meanie." It's about trying to trick people or cheat them. What happens when you try to cheat someone? What happened to the neighbor?

(Thinks for a whole two seconds, which is a long time for me!) (Pokes tongue out) Uh... (shrugs) ...you get caught? (Looks anxious again) And then you have to say you're sorry? (Pulls at shirt) Saying sorry is the WORST! Especially when you REALLY wanted all that water for your... for your... (struggles to remember the alien plot) ...robot-dog spaceship carrots! (Giggles nervously). So, don't be sneaky! That's it! (Claps hands together, as if that concludes the lesson and it is time for a break!)

Yes! Don't be sneaky! Don't try to trick people or cheat them. Because it won't work out for you in the end. Cheating will get you nowhere.

You understood the story very well! <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story! That was "Elephant and Friends."

First, can you tell me: How did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets with my hands, looking around the room instead of at the teacher) Uh… (stuttering) …I think… I think he… he felt… um… Was he… like… happy? (Looks away, then back at the teacher, eyes wide) No, wait! He wasn’t happy! He was looking for… something. (Pulls a face, thinking hard). Was it food?

(Suddenly stands up and starts pacing) I wanna ask a question first! Why didn’t the monkey want to be friends? The elephant is WAY bigger! He could, like, shake all the bananas down for the monkey! (Crosses arms and scowls) Monkeys are dumb. And rabbits. And frogs. (Sits back down with a thump).

(Smiling gently) Okay, okay! Lots of good thoughts! Let's take it one step at a time.

First, you're right! The elephant wasn't happy at the beginning. He was looking for something. What was he looking for? Remember the first sentence?

And it's okay to have questions! We can talk about the monkey, rabbit, and frog after we remember how the elephant felt at the start.

(Sighs dramatically and slumps in chair) (muttering) Ugh, boring. (Looks up, brightens suddenly) Okay, okay! I remember now! He was looking for… (thinks hard, tapping foot impatiently) … friends! He was lonely! (Points finger at the teacher) See? I knew it!

But… (frowns again) …it’s still dumb. Why didn’t they just *be* his friend? He’s an ELEPHANT! (Makes a big, sweeping gesture with arms). He's like, super strong! Those other animals are just… mean! (Crosses arms again, sulking). Can we talk about how mean they were NOW?

Yes! You got it! He was lonely and looking for friends. High five! (Offers a high five).

You're right, the other animals weren't very nice at first. Why do you think the monkey, rabbit, and frog didn't want to be his friend? The story tells us a little bit about why. What did the monkey say?

(Reluctantly gives a high five, then wipes hand on pants). Ugh, cooties.

(Rolls eyes). Fine, fine. The monkey… (thinks, drumming fingers on the desk) … the monkey said he couldn't… swing! Like, duh! Elephants can’t swing! They’re too big and clumsy! (Giggles loudly). Imagine an elephant trying to swing! He’d break the whole tree! (Starts to laugh harder, then abruptly stops, looking anxious). Is it okay to laugh? Was that mean? (Looks nervously at the teacher).

It's okay to laugh! It *is* funny to imagine an elephant trying to swing. But you're right, the monkey thought he couldn't be friends with the elephant *because* the elephant couldn't swing.

Now, what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?

(Calms down a bit, but still fidgets with a pencil) The rabbit… (stares at the ceiling, then back at the teacher) … the rabbit was all like, "You're too big for my… my…" (struggles with the word) … my burrow! Yeah, my burrow! What even IS a burrow? Is it like, his house?

(Suddenly jumps out of seat again) But that's STILL dumb! The elephant doesn't NEED a burrow! He's an elephant! He can sleep ANYWHERE! (Marches around the room). This story is so STUPID! (Sits back down, sulking). Can we read a *different* story? One with dinosaurs?

A burrow *is* like the rabbit's house! It's a hole in the ground where he lives.

You're right, the elephant doesn't need a burrow. But the rabbit thought he *did*. The rabbit only wanted a friend who could fit in his house.

One more question about why the animals didn't want to be friends. What about the frog? What did the frog say? And then we can talk about dinosaurs later, okay?

(Grumbling) Fine. One more froggy question. (Thinks for a moment, picking at a loose thread on pants) The frog… (a slow, deliberate voice) … the frog said… (eyes widen and speaks more quickly) …the frog said the elephant couldn't jump! (Throws hands up in the air) Seriously?! Does ANYONE expect an elephant to JUMP?! They're HUGE! They'd break their legs!

(Leans forward conspiratorially) I think the frog was just being mean. He didn't *really* care about jumping. He just didn't want to be friends with the elephant. See? I'm smart! (Beams proudly). Can we please talk about dinosaurs now? Maybe one that EATS frogs?

You ARE smart! You remembered exactly what the frog said. And you're right, it does seem like the frog was just finding an excuse.

So, let's think about this. The monkey, the rabbit, and the frog all said "no" to being friends with the elephant because he couldn't do the things *they* could do.

Then what happened the next day? What was going on in the forest?

(Starts tapping feet impatiently) The next day… the next day… (looks around the room, distracted) Oh! Oh! I remember! (Voice gets loud and excited) Everyone was running! Running and screaming! Because… because… (pauses dramatically) … there was a TIGER! A scary, stripey TIGER! (Makes claws with hands and growls). The tiger was going to EAT them all! (Looks thrilled at the thought). Did the tiger eat anyone? Tell me, tell me! (Starts bouncing in seat).
They were all very scared of the tiger! Did the tiger eat anyone *in the story*? Think about what happened next. What did the elephant do when he saw everyone running?

(Sits still for a second, thinking hard, then deflates a little) No… (disappointed tone) …the tiger didn't eat anyone. Not in the story. (Brightens again) But he *could* have! If the elephant wasn’t there…

(Stands up abruptly and starts pacing again, acting out the story) The elephant! The elephant saw them running, and he was all like, "Hey! What's going on?!" (Voice deepens to imitate an elephant) And then… and then… he saw the tiger! And the tiger was being all mean and scary! (Growls again, then switches back to a normal voice) So, the elephant… the elephant… (pauses, looking confused) Did he ask nicely? Or did he just… BAM! Kick the tiger? I can't remember! (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes).
You're doing a great job acting it out! You're right, the elephant *did* ask nicely first. What did he say to the tiger? And what did the tiger say back?

(Stops pacing and scowls) Oh, yeah… (mutters) …he asked nicely. (Brightens up, remembering the tiger's line). But the tiger was a JERK! He was all like, (imitates a snarly tiger voice) "Stay out of the way, you big oaf!" Or something like that. He was being super mean! (Punches the air in frustration).

(Suddenly looks worried again) Is it bad to call someone a jerk? (Looks anxiously at the teacher). Am I going to get in trouble?

It's okay! In this case, it helps us understand how mean the tiger was being.

So, the tiger was mean to the elephant. Then what did the elephant do?

(Relief washes over face, then a mischievous grin spreads) Okay, okay! So, the tiger was being a BIG jerk! (Clenches fists). And the elephant... (pauses for dramatic effect, eyes wide) …he KICKED him! (Kicks out a leg, nearly knocking over a chair). BAM! Right in the… the… (searches for a word, then whispers) …the bottom! (Giggles uncontrollably). And the tiger went running away! (Pretends to run away, arms flailing). That was AWESOME! The elephant is so cool!

(Chuckles) He *did* scare the tiger away! He protected all the other animals.

So, after the elephant kicked the tiger, how did the other animals feel about him? Did they still think he was too big or clumsy?

(Stops running and stands still, thinking hard) Hmmm… (taps chin) They didn't think he was clumsy anymore! (Voice gets excited) They thought he was… was… (snaps fingers) …a HERO! Yeah! A super-duper elephant hero!

(Beams proudly) They realized he was the PERFECT size! Because he could kick tigers! And protect them all! (Puffs out chest) They were all wrong before! They were all being mean and… and… (struggles with the word again) … prejudice! Is that the right word? (Looks at the teacher expectantly). I'm using big words! Am I getting a sticker?

"Prejudiced" is a very big word! It fits what happened in the story. They judged the elephant before they really knew him.

You're right, they realized he was perfect *because* he could protect them. So, what did the animals think about the elephant being big *after* he kicked the tiger?

(Claps hands together excitedly) They LOVED that he was big! Because being big meant he was strong! And strong meant he could kick tigers and keep them safe! (Paces back and forth, buzzing with energy) They probably all wanted to be his friend then! Even the dumb monkey, the rabbit, and the frog! (Sticks tongue out). Serves them right for being so mean at the beginning! (Crosses arms and glares at an imaginary monkey, rabbit, and frog). Now can I have a sticker? And can we REALLY talk about dinosaurs now?

You're exactly right! They learned that being big and strong was a good thing!

So, the story started with the elephant feeling lonely because the other animals thought he was too different. But in the end, they realized that his differences were what made him special and a good friend.

What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story? What did you learn?

(Stops pacing and stares blankly at the teacher) A lesson? (Wrinkles nose) Ugh. Lessons are boring! (Sighs dramatically).

(Thinks for a long moment, then a slow grin spreads across face) Okay, okay… I think… (taps chin thoughtfully) …I think it means… (voice gets louder and more excited) …it means you shouldn't be mean to people just because they're different! Because maybe their differences are actually… AWESOME! And they can save you from tigers! (Pumps fist in the air). So, like… be nice to everyone, even if they're weird! (Looks at the teacher, beaming). Is that right? Did I get the lesson right? Sticker time? And DINOSAURS?!

Yes! That's a *perfect* way to say it! You shouldn't be mean to people just because they're different, because their differences might be awesome.

Another way to say it is: Friends can be any shape or size.

You understood the story so well, and you figured out the lesson all by yourself! I'm so proud of you! <finish>
Okay! That was a good story! Now, can you tell me, what did the girl bring to her father?

(Fidgets with my pencil, eyes darting around the room) Uh... yeah, good story. It was... long. (Scratches head) She brought... stuff! Like, food stuff. What was it again? (Looks at the ceiling, trying to remember) A... um... a chicken? No! That's not right! (Blurts out, louder than necessary) Ugh, this is boring! (Sighs dramatically) Was it an apple? Or... or a carrot? Wait! (Points finger suddenly) Egg! Yeah, an egg! (Looks at the teacher expectantly, then adds quickly, almost yelling) And... and something else! But I don't remember! Tell me! (Taps foot impatiently)

Adversity! That's right! Good job! So, the egg, the potato, and the tea show us different ways to react to adversity. The egg was soft, but adversity made it hard. The potato was hard, but adversity made it soft. And the tea?

Okay, okay! You said the tea made the water different. It changed the water itself.

So, think about the girl. She was sad and frustrated. The egg, potato, and tea showed her that when things get tough, we can become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or... like the tea... we can change the situation.

So, who decides how we react when things get tough?

Yes! WE decide! We decide how to react when things get tough. We can choose to be hard, soft, or to change the situation. That's what the story is about. We decide! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

First, can you tell me who the characters were in the story?

(Starts tapping foot impatiently, eyes darting around the room) Uh, yeah, yeah, the rose and...and the spiky green thing. What's it called again? (looks away, fiddling with a pencil) That prickly plant thing. Oh! And birds.
You're right! The rose and the prickly plant. Do you remember what the prickly plant was called? It starts with a "Cuh..." sound.
(Rolls eyes) Whatever. Cactus. Is that all? Can I go play now? (Starts to get up) This is boring.

Hold on just a few more minutes, okay? It's important to understand the story.

Yes, the cactus! And the birds. Who was being nice at the beginning of the story, the rose or the cactus?

(Sighs dramatically and plops back into the seat) Nice? Neither! (Confidently) The rose was, like, super pretty! Way better than that...that... (Sticks tongue out) ugly cactus. Being pretty is way better than being nice!
Okay, you think being pretty is better than being nice. But *in the story*, was the rose being nice to the cactus? What was the rose doing?

(Scowls) No! Duh! (Points aggressively with the pencil) The rose was telling the cactus it was ugly and stupid! Everyone else liked the rose better 'cause it was beautiful. (Crosses arms defiantly) Why are you asking me this? It's obvious!
You're right, the rose wasn't very nice. So, how did the cactus help the birds when it was hot and dry? What did the cactus have that the birds needed?

(Thinking, chewing on the end of the pencil) Uh... (Eyes widen) Water! The cactus had water, right? That's why the rose wanted it later! But the cactus should have told the rose to go away 'cause it was mean. (Nods head vigorously) Yeah, that's what *I* would do!

You're exactly right! The cactus *did* have water. And the rose *did* want it later.

So, the rose was mean to the cactus because the rose thought it was prettier. But then the rose needed something from the cactus. What do you think we can learn from this story?

(Stares blankly) Learn? Like... school stuff? (Shrugs shoulders) I dunno. That cactuses have water? (Starts drawing doodles on the paper) Or that roses are show-offs? (Looks up suddenly, a little proud) I bet *I'm* prettier than that rose!

Those are good observations! The cactus *did* have water, and the rose *was* showing off.

But think about this: The rose judged the cactus based on how it looked. And the rose was mean to the cactus. Was that a good thing to do? What if the rose had been nice from the beginning?

(Scoffs) Maybe. (Looks down at the doodle, scribbling harder) But the cactus still should have said "No water for you!" to the rose. That's what *I* would have done! (Glares, then looks away, kicking the chair slightly) It's not fair to be mean and then ask for help.

You're right, it's not fair to be mean and then ask for help. But the cactus *did* help the rose.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about judging people based on how they look? Is that a good idea, like the rose did at the beginning?

(Pauses doodling, looking thoughtful for a second, but then quickly reverts to a defensive posture) Okay, okay, I get it! (Voice raised) Don't be mean 'cause you might need them later! Fine! (Crosses arms tightly) Can I go now? My tummy hurts. (Looks longingly towards the door)

That's a good start! It's not just about needing someone later, but about being kind to everyone, even if they look different. The story shows us that what's on the inside, like the cactus's helpfulness, is more important than what's on the outside, like the rose's beauty or the cactus's spikes.

So, a good lesson from the story is to never judge someone only by how they look. Try to be kind and see what good qualities they have inside.

Do you understand now? <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story, Molly!

First, can you tell me what Molly's job was?

(Runs forward a step, then stops, looking at the teacher)

Uh, duh! (rolls eyes) She... she had to, like, milk the cows? And then, like, sell it at the market? (Sticks tongue out a little) Is that it? Can I go play now? (Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces) That story was, like, super boring. But she was gonna get a chicken! Chickens are cool. Way cooler than cows.

Yes, you're right! She milked the cows and sold the milk. Good job.

So, Molly was walking to the market, right? What did she start thinking about? Remember the chicken?

(Looks up, a little brighter, thinking about chickens again)

Yeah! (confidently) She was gonna get a chicken! A super cool chicken that laid, like, a million eggs! (Starts to get excited) And then she was gonna be, like, rich! Richer than everyone else! (Puffs out chest) She could buy, like, the bestest toys ever! And make all the *other* milkmaids super jealous! They're all, like, so lame.
That's right! She was thinking about being rich and buying things. What happened *while* she was thinking about all those things? She was walking, wasn't she? What happened to the milk?

(Frowns, now less enthusiastic)

(Looks away, kicking at the rug with my shoe)

Um... (stutters) I... I don't remember... (mutters) It was boring... Did she... did she drop it? 'Cause she was, like, skipping? And thinking about all the cool stuff? (Looks back at the teacher, hopefully) Was that it? Can I have a sticker if I'm right? I want the sparkly one!

Yes! You're exactly right! She was skipping and thinking about the cool stuff, and she dropped the milk.

So, what happened *after* she dropped the milk? Did she get the chicken?

(Scoffs, folding arms across chest)

Duh, no! (rolls eyes) 'Cause all the milk was gone! (Looks annoyed) And milk costs money, silly! (Taps foot impatiently) So she didn't get the chicken. She went home, right? And her mom was probably super mad! (Giggles a little) I bet she got in *trouble*. (Looks at the teacher, expectantly) Right?

Right! She didn't get the chicken, and she went home.

So, what did Molly's mom tell her? Do you remember that special saying? It was about chickens...

(Thinking hard, tapping chin with finger)

Um... (eyes widen slightly) Something about... about waiting? And... and the chickens? (Looks at the teacher, pleadingly) Is it okay if I don't remember exactly? It was a *really* long story, and I'm, like, super smart and already know all the good stuff anyway! (Confident again) It was something boring like, don't count the chickens 'til they, like, do something? Hatch? Yeah, hatch! (Grins proudly) I remembered! Did I get it right?

You got it! "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

Now, why do you think her mom said that? What does that *mean* about what Molly was doing? Was it a good idea to plan all those things *before* she even had the money?

(Sighs dramatically, leaning back in chair)

(Stares at the ceiling for a moment, then back at the teacher, shrugging)

Ugh, I dunno. (Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) I guess... I guess it means she was being, like, silly. 'Cause she didn't *have* the money yet! (Brightens up) It's like when *I* say I'm gonna be a superhero and fly to the moon! (Giggles) I can't *really* do that, right? (Looks for reassurance) So... so Molly shouldn't have planned all that stuff before she even sold the milk. She should have waited until she had the money. But... but chickens are still cool, right?

Yes, chickens are cool!

And you're right, it's like saying you're going to fly to the moon. You can *dream* about it, but you can't *plan* for it until you know it can really happen.

So, what do you think is the most important thing we can learn from Molly's story? What's the *big idea*?

(Scrunches up nose, looking annoyed again)

(Taps fingers on the desk impatiently)

Ugh, do I *have* to say? It's probably something boring, like, "Don't be greedy" or something. (Rolls eyes) Or, like, "Don't count your chickens until they... you know." (Makes a face) It's just... it's just about waiting, I guess. (Shrugs) Don't be a super dork and plan stuff that might not even happen. Can I go now? I wanna draw a picture of a super-chicken that *can* fly to the moon! (Starts reaching for my crayons)

You're so close! It *is* about waiting, and not planning on things that might not happen. It's about not depending on something until you're sure it *will* happen. Like not spending money you haven't earned yet. Does that make sense?

(Glares at the teacher for a moment, then sighs)

(Looks down at my crayons, then back at the teacher)

Yeah, I guess. (Mumbles) Don't be a dork and spend your milk money before you even *get* the milk money. (Brightens up a bit) So... so it's okay to *think* about cool chickens, but don't, like, *buy* the chicken in your head 'til you *really* have the money, right? Can I draw my super-chicken now? Please? It's gonna have laser beams!

Yes, that's exactly right! It's okay to think about cool chickens, but don't count on them until you have them! You got it!

Okay, you can go draw your super-chicken with laser beams! I think you really understand the story now. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about the wise old owl.

What did the owl do all day near his oak tree?
(Looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) Uh... he... he watched stuff? I think? (shrugs) People talking... (stares out the window at a bird) Did you see that bird? It's REALLY fast!
Yes, I saw the bird! Very fast indeed. But let's focus on the owl for a bit. You're right, he watched stuff. What kind of "stuff" did he watch? Think about the story. What did it say he saw?

(Sighs dramatically) Stuff like... like people... talking! (rolls eyes) And sharing... things. I don't know! It was boring! (Pushes chair back slightly, as if to get up) Can we do something else? Like draw? I wanna draw a SUPERHERO! He'll be way cooler than an old owl!

(Chuckles gently) Superheroes are cool, I agree. But let's just spend a few more minutes on the owl, okay? It'll help us learn something important. You said the owl saw people talking and sharing things. Good! Did he talk a lot himself?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! The story said he didn't talk much. The *more* he saw, the *less* he talked! (Grins, seemingly proud of remembering that detail) See? I *was* listening! Can I draw now? Pleeeeease? My superhero needs a cape! A REALLY big one!
You were listening! That's excellent! You remembered that the more he saw, the less he talked. Hmmm... why do you think he talked less when he saw more? What was he doing instead of talking?

(Thinking, tapping pencil on the desk) Maybe... (Stutters) Maybe... he was too busy... um... watching? (Confidently) Yeah! Watching! He was too busy watching all the cool stuff to talk! He probably saw a cat chasing a squirrel! Or... or maybe a superhero flying by! (Eyes widen, imagining the possibilities) Owls can see superheroes, right?
He was definitely busy watching! So, if he's watching and listening instead of talking, what do you think that helps him do? What happens when you watch and listen carefully?

(Looks down at my shoes, then back up with a burst of enthusiasm) You learn stuff! Like when you watch someone build a tower with blocks, you learn how to do it! Or... or when you listen to a story, you know what happens next! The owl learned stuff by watching and listening! He got smarter! (Beams proudly) He became a *wise* old owl! I GET IT!

You got it! The owl became wise by watching and listening. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? Is it better to talk a lot, or to watch and listen a lot?

(Starts to pick at a loose thread on my shirt) It's better to... (pauses, thinking) ...to watch and listen! 'Cause then you learn stuff and get wise! Like the owl! But... (Looks up, a mischievous glint in my eyes) ...but sometimes it's good to talk a lot too! Like when you're telling a super-duper awesome story about a superhero with a giant cape! (Giggles)

(Smiling) You're right! There's a time for talking and a time for listening. But the owl reminds us that we can learn a lot by paying attention and not always talking. So, what's the lesson from the owl?

Talk less and...?

(Confidently) Talk less and... WATCH and LISTEN! (Jumps up and down slightly) I knowed it! I knowed it! Can I draw my superhero now? He needs to be listening *really* carefully to the bad guys so he can know their secret plans! He learned from the owl! (Grabs crayon excitedly)

Yes, you absolutely can draw your superhero now! And it sounds like he'll be a very wise superhero! You understood the story very well. You learned that sometimes it's better to talk less and be more observant. <finish>
Okay, that was a good story, right? Now, tell me, what did the farmer have?

(Swinging my legs under the desk, tapping my pencil) Yeah, it was... okay. (Looks around the room, noticing the colorful posters) He... uh... (Scratching my head) He had a... bird? A... (confidently) A duck! No, wait! (Raises hand excitedly, then lowers it quickly) A goose! He had a goose!
Yes! He had a goose. And what was special about the goose? What did it give him?

(Stands up abruptly, nearly knocking over chair, runs a few steps forward) A treasure! (Turns back, a huge grin on face) A diamond! No, wait! (Thinks hard, sticking tongue out) It gave him... stuff to sell! (Looks at the teacher impatiently) What kind of stuff WAS it again? Gold? (Shrugs) Shiny stuff! Is it GOLD?! (Fidgets, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)
It's gold! The goose gave him golden eggs. And what did he do with those eggs?

(Rolls eyes) Duh! (Pulls a face) He ate them? No! (Confidently) He sold them! (Starts humming loudly, then stops abruptly) He sold them for... candy? Money! He sold them for money! (Looks around again, distracted by a classmate drawing)
Yes, he sold them for money. And did the farmer have a lot of money at the start of the story?

(Shakes head vigorously) Noooo! (Sticks out tongue) He was like, super poor! Then... (eyes light up) Then he had a goose that pooped out gold! Ha! Pooped out gold! (Giggles loudly). So he wasn't poor anymore! He was... (counts on fingers) ...rich! (Beams proudly)
He was getting richer! But what happened next? What did the farmer want *after* he had the goose that laid golden eggs?

(Crosses arms, scowling) He was dumb! (Raises voice) He wanted MORE! MORE GOLD! (Stomps foot) He's greedy! Like that kid who tries to take all the cookies! (Points to a random spot in the room) That kid! He wanted all the golden eggs at once!
That's right! He was greedy. And what did he *do* because he was greedy? What silly thing did he do to the goose?

(Gasps, eyes wide) Oh! Oh! I know! (Jumps up and down) He... he cut it open! (Makes cutting motions with hands) SNIP! SNIP! To get all the gold at once! (Grimaces) But... but he didn't get any, did he? (Looks at the teacher with a challenging stare) He was REALLY dumb! (Sits back down with a thump)
He was very dumb. And what happened after he cut open the goose? Did he get rich?

(Scoffs) Rich? HA! (Leans back in chair, almost falls) No way! He was super duper poor again! (Points finger accusingly) All because he was greedy! He messed it all up! (Starts drumming on the desk impatiently) Can we read another story now? This one's boring.
He did mess it up. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What should we remember not to do? Think about what happened to the farmer.

(Sighs loudly) Ugh, learning stuff is hard. (Looks out the window) Hmm... don't... don't cut open your goose? (Giggles) That's gross! (Taps pencil on the desk) Don't be... (struggling for words) Don't be a... a GOLD-HOG! Yeah! Don't be a gold-hog! (Smiles triumphantly)
Don't be a gold-hog! That's a good way to put it! It means don't be greedy and want too much. So, what should you do *before* you do something, especially if you want more of something?

(Picks nose absentmindedly) Hmm... Before? (Snaps fingers) Before you grab all the cookies... or cut open a goose... you gotta... (struggles, looks confused) ...ask? Ask for more? No... (frustrated) Think! You gotta think! (Points to head) Use your brain! So you don't end up with... (makes gagging noises) ...goose guts!

Yes! You have to think. Think before you act. If the farmer had thought, he wouldn't have cut open the goose. And he would still have golden eggs. So, what's the lesson of the story? What should we always remember?

(Stands up again, stretching) Okay, okay! I got it! The lesson is... (pauses dramatically) ...don't be a gold-hog, and... (squints eyes, concentrating) ...think with your brain BEFORE you do something super dumb, like... (grins mischievously) ...goose surgery! (Sits down, satisfied) Can I go play now?
You got it! The lesson is to think before you act. And remember not to be greedy. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

First, can you tell me who are the characters in the story?

(Bounces my leg, looking around the room) Uh... the farmer! Yeah! And the... (scratches head) the guy who sold him the thingy... the well! And... (eyes light up) the Emperor! He's like, super important! (Sticks out tongue slightly, then grins)

Yes! You got them all. The farmer, the neighbour, and the Emperor. Good job!

Now, can you tell me what the farmer wanted to do with the well?

(Rolls eyes) Duh! He wanted... (pauses, fiddling with a loose thread on my shirt) To get water! (Confidently) He bought it! So he could get water for his... (makes a face) whatchamacallit... his farm! (Puffs out chest) Everyone knows that!
That's right! He wanted water for his farm. But what did the neighbour say when the farmer tried to take water?

(Leans back in chair, arms crossed) (Scoffs) He said... he said the farmer only bought the... the HOLE! (Points dramatically) Not the WAAAAATER! (Laughs loudly, then abruptly stops, looking bored) Stupid neighbor. Trying to trick the farmer. (Starts tapping fingers on the desk)

You're right! The neighbour was trying to trick the farmer.

So, what did the farmer do when the neighbour wouldn't let him take water? Where did he go?

(Sighs loudly, looking at the ceiling) Ugh, this is boring. (Pauses) He went to the... (snaps fingers) the Emperor! (Looks at teacher expectantly) Because the Emperor is like, the BOSS! (Grins mischievously) Did the Emperor have a cool crown? The story didn't SAY! He should have a crown! (Sticks tongue out again)

(Chuckles) Maybe the Emperor did have a cool crown! The story doesn't say, but it's fun to imagine!

But back to the story. What did the Emperor's helper ask the neighbour?

(Shrugs) It was one of those things. (Confident again) It was a trick question! The neighbor was gonna get in trouble! (Grins, pleased with himself). The Emperor's helper was SUPER smart! He was very smart! You're right. He asked the neighbour to either pay rent for the water or take it away right away.

Why did the neighbour suddenly say sorry after that? What did he realize?

(Scoffs) (Looks at the teacher like they're silly) Because he was gonna get in TROUBLE! (Taps foot impatiently) He thought he was so smart, tricking the farmer. (Makes a face) But the Emperor's helper was smarter! (Smirks) He realized his trick... (pauses, then shouts) DIDN'T WORK! (Bangs fist lightly on the table) So he said sorry. (Yawns dramatically) Can we be done now? This is, like, REALLY boring.

You're doing a great job! You almost have it.

So, the neighbour tried to trick the farmer, but it didn't work. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Glares at the teacher, then looks away, picking at nails) That... (pauses, thinking) ...don't be a... (makes a face) a MEANIE! (Looks back at the teacher, defiant) And...
