Yes! You got it! The story is teaching us that it's not good to cheat. Cheating doesn't work in the end.

We can say that cheating will get you nowhere.

And yes, you can draw a picture of the Emperor with a REALLY BIG crown with lots of diamonds! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story about the elephant!

So, tell me, at the start of the story, how did the elephant feel?
(Wriggles in seat, looks around the room) Uh... the elephant? (shrugs) Was he... like... playing?
Hmm, not quite. Do you remember what the elephant was trying to find in the forest? Was he looking for something?

(Eyes widen, a thought seems to spark) Find... find! He was finding... (starts picking at a loose thread on his shirt) something shiny? Or... or maybe... was it lunch? I'm hungry! (Looks expectantly at the teacher) Can we have snack time now?

(Chuckles softly) We'll have snack time later, I promise! But let's think about the story for a little bit longer.

Think back... the elephant wasn't looking for something to *eat*. He was looking for someone to be with. What do you call people (or animals!) that you like to be with?

(Stands up abruptly) I know! I know! (Runs a few steps away, then back) FRIENDS! (Points emphatically) He was looking for FRIENDS! Like... like me and (names a classmate he doesn't particularly like)! (Sits back down, but bounces leg)

Yes! That's exactly right! The elephant was looking for friends.

So, if he was looking for friends, how do you think he was feeling at the very beginning of the story when he didn't have any? Do you think he was happy or sad?

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically) Duh! He was sad! (Crosses arms, looks away) Anyone would be sad if no one wants to play with them. I know! I'm always the fastest runner! (Suddenly excited, forgets the story for a moment) Wanna race me? I bet I can beat you! I'm super fast!
(Smiling) I bet you are super fast! Maybe we can race later. But right now, let's focus on the elephant. You said he was sad. Why was he sad?

(Grumbling, reluctantly focuses back) 'Cause... (Sticks tongue out slightly, thinking hard) 'cause no one... (Uses fingers to count something silently, getting distracted by his own fingers) 'cause the monkey was dumb! And the rabbit was a stinky bunny! And the frog... frogs are yucky! (Wrinkles nose in disgust) They didn't want to be his friend! So he was sad! (Confidently) I'm right!

You're exactly right! He was sad because the other animals didn't want to be his friend.

Now, why didn't the monkey want to be his friend? What did the monkey say?

(Sighs loudly, slumping in chair) Ugh, this is boring! (Starts humming a tune) The monkey... the monkey... (Looks up at the ceiling, clearly trying to remember but also distracted) He said something about... (Suddenly shouts) TREES! The elephant couldn't climb trees! (Claps hands once, pleased with himself)

Yes! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees.

And what about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?

(Starts tapping rhythmically on the desk with a pencil) The rabbit... (Taps faster) the rabbit... (Stops tapping suddenly, points the pencil at the teacher) The rabbit was a scaredy-cat! He said the elephant was TOO BIG! (Pokes the desk with the pencil for emphasis) Too BIG for his hole! (Grins mischievously) He's got a little hole!

(Trying not to laugh) He did think the elephant was too big for his burrow, yes.

And what about the frog? Do you remember why the frog didn't want to be friends?

(Leans back in the chair, almost tipping over) The frog? (Makes a face) He was probably all slimy! (Shudders dramatically) Frogs are gross! He probably said... (Puts on a silly voice) "You can't jump high like meeee!" (Laughs at own joke) He's a silly frog! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, waiting for a reaction)

(Smiling) That's right! The frog said the elephant couldn't jump.

So, all the animals turned the elephant away because he was different. Then what happened the next day?

(Immediately jumps up, excited again) I KNOW! I KNOW! A TIGER! A big, scary TIGER! (Starts pacing around the room, acting like a tiger) ROAR! ROAR! He was chasing everyone! (Stops pacing, points finger) And the elephant... he kicked the tiger! (Pantomimes kicking something really hard) BAM!
Yes! The tiger was scaring all the animals. And what did the elephant do?

(Stands tall, puffing out chest) The elephant... (Adopts a deeper voice, pretending to be the elephant) "HEY TIGER! STOP IT!" (Returns to normal voice) But the tiger didn't listen! He was being mean! (Frowns) So the elephant KICKED him! (Giggles) Right in the butt!

(Chuckles) He did! He kicked the tiger.

And what happened *after* the elephant kicked the tiger? How did the other animals feel about the elephant *then*?

(Taps foot impatiently) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Oh! Oh! They... they liked him! (Beams proudly) 'Cause he saved them! He was their hero! (Strikes a superhero pose, then quickly drops it) He wasn't so bad after all! They were all friends then! (Claps hands together happily)

That's right! They realized the elephant was helpful and brave!

So, at first, the animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant because he was different. But then, after he saved them, they *did* want to be his friend. What do you think that tells us about being friends? Can friends only be a certain way, or can they be different?

(Frowns, clearly thinking but also fighting against the thinking) Different... (Pulls at a stray thread on his shirt) Hmmm... (Looks up at the teacher, then back down at his shoes) Maybe... maybe it's okay to be different? (Shrugs) I dunno. But the elephant was cool when he kicked the tiger! (Grins mischievously) That was awesome!

It *was* awesome! And you're right, maybe it *is* okay to be different. The monkey was good at climbing, the rabbit was small and could hide, the frog could jump... and the elephant was big and strong and could scare away tigers!

So, what did the animals learn in the story? Did they learn that friends all have to be the same size and be good at the same things? Or did they learn something else?

(Rocks back and forth in his chair) They... (Struggles to find the words, looks frustrated) They learned... learned... (Suddenly brightens) That elephants are good for kicking tigers! (Laughs and claps) And that's why they're good friends! (Looks at the teacher, expecting praise) I'm super smart!

(Smiling) You *are* super smart! Elephants *are* good for kicking tigers in this story, aren't they?

But let's think a little deeper. Was the elephant *only* good for kicking tigers? Or did he have other good qualities that made him a good friend? Think about how he was trying to be friendly *before* the tiger even showed up.

(Sighs, clearly impatient) Uh... (Looks around, trying to distract himself) He was... (Forces himself to focus) He was... nice? (Says it like a question) He asked the tiger nicely to stop! (Suddenly excited) But the tiger was mean! So he had to kick him! (Looks proud of himself) See? I'm smart!

You are very smart! He *was* nice! He tried to be friendly and helpful, even before he kicked the tiger.

So, the animals learned that even though the elephant was different, he could still be a good friend. He didn't need to climb trees or jump high to be a good friend. He was a good friend just the way he was.

Does that give you an idea what the story is trying to teach us?

(Giggles, poking at the desk with his finger) So... so I don't have to be good at climbing trees to have friends? (Looks thoughtful for a moment, then shrugs) I still wanna kick a tiger! (Grins mischievously) Can we go outside now? I'm bored!

(Chuckles) You don't have to be good at climbing trees to have friends, and hopefully, you won't *have* to kick a tiger!

The story is trying to tell us that friends can be different sizes, and good at different things. It doesn't matter if you can't swing in trees or fit in a burrow. What matters is being kind and helpful, like the elephant was.

Do you think you understand what the story is trying to teach us now? Friends can be any shape or size. <finish>

Okay! That was a good story, right? Let's talk about it.

First, can you tell me who the story is about?
(Confidently) Uh, yeah, the story was... okay. (Looks around the room, fiddling with my pencil) It was about... uh... a girl and her... dad! (Grinning, proud of myself for remembering that much)
Great job! You remembered! What was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Shrugs, starts doodling on my paper) She was, like... mad. Or bored. Or somethin'. (Sighs loudly) Life was... uh... (Uses complex words) unsatisfactory! Yeah, that's it! (Looks up, pleased with myself again, but then quickly loses interest and starts tapping my foot)
"Unsatisfactory" is a big word! Good job! She wasn't happy, right? What did she do because she wasn't happy?

So, she was going to sell the milk, buy a chicken, and then sell the eggs. What happened while she was thinking about all of this?

(Glares, fidgets with a pencil)

She... she tripped? And spilled the milk? Is that it? (Taps pencil loudly) Can I be done now? This is taking forever! I wanna draw!
She didn't exactly trip, but you're right, the milk spilled! Why did the milk spill, do you think? What was she doing when it spilled?

(Leans back in chair, arms crossed)

She was... she was like, dancing! And skipping! And being all... (Makes a face) ...happy. So she wasn't looking where she was going. (Sticks tongue out slightly) That's what happens when you're too happy!

That's a good way to put it! She was very excited and skipped, and wasn't paying attention.

So, what happened to all her milk? And the money she was going to get?

(Shrugs, looks down at shoes)

Gone. It all spilled. No money. (Mumbles) Stupid milk. (Looks up suddenly, with a slightly aggressive tone) Is that the end? Because I *really* want to go play outside!

Yes, that was the end of her milk and her money. So, she didn't get to buy the chicken, did she?

What did her mother say to her at the end? Do you remember?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes)

Something about... something about chickens. And... (Taps chin, looks vaguely annoyed) ...counting them. Don't count your chickens...before... before... (Throws hands up in the air) I don't know! It was a stupid saying anyway! (Glares at the teacher) Can I just go now, please? I'm bored!

You're so close, Molly! Her mother said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch."

What do you think that means? Why did her mother say that?

(Grumbling, kicks the chair leg)

Means... means don't be stupid and think you're gonna get something before you actually have it? (Looks away, scuffing shoes on the floor) Like... like thinking you're gonna have all those eggs when you don't even *have* the chicken yet! (Voice gets louder, more agitated) It's obvious! Can I go NOW?! (Starts to fidget more intensely)

You got it, Molly! You explained that perfectly. Don't count on something until you actually have it.

So, what did Molly learn in the story?

(Sighs dramatically and leans back in the chair, looking at the ceiling)

Ugh. That... that being all happy and dreaming about stuff is bad? And that you should just... I don't know... be boring and not think about anything? (Looks back at the teacher, a little defiant) Is that what you want me to say? Because that's dumb! (Starts to tap loudly on the desk again)
(Calmly) Not exactly that being happy is bad, but what about being too sure of something before it happens? What do you think?

(Glares at the teacher, then mumbles)

Fine. Don't get all excited about something 'til it really happens. Or you'll spill all your milk and be sad. Happy now? (Crosses arms tightly and stares intently at the teacher) Can I PLEASE go now? I'm going to EXPLODE if I have to stay here for one more second!

Yes, Molly! You understood the story and what it means. You shouldn't depend on things happening until you are sure they will.

<finish>

Okay! Hi there! That was a good reading of "A Wise Old Owl"!

Now, can you tell me one thing the owl did every day?

(Bounces foot, looks around the room) Uh... Hi! (grabs a pencil and starts chewing on the eraser). He... he saw stuff? (Points vaguely towards the window). Like, things happening? Did I... did I get it right? (looks at the teacher nervously).

Yes! You got it exactly right! The owl *saw* things happening.

What kind of things do you think he saw? Maybe things near his tree?

(Starts drawing doodles on the desk with the chewed pencil) Uh... (Stops doodling and looks up suddenly) People! He heard people! (Raises hand slightly, then puts it back down quickly). Talking... and stuff. (looks away, shrugging shoulders). I don't know... stories? Is it almost recess? (Starts tapping foot again, more rapidly).

You ARE doing great! People talking and stories are exactly right! The owl heard people talking and sharing stories.

Now, the story says the owl saw *more* things and then he did *less* of something else. What did he do less of?

(Eyes widen, fidgets with the edge of his shirt) Less...? (Stares intently at a spot on the floor). Less... uh... (Shrugs shoulders, a dramatic frown appears). This is hard! (Voice rising slightly). He... he did less chores? (Looks up hopefully, then immediately looks down again, kicking lightly at the desk leg). I don't wanna play this game anymore! (Muttering under breath).
(Softly) It's okay, it *is* a tricky question! It wasn't chores. Think about what comes out of your mouth. What did the owl do *less* of, the more he saw and heard?

(Crosses arms and slumps in chair. Voice is now loud and whiny) I don't KNOW! (Looks out the window, completely disengaged). This is boring. Owls don't even DO chores! They just, like... hoot! (Makes a loud, exaggerated "Hoo!" sound). Can I go play now? (Taps foot insistently).

(Chuckles softly, but remains patient and calm) Okay, okay. You're right, owls hoot! But this owl did something *less* than hooting. Think about using your words. What do we call using your words? What is talking called?

(Grumbling) Talking is... talking! Duh! (Rolls eyes, then picks at a loose thread on shirt). So... the owl talked less? (Looks up suspiciously, as if expecting a trick). Is that right? I wanna draw a monster now. (Reaches for the pencil again).

YES! The owl talked less! You got it!

So, the owl saw more things, and heard more stories, and he talked less. Why do you think that made him wise? What happens when YOU listen carefully?

(Scoffs, eyes narrowing) Wise? (Starts scribbling furiously on the desk again, making angry lines). 'Cause he was old! Old people are ALWAYS wise! (Points the pencil aggressively). And when *I* listen carefully... (pauses, looking genuinely confused for a moment)... I get bored! (Throws pencil down on the desk with a clatter). I hate owls! (Looks away, arms crossed again).

(Takes a deep breath and smiles warmly) Okay, even if you don't like owls, let's just think about this for a minute. If you are listening carefully, do you learn new things? Do you hear things you didn't know before?

(Muttering and avoiding eye contact) Maybe... Sometimes... Depends on who's talking. If it's about superheroes, then yeah! (Suddenly brightens up for a split second, before returning to grumpy mode). But owls are boring. They don't even have superpowers! (Kicks the desk again, softer this time). Learning is dumb.
(Ignoring the negativity, gently pushes the point) So, if you listen to a story about a superhero, do you learn about their powers and what they do?

(Reluctantly) I guess... (grunts). Yeah, I learn about their powers. Like, Superman can fly and he's super strong. And he shoots lasers from his eyes! (Eyes widen slightly with genuine interest). But that's DIFFERENT! That's COOL! Owls are just... feathered lumps.

Okay, so you agree that listening can help you learn things! The owl learned from watching and listening. He didn't need superpowers, he just used his eyes and ears.

So, if you talk *less* and listen and watch *more*, do you think *you* might learn more too? Even about things that aren't superheroes?

(Stares at the desk, tracing the scribbled lines with a finger. A long pause). I... I guess so? (Looks up, a flicker of curiosity in his eyes, but quickly replaced with skepticism). But... but what if the stuff I learn is BORING? (Voice is quieter, less aggressive). Like... like owl stuff? (Shrugs, chewing on fingernail now). Maybe... maybe if it was about... (hesitates) ...dinosaurs? (Looks at teacher expectantly, a tiny glimmer of hope in his eyes).

Dinosaurs! That's a great example! If you listened to someone who knows a lot about dinosaurs, wouldn't you learn amazing things? What they ate, how they lived... all sorts of cool facts! You wouldn't learn those things if you were talking all the time, right?

So, what's one thing you learned about the owl? Not that he's boring, but something the story tells us.

(The dinosaur mention seems to have slightly improved the mood. Still fidgety, but a bit more engaged). Okay... Okay. (Thinking, tapping fingers on desk). He... (pauses, searching for the right words). He learned stuff... by... (looks up at the teacher, then back down) ...not talking so much. (A small, almost hesitant smile). Is that... is that right? Can we talk about dinosaurs now? Did you know that the T-Rex had tiny arms? (A flash of excitement in his eyes).

Yes! That's exactly right! He learned by not talking so much. He watched, he listened, and he became wise.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? If the owl talked less and learned more, what should *we* try to do?

(A genuine, though still hesitant, expression now). Hmmm... (taps chin thoughtfully). Maybe... maybe we should... try to listen more? (Looks up, a hint of pride). And... and not talk so much? (Shrugs, then smiles a bit wider). So we can learn about... (pauses dramatically)... dinosaurs! (A small giggle escapes). Can we REALLY talk about dinosaurs now? PLEASE?!

Yes! Exactly! You got it! Listen more, and talk less. It helps you learn and become wise, just like the owl! And you can learn about dinosaurs, or anything else that interests you!

I think you understand the story very well. <finish>
Okay, let's talk about the story! You just read "The Golden Egg." What was the goose good at doing?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently, looking around the room)

Umm... (Stuttering) Laying eggs? Golden eggs! Yeah, golden eggs. Big deal. Can I go play now? (Pulls at my sleeve and looks expectantly at the door) They... they made money, I guess? (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my pants)

(Smiling gently) Yes, you are right! The goose laid golden eggs. That *was* a big deal because the farmer could sell them!

So, the goose laid golden eggs. Did the farmer like that at first?

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes)

Duh! Of course, he did! He got money! (Crosses my arms, fidgeting) Everyone likes money. What's the point of this? It's boring. Can we read about superheroes instead? (Starts humming loudly and rocking back and forth)

(Maintaining a calm and encouraging tone) I know it might seem a little boring, but understanding stories helps us in lots of ways, even with superheroes!

Okay, you're right, he liked the money. So, what changed? Why wasn't he happy with one golden egg a day?

(Groans and leans back in my chair, almost tipping over.)

He wanted MORE! (Eyes widen briefly, then narrows again) Stupid farmer. He's greedy! I want more cookies after lunch too! (Looks at the teacher accusingly) Is lunch soon? I'm hungry.

(Chuckles softly) Okay, yes, you're right! The farmer was greedy. He wanted more!

So, what did the greedy farmer DO to get more eggs?

(Sighs dramatically and throws my hands up in the air)

I dunno! (Pauses, then blurts out) He... he cut the goose open! (Looks away quickly, a little bit nervous) It was gross! Why would he do that?! (Frowns and kicks the desk lightly) That's what happened. Can I have a sticker now?

(Nods encouragingly) You're exactly right. He cut the goose open. It *was* a very silly and gross thing to do.

And what happened after he cut the goose open? Did he get more golden eggs?

(Shakes my head violently, making my hair fly around.)

No! (Voice rising) He got BLOOD! And guts! Yuck! (Makes a gagging sound) He was stupid! Now he has no golden eggs! (Taps fingers rapidly on the desk, starting to get agitated.) He's gonna be poor now! Serves him right!

(Quietly says) You're right. He got no more golden eggs and he became poor.

So, the farmer was greedy. He did a silly and gross thing. And then he lost everything.

Before he cut the goose open, he was doing okay, right? He had golden eggs. What do you think he should have done instead of cutting the goose open?

(Thinking, and picking my nose absentmindedly.)

Ummm... (Shrugs) Keep the goose? (Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher with a defiant look) I don't know! This is hard! Just keep getting the eggs? But he wanted MORE! (Sticks tongue out slightly) Maybe he should have just... waited? (Looks down at my shoes, suddenly quiet)

(Smiling gently) "Waited." That's a really good word. He could have waited and been happy with what he had.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson we can learn from the farmer and the goose? Is it good to be greedy?

(Scowls, kicking the leg of the desk again, harder this time.)

No! (Looks at the teacher with a flash of anger) Greedy is BAD! He was a dummy! (Crosses arms tightly across my chest.) I already SAID that! Don't be greedy... or you get nothing. (Mumbles the last part, looking down.) Can I go now? This is making me feel... weird. (Starts to tear up slightly)

(Softly, with a reassuring tone) You're right. Greedy *is* bad. And you're very close to understanding the lesson.

It's not just about *being* greedy. It's about what the farmer *did* because he was greedy. He acted too fast without thinking. What could the story be teaching us about doing things without thinking first?

(Sniffling, wiping my nose with the back of my hand)

(Thinking really hard and looking at the floor) ... If you do something... bad... 'cause you want too much... (Stuttering) then... then you... mess everything up? (Looks up at the teacher, eyes wide and a little scared) And... and then you get nothing? (Voice cracks) Is that... is that right? (Fidgets nervously with my fingers)

(Nodding slowly and encouragingly) That's *exactly* right. If you do something without thinking, especially when you want too much, you can mess everything up.

So, we can say... think... *before* you...?

(Looks down, then back up, a little brighter)

Think before you... (Pauses, tapping my foot) ... before you ACT! (Says it loudly and confidently) Yeah! Think before you act! (Grins quickly, then fidgets again) Can I go draw now? Please? (Looks pleadingly at the teacher) I promise I'll think before I draw! (Giggles nervously)

(Smiling warmly) "Think before you act!" You got it! That's the lesson the story is trying to teach us. The farmer didn't think, and he made a big mistake.

Yes, you can go draw now! I think you understand the story very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Farmer and the Well!

First, can you tell me who the people in the story are?

(Starts tapping foot impatiently) Uh, yeah, yeah, I read it. (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) There's a… uh… a farmer. And… and a… (stares blankly) a mean guy! Who sold him something. And… and a king! (Puffs out chest) Because kings are cool!

That's right! You got them all! The farmer, the mean guy who was his neighbor, and the emperor (the king!).

What did the farmer buy from his neighbor?

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically) Ugh, *that* part. (Stands up abruptly and starts pacing). He bought the… the thingy! The… big hole in the ground! (stops pacing and throws hands up in the air) I don't remember the name! Why does it even matter? It's a hole!

(Chuckles softly) You're right, it *is* a big hole! We call it a well. The farmer bought the well.

So, the farmer bought the well. Did the neighbor let him use it?

(Crosses arms, scowling) Nope! The meanie didn't let him! He said… he said it was HIS water! Even though the farmer had the… the… (struggles to remember) the hole! (Kicks the leg of my chair) That's not fair! (Voice rising) It's MY turn to use the swing at recess, but *she* won't let me! It's just like that! (Starts to tear up).

(Softly) I understand that feels unfair. It *wasn't* fair of the neighbor.

Why do you think the neighbor didn't let the farmer use the water?

(Sniffling, wipes nose on sleeve) 'Cause he's a jerk! (Voice trembling) He wanted to be… mean! Like… like… Tommy in my class who always takes my crayons! (Hiccups). He just wanted to be… (struggles to find the word) …*bad*! (Sits down heavily, staring at the floor).

You think he wanted to be mean, like Tommy taking your crayons. That's a good way to put it. Maybe he thought he could trick the farmer.

What happened when the farmer went to the emperor? What did the emperor's helper say to the neighbor?

(Eyes widen, voice gets louder and more animated) Oh! Oh! I remember that part! (Stands up again, pointing an accusing finger) The king's helper... the smart guy... he said… he said something like… (furrows brow, trying to remember) “You either gotta… gotta pay for the water... or… or… (snaps fingers) take it all OUT!" (Jumps up and down excitedly). Yeah! Take it ALL OUT!

That's right! He had to either pay rent for the water, or take it all out.

Why do you think the smart helper said that? What was he trying to make the neighbor understand?

(Paces back and forth, muttering) Pay rent… take it out… pay rent… take it out… (stops suddenly, a smirk spreading across face) Hah! 'Cause it's impossible! He CAN'T take it all out! (Bursts out laughing) He'd need, like, a million buckets! (Continues laughing, pointing at an imaginary neighbor) He's so dumb! (Calms down abruptly, looking around nervously).

You're right! It would be impossible to take all the water out.

So, what did the neighbor do when he realised he couldn't trick the farmer?

(Shrugs, looking bored again) He… he said sorry. (Mumbles) Big deal. (Sighs loudly) Probably didn't even mean it. People *always* say sorry when they get caught! (Rolls eyes) It's not like he gave the farmer all his toys or something! Then *that* would be a real sorry! (Crosses arms, looking sulky).
He did say sorry. Why do you think he said sorry? Did he really change his mind, or was it something else?

(Taps foot impatiently) Ugh, because he had to! (Makes a face). The king was going to make him pay, or make him look like a dummy trying to empty the well. He didn't want to get in trouble! (Points finger) That's why! It's like when I have to say sorry to Lily for grabbing her doll, even though *she* was hogging all the blocks! (Glares at an imaginary Lily). It's not fair!

So, he said sorry because he didn't want to get in trouble. He didn't *really* want to be nice. He was trying to cheat the farmer, but it didn't work.

So, after hearing the whole story, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What lesson can we learn from the farmer and the well?

(Stares blankly, picks at fingernails) Lesson? (Scowls) Stories always have lessons. It's boring! (Thinks for a moment, then bursts out) Oh! (Gets excited again) Maybe it's about how you shouldn't be a meanie! (Points accusingly) 'Cause you'll get caught! And then you have to say sorry, even if you don't mean it! (Crosses arms, pouting) But it's still not fair!
You're close! It *is* about not being a meanie. It's about what happens when you try to trick people or cheat them. Do you think the neighbor got away with cheating the farmer?

(Shakes head vigorously) Nope! The king was too smart for him! (Grins) He showed him! (Suddenly worried) But… but what if the king wasn't there? What if nobody saw the meanie being mean? (Frowns, chewing on lower lip) Then he would get away with it! (Eyes dart around nervously). That's not fair *either*!

Even if the king wasn't there, trying to cheat people isn't a good idea. So the story teaches us that cheating will not get you anywhere. The neighbour had to apologise in the end.

Do you understand?

(Nods slowly, still looking anxious) Yeah… I guess so. (Mumbles) Don't cheat… or you'll get caught… and have to say sorry… even if you don't wanna… (Looks up suddenly, brightening) Hey! Can we read a story about a dragon next time? Dragons are WAY cooler than wells! (Starts fidgeting, eager to move on).
Yes, trying to cheat others is never a good idea. Cheating will get you nowhere. And yes, next time we can definitely read about a dragon! <finish>

Okay, [Student's Name], that was a great job reading "Elephant and Friends"! Now, let's talk about the story.

Why was the elephant sad at the beginning?

(Starts fidgeting with my pencil, avoiding eye contact) Uh... (shrugs) ...dunno. 'Cause... 'cause he was, like, all by himself? (Taps pencil loudly on the desk) He didn't have anyone to play with, I guess? (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Can we, like, color now? This is boring.
It's okay! Being all alone *can* be sad. The story said he was looking for something. What was it? Take your time to think.

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair). Friends! Duh! (Rolls eyes) Like, I even *care* about what he wanted. He's just a stupid elephant. (Mumbles under breath) Why do *I* have to talk about elephants? (Starts humming loudly and tapping feet impatiently). Is this going to take long? I want to go outside.

Okay, [Student's Name], it sounds like you're a little frustrated right now. But we're almost done. Let's just focus on the story for a few more minutes, okay?

You're right, the elephant wanted friends. Why did the monkey, rabbit, and frog *not* want to be his friend? What did they say?

(Scowls and crosses arms) The monkey... said he couldn't... um... (stares blankly at the ceiling) swing? Yeah, he couldn't swing! And the rabbit... (makes a rude noise) said he was too... BIG! (Giggles) Too big for the hole. Stupid rabbit! And the frog... (Sticks tongue out) couldn't jump. So what? It's not MY problem! (Starts kicking the desk lightly). Can I go now? My tummy hurts.

You remembered what each animal said! That's great!

So, the monkey, rabbit, and frog didn't want to be friends because the elephant was different. Right?

What happened the next day in the forest?

(Leans back in chair, looking out the window) Ugh, more boring elephant stuff? (Sighs deeply) The... the animals were running? (Frowns) 'Cause... 'cause a tiger was gonna eat them, or something. (Shrugs) Big deal. Tigers eat stuff. (Starts drawing doodles on the desk with the pencil). I'm hungry.

You're doing great! You remembered about the tiger.

Who helped the animals when the tiger came?

(Scoffs) The elephant, I guess. Who ELSE would it be? (Taps pencil harder on the desk, making an annoying rhythm). It's always the elephant. Why does it HAVE to be the elephant? Can we talk about dinosaurs instead? Dinosaurs are WAY cooler. Did you know the T-Rex had tiny arms? (Starts making T-Rex noises). Rawr!

Yes, the elephant!

How did the elephant help? What did he do to the tiger?

(Groans loudly) He... he kicked it! (Giggles mischievously) He kicked the stupid tiger! Serves it right! (Starts pretending to kick something under the desk). Take THAT, tiger! (Looks up with a slightly crazed grin). He kicked him really hard, I bet! Did he break his bones?

He scared the tiger away!

After the elephant scared away the tiger, did the other animals want to be his friend then?

(Stares blankly) Yeah, I guess. (Picks at fingernails) They were all, like, "Oh, Elephant, you're so great!" (Makes a gagging sound) Stupid animals. They only liked him 'cause he was big and strong. (Mumbles) That's not fair. (Crosses arms and glares at the teacher) Can I *please* go now? I'm REALLY bored.

You're right, [Student's Name]. They *did* only like him because he was big and strong and saved them from the tiger.

So, at first, they didn't want to be his friend because he was too big to swing, fit in a burrow, or jump. But then they *did* want to be his friend because he was big enough to scare away the tiger.

What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to only be friends with people who are just like you?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) I dunno! (Stares out the window again, completely disengaged) Maybe... maybe it means you should only be friends with people who can kick tigers? (Giggles, then shrugs) Who cares? I want snack time! (Starts drumming fingers impatiently on the desk) Can I have a cookie? I'm hungry and this is dumb. (Mumbles under her breath) Stupid elephant.

It's not *just* about kicking tigers. Think about it: The monkey, rabbit, and frog missed out on having a good friend because they only looked at how the elephant was different from them.

Do you think they were wrong to do that? Why?

(Rolls eyes, looking annoyed) Whatever! (Sticks out tongue) It's THEIR choice who they're friends with! Maybe they didn't *like* elephants! Maybe elephants smell bad! (Wrinkles nose) I don't have to be friends with everyone, and neither do they! (Crosses arms defiantly) You can't MAKE me be friends with the elephant! He's probably got cooties! (Starts humming loudly again, trying to block out the teacher). Lalalalala I can't hear you!

You're right, you *can't* make someone be friends with someone else. But the story shows us that sometimes, the people who are different from us can be good friends too. The elephant was different, but he was also helpful and brave.

Maybe being friends isn't just about being the same size or being able to do the same things. Maybe it's about something else. What do you think?

(Scoffs and looks away, fidgeting with her shoelaces). (Mumbles) "Something else"... like... like... (pauses, thinking hard, but clearly not wanting to admit anything) ...like... (grumbles) ...like... helping people? (Looks up quickly, then looks away again, blushing slightly) But... but only if they're REALLY in trouble! And... and you don't have to be NICE about it! (Kicks the desk lightly) Just... just get the job done! (Huffs) Can I go now? I said the helping thing!

Helping people is a great idea! So, maybe friends can be different sizes and shapes, and they can help each other in different ways. The elephant couldn't swing in the trees, but he *could* scare away a tiger.

What do you think the story is trying to teach us about friends? Is it okay to be friends with someone who is different from you?

(Glares at the teacher, then sighs heavily) Fine! (Mumbles) Maybe... maybe it's okay... sometimes... (Avoids eye contact, scuffing shoes on the floor). But... but only if they're NOT too annoying! And they better not try to make me swing in trees or jump like a frog! (Looks up, eyes narrowed) And they HAVE to share their snacks! (Folds arms and stares defiantly) Now, can I PLEASE go? My brain is gonna explode!

Okay! It sounds like you understand the story and what it's trying to tell us: Friends can be different, and that's okay! The elephant and his new friends can all help each other in different ways. And yes, sharing snacks is important too! <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story, [student's name]! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. First, tell me, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets, looking around the room) Uh… yeah, it was a story. (Shrugs) She was… uh… mad? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Like, the story said she was, um… (Sticks out tongue slightly, trying to remember) Frus… frus… (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Frustrated! Yeah, that’s it. She was frustrated. (Confidently) And she wanted her dad to do something about it! (Taps foot impatiently) Can we be done now? I wanna go play.

(Smiling patiently) You remembered! She *was* frustrated. Good job!

Why do you think she was frustrated? The story doesn't say exactly, does it? But what do *you* think being frustrated means?

(Sighs loudly, rolls eyes) Ugh, this is boring! (Crosses arms) It means she's... (Taps chin with finger, looking around the room) ...like, when you can't get something you want! (Suddenly stands up) Like, when I want to go outside and play, but it's reading time! (Sits back down abruptly, slouching) That makes me frustrated! (Glares at the teacher) So she probably wanted something and couldn't have it! (Mumbles) Duh.

Okay, that's a great example! So she was feeling like you feel when you want to play outside but it's reading time. Got it.

So she goes to her dad. What does her dad *do*? He doesn't just *tell* her something, does he?

(Starts swinging legs under the desk, making a small thumping sound) No! He... (Thinking, furrows brow) ...he did that thing with the... (Snatches a nearby crayon and starts scribbling on the desk) ...the egg and the potato and... (Throws the crayon down) ...and the... the stinky leaves! (Wrinkles nose) Yuck! He put them in the water. (Stands up again, takes a step toward the door) Can I go to the bathroom?

(Gently redirects student) Yes, he put them in the water. Good remembering!

Now, what happened to the egg *after* it was in the water? Was it the same as before?

(Grumbling) Noooo. (Walks back to the desk and kicks at the leg) It got... (Looks at the teacher suspiciously) It got hard! (Pokes finger hard on the desk) Like a rock! (Giggles loudly, then stops abruptly) So? What's the big deal? (Arms crossed again)

(Chuckles softly) It *did* get hard like a rock! You're right.

And what about the potato? What happened to *it* in the water?

(Stares blankly) Uh... (Shrugs dramatically) ...it got mushy? (Pokes at the desk again, softer this time) Like... like baby food! (Makes a gagging sound) Gross! Why are we talking about this yucky stuff? (Whines) This is so boring! (Starts humming loudly and out of tune)

(Waits for humming to stop) You're doing great! The potato got mushy.

And the tea leaves? What did *they* do? This one is a little trickier.

(Stops humming, looks annoyed) (Sighs heavily) The tea leaves... (Pulls a face) ...they made the water yucky brown! (Makes a disgusted sound) Like muddy puddle water! (Stands up, paces a few steps) Can I just tell you what the dumb story means? This is taking forever! (Throws hands up in the air)

(Calmly) Okay! You can tell me what the story means. But first, tell me *why* you think the dad showed her the egg, the potato, and the tea. What was he trying to teach her? What did the water *mean* in the story?

(Sits back down with a thump, looking sulky) (Grumbling) Fine! (Looks down at hands, picks at fingernails) The water... (pauses) ...is like when things are bad! (Looks up quickly, then looks away) And the egg and the potato... they're like... like what happens to YOU when things are bad! (Taps fingers rapidly on the desk) So, like, you can get hard like an egg, or mushy like a potato! (Stands up and starts walking around again) Or you can be like the tea and change the water! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Am I done now?

(Smiling encouragingly) You are *so* close to figuring it out! You're right, the water is like when things are bad, and the egg and potato are like how you react.

So, if you get hard like the egg... is that a good thing or a bad thing? And if you get mushy like the potato, is *that* a good thing or a bad thing?

(Stops pacing, scowls) (Mumbles) I don't know! (Kicks the chair leg) It's dumb! (Raises voice) Everything's always gotta be good or bad! (Looks upset, on the verge of tears) Maybe I just wanna be a potato sometimes! (Sniffs, rubs nose with the back of hand) Can I go to the nurse? My tummy hurts.

(Softly) It's okay to feel like a potato sometimes! It's hard when things are tough.

But the story is trying to say that we have a choice. The egg *could* have stayed soft, and the potato *could* have stayed hard. The hot water is like the problems we face. But *we* get to decide if we become hard, or soft, or... like the tea.

So, what about the tea? Was that good or bad? What do *you* think? The tea *changed* the water itself.

(Sniffling, still rubbing nose) (Looks at the teacher with watery eyes) (Mumbles) I... I dunno. (Stares at the floor, then back up at the teacher) ...the tea... it made the water... (Thinking hard) ...it made it... better? (Looks up, hopeful) Like, it didn't just change *itself*, it changed the *water*! (Forces a small smile) So... so maybe that's... good? (Looks away again, fidgeting with fingers) I still wanna go to the nurse.

(Nodding gently) Yes! The tea made the water *better*. It changed the whole situation.

So, the story is trying to tell us that when bad things happen (the hot water), we can choose how we react. We can become hard (like the egg), or soft (like the potato), or we can even change the situation itself and make it better (like the tea).

So, what do you think the *big idea* of the story is? What is the story trying to teach us about how we deal with problems?

(Sighs, but it's a smaller sigh this time) (Looks at the teacher, then at the door) (Mumbles) ...that... we get to choose? (Looks back at the teacher, a tiny bit of defiance in the eyes) ...that... even when things are bad, we don't have to just... (searches for the word) ...break? (Voice a little louder) We can... we can try to make things... better! (Looks down again, scuffing shoe on the floor) (Quietly) I guess... (Shrugs) Can I *please* go to the nurse now? I really don't feel good.

(Smiling warmly) Yes, you absolutely can go to the nurse. You did a great job figuring out that story! You're right, the story is about how *we* get to choose how we react when things are hard, and that we can even try to make things better. We decide how to respond to difficult situations.

You worked really hard today! Okay, let's get you to the nurse. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about "The Needle Tree."

First, can you tell me, who are the main people in the story?

(Starts tapping my foot impatiently, looking around the room)

Umm... (Stuttering) There... there was a tree... and... and two... two guys! One was... mean! (Looks away, scowling) Yeah, mean! And the other one was... uh... there too. (Shrugs, picking at my fingernails) Can I go play now?

(Smiling gently) I know you want to play, but let's just talk about the story for a few more minutes. You're doing great!

You're right, there *were* two guys, and one *was* mean. What were their names? Or were they called something else? Maybe something like brother?

(Rolls eyes dramatically) I don't know! Names are boring! (Sighs loudly) They were brothers! The mean one was... um... the older one! And the other one was... (Sticks tongue out) ...the *younger* one! Duh! (Starts swinging legs back and forth) Can we be done now? I'm bored! (Frowns)

Okay, older brother and younger brother! You got it!

What did the older brother do for work?

(Stands up suddenly and starts pacing around the desk)

Work? (Raises voice) Work is for grown-ups! (Continues pacing) He... he did something with... (Stops pacing and looks at the ceiling, mumbling) ...wood? (Looks back at you, confused) I don't remember! This is so boring! (Suddenly sits back down, slumping in the chair)

That's okay! He *did* do something with wood!

He chopped wood in the forest. Do you remember what he did with the wood after he chopped it?

(Scoffs) Chopped wood! Big deal! (Crosses arms and glares) Who cares what he did with it? (Mumbles) Probably built a stupid house... or something. (Starts fiddling with a loose thread on the carpet, avoiding eye contact) Can't we talk about something else? Like... like recess? Or snacks? (Voice rising in frustration) This story is dumb!

(Calmly) It's okay if you think the story is dumb. But let's just finish talking about it, okay? Then you can go play.

He chopped the wood and sold it. Where did he sell the wood?

(Sighs dramatically and leans back in the chair, staring blankly at the ceiling)

Sold it? (Voice dripping with sarcasm) Oh, wow! He sold wood! Super exciting! (Forces a fake yawn) He sold it... at the... (Snaps fingers) ...at the... market! (Looks pleased with himself for remembering, but the tone is still sarcastic) Now can I PLEASE go? (Stands up, ready to bolt)

Yes, he sold it at the market! Well done.

Now, what happened when the older brother was in the forest chopping wood one day? Did he meet someone... or *something*?

(Stops halfway to the door, then shuffles back, reluctantly)

Ugh, FINE! (Glares at the floor) He met... (Grunts) ...a TREE! (Rolls eyes) A talking tree! Like that's even real! (Arms crossed tightly, tapping foot impatiently) It wanted... (Mumbles) ...apples... or something. This is SO dumb!
You're right, it was a talking tree! And the tree *did* want something. What did the tree *give* the older brother, instead of being chopped down?

(Forces out a loud sigh)

Apples! Golden... shiny... stupid apples! (Kicks at the leg of the chair) He got apples... but he was... (pauses, thinking for a second) ...MAD! (Slammed hands on the desk). He wanted MORE! (Looking angry.) Why couldn't he just be happy? (Mumbles) Like a normal person... or tree! (Looks down at hands, picking at fingernails again.)

He *did* want more! You're doing great!

What happened when the older brother got greedy and tried to cut the tree down anyway? What did the tree do?

(Eyes widen slightly, a flicker of interest)

The tree... (pauses, a hint of excitement creeping into voice) ...it zapped him! (Grins mischievously) With... (Thinks hard)... with pokey things! (Pulls a face) Needles! Yeah! It hurt him! (Claps hands with joy) Serves him right for being greedy! (But then quickly returns to a bored, slouching posture, picking at fingernails) So can I go now?

Needles! That's right!

What happened to the older brother after the needles? Did someone help him? Who?

(Grumbling) Ugh, fine. (Mumbles) The... other... guy... helped him. (Looks away, scowling) The... the younger... brother! (Stares at the floor, kicking the leg of the chair again) He took out the... pokey things. So boring. (Mumbles again, almost inaudibly) Should've left him there. (Looks up defiantly) Can I please go now?! This is taking forever!

The younger brother helped him! Yes!

Why do you think the younger brother helped him, even though the older brother was mean?

(Stares blankly, shrugs)

I dunno! He was... dumb? (Shakes head) Or... maybe... (pauses, thinking for a very short time before resuming the pace of the conversation) ...he had to! (Voice rising in frustration) Because they were... BROTHERS! (Slams hands on the desk again) I don't know, okay?! (Looks away, fidgeting) Why do you keep asking me questions? (Mumbles) This story is stupid and I wanna go play!

(Calmly) Okay, okay. You're doing so well. Just a few more questions.

After the younger brother helped him, what did the older brother say? Did he say thank you? Or sorry?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes)

He said... (Grunts) He said... (Thinks for a *very* brief second) ...sorry! (Voice dripping with sarcasm) Like that makes everything better! (Mumbles) Probably just wanted more apples. (Looks away, clearly uninterested) Can I PLEASE go now? I promise I'll be good for the rest of the day! (Pulls a pleading face)

He said sorry! Good job!

And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do?

(Lets out another exaggerated sigh)

Ugh, the tree... (Pauses, fidgeting) ...the tree gave them more... shiny... stupid apples! (Voice laced with annoyance) Happy ending! (Rolls eyes dramatically) Now can I GO?! I'm gonna explode if I have to talk about this dumb tree for another second! (Jumps up and down, practically vibrating with impatience)

Yes, the tree gave them more apples!

So, the older brother was mean and greedy at first. But then he said sorry, and the tree gave them more apples. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Stares blankly for a moment, then explodes)

I DON'T KNOW! (Stomps foot) I DON'T CARE! (Throws hands up in the air) It's a STUPID STORY! (Voice cracking, on the verge of tears) I just wanna go PLAY! (Starts pulling at sleeves) I HATE this story! (Looks at the teacher with a mixture of anger and distress) Can I just... can I just leave? Please? (Eyes welling up)

(Softly) Okay, it's okay. It sounds like you're feeling really frustrated. Let's try one more thing, and then you can go play, okay?

Think about the younger brother. He was kind, even when his older brother was mean. And then the tree gave them more apples. Maybe being kind is important? What do you think?

(Sniffling, wiping eyes with sleeve)

(Mumbles, almost inaudibly) ...Maybe... (Looks down at the floor, kicking at the carpet again) ...Maybe being... nice... is... good...? (Shrugs, still clearly upset and wanting to leave) But... it's still... boring! (Looks up with a pleading expression) Can I REALLY go now? Please? I promise I'll be super duper quiet and good!

(Smiling gently) Yes, you can *really* go now. You did a good job!

Being kind *is* good. The story is trying to teach us that if we are kind, good things can happen. It's like the saying: kindness will always be rewarded!

Go have fun playing! <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read about King Midas. What did he wish for?

(Wriggles in seat, looks around the room, then back at the teacher, speaking loudly) He wished for... everything to be GOLD! All gold! (Beams, then immediately looks bored) Is this gonna take long? I wanna go play.

(Smiling patiently) We'll be quick, I promise! Just a few questions.

So, he wanted everything to be gold. Was he happy when he first got his wish?

(Scoffs, rolls eyes) Duh! Of course he was happy! He got GOLD! (Stands up, starts pacing a little) Gold is awesome. Shiny and... stuff. Can I go now? (Doesn't wait for a response, keeps talking) I would get a gold car and gold candy and a gold playground!

A gold playground! That sounds...interesting.

But what happened when he got hungry? Could he eat his food? Why or why not?

(Stops pacing, frowns, kicks at the rug) No! (Confidently) 'Cause it was GOLD! (Crosses arms, glares at the teacher) Gold is not food. Everyone knows that. (Pauses, taps foot impatiently) It's just...gold! Can I go now? (Voice gets louder) This is boring!

You're right, gold is not food!

What about his daughter? What happened when she hugged him?

(Shrugs, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) She turned to gold too. (Yawns loudly) So? It's her problem, not mine. (Looks directly at the teacher, challenging) Are we done yet? I'm hungry! And I want to play tag!
Okay, but think about this: How did Midas feel when his daughter turned to gold? Was he still happy about his wish?

(Scowls, thinking for a moment, voice dropping slightly) Hmph. (Looks away, kicking the rug again, muttering) ...guess not... Gold daughter no good. (Looks back up, louder again) Still not my problem! He was dumb to wish for gold anyway! He should have wished for candy! (Eyes light up) All the candy in the world! (Immediately forgets about the question) Can you imagine? (Starts to get excited about the candy)

All the candy in the world *would* be something! But let's think about Midas for one more minute.

Why wasn't a gold daughter "good," do you think? What could he NOT do with a gold daughter?

(Sighs dramatically, leans back in his chair) Ugh, fine. (Thinks for a very short time, then blurts out) He couldn't hug her back! (Looks away, scowling again) Or... or play with her. (Mumbles, barely audible) ...or anything...

Can I PLEASE go now? I answered the question!

Yes, you did!

So, Midas couldn't hug her or play with her. He couldn't even eat! He thought gold would make him happy, but did it? What did he learn?
(Jumps up, ready to bolt) He learned... (Grumbling, reluctantly) ...Gold is not everything? (Confidently, with a smirk) He should have wished for candy! (Heads for the door) Bye!

You're so close! He learned that gold wasn't everything, and it actually made him very unhappy. He thought he wanted a lot of something (gold!), but it ended up hurting him.

Do you think wanting too much of something can be a bad thing?

(Pauses at the door, foot tapping impatiently) Maybe... if it turns your daughter into a gold statue. (Shrugs) But candy can't hurt you! More candy is always better! (Grins mischievously) See ya! (Runs off)

(Chuckles softly) Maybe... but too much candy can hurt your tummy!

So, Midas wanted too much gold, and it made him sad. Sometimes, wanting *too much* can lead to problems. That's something important to remember. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, can you tell me, what was the fox looking for?
(Confidently) Food! The fox... (taps foot impatiently) was looking for food! Duh! (rolls eyes)
(Smiling) You are absolutely right! He was looking for food. And what did he find on the farmer's wall?
(Looking around the room, then back to the teacher, shrugs) Grapes? Big, purple grapes! I heard you already read the story so you should already know that! (starts humming a tune)
(Chuckles softly) I do know! I just want to make sure you remember. Were the grapes easy for the fox to get?
(Scoffs) No! (Crosses arms, leans back in chair) He jumped and jumped and jumped! He couldn't get them. Stupid fox. (Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt)
(Gently guides student to focus back on the story) You're right, he jumped a lot! How did the fox feel when he couldn't reach the grapes?
(Shrugs again, avoids eye contact) I don't know... mad? (Starts drumming fingers on the desk). Who cares anyway? (Yawns loudly). Can we be done now? This is boooooring.

(Patiently) I know stories can be long, but we are almost there. Let's think about it. The fox really, really wanted those grapes. But he couldn't get them. How do *you* feel when you really, really want something, but you can't have it?

(Glares) I just get it myself! (Stands up, starts pacing back and forth). I don't give up like that dumb fox! He should have found a ladder! (Pauses, thinking for a split second) ...Or maybe asked someone to help him? Nah, that's dumb.
(Nods encouragingly) Okay, so the fox didn't get the grapes. What did he say about the grapes when he walked away?
(Stops pacing, rolls eyes) He said they were sour! (Makes a face) "Sour grapes!" Blah! He was just being a baby. (Sits back down, kicks legs under the desk)
(Smiling) Why do you think he said they were sour? Were they really sour?

(Sighs dramatically) How should I know?! I wasn't there! (Points aggressively) But he probably just said that 'cause he couldn't get them! He was making it up! He was a loser fox. (Looks out the window, distracted)
(Gently) So, he couldn't get the grapes, and then he said they were sour. Do you think maybe he was trying to make himself feel better?
(Shrugs, picks at fingernails) Maybe. (Mumbles) Whatever. Can I go play now? I'm done with this dumb story. It's not even about awesome superheroes or anything.

(Keeps the conversation going) Okay, almost done! So, if the fox couldn't get something he wanted, and then said he didn't want it anyway... what does that teach us? What's the story trying to tell us about wanting things?

(Grumbling) That foxes are dumb? (Looks at the teacher with a challenging expression) I don't know! I just wanna color! Stories are stupid. (Starts tapping a pencil loudly on the desk) I bet the grapes weren't even that good anyway. (Mumbles under breath) Probably full of seeds...
(Smiling patiently) Okay, let's try this. The fox wanted something but it was hard to get. He gave up. Is that okay? Should we always give up when things are hard?

(Scoffs) Depends! If it's REALLY hard... yeah! Why bother? It's easier to just do something else! (Eyes light up suddenly) Like play tag! Or build a tower with blocks! Can I go do that now? Please? (Starts fidgeting in the seat)
(Slowly) Okay, sometimes it's okay to do something else. But sometimes, is it good to keep trying, even when things are hard?

(Grumbling) I guess... (looks down at shoes) If you REALLY want it. But that fox didn't REALLY want those stupid grapes, did he? He said they were sour! So... (trails off, thinking) Maybe... maybe he should have asked the farmer for help? (Looks up, surprised at own suggestion) But that's dumb. Foxes don't talk to farmers.

(Encouragingly) It *is* a made-up story, so anything is possible! Okay, so the fox gave up and then said the grapes were sour. Maybe the story is trying to teach us that if we can't have something, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it in the first place? And maybe we should keep trying?

(Thinking hard, fidgeting) Hmmm... (pauses) So... like, if I really, REALLY wanted a cookie, but Mom said no, I shouldn't just say I didn't even WANT a cookie 'cause they're yucky anyway? (Looks up, searching for approval)

(Suddenly stands up) COOKIES! Can we get cookies?! I'm hungry again!

(Chuckles) Exactly! You shouldn't say you didn't want it if you really did. It's okay to be disappointed.

And maybe, just maybe, you could find a different way to get a cookie later, or maybe find something else yummy to eat instead.

So, the story teaches us that it's important to try our best and not give up easily. And if we can't have something, we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it in the first place. That's like the fox saying the grapes were sour! You understood the story! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Proud Rose."

First, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?
(Looks away, fidgeting) Uh... a rose... (pauses, taps foot impatiently) and... and... some... spiky thing. (shrugs) I dunno.
That's right! A rose is definitely one of them. The "spiky thing" is called a cactus. Can you say "cactus"?
(Rolls eyes) Cactus. So? (Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Can I go play now?

Almost! Just a few more questions about the story, okay? Then you can go play.

So, the rose and the cactus. What did the rose think about the cactus? Did she like him?
(Scoffs) Like him? Nah. The rose was, like, super pretty and the cactus was just... (makes a face) ...spiky and boring! She kept saying mean stuff, right? (Confidently) I remember THAT part.
You do remember! Good job! What kind of mean things did the rose say? Can you remember one?
(Thinking, scrunches up face) Uh... (Shrugs) Something about being ugly? I don't know! It was a long story! (Starts to get up from the chair) Can I PLEASE go now? I'm bored!

Okay, one more quick question, then you can go. You're doing great!

The rose thought the cactus was ugly. And what happened when it got really, really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?
(Sighs dramatically, plops back down in the chair) It got all... droopy? (Confidently) 'Cause there was no water! Duh! (Looks around the room, clearly wanting to leave)
Yes, it got droopy. It started to wither. And what about the cactus? What was the cactus doing? Remember the sparrows?
(Stares blankly) Sparrows? What sparrows? (Stands up again, ready to bolt) I don't remember no sparrows! Can I GOOOOOOO? This story is dumb.

The story said the cactus had water for the sparrows. The sparrows came to the cactus. If the rose was droopy and needed water, and the cactus had water... what do you think happened next? Think hard!

(Crosses arms, glares) Ugh. (Grumbling) Fine. The dumb rose probably asked the spiky thing for water, right? (Reluctantly) And the spiky thing probably gave it to her. (Looks away, muttering) Stupid story. Now can I GO?

You got it! The rose *did* ask the cactus for water, and the cactus *did* give it to her. Even though the rose was mean!

So, the rose was pretty but needed help, and the cactus was spiky but *had* help to give. What do you think we can learn from this story? It's okay if you don't know! What's the story trying to tell us?

(Shrugs, scuffing shoes on the floor) I dunno. (Pauses, thinking for a brief moment, then blurts out) Maybe... maybe even if someone's mean, you should still... help them? (Immediately regrets saying it) Whatever. (Runs off to play before the teacher can say anything else)

That's a great start! It's also about not judging people just by how they look. The rose thought she was better because she was pretty, but the cactus was the one who could help. So, never judge someone just by their looks! They might be helpful or kind in ways you don't expect. <finish>

Okay, great reading! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

So, tell me, what was Molly going to do with the milk?

(Starts running around the room) Yeah! Milk! (Stops abruptly, looking at the teacher) She... uh... (Looks away, kicks at the floor) sell it? Yeah! Sell the milk! (Confidently) She was gonna sell it at the market! It was a really BIG market! (Starts to run around again) Milk! Market! Money!

Yes, you are right! She wanted to sell the milk at the market. Good job!

And what did she start thinking about while she was walking?

(Stops running, but fidgets with my hands) Uh... things. (Shrugs) Stuff. Like... (Grimaces) ...I dunno. (Looks at the teacher with a slightly defiant look) Things she wanted to buy! Duh! Like... more chickens! (Suddenly yells) Chickens make lots of eggs! More money!

You're exactly right! She was thinking about all the things she could buy.

And what happened when she started thinking about all those things and got excited?
(Rolls eyes) Ugh, I know THIS! (Puffs out chest) She... she spilled the milk! (Crosses arms) Stupid milk! (Scowls) Then she had no money! (Taps foot impatiently) Can I go play now?
Yes, she spilled the milk! That was a big problem, wasn't it? Why was it a problem that she spilled the milk?

(Sighs loudly) 'Cause... (Sticks out tongue) ...no milk, no money! (Waves hands dismissively) It's, like, SO obvious! She couldn't buy the chickens! (Starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Chickens are dumb anyway.

You got it! No milk, no money. And no chickens!

So, what did her mother tell her at the end of the story? Do you remember?

(Confused expression) Her... mom? (Scratches head) Did she... like, yell at her? (Frowns) I'd yell at her! (Stomps foot) Stupid milk! (Thinking) Oh! Oh! Wait! (Looks at the teacher, suddenly excited) Something about... eggs! And... (Trails off, looking lost) ...hatching? (Shrugs) I don't know! It was boring! (Turns to leave)

You're close! Her mother said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch." What do you think that means? Maybe we can think about it like this: should Molly have been planning to buy more chickens when she didn't even HAVE the money yet?

(Stops at the door, hesitates, then stomps back) (Glares at the teacher) I *know* what it means! It means... (Sticks tongue out again) ...don't be a dummy! (Points at the teacher) She didn't HAVE the money! (Crosses arms again) So, like, don't spend it 'til you have it! Duh! Now can I go? Please? (Starts bouncing on the balls of my feet)

You're getting it! So, it's not just about money, is it? It's about *knowing* for sure that something is going to happen before you start planning for it. Molly was counting on getting money from the milk, but she didn't *know* she would get the money, did she?

What's something else you might count before it happens?

(Sighs dramatically) Ugh, more questions? (Taps foot impatiently) (Thinking, looking around the room) Like... (Points at a picture on the wall) ...like drawing a PERFECT picture! You can't say it's perfect BEFORE you draw it! (Grins, pleased with myself) 'Cause maybe you mess it up! (Suddenly runs over and grabs a crayon) I'm gonna draw a perfect picture! (Runs off to a table without waiting for a response).

That's a great example! You can't be sure it will be perfect until you've finished it.

So, what's the lesson of the story then? What should Molly have learned?

(From across the room, where I am scribbling furiously) (Yelling) Don't spill the milk! And... (Stops drawing and thinks, chewing on the end of the crayon) ...don't be a dummy and spend your money 'til you HAVE it! (Goes back to drawing, humming loudly). And chickens are dumb! (Muttering to myself).

Okay, almost there! So, it's like... don't *depend* on something good happening until you are *sure* it will happen.

Can you say that back to me?

(Stops drawing, looks up with a bored expression) (Groans) Do I HAVE to? (Sighs) Fine. (Mumbles) Don't... (Looks away, then back, speaks louder) Don't... depend on something... (Grimaces) ...good... happening... (Points crayon at teacher) ...'til you're SURE it will happen! (Drops crayon and runs to the door) Can I go NOW?! I'm DONE!
Yes! That's it! You got it! Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen. That's a very important lesson. <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story about the Wise Old Owl!

So, what did the owl like to do every day?
(Grins, fidgeting with a crayon in hand, eyes darting around the room) Uh... (stutters) He... uh... saw stuff? (Looks away, then blurts out) People talking! He heard people talking! Yeah!
That's right! He saw a lot and he heard a lot. Where did he see and hear all these things?
(Starts to run towards the window, but then stops and turns around, sighing loudly) By the tree! (Rolls eyes) The oak tree. Duh. (Confidently) He was *by* the oak tree.
Yes! He was by the oak tree. And what happened the *more* he saw and heard? What did he do *less* of?
(Taps foot impatiently, picks at a loose thread on pants) Less...? Uh... I dunno. (Shrugs dramatically) Play? Did he play less? I wanna play! Can we play now? (Reaches for a toy car on the desk)
(Chuckles softly) We can play later! But first, let's think about the owl. The story says the *more* he saw, the *less* he did something else. Did he talk more or less?
(Snatches the toy car and zooms it across the desk, making car noises) Vroom! Vroom! Less talk! (Stops playing, looks up, grinning) He talked less! Cause he was listening! (Confidently) I knew that!
You got it! The more he saw and heard, the less he talked. Why do you think he talked less? What was happening to him when he was watching and listening?

(Pushes the car off the desk accidentally, then ignores it and looks at the teacher, arms crossed) Hmph. (Thinking, then blurts out, loudly) He was... (Sticks out tongue) ...learning! He was getting smarter! That's why he's a *wise* old owl! (Proudly) I'm smart too!
Yes! He was learning and getting smarter. So, the owl watched and listened and learned. And what did that make him?
(Starts humming loudly, then stops abruptly) Wise! (Points to self) Like *me*! (Giggles and wiggles in seat) 'Cause I'm learning stuff too! Can I go play now? I wanna learn *outside*!
That's right, it made him wise! So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? If you watch and listen and don't talk so much, what might happen?

(Frowns, looks at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, sighing dramatically) Ugh. Teach us...? (Rolls eyes) That... (Stuttering slightly) ...if you be quiet... you get... uh... (Suddenly brightens) ...smarter! You get wise! Like the owl! And then... (Trails off, distracted by something outside the window).
Exactly! So, the story is teaching us that sometimes it's good to talk less and watch and listen more. What do you think? Is that a good idea?

(Confidently, but already halfway out of seat) Yeah! 'Cause then you know stuff! More stuff than other people! (Points at another student) Like... like *him*! He never listens! (Runs to the door). Can I go *now*? Please? I learned it!
Yes, you did learn it! The owl watched and listened, and he became wise. We can learn from that too. You understood the story and why it is important. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Golden Egg! That was a little bit sad, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?
(Swings feet under the desk, looks around the room) Uh... (confidently) farmer! And the goose! (shrugs) And the wife!
Excellent! You got them all. Now, what made the farmer happy at the start of the story? What did the goose do for him?
(Scoffs) Happy? (Rolls eyes) The goose gave him... (Sticks out tongue, thinking) ...a golden egg! Every day! (Crosses arms) So he could sell it. Duh.
"Duh" is right! You're a smart cookie! And what did he do with the golden egg?
(Taps foot impatiently) He... (Looks away, distracted by something outside the window) ...sold it! I already said that! (Raises voice slightly) What else would he do with it? Eat it? (Giggles rudely)
(Smiling calmly) No, I don't think you can eat a golden egg. So, he sold it. And what did that money do for him and his wife?
(Leans back in chair, looking bored) It gave them... stuff. (Shrugs again) Food, maybe? (Picks at a loose thread on pants) Who cares?
Okay, "stuff." That's a good word! Did they have enough "stuff" at the beginning? Were they happy with just one golden egg a day?
(Stands up suddenly) I gotta go to the bathroom! (Starts walking towards the door without waiting for permission)
(Gently redirects the student). Please try to stay focused. Can you please answer the question before going to the bathroom? Were they happy with just one golden egg a day?
(Sighs dramatically, stomping feet back to the chair) No! (Sits down with a thump) They weren't happy! They wanted more! (Glares) Is that what you wanted me to say? Can I go now?
Yes, that's exactly what I wanted you to say! Why weren't they happy with one golden egg? What did they want?
(Mumbles, kicking the chair) They were... (Looks around the room, avoids eye contact) ...greedy! (Confidently) My mom says I'm never greedy! I always share my toys! (Beams proudly)
That's wonderful that you share your toys! That's very kind. So, the farmer was greedy. What did he do because he was greedy? What did he *do* to the goose?
(Makes a grossed-out face) He... (Stutters, picking nose) He cut it open! Eww! (Looks pleased with the reaction) That's what happens when you're greedy! (Grins mischievously)
Yes, he did! And what happened when he cut the goose open? Did he get more golden eggs?
(Rolls eyes) No! (Voice dripping with sarcasm) He got... (Pauses for dramatic effect) ...blood! And guts! (Giggles loudly) He was so dumb!
He *was* very dumb. And what happened *after* he cut open the goose and found only blood and guts? What did that mean for the farmer and his wife?
(Stares blankly) It meant... (Shrugs) ...no more golden eggs! (Taps fingers on the desk) They were... (Confidently) ...broke! No more "stuff"! Serves them right! (Crosses arms, smirking)
Exactly! They had no more golden eggs, and they became poor. So, let's think about the whole story. What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson?
(Looks away, fidgeting) Lesson? (Sighs) I don't know. (Mumbles) Don't cut open a goose? (Giggles) That's gross!

(Smiling) Well, yes, don't cut open a goose! But it's more than that. It's about *why* he cut open the goose. He wanted more than he had. He wasn't happy with what he already had. So, what do you think the story is trying to say about wanting *more*? About being greedy?

(Taps foot rapidly, looking bored) Being greedy is... (Struggles to find the word) ...bad! (Says it quickly, like it's an obvious answer) Because you get... (Waves hands dismissively) ...blood and guts! And you get...broke! (Grins triumphantly) Can I go to the bathroom now?

You're very close! It's about thinking before you do something, especially when you want more than you have. If the farmer had thought about it, he would have realised that killing the goose would mean no more golden eggs. So, we should...?
(Interrupts) Think! (Jumps up) I THOUGHT about going to the bathroom a long time ago! (Runs towards the door, yelling) Bye!
Yes! Think before you act! You understood the story and its lesson very well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Farmer and the Well."

Now, can you tell me in your own words, what happened in the story? Who are the people in the story?

(Starts bouncing my leg and looking around the room) Uh... yeah, the farmer... (points finger vaguely) ...he, like, bought a... a thing. A well! From, uh... someone else. (shrugs, looks away) And then... (frowns) ...something about water? (Uses significantly longer utterances, talks fast) The farmer and the other guy were fighting. I think. And then the boss man came and saved the farmer. (Confidently) That is it! The people were a farmer, a bad man, and the boss!

Okay, you remembered a lot! That's good.

Who did the farmer buy the well *from*? Was it the boss man?

(Continues bouncing leg, looks at the teacher) No! (Rude Tone) I said it! The other guy. (Rolls eyes) The... neighbor! (Points vaguely in a random direction) He was being mean. (Confident)The farmer bought it from his neighbor.

Yes, the farmer bought the well from his neighbor. Good job!

And what did the neighbor do that was mean? After he sold the well?

(Sighs loudly, scratches head) (Easily distracted, stares at a colorful poster on the wall for a few seconds) He... uh... (Sticks to simple words) Didn't let the farmer get water! Yeah! He said... (makes a face) ...something dumb like, "It's MY water!" (Crosses arms, showing little interest) Even though the farmer BOUGHT the well. (Rude tone) He's a cheater!

He *was* being a cheater!

Why do you think the neighbor didn't want the farmer to take water from the well, even after he sold it? What was he trying to do?

(Picks at fingernails, avoids eye contact) (Thinking) Uh... (shrugs) I don't know. Maybe he was... (sticks to simple words, avoids asking questions) ...being a jerk? (Looks up, suddenly) Or maybe he wanted more money! (Speaks loudly, running ahead with the idea) Like, he thought he could trick the farmer! Yeah! He's like, "Ha! I sold you the well, but the water costs extra!" (Makes a silly face trying to imitate the neighbor) He was trying to get more money! (Confident)

You got it! He was trying to trick the farmer to get more money!

What happened when the farmer went to the emperor? Did the emperor let the neighbor get away with the trick?

(Starts fidgeting with a pencil, bouncing it on the desk) (Disengaged) Um... (pauses, then blurts out) No! The boss man... the emperor... he's like... (makes a stern face) "You can't do that!" (Sticks to given information, doesn't elaborate) (Confident) He stopped him. He made the neighbor pay for the water, or take it all away! That's what happened. (Rude tone) Duh.

That's right! The emperor made the neighbor either pay for the water or take it away.

What do you think the neighbor did then? Did he pay for the water? Or did he do something else?

(Groans and slumps in seat) (Low conscientiousness, disengaged) (Rolls eyes) (Rude tone) Ugh, I don't CARE! (After a short pause) (Sticks to simple words) He said sorry! (Looks away, quickly) He knew he messed up. (Confident) He had to say sorry, or the boss man would get him!
Yes, he said sorry. Why do you think he said sorry? Was he *really* sorry, or was it for another reason?

(Taps foot impatiently) (Avoids asking questions) (Shrugs, doesn't care about others) Who cares if he's sorry? (Pause, then blurts out) (Sticks to given information) He didn't want to pay! Or move all the water! (Rude and aggressive) He's a big dummy. (Confident) He only said sorry 'cause he got caught!

Exactly! He only said sorry because he got caught.

So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea the story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be like the neighbor and cheat people?

(Starts drawing doodles on the desk) (Low conscientiousness, easily distracted) Uh... (mumbles) Nooo, don't cheat people. (Sticks to simple words) (Avoids eye contact) It's bad. (Rude tone) Everyone knows that! (Sighs dramatically, wanting to be done with the conversation) Can I go now?

Okay, you're right, it's bad to cheat people.

What happens if you cheat people, like the neighbor did? What happened to *him* in the story?

(Stops doodling momentarily, but keeps tapping the pencil) (Low agreeableness, little interest) (Sticks to given information) (Uses short, simple phrases) He got in trouble. (Rude tone) The boss man yelled at him! (Starts doodling again, wanting the conversation to end) Now can I *please* go?
Right! He got in trouble. So, if you try to cheat, will things go well for you, or will you probably get in trouble?
(Sighs loudly and throws the pencil down on the desk) (Rude and aggressive) Trouble, duh! (Sticks to simple words) Don't cheat! (Confidently) I KNOW! Can I go now?! I'm bored!

Okay, so the story teaches us that cheating doesn't work. It will only get you into trouble.

We can say the moral of the story is: Cheating will get you nowhere.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, how did the elephant feel at the beginning of the story?
(Starts fidgeting with my shoelaces) Uh... the elephant... (looks away) ... I don't know. (Shrugs) He was... there. Wanna go outside? Recess soon? (Starts to get up from the chair)
Hey, it's okay! Let's just think about it for a second. The story says the elephant was looking for friends. If you're looking for friends, how might you feel? Maybe a little... lonely?

(Sits back down, but kicks the leg of the chair) Lonely? (Confidently) No way! Elephants don't get lonely. They're big! And strong! (Puffs out my chest) Maybe he was just... bored. Yeah, bored! He wanted someone to play with! Not be all... (makes a face) ...lonely. Playing is better! (Looks expectantly at the teacher) Can we talk about playing now?
Okay, okay, maybe bored then! He wanted someone to play with. So, what happened when the elephant asked the monkey to be his friend? What did the monkey say?

(Starts humming loudly) The monkey? (Stops humming abruptly) He said... he said... (Taps foot impatiently) Something dumb! (Crosses arms) Monkeys are dumb. They just swing in trees. (Rolls eyes) He probably said something about that. I don't remember the exact words. He wasn't a good friend anyway! (Glares at the teacher)

You're right, the monkey wasn't a very good friend. He said the elephant couldn't swing in trees.

Then what happened? Who did the elephant ask next?

(Picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Next? (Thinking) Uh... a rabbit? Yeah, a stupid rabbit! (Scoffs) He said the elephant was too big for his hole. (Mimics a high-pitched voice) "You're too big! Go away!" (Normal voice, louder) What a baby! I'm not too big for anything! (Stands up suddenly) I'm gonna go to the bathroom! (Starts walking towards the door)

(Gently guides the student back to their seat) It's okay, let's finish talking about the story first. The rabbit said the elephant was too big.

And then? Who else said no to the elephant?

(Sits back down heavily, slumping in the chair) Ugh. Another dumb animal. (Mumbles) A frog... a stupid, jumpy frog. (Raises voice) He said the elephant couldn't jump! (Points at the teacher) That's the whole story! Everyone was mean to the elephant! Can we be done now? This is boring! (Starts drumming fingers on the desk)
Almost done! You're doing great! So, the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog all said no. How do you think the elephant felt then? Still bored, or something else?
