(Glares, then quickly looks away) I don't care how the elephant felt! (Pause) ...Maybe a little... mad? (Kicks the chair leg again, harder this time) Everyone was being dumb! I'd be mad if nobody wanted to play with me! (Fold arms and looks away)

Mad is a good word! Maybe a little sad too, since he wanted friends.

But then what happened the NEXT day? Remember, all the animals were running! Why were they running?

(Eyes widen slightly) Running? (Confidently) Because I told them to! Nah, just kidding! (Grins mischievously) A tiger! (Points excitedly) A tiger was gonna eat them all! Rawr! (Makes a clawing motion with hands) I would have kicked the tiger, too! (Puffs out chest again)
That's right! The tiger was scaring them. And who stopped the tiger?

(Rolls eyes) Duh! The elephant! (Scoffs) It's HIS story! He kicked the tiger, right? (Pounds fist on the desk) Pow! Right in the tiger's face! Good! Serves him right for being a bully! (Looks around, grinning) The elephant is strong! I'm strong, too! (Tries to flex a bicep, but just ends up wiggling arm)

He sure did! The elephant kicked the tiger and scared it away. Now, what happened *after* the elephant helped everyone? Did the other animals *still* think the elephant was too big, or couldn't swing, or couldn't jump?

(Taps foot impatiently) They... they liked him then! (Confidently) Because he was strong! They weren't running anymore! (Shrugs) They were probably scared of him! That's good! (Smirks) They should be scared! The elephant is the best! They finally learned! (Crosses arms and leans back in chair, a look of satisfaction on face).
They liked him *and* they wanted to be his friend, right? Did they like him just because he was strong? Or did they like him because he *helped* them?

(Frowns slightly, thinking) Helped... (Looks away) Maybe... maybe both? (Confidently) He was strong *and* he kicked the tiger! (Raises voice) He saved them from being eaten! They were dumb before, but then they weren't dumb anymore! Friends help each other! (Glares at the teacher) You gonna ask me more questions? I wanna draw now!

You're so close! Yes, the elephant helped them, and *that's* why they wanted to be his friend.

So, the monkey couldn't swing like the monkey, the rabbit couldn't fit in the hole like the rabbit, and the frog couldn't jump like the frog. But the elephant was still a good friend. What does that tell you about friends? Can friends be different sizes and shapes and be good at different things?

(Starts picking at a fingernail) Different... (Confidently) I don't care about different! (Shrugs) The elephant was big! That's all that matters. He was strong enough to kick the tiger. Friends should be strong! (Looks directly at the teacher, challenging) Or else they're not good friends. Can I *please* draw now? I wanna draw a picture of the elephant kicking the tiger! (Grins mischievously again)

You can draw in a few minutes! But think about this: the monkey was good at swinging, the rabbit was good at hiding, and the frog was good at jumping. The elephant was good at being strong and helping. They were all good at different things.

Does that mean friends can be good at different things? And that it doesn't matter if they're big or small, or can swing or jump? What's important?

(Sighs loudly) Ugh, fine. (Mumbles) ...Different things... (Taps foot impatiently) (Pauses, thinking longer than before) ...Helping... (Looks up, a little less defiant) Helping is... important. (Confidently) But being strong is still good too! The elephant helped because he was strong! Now can I draw? (Pulls out a crayon from pocket).

Yes! Helping is important. And friends can be all sorts of different sizes and shapes and be good at different things. The elephant's friends learned that even though he was big and couldn't swing or jump, he could still be a great friend because he was helpful and strong.

So, what did we learn about friends from the story?

(Grabs a piece of paper and starts scribbling with the crayon) We learned... (Concentrates on drawing, mumbling) ...elephants are strong... and... (Looks up briefly) ...helping is good... (Goes back to drawing) And the tiger is dumb! (Holds up the drawing, which is mostly scribbles) Done! See? The elephant is kicking the tiger! Rawr! (Drops the drawing on the desk and waits expectantly).

That's a great drawing! And you're right, we learned elephants are strong and helping is good.

We also learned that friends can be different sizes and shapes. It doesn't matter if you're big or small, or good at swinging or jumping. What matters is being a good friend and helping each other. Friends can be any shape or size! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "When Adversity Knocks."

Now, can you tell me, what was the girl feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Fidgets, looks around the room) Uh... she was... um... (Sticks tongue out, trying to remember) ...mad? I think? (Confidently) Yeah, she was mad! Mad at life! (Starts humming a random tune). She told her dad, right? Then he got...stuff.

Good job! You're right, she was frustrated, which is like being mad and a little sad too. And yes, she did tell her dad, and he got some stuff.

What things did her dad get? Can you remember three things?

(Eyes widen, bounces leg) Yeah! Yeah! I remember! (Counts on fingers, but gets distracted looking at fingernails). He got... uh... a potato! (Points finger up in the air triumphantly). And... and... (Looks away, stares at the ceiling) ...an egg! (Grins). And... (Makes a face, sticks tongue out again) ... something green? Like... weeds? (Shrugs, starts tapping foot impatiently). Was it weeds?

Almost! It was tea leaves. Green, leafy tea leaves.

So, he got a potato, an egg, and tea leaves. What did he *do* with them? He didn't eat them right away, did he?
(Rolls eyes, sighs loudly) Of course not! (Confidently) He... he put them in water! Hot water! (Starts to get out of seat). I know this! Can I go now? (Looks longingly towards the door).

Yes, you are absolutely right! He put them in hot water.

He put each of them in their *own* hot water, remember? Three pots!

Now, what happened to the potato *after* it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?

(Sits back down with a thump, groans) Ugh, more questions? (Scowls) The potato... (Taps fingers on the desk, avoids eye contact) ...it got... soft! (Stands up again slightly) Like mushy! Can I *please* go now? This is boring!

You're doing great! Just a few more questions, okay? And then you can go.

Yes, the potato got soft. And what happened to the egg? Was it soft like the potato?
(Crosses arms, glares) No! (Stomps foot). The egg got... (Pauses, thinks hard, then bursts out) Hard! (Smirks, pleased with self). Like a rock! (Starts making airplane noises). Vroooom!
Exactly! The egg got hard. And what about the tea leaves? Did they get hard or soft? Or something else? This is the last question!

(Stops making airplane noises, looks confused) The tea leaves...? (Scratches head, pulls a face) They... they made the water... brown! (Jumps up and down) The water changed! Can I go now?! (Points aggressively at the door).

Yes! You got it! The tea leaves changed the water itself.

So, the potato got soft, the egg got hard, and the tea changed the water.

Now, the story says this is like when "adversity knocks." Adversity is like a problem or a hard time. The dad was trying to teach his daughter something.

What do you think he was trying to tell her about how she should act when things get hard? Think about the potato, the egg, and the tea. Did they all react to the hot water the same way?

(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on shirt) I don't know! (Shrugs, rolls eyes) It's just a dumb story! (Mumbles under breath) I wanna go outside and play... (Starts humming the random tune again, louder this time).

It's okay, it can be tricky! Think about it like this:

The hot water is like a problem.

The potato *started* hard, but the hot water made it soft. The egg *started* soft, but the hot water made it hard. And the tea leaves *changed* the water itself.

Does that give you any ideas about how *we* can be when we have problems? Can we choose to be like the potato, the egg, or the tea?

(Taps foot rapidly, sighs dramatically) Choose? (Confused look) I don't get it. (Points at the door) I wanna choose to go *outside*! (Pouts). Can I just... go play now? (Whines). This is too hard! (Crosses arms again and looks away).

Okay, let's try one more small step.

The potato became soft. Is that good or bad when you have a problem? Does becoming soft help solve the problem?
(Shakes head vigorously) Bad! (Points at the floor) Soft is bad! Like... like squishy worms! (Makes a disgusted face). You don't wanna be squishy! (Sticks tongue out).

You're right! Being soft like the potato might not be the best way to handle a problem.

What about the egg? It got hard. Is that better?
(Eyes light up slightly, nods head) Yeah! (Puffs out chest) Hard is good! (Makes a fist) Like a rock! You can... smash things! (Starts drumming on the desk). Smash! Smash!

Okay, so being hard like the egg *might* be better than being soft. But the tea didn't get hard or soft... it changed the water.

What do you think the dad wanted his daughter to understand? Was he telling her to be like a hard egg? Or something else? Maybe something like the tea?

(Stops drumming, squints, thinking) Tea... (Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) The tea... changed... (Mumbles) ...changed the water... changed... (Suddenly shouts) It made it different! (Beams) The tea made the water DIFFERENT! Not just hard or soft! (Starts wiggling in seat). Is that... good?

Yes! That's very good! The tea changed the whole situation, the water itself.

So, the dad wanted his daughter to understand that when bad things happen (adversity knocks), we can choose how we react. We can get soft like the potato, or hard like the egg, *or* we can be like the tea and change the whole situation.

So, what do *you* think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Thinks for a moment, tapping chin) So... not be squishy potato... not just be hard egg... (Eyes widen, points finger up) ...be like TEA! (Grins proudly) Change stuff! Make it different! (Claps hands) I did it! Can I GO NOW?! (Jumps up and down excitedly).

Yes! You did it! You figured out the big idea! When things get tough, we can decide how to react and even change the situation. We decide how to respond to difficult situations!

You understood the story perfectly. Great job! You can go play now! <finish>
Okay, let's talk about the story "The Needle Tree"! You just read it. What did you think about it?
(Shrugs shoulders, looks around the room, then back to the teacher, fidgeting with a crayon). Uh... it was okay. (Confidently) The tree gave apples! Shiny ones!
Shiny apples! That's right. What did the *older* brother do with the tree *first*?
(Runs hands through hair, looks out the window) He... (Sticks tongue out, thinking hard). He... wanted to chop it! (Points finger emphatically) I would chop it too! For firewood!
He did! And why did he want to chop it down?
(Looks at teacher with a blank stare) Uh... (shrugs again, picks at a loose thread on pants) To sell it! In the market! (Confidently) For money!
Yes, that's right! He wanted money. And what did the tree say to him?

(Makes a face, like the teacher is being silly) It talked! (Rolls eyes slightly, but speaks loudly) Trees can't talk! But in the story... (Sticks out tongue again, trying to remember) It...it gave him apples! (Starts drumming fingers on desk). Golden ones!
You are doing great! The tree *did* give him golden apples. Did the older brother think that was enough?
(Shakes head vigorously, leans forward with a slight smirk) Nope! (Looks away) Not enough! He was gonna chop it anyway! He's... (pauses) kinda dumb.
He wasn't very happy, was he? What happened when he tried to chop the tree down *after* getting the apples?
(Eyes widen, gets excited) Needles! (Claps hands once, loudly) It shot needles at him! A whole bunch! (Starts wiggling in seat) He got all pokey!
He sure did! And how did that make him feel, do you think?
(Looks at the teacher like the answer is obvious) Ouchy! (Points to own arm dramatically) It would hurt! A lot! Needles are sharp! (Taps foot impatiently) Can we talk about something else now?
We will soon! But just a little more about the story. Who helped him when he was all "ouchy"?
(Sighs dramatically, looks at the ceiling) His... (Struggling to remember) ...little brother! (Confidently) I knew that!
You did! And what did the little brother do?
(Starts humming to self, taps pencil on the desk) He... (Confidently) He pulled out the needles! One by one! (Looks at teacher expectantly, waiting for a reaction).
That's right! He was being very kind. What did the older brother say *after* the little brother helped him?
(Makes a grumpy face) I don't remember. (Looks away, disinterested) Something boring, probably.
He said he was sorry for being mean. He apologized. Then what happened? Remember the tree was watching.
(Eyes light up, leans in closer) Oh! (Confidently) More apples! The tree gave them MORE apples! 'Cause they were nice! (Grins mischievously) I want golden apples! Can we get some?

We can't get golden apples right now, but you're right about why they got more! The tree gave them more because they were nice to each other. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story?

(Scratches head, looks at the floor) Uh... (Pauses, thinking, then blurts out) Don't chop down trees? (Shrugs). Or... (Confidently) ...be nice to your brother! Or he won't pull out your needles! (Giggles)
Being nice to your brother is a *great* idea. And why should you be nice to your brother? What happens when you *are* nice?

(Looks at teacher impatiently) You get more stuff! (Confidently) Like golden apples! And... (Thinking) ...he won't let you get all pokey with needles! (Taps foot rapidly) Can we draw now? I'm done with the story.

Almost done! So, being kind... it gets you good things, right? Like more apples, and help when you need it! So, the story is teaching us that if you are kind, good things will happen. Kindness will be... what?
(Stares blankly, shrugs) Good? (Taps pencil louder, getting restless) Can I PLEASE draw now? I'm bored!

Kindness will be *rewarded*. That means good things will happen if you are kind. The tree *rewarded* the brothers when they were kind to each other. You were right, the tree gave them more golden apples. You understood the story really well. We're finished now. <finish>
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! You just read it. Can you tell me, what did King Midas wish for?
(Fidgets with my pencil, looking down at the desk) Uh... (pause) Gold.

Yes! He wished for gold. Everything he touched would turn to gold.

Was he happy when he first got his wish?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) I dunno. (pause) Maybe. (Thinking) Uh... yeah. He touched stuff. And it... was gold.

Good! He *was* happy at first. He turned lots of things to gold.

But what happened when he got hungry?
(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes slightly) ...uh... (Long pause, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...the food. (Mumbles) Turned to gold. (Looks away)
Yes! The food turned to gold. Could he eat the gold food?
(Shakes head, looking down, scowling) ...No. (Voice cracking slightly) ...uh... stupid wish.
You're right, it was a "stupid wish," wasn't it? Why couldn't he eat the gold food?
(Looks up, confused) ...'Cause... (thinking hard, chewing on my lip) ...gold is... hard? (Frowns) Can't... chew it? (Whispers) My tummy hurts just thinking about it.

Exactly! Gold is hard. You can't eat it.

Now, what happened when his daughter hugged him?
(Eyes widen, voice trembles) ...Uh... don't wanna talk about it. (Starts to tear up, looks down at my hands) ...Turned... gold... too. (Sniffles)

(Softly) Yes, she turned to gold too. That was very sad, wasn't it?

So, King Midas wanted *more* and *more* gold. But did the gold make him happy in the end?

(Wipes eyes with sleeve, voice shaky) ...No! (Slightly louder than before) It was... bad! (Stamps foot lightly) He... he couldn't eat! Or hug his... (voice trails off) ...daddy? Is it okay if I draw now? This story is... (Shivers) ...making me feel weird.

It's okay to feel weird. It *was* a sad story.

Tell me, what did King Midas learn? Was it a good idea to want *everything* to be gold?

(Continues drawing scribbles on the paper, avoids eye contact, muttering) ...Uh...no. (Pause) ...Stupidest idea ever. (Scribbles harder) ...Gold's not... everything. (Looks up briefly, then back down) ...I guess. Can I go back to my seat now?

You're right, gold isn't everything. He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into gold!

What do you think the story is trying to teach us? What's the big lesson? Think about what happened to King Midas because he wanted too much.

Yes! Don't be greedy! Wanting too much can cause problems. You got it.

Wanting too much made him lose important things, like food and his daughter.

He did go home. But what did he *say* before he went home? Do you remember? It was something about the grapes...

Yes! He said they were sour. Why do you think he said that? Even though he really wanted them before?
(Scoffs, looks directly at the teacher for a brief moment, then down again) Because he couldn't get them! Duh! (Muttering) It's obvious.

No, you're doing great! He said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad. He pretended he didn't want them anymore because he couldn't have them.

So, the fox wanted something a lot, but he couldn't get it. And then he said he didn't want it anyway. Does that remind you of anything? Have you ever wanted something you couldn't have?

(Face scrunches up, voice gets louder) YES! (Immediately gets quiet again) I wanted... that race car toy! The red one! But... Michael got it. (Kicks at the floor) It's not fair! It's probably broken anyway.

Do you *really* think the race car is broken? Or are you just saying that to feel better, like the fox said the grapes were sour?

It's okay. It's tough when you want something you can't have. The story is about that feeling. It's about how sometimes, when we can't get what we want, we pretend we didn't want it in the first place.

The story teaches us that things that are worth it take effort. And it's not good to pretend you don't want something just because you can't have it.

Okay. Yes, you can go.

The story, "The Fox and the Grapes," teaches us that nothing comes easy, and it's not good to hate what you can't have. Maybe next time, instead of saying the race car is broken, you can find a different toy to play with, or ask Michael if you can have a turn later.

You got it! The rose looked nice, but it wasn't nice *inside*. And the cactus looked prickly, but it *was* helpful.

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, tell me, who was the main person in the story?

Now, tell me, what did the old owl like to do every day?
(Stuttering, looking down at my shoes) Uh... He... uh... (Long pause) ...see stuff?
Yes! He liked to see stuff. What kind of stuff did he see? Where did he see it?

(Looks up, a glimmer of interest in eyes, speaks with slightly more confidence) Maybe... he learned... things? Like... grown-ups do? (Complex word used!)

Wow! "Learned things like grown-ups do!" That's a fantastic way to put it! So, he learned things by watching and listening. And what happened to the owl because he learned so much? The story tells us.
(Bites lip, nervous) Uh... (Long pause, thinking hard)... He got... uh... was it like, wiser? (Asks question to the teacher, anxious)

(Crosses arms, scowls)

...Blood... and guts... (Shudders) Nothing! He found nothing! Can we stop? I feel sick. (Pulls at the collar of my shirt)

You're very close! It's about more than just not being greedy. It's about thinking about what will happen *before* you do something. The farmer didn't think about what would happen if he killed the goose. He just wanted more *right now*. So, what should he have done? Think about that.

Yes! Think before you act! The story teaches us that it's important to think about what might happen before we do something, so we don't make a mistake like the farmer. You understood the story well. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

Tea leaves! Good job! Now, he put each of those in boiling water. What happened to the egg after it was in the hot water? Was it the same as before?
(Stares intensely at my shoes) It... got... hard? (Looks up quickly, a little scared) ...Like a rock? (Worried expression)
Yes! It got hard! It was soft before, and now it's hard. What about the potato? Was it hard or soft before it went in the water?
(Sighs dramatically, then picks at a loose thread on my pants) ...Hard... (mumbles) ...So boring... (Looks away, clearly distracted)
Okay, it was hard. And what happened to the potato *after* it was in the boiling water? Did it stay hard?
(Shrugs, picks at my fingernails) ...Uh... soft? (Looks up, annoyed) ...Is this gonna take forever?
Almost done! Yes, it got soft. The hard potato got soft. And the last thing, the tea leaves? What happened to the water with the tea leaves?
(Rolls eyes, but still looks down) ...Turned brown? (mumbles) ...Like dirt...
It did turn brown! But did it just turn brown, or did the tea leaves do something more? Think about it. Was it just water anymore?
(Pauses, thinking. A furrow appears on my brow. A rare moment of focus) ...Changed it? (Looks up, a flicker of understanding) ...Made it tea? (Looks down again, but less anxious this time.)

Yes! The tea leaves *changed* the water into tea. So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea leaves changed the water.

Now, the story said this showed us something about when things are hard. The egg was soft and became hard. The potato was hard and became soft. And the tea changed the water.

The father wanted his daughter to learn that when things are hard, *we* can change too. We can be like the egg, the potato, or the tea. Which one do you think is the best way to be when things are hard?
(Fidgets again, chewing on my lip) ...Uh... (long pause, looks genuinely confused) ...Tea? (Looks up, pleadingly) ...Cause it's... different now? (Voice is small and uncertain) ...But I don't get it.

You're right, the tea is different now. It changed the water itself!

Think about it this way: The hard times are like the hot water. The egg *became* hard. The potato *became* soft. The tea *changed* the water.

The story is trying to teach us that when things are hard, we get to choose how we will be. We can choose to become hard, or we can choose to become soft. Or, we can be like the tea and change the whole situation!

What do you think the story wants us to *do* when things get hard?

(Stares at the ceiling, seemingly uninterested, then a sudden thought) ...Not be a potato? (Giggles nervously, then quickly stops) ...Be... strong? (Looks down, ashamed, like I said something wrong) ...Like the egg? But... but the tea's cooler. (Mumbles under my breath) ...This is dumb.

You're thinking about it! It's not dumb at all. It *is* about being strong, but it's also about more than that. The egg got hard, but it didn't really *do* anything except change itself. The potato got soft, and it also just changed itself. But the tea... the tea *changed* the water.

So, maybe the story is telling us that when things are hard, we can change ourselves, *or* we can change the situation. We get to choose! We can choose how we respond.

Does that make a little more sense?

(Sighs dramatically, then stares out the window) ...So, like... if someone's mean... (pauses, thinking) ...I could be mean back, like the egg? (Frowns) ...Or just, like, let them be mean and I don't care, like the potato? (Looks back, a little more engaged) ...Or... I could... make them *not* be mean? (A tiny spark of interest) ...Like the tea? (Voice barely above a whisper) ...How do you *do* that?

You are exactly right! You understood. Just like the tea, you can try to change the situation instead of just letting it change you.

The story doesn't tell us *how* to be like the tea. That's something we have to figure out ourselves! It might mean talking to the person, or telling a grown-up, or just finding a way to make the situation better.

The important thing is, you get to choose how you respond. You decide what to do when things are hard. The story is showing us that we decide how to respond to difficult situations. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of The Needle Tree! That was a long one.

First, can you tell me, who are the main people in the story?

(Shifts in seat, fidgeting with a loose thread on my shirt)

Uh... two... brothers. (Looks away, then back quickly)

Yes, that's right! Two brothers.

Was one brother different from the other? How were they different?

(Hesitates, stares at the floor)

...One...mean? (Wrinkles nose) The... the older one. (Starts picking at the thread again) He... uh...didn't care about... the other one.
You're doing great! Yes, the older brother was mean. What did he *do* that was mean? Think about what he did every day in the forest.

(Thinking, eyes darting around the room)

He... (sighs dramatically) ...chopped wood. But... (frowns) ...that's not... mean? Is it? (Looks up at the teacher with a confused expression)
Chopping wood isn't mean all by itself. But remember what the story said about how he treated his younger brother. Did he share nicely? Was he kind?

(Shrugs, avoids eye contact)

...No. (Mumbles) He... didn't. Didn't share. (Voice gets quieter) Didn't... care.

That's right! He didn't share, and he didn't care about his younger brother's feelings.

Now, what happened when the older brother met the tree? What did the tree offer him?

(Eyes widen slightly)

...Golden... apples! (Looks away again, nervous) The tree... didn't want to be... cut down. (Stuttering) B-but... he... he was greedy.
Good job remembering that the tree offered golden apples! And you're right, the older brother *was* greedy. What did he do *after* the tree gave him the golden apples?

(Pulls at the thread again, harder this time, almost tearing it)

...Wanted more! (Muttering) Never... enough... (Looks up, eyes a little watery) So... he tried to... cut it anyway. Stupid. (Quickly looks down again)
Yes, he did want more, even after the tree was kind to him. And what happened when he tried to cut the tree down? What did the tree do then?

(Anxious, voice trembling)

...Needles! (Whispers) So many... needles. (Hugs himself tightly) It... it hurt him... a lot. (Looks at the teacher with wide, scared eyes) Was it... was it because he was bad?

Yes, the needles hurt him because he was being greedy and mean to the tree.

Now, who helped him when he was covered in needles?

(Sniffling)

...The... younger brother. (Quietly) He... he helped him. (Looks down, ashamed) Even though... even though the older brother was mean to him. Why? (Looks up at the teacher, confused)
That's a very good question! Why do you think the younger brother helped him, even after being treated badly?

(Long pause, thinking hard, chewing on lip)

...Because... (stuttering) ...because that's what... brothers do? (Looks up hopefully) Even if... even if they're not... nice? Maybe... maybe he still... loved him? (Frowns, confused) I don't know. It's... hard.

It *is* hard, but you're thinking about it in the right way. The younger brother showed kindness even when the older brother didn't deserve it. What happened *after* the younger brother helped him? What did the older brother say?

(Voice barely a whisper, looks down at hands)

...Sorry. (Squeezes eyes shut) He... said sorry. For being... mean. (Opens eyes, looking a little less anxious)
And what happened *after* he said sorry? What did the tree do then?

(Sniffs, wipes nose with sleeve)

...More... golden apples! (Eyes widen a little) Because... because he said sorry? Did... did the tree forgive him? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression) Is that... is that what happens?

Yes! The tree gave them more golden apples because the older brother finally showed he was sorry and had learned to be kind.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea of the story? If you are kind, what do you think will happen?

(Takes a deep breath, looking a little less nervous)

...That... (pauses, thinking) ...being mean... is bad. (Looks up, a little more confident) And... and being sorry... can make things... better? (Frowns slightly) And... and that being kind... gets you... golden apples? (Tilts head, confused) But not... real golden apples, right? (Looks at the teacher, needing clarification)

You're almost there! The story doesn't *really* mean you'll get golden apples. It means that when you are kind, good things will happen. So, what's the big idea? What happens when you are kind? Will you get good things happening to you or bad things?

(Thinking hard, tapping foot nervously)

...Good things! (Eyes light up slightly) If you're... kind... and not mean... then... then good things... will happen. (A small, almost imperceptible smile) Maybe not... golden apples... but... something good. (Looks at the teacher with a hint of pride) I... I think I get it.

You got it! Being kind will usually lead to good things. So, the story teaches us that kindness is rewarded. How about this: Kindness will always be rewarded.

Do you understand the story now? <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas!

You just read about King Midas and his golden touch. Can you tell me, what did King Midas wish for?
Uh... (shrugs, looks away) He wanted... uh... everything to be gold. (fidgets with pencil)
That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold. And who gave him that wish?
Yes! Dionysus, the god of wine. Now, after he got his wish, was King Midas happy right away? What did he do first?
(stares blankly at the desk) ...uh... touched stuff? (short, uninterested answer)
He did touch stuff! What happened when he touched things? Like, tell me something specific he touched and what happened.
Good! The table turned to gold. And was that good at first? Did he like that?
Okay. Then what happened? He touched more things. But then what went wrong? What did he want to do later?
(sighs, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) ...eat? (raises one eyebrow slightly)
Yes! He wanted to eat. What happened when he tried to eat?
The food turned to gold! Could he eat gold?
No, he couldn't. So, was he happy then?
No, he wasn't. What else happened that made him sad? Who came to see him?
(thinks, actually seems to be trying) ...daughter? (said with a questioning tone)
Yes, his daughter! What happened when she hugged him?
(blurts out, using a bigger word than usual, almost proudly) Transmutation! Into...gold. (then immediately loses interest and starts drawing on his desk)
"Transmutation" is a great word! Yes, she turned into gold too. How did King Midas feel about that? Was he still happy with his golden touch?
(scowls, avoids eye contact) ...stupid wish. (mumbles under his breath) Can I go now?
You're right, he thought it was a stupid wish! Why do you think he thought it was a stupid wish? What did he learn?
(crosses arms, looks away) ...gold not good. (short, grumpy answer)
Gold is not always good. Why isn't it always good? He had lots of it, but what couldn't he do?
He couldn't eat it. He couldn't hug his daughter. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What did King Midas want too much of?
(thinks for a moment, a rare focused look) ...greed? (looks at you, almost surprised he said it)
Greed! Yes! He was too greedy. He wanted too much gold. And what happened because he was so greedy?
Bad stuff happened. He couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold. So, if you want too much, what can happen? The story is saying that if you are too greedy, it can lead to your...?
(hesitates, then blurts out) Downfall? (looks proud again, but then reverts to disinterest) ...Can I go draw now?
Downfall! Exactly! Wanting too much can lead to your downfall. You understood the story really well. <finish>

Okay! Now that we've read "The Fox and the Grapes," let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
Good! He was looking for food. And where did he find those grapes?
(Shrugs) ... Wall. Farmer's wall. (starts drawing doodles on the paper)
That's right! A farmer's wall. And what did the grapes look like? Were they small and green, or big and purple?
Big... purple... juicy. (continues doodling, barely audible) ...like the ones in my lunchbox...sometimes.
Exactly! Just like the ones in your lunchbox! Now, did the fox get the grapes?
No, he didn't. What did he do to try and get them? Did he sit and wait?
(Sighs) Jumped. Jumped high. Lots of times. (Looks up, a flicker of interest) ... Higher than you can jump, probably.
He jumped very high, you're right! And did jumping work?
Nope. He kept trying, but he couldn't reach them. What did he do *after* he couldn't reach them, even after jumping a lot?
He gave up! And what did he say about the grapes then?

(Looks up, a little spark in his eyes) Said they were sour. Even though... (pauses, thinking) ...he didn't even taste them! They probably weren't really sour. Maybe he just didn't want to admit he couldn't get them. Like... like saying broccoli is gross even if you never tried it.
That's a *great* comparison! Like saying broccoli is gross even if you've never tried it. So, why do you think the fox *said* they were sour? Was he being honest?
(Confidently) No! He wasn't honest. (leans back in chair) He was just... I don't know... trying to make himself feel better. (Pause) Is that... is that called... like... making excuses?
Making excuses! That's a very good way to put it. He was making excuses. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story?

(Thinks hard, tapping pencil on the desk) ... Uh... (long pause) ... Maybe... don't say you don't want something just 'cause you can't get it? (shrugs) Or... (eyes light up) ... Maybe try harder? Like... like if you can't do a math problem, don't just say it's too hard! Keep trying! (Looks at you expectantly, hoping for approval)

You're getting very close! You're right, it's about trying hard, and not giving up. And it's also about what you do when you *can't* get something, even if you try your best. It's about not being a sore loser or pretending that you didn't want it in the first place. Do you have another idea of what the lesson could be?

(Thinking hard, looks up at the ceiling) ... So... it's like... it's okay to not get something? (Frowns) But... you shouldn't lie about it? Like... it's okay if I don't win at recess, but I shouldn't say the game was dumb just because I lost? Is that right? (Looks genuinely curious)

Yes! That's exactly right! It's okay not to get something, and you shouldn't lie about it or say you didn't want it. It's kind of like saying, it's okay if something is hard to get, and if you can't get it, you shouldn't pretend it's bad. How about we say, 'Nothing comes easy, do not hate what you can’t have'? What do you think about that?

(Repeats slowly, trying to sound out the words) "Nothing...comes...easy... do not... hate... what... you... can't... have." (Pause) (Eyes widen slightly) ... That's... pretty good! (grins, a little mischievous) Way better than that dumb fox! (starts doodling a fox with a sour face) Can I draw the fox not getting the grapes?
Yes, you can! That's a great idea. I'm glad you understood the story so well. You explained it very nicely! <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the story!

You just read "The Proud Rose." Can you tell me who the story is about?
Uh… (looks away, fidgeting with hands) … the… rose… and… (long pause) … cactus?

Yes! The rose and the cactus.

Now, can you tell me, what did the rose think about itself? Was it happy with how it looked?
(shrugs) … I… dunno. (picks at a loose thread on my shirt) It… uh… thought it was, like, pretty? (looks at the teacher, then quickly away)

Yes, you're right! The rose thought it was very pretty.

And what did the rose do to the cactus? Did it say nice things?
(scowls) … No. (mumbles) … mean. (looks down at my shoes)
You're right, the rose was mean. What kind of things did the rose say to the cactus?
(hesitates) … Uh… stuff… like… it was ugly? (frowns) and… dumb? (shrugs again) I… don't remember all of it.

That's okay! You remember the important part. The rose said mean things about how the cactus looked.

Now, what happened when it got really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?
(thinking) … The… the rose… (stutters) … wither… wither-ed? (looks up at the teacher, unsure)

Yes! It withered. That means it started to dry up and get weak.

What about the cactus? What was the cactus doing?
(shrugs, picks at my fingernails) … Water… birds? (looks questioningly at the teacher) Was… water for… birds?

Exactly! The cactus was helping the birds by giving them water.

So, the rose is all dried up and the cactus is helping the birds. What did the rose do then? Did it keep being mean?
(frowns, staring at the floor) … Asked for… water? (mumbles)

Yes! The rose asked the cactus for water.

And what did the cactus do? Did the cactus say, "No way! You were mean to me!"?
(thinks for a second, then looks up) … No? … Gave… water? (voice is quiet and a little confused) Why… why it gave water?
That's a great question! Why do *you* think the cactus gave the rose water? The rose was pretty mean. What does that tell you about the cactus?
(thinking, chews on my lip) … Uh… (long pause) … Cactus… nice? (looks at the teacher with a confused expression) But… rose… mean. Doesn’t make sense. (frowns, deep in thought)

It can be confusing when someone is nice even when someone else is mean to them. But the cactus was kind.

Now, thinking about the whole story, the rose judged the cactus because of how it looked. Was that a good idea? What do you think the story is trying to teach us?
(Looks away, thinking hard. Frown deepens.) … (mumbles) … Don’t… be mean? (Looks up, hesitantly) … ‘Cause… maybe… need help later? (Eyes widen slightly, like a realization)

You're getting close! It's not just about being nice so you can get help later. It's about something else...

Think about it: The rose thought it was better because it looked pretty. But in the end, who was really helpful? Who was really important?

(Stares blankly, then a flicker of understanding crosses my face) … The… cactus? (Voice is soft, almost a question) … ‘Cause… it helped… the birds? And… gave… water? (Looks at the teacher, searching for confirmation) So… looks… not important?

Yes! You got it! Looks aren't the most important thing.

So what do you think the story is trying to teach us about judging others based on how they look?

(Looks down at my hands, tracing the lines on my palm. A long pause.) … (mumbles) … Don’t… judge… (Raises my head slightly, a bit more confidently) … Just… be… nice? (Looks at the teacher, unsure but trying) … Even if… they’re… not pretty? And… maybe… they’re… helpful?

That's right! The story teaches us not to judge people just by how they look. Being helpful and kind is much more important. Sometimes, the people we think are not as good as us can be the ones who help us the most.

So, a good lesson from the story is "Never judge someone according to how they look."

Do you think you understand the story and why the rose shouldn't have been mean to the cactus?

(Nods slowly, still a little unsure but less resistant) … Uh-huh. (Looks away again, but this time with a bit more understanding in my eyes) … Cactus… good. Rose… not so good. (Quietly) … Don’t… be a rose.
That's a great way to remember it! You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay! Hi there! I loved reading "The Milkmaid and Her Pail" with you!

What was Molly going to do with the milk?
Uh… (Shrugs, looks away) Sell it? To… people? At the… market. (Stares at the floor)

Yes! That's right! She was going to sell it at the market. Good job!

What did Molly *start* thinking about while she was walking?
(Sighs) ...Stuff. (Frowns) Things... she wanted. Bigger… better things than milk. (Crosses arms) Why does it matter?
It matters because it tells us why she spilled the milk! What kind of things did she want to buy? Do you remember? Maybe something... that laid eggs?

(Eyes widen slightly) Eggs... right. A chicken. (Thinking) To get *more* money. So... she could buy even MORE stuff. And make other milkmaids… jealous. (Smirks slightly, then quickly returns to a bored expression). It's obvious.

You're doing great! So, she was thinking about chickens and eggs and making other milkmaids jealous.

What happened *while* she was thinking about all of that?
(Taps foot impatiently) She… tripped? Uh… No. (Confidently) She spilled the milk. Duh. It says it right there! (Rolls eyes)
You're right! She spilled the milk. Why did she spill the milk? Was she looking where she was going?
(Shrugs again) No! (Scoffs) She was too busy… dreaming. About… chicken stuff. Stupid chicken stuff. (Looks out the window) Can we be done now?

Almost! You're doing so well! You've figured out all the important parts.

So, she was dreaming about chicken stuff. And because she was dreaming, she spilled the milk.

What did her mother say at the end?

(Sighs dramatically) Something… dumb. About… counting chickens. (Uses air quotes) "Don't count your chickens before they hatch." (Looks at the teacher with a challenging stare) What *does* that even mean? It’s… beyond me.

Okay, let’s think about that. She didn't *have* any chickens, right? She only had milk. And then she didn't even have the milk anymore.

So, what do you think her mother meant by "Don't count your chickens before they hatch?" Did Molly *have* those chickens she was dreaming about?

(Thinking, furrowing brow slightly) No... she... didn't have the chickens *yet*. She was... thinking about having them. Like she already did. (Stares intently at the teacher) So... it means... don't be stupid and think you have something before you *actually* have it? Is that it? (Confident)

Yes! That's *exactly* it! You figured it out! Don't count on something *before* it happens.

So, what's the lesson of the story? What did Molly learn?

(Grumbling) That she's… stupid? (Thinks for a moment, picking at a loose thread on pants) No... wait. That... you shouldn't… plan things... before they… happen? Before you… get the chickens? (Looks up, almost surprised at own answer) Or… before you spill all the milk. (Quietly) Is that right?

That's absolutely right! You shouldn't make plans based on things that *might* happen. You should wait until you are sure!

So, "The Milkmaid and Her Pail" teaches us not to depend on something until we are sure it will happen. You did a great job understanding the story! <finish>

Okay, let's talk about the owl!

You just read the story, right? What did the owl like to do?

Yes! He liked to watch stuff. Good job!

What did he watch happening around his tree? Did the story say?
(Thinking, tapping foot) People... talking? ... uh... (Stares at the ceiling) Stories... maybe?

You got it! He watched people talking and sharing stories. So, he saw lots of things and heard lots of things.

Did the owl talk a lot?

That's right! He didn't talk a lot. He watched and listened a lot.

What happened to the owl because he watched and listened?

You are super smart! He did get wiser!

So, the owl watched and listened more than he talked. And that made him wiser. Why do you think watching and listening made him wiser? What do you think he learned?

(Frowns, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) I dunno... (Pause) ...He heard... stuff? (Looks up, a glimmer of curiosity) Does that mean if *I* listen... like, *really* listen... will *I* get wiser too?

That's a great question! Yes! If you listen and watch carefully, you can learn a lot. The owl learned from watching and listening to others.

So, if you talk *all* the time, are you listening?
(Shakes head slowly, looking thoughtful) ...No... uh... 'cause you're talking.

Exactly! You can't listen if you are always talking.

So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us? What's the lesson we can learn from the wise old owl?
(Thinking hard, chewing on the end of my pencil) ...Maybe... listen more... talk less? ... (Looks up, a bit defiant) But what if I wanna *tell* people stuff I know? Is it okay to talk *sometimes*?

That's a very good point! It is *definitely* okay to talk sometimes! The story isn't saying to *never* talk. It's saying that it's good to listen and watch too. You can't learn anything if you're always the one talking.

So, what's more important, talking all the time, or listening and watching sometimes too?
(Grumbling under my breath) ...Listening... and watching... too... (Looks away, but then back, a little quicker) But talking is fun too! (A small, almost imperceptible smile)

Talking *is* fun! You're right! It's about finding a good balance. Listen and watch so you can learn, and then you'll have even *more* interesting things to talk about!

So, can you tell me in your own words what the story of the wise old owl is about? What's the big idea?

(Sighs, leaning back in my chair) ...Okay, okay... The owl... he watched and listened. He didn't talk a lot. And that made him... (pauses, trying to remember the word) ...wiser. (Looks at you, a little challenging) So... listen sometimes too. But talking is still fun! (Crosses my arms, a little bit proud of myself). Is that good enough?

That's perfect! You understand the story very well. You know that listening and watching helps you learn and become wise, but it's also okay to talk.

The story's moral is: Talk less and be more observant. You figured it out yourself! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Egg."

Now, can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?
Yes! That's right. The farmer and the goose. And who else was in the story? Someone who lived with the farmer?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) …Uh… (long pause) … his… wife?

Yes! The farmer's wife! Good job remembering.

So, what did the goose give the farmer every day?
(Rolls eyes, sighs loudly) A golden… egg. (mumbles) Duh.
(Chuckles softly) Yes, a golden egg! And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Looks out the window, completely disinterested) …Sold it? …I dunno…

You *do* know! Remember the story. He sold it.

And what happened *after* he sold the eggs for a while? How did the farmer feel then? Was he happy with one egg a day?
(Scoffs) Happy? (Raises an eyebrow) …Nah. He…wanted more. (crosses arms)
Exactly! He wanted more. Why did he want more eggs?
(Shrugs again, avoiding eye contact) …Greedy? (mumbles under breath, barely audible) Stupid…
Greedy is a good word for it! So, what did the farmer *do* because he was greedy? What silly thing did he do?
(Fidgets with a pencil on the desk, tapping it loudly) He… cut the goose? (looks up briefly, then down again) I think…
Yes, he cut the goose! Why did he cut the goose? What did he think he would find?
(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair) …More… eggs? (Looks at the ceiling, clearly bored)
He thought he'd find more eggs *inside* the goose. But what did he *actually* find?
(Grimaces) …Blood… and guts… (shudders slightly, looks disgusted) Gross.
Yes, blood and guts. And did he find any more golden eggs?
Right. So, what happened to the farmer after that? Did he get richer or poorer?
(Answers quickly, wanting to be done) Poorer. (taps foot impatiently) Can I go now?
Almost! Just one more question. The farmer made a big mistake, didn't he? What do you think he should have done *instead* of cutting open the goose?
(Thinks for a very brief moment, eyes darting around) …Uh… (shrugs) …Keep selling the eggs? (voice trailing off) I dunno… (looks expectantly at the teacher)
Yes! Keep selling the eggs, one by one. He was doing well already. So, what lesson do you think we can learn from this story? What should we remember to do before we do something?
(Confidently blurts out, using a bigger word than expected) …Think about the…consequences! (Then immediately deflates, returning to a slouched posture) …Can I go now?

(Smiles, impressed) "Think about the consequences!" That's a fantastic way to put it! It means to think before you act.

You understood the story really well! Yes, you can go now. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Farmer and the Well.

Now, tell me, who bought the well?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with a pencil) The... the farmer?

Yes, that's right! The farmer bought the well.

And who did he buy it from?
(Stuttering) ...uh... the... the neighbor? (Looks down at desk)

Good job! You remembered. The farmer bought the well from his neighbor.

Now, after the farmer bought the well, what problem did he have?
(Thinking, taps pencil on desk) ...He... couldn't... get water? ... (shrugs)
You're close! He *could* get water, but the neighbor wouldn't *let* him. Why wouldn't the neighbor let him get water?
(Scoffs) ...Stupid neighbor... (mutters under breath) He said he only sold the... the hole? Not the water? (Looks up, eyes narrowed) That's dumb. Can he even DO that?

You're right, that *is* a bit silly, isn't it? The neighbor said he sold the well, but not the water inside.

So, what did the farmer do because he couldn't get water?
(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) ...Went to... the... the king guy? The... emperor? (Looks around the room, distracted)

Yes, the emperor! He went to the emperor for help.

What did the emperor's helper, the courtier, say to the neighbor?

(Thinking, furrowing brow) ...Something about... paying rent? Or... taking the water away? All of it? (Looks at teacher expectantly) That was a... (searches for the word) ... conundrum! (Smirks proudly)

"Conundrum!" That's a great word! Yes, the courtier said the neighbor had to either pay rent for the water or take all the water away immediately.

Why do you think the courtier said that? What was the courtier trying to show the neighbor?

(Leans back in chair, crosses arms) 'Cause it was a stupid trick! (Voice getting louder) The neighbor was trying to be a jerk! The courtier... (pauses, thinking)... was showing him he couldn't be a jerk! (Glares at an imaginary neighbor) People can't just sell holes without the stuff inside!

You're exactly right! It *was* a trick, and the courtier showed him that his trick wouldn't work.

So, what happened in the end? What did the neighbor do?
(Grumbling) ...Said sorry? (Looks away, unimpressed) And went home. (Mumbles) Shoulda made him pay anyway...
He did say sorry and went home. Why do you think he said sorry?
(Scoffs) 'Cause he got caught! (Rolls eyes) He knew he was being dumb. (Shrugs) Stupid people say sorry when they get caught being stupid. That's what my brother does!
Okay, he got caught. And because he got caught, his trick didn't work. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the story trying to teach us?
(Thinking, chews on end of pencil) ...Don't be a jerk neighbor? (Looks up, tilting head) Don't try to trick people 'cause you'll get in trouble? (Frowns) Is that it?
You're getting very close! It's about what happens when you try to trick or cheat people. What happens in the story when the neighbor tries to cheat the farmer?

(Taps foot impatiently) ...He... loses? (Looks up, a glimmer of understanding) He gets tricked BACK! By the... the courtier guy! (Smiles slightly) So... don't cheat, or someone will cheat YOU back! (Nods confidently) I knew that.
Yes! If you try to cheat someone, it won't work out for you in the end. Cheating will get you nowhere. You understood the story very well. <finish>

Okay, wonderful reading! That was a fun story, wasn't it?

So, tell me, at the beginning of the story, how did the elephant feel?
Uh... (shrugs) Lonely. (looks away, starts picking at a loose thread on my shirt)
Lonely, yes! You are right. Why was the elephant lonely?
Exactly! Because he had no friends. And what did the elephant do to try and not be lonely anymore?
(Sighs, avoids eye contact) Asked... asked... animals. (Struggles to find the words) To be friends?
Yes, you got it! The elephant asked the other animals to be friends. What happened when he asked the monkey?
(Thinking, taps foot impatiently) Monkey... said no. (Looks up briefly, then back down) Can't swing.
That's right! The monkey said no because the elephant couldn't swing. What about the rabbit? Why didn't the rabbit want to be friends?
(Grumbling) Too big. (Rolls eyes) Stupid rabbit hole.
(Chuckles) You're right, the rabbit thought the elephant was too big for the burrow. And what about the frog?
(Shrugs again) Jump... can't jump. (Starts doodling on the desk with a finger)
Okay. So, the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog all said no. How did the elephant probably feel then? Was he still happy?
(Mumbles) No. (Looks down at the desk, drawing circles)
No, he probably felt even more lonely, right? Then, the next day, something happened in the forest. What was it?
Yes! The tiger was chasing everyone. And what did the elephant do?
(Looks up, a hint of interest) Kicked... tiger. (A small smirk appears)
He did! He kicked the tiger! Why did he do that?
(Confidently) 'Cause... tiger bad! (Puffs out chest a little)
You got it! The tiger was being bad and scaring everyone. And then what happened after the elephant kicked the tiger?
(Eyes widen slightly) Friends! (Looks at you, genuinely curious) Were... friends now?
Yes! The other animals wanted to be his friend *after* he kicked the tiger. Why do you think they changed their minds?
(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead) ...Hmm... (Uses a bigger word) Protected them! But... (Confused) Why not before?
That's a great question! Why do *you* think they didn't want to be friends before, but they did after the tiger? Think about why the monkey, rabbit, and frog said no.
(Thinking, taps desk) They... needed help? (Looks up, hopeful) But... friends help anyway, right? Like... even if you can't swing?

You're getting it! You're exactly right. They needed help, and the elephant could help them even though he was big and couldn't swing or jump. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends? Can friends only be a certain size?
(Shakes head slowly) No. (Thinks some more, then speaks more clearly) Friends... help. Even if... different. (Looks at you, almost smiling) Is that right?

That's *exactly* right! Friends can be different sizes, and shapes, and be good at different things. What matters is helping each other. This story teaches us that friends can be any shape or size! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a good story, wasn't it?

Now, can you tell me, what did the girl bring her dad?
Uh... (shrugs) An egg... and... uh... (looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) potato... tea?

Yes! You got them all! An egg, a potato, and tea leaves.

(Stares blankly, avoiding eye contact) ...Boiled 'em? ... Uh... in water? (Shrugs again, looks around the room)

Yes, he boiled them in water! Good job!

Now, what happened to the egg after it was boiled? Was it the same as before?

That's right! The soft egg became hard. And what about the potato? What happened to the potato when it was boiled?

Yes! The hard potato became soft. You're doing great!

Now, this is the tricky one. What happened to the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?
(Furrows brow, actually thinking for a moment, a glimmer of interest in eyes) ...Uh... They... changed the water? (Looks at the teacher, a little bit proud) They made it... tea?

Exactly! The tea leaves changed the water itself. Amazing!

So, the egg changed, the potato changed, and the tea changed the water. Do you think the hot water was like something hard happening to them?
(Nods slowly, picking at a fingernail) ...Yeah... Maybe... Like when you... fall down?

That's a great example! Falling down is definitely something hard.

So, the egg, the potato, and the tea, they all faced the same problem, the hot water. But did they all react the same way?

(Looks at the teacher, tilting head slightly. Actually seems a bit engaged now.) ...No. The egg got hard... and the potato got... squishy... (A pause) And the tea... made tea. (A small, almost imperceptible smile)

That's it! They all faced the same problem, but they all reacted differently.

So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about when hard things happen to *us*?

(Looks down at shoes, thinking hard. Actually thinking! Uses a slightly more complex sentence than before.) ...That... um... we can... be like the egg, or the potato, or... or the tea? (Looks up, searching for the right words) ...We can change... in different ways... when bad stuff happens? (A little proud again) Is that right?

That's *exactly* right! You explained it perfectly! When hard things happen, we can choose how we react. We can become hard like the egg, soft like the potato, or we can even change the situation like the tea!

So, what is the moral of the story? What does the story teach us?

(Pauses, considering. Seems genuinely thoughtful.) ...That... even when bad things happen... we still get to... choose? (Looks up, a hint of curiosity in eyes.) ...Choose what happens next? (A small smile again, a bit more pronounced this time.)
Yes! That's it! We decide how to respond to difficult situations! We have a choice! You understood the story so well! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Needle Tree."

Now, can you tell me, who are the characters in the story?
Uh... (shrugs) the... uh... brothers. (looks away, fidgeting with pencil) And the... tree? (thinking)

Yes! Good job. There are two brothers, and a magical tree.

Which brother went to the forest first? Was it the older brother or the younger brother?
(hesitates) ...Older... brother. (looks down at the desk, mumbling)

That's right! The older brother went to the forest first.

What did the older brother want to do with the tree?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) Cut... it down. (Shrugs)
Yes! He wanted to cut it down. Why did he want to cut it down? What did he usually do with wood?
(Sighs, avoids eye contact) ...Sell it... (pauses) ...in the market... I think?

That's right! He wanted to sell the wood in the market.

Now, what did the tree say to the older brother? Did the tree want to be cut down?
(thinking, taps pencil on desk) ...No...(pause) It said... uh... golden apples? (looks up briefly, then back down)

Yes! The tree offered him golden apples if he didn't cut it down.

Did the older brother take the golden apples?
And was he happy with the golden apples?
He did want more! What happened when he tried to cut the tree down anyway?
(shrugs, avoids eye contact) Needles. (pauses) A lot of them.
Yes, lots and lots of needles! How do you think the older brother felt when he was covered in needles?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) Hurt? (Shrugs) I don't know.
He was probably very hurt and in pain. Now, what did the *younger* brother do when he found him?
Yes! He carefully took out all the needles. Was that a kind thing to do?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) Uh...maybe? (Shrugs)

Yes, it was a very kind thing to do, especially since the older brother wasn't very nice to him.

What did the older brother say to the younger brother after he took out the needles?
(hesitates) ...Said sorry...? (looks down at the desk, mumbling)
Yes! He apologized. Why do you think he said sorry?
(thinking, taps pencil on desk) ...Because... younger brother helped? (looks up briefly, then back down) ...I don't know...

That's a good start! He said sorry because his younger brother helped him, even though he hadn't been very nice to him before. He realized he had been wrong to treat his brother badly.

What happened after the older brother apologized? What did the tree do?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) More... uh... apples? (shrugs)

Yes! The tree gave them more golden apples.

So, the older brother was mean and greedy at first, and he got needles. Then, he was sorry, and the tree gave them more apples. What do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it better to be mean, or kind?
(Sighs, avoids eye contact) ...Kind...? (pauses) ...I guess. Is this over yet?
Yes, it's much better to be kind. And why do you think it's better to be kind? What happened in the story when someone was kind?
(Stares blankly, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) ...Got apples...? Can I go now?

Yes, the brothers got more apples. Being kind can bring good things! The story shows us that when we are kind, good things can happen to us. The younger brother was kind and helped his older brother, and then they both got golden apples.

So, what is the story trying to teach us about being kind? If you are kind, what will happen?
(shrugs, avoids eye contact) Uh... good things happen...? Can I draw now? This is boring.

Yes, that's right! Good things can happen. This story, "The Needle Tree," teaches us that kindness will always be rewarded. Remember that! You were very close to figuring that out by yourself.

I think you understand the story now. <finish>

Okay, [User's Name], that was a great job reading the story of King Midas!

Now, tell me, who was King Midas? Was he a farmer? Or a king?
(Looks down, fidgeting with hands) Uh... a...king?
That's right! He was a king! And what did King Midas do for the Satyr? Was he mean? Or helpful?
Yes! He was helpful. Because he was helpful, who gave him a wish? Do you remember the name of the god?
(Thinking, chews on fingernail) ... (long pause) ...Dion... uh... Dionysus? Was it? (looks up briefly, then down again)
You got it! Dionysus! And what did Midas wish for? What did he want to happen when he touched things?
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on clothes) ...Gold...everything...gold. (mumbles)
That's right! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold. Was Dionysus happy about this wish? Did he think it was a good idea?
(Shakes head slightly, looking anxious) ...Uh...no? (Stutters) He... he warned him?
He did warn him! Good job remembering. Now, when he got his wish, was King Midas happy at first? What did he do?
(Forces a little smile but it fades quickly) He... (pause) ...touched stuff. (Looks away) Made it gold. He... he liked it at first? I think?
Yes, he liked it at first. He touched things and made them gold. But what happened when he got hungry? Could he eat?
(Frowns, voice barely a whisper) ...No. Food...gold too. (Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor)
That's right. And then what happened with his daughter?
(Eyes widen slightly, a flicker of fear in expression) ...Uh... (long pause) ...hug...gold... (voice trembling) She...gold too? (looks away, clearly upset)
Yes. She turned to gold too. How do you think King Midas felt then? Was he still happy about the golden touch?
(Starts to tear up, voice cracking) ...No! Bad! (Sniffles) He... sad. (Looks down, shoulders slumped)

He was very sad. He realised the golden touch wasn't such a good thing after all. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? Why was the golden touch a bad thing for King Midas, even though he wanted it so much?
(Wipes eyes with sleeve, avoiding eye contact) ...Uh... (long pause) ...'cause... (stutters) ...not... not everything good? Gold... not eat... not hug... (mumbles, almost unintelligible) ...bad wish?
That's a really good start! Gold is nice, but it's not everything, is it? He couldn't eat, he couldn't hug. So wanting *only* gold made him very unhappy. Do you think he wanted too much gold?
(Nods slowly, still sniffling) ...Too much. (Looks up briefly, then down again) He... greedy?

Greedy! That's a great word! He was greedy. And because he was so greedy, he lost things that were much more important, like his food and his daughter. So, what do you think the story is trying to tell us about being greedy? Is it a good thing? Or a bad thing?
(Looks up, a little more confident now, but still quiet) ...Bad... bad thing. (pauses) ... Wanting too much... makes you sad?

Yes! Wanting too much can make you sad. The story teaches us that being too greedy can lead to bad things happening. It can make us lose the things that really matter. Can you think of another word to describe what happened to King Midas because he was greedy? Did things get better for him? Or did things get worse?
(Thinking, chewing on fingernail again) ... Worse? He...he lost his daughter. (Looks away, a sad expression on face). Is... is there a word for that? (voice barely audible)

Yes, things got worse for him. And there *is* a word for that. When someone's greed leads to bad things happening to them, we can say it leads to their...downfall. So, greed can lead to someone's downfall. Does that make sense?
(Nods slowly, looking a little less anxious) ...Downfall. Like... falling down? Because he was...greedy?
Exactly! Like falling down because he was greedy. He wanted too much, and it made him fall. You understand the story really well now! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Fox and the Grapes.

First, tell me: What was the fox looking for?

(Shifts in seat, fidgeting with hands)

Uh... food? (Looks away)

And what did he find on the farmer's wall?

...grapes. (Mumbles)

Big... purple... (shrugs) I don't know. (Anxious tone)

...Juicy? Uh... (Stutters) I... I don't remember. (Starts to tear up)

(Softly) Hey, it's okay. Don't worry. It's right there in the story. Let's look at that part again together. (Points to the words "big, purple, juicy grapes") See? Juicy!

So, the fox saw big, purple, juicy grapes. What did he try to do?

(Sniffling, wiping eyes with sleeve)

...Reach... them? (Quietly) I don't... I don't like this. (Looks down, on the verge of crying)

(Pauses, realizing the student is getting upset. Softens tone and changes approach)

Okay, let's try something different. Instead of questions, how about you tell me one thing you remember about the story? Just one thing. Anything at all.

(Huddles in seat, voice barely audible)

...He... he couldn't get them. (Shakes head slightly, avoiding eye contact)

He tried and tried, right? What did he do after he couldn't reach the grapes? Where did he go?

(Sniffs, looks down at hands)

...Home... (Mumbles, voice shaky) ...went home... 'cause... 'cause he couldn't...
He did go home! And why did he go home? You said it... because he couldn't...?

(Looks up briefly, eyes red and watery)

...Couldn't get... grapes. (Voice cracking) They were... sour. (Looks down again, starting to cry softly) I... I want to stop.

(Immediately stops the lesson, kneels down to be at the student's level)

Okay, we will stop right now. It's okay. You did a great job, and we can talk about this another time. You are doing so well, and I am really proud of you. How about we read a different story, or draw a picture? What would you like to do? <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story of the Proud Rose! That was a good one, right?

First, can you tell me, who are the two main characters in the story?

That's right, she was mean! Can you remember *how* she was mean? What did she do to the cactus?

Yes! She probably called him ugly. Good job! So, the rose thought she was pretty and the cactus was ugly.

Now, what happened when it got really, really hot and there was no water? What happened to the rose?
(Starts to bite fingernails, eyes darting around the room) …uh…(hesitates, then whispers) …withered?
Yes! She withered. What does "withered" mean? What happened to her when she withered? Did she get bigger and stronger? Or smaller and weaker?
(Pulls away from the teacher, shrinking into self) … smaller…(voice cracking slightly).
Smaller and weaker. Good. And why did she wither? What did she need that she didn't have?
Yes, water. The rose needed water. And what about the cactus? Did he wither?
(Shakes head slightly, still looking at hands) …no.
No, he didn't! Why didn't the cactus wither? What was he doing that helped the sparrows?
(Long pause, fidgeting intensifies, on the verge of tears) …uh…(almost inaudible) …don't know…(sniffles again).

(Wipes nose with sleeve, avoids eye contact) …Sparrows…

Yes! The sparrows were getting water from the cactus. So, the cactus *had* water, even when it was hot and dry.

Now, the rose is withering, and the cactus has water. What does the rose do? Does she keep being mean, or does she do something different?
Yes! She asks for water! And does the cactus say no?

No! He shares his water. Even though she was mean to him before.

So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Is it good to be mean to people who look different than you?
(Begins to cry silently, wiping eyes) …No…(Shakes head vigorously).
No, it's not good to be mean. Why isn't it good to be mean? What did the rose learn in the end? Did looking pretty help her when she needed water?

Yes. We all need help sometimes, and it's important to be nice to everyone, even if they look different. The cactus was able to help the rose, even after she was mean. So, what's the big lesson of the story? Should we judge people just by how they look? Or should we be nice to everyone?
(Sniffling, voice barely audible) …Be…nice…(Hiccups softly). (Looks down at hands, fiddling with fingers)

That's right. We should be nice to everyone. And we shouldn't judge people just by how they look. Sometimes, the people who look different or who we don't understand can be the ones who help us the most.

You did a great job today, even though it was a little tough. You really thought hard about the story. We should always be nice, and we shouldn't judge people according to how they look! <finish>

Okay! Great job reading the story of Molly the Milkmaid! Now, let's talk about it.

First, what was Molly going to do with the milk?
(Looks away, fidgets with hands) Uh... sell it? ... at the market?

Yes! That's right! She was going to sell it at the market.

And what did Molly *start* thinking about as she walked?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) ... Things? ... (Stuttering) Money... things?

Good try! She was thinking about things, and about money!

What did she want to *buy* with the money? What was the first thing she imagined getting?
(Long pause, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) ...A chicken...? Uh... I think.

You got it! A chicken!

And what did she think the chicken would *do* for her?
(Sighs, looks down at shoes) ...Lay eggs...? ... I don't know. (Mumbles) This is boring.

It's okay! We're almost done. Yes, the chicken would lay eggs!

So, she thought she could sell the eggs and get even *more* money? Is that right?
Okay! So, Molly was imagining all the things she would buy with the milk *and* egg money. What happened *then*? What went wrong?
Yes! The milk spilled! Why did the milk spill? What was she doing when it spilled?
She was skipping! And because she was skipping, the milk spilled. So, did she get to buy the chicken?

No, she didn't. She went home with nothing.

Now, why do you think her mother said, "Don't count your chickens until they hatch?" What does that *mean*?
(Stares blankly, fidgets) ...Huh? ...Don't...count...chickens...? (Sighs loudly) I don't get it. Can I go now?

It means don't make plans based on something that might not happen. Molly was making plans about selling eggs before she even *had* a chicken!

Do you understand now? Did Molly *have* the chicken yet?
(Grumbling) ...No... (Looks down, kicks at the floor) ...Didn't have chicken...

Right. She didn't have the chicken. So, she shouldn't have been planning what she would do with the egg money *yet*.

So, what do you think the big idea, or the lesson, of the story is? What did Molly learn?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) ...Don't skip...? ... I don't know! Just... leave me alone.

It's not just about skipping. It's about waiting until you *have* something before you start planning what to do with it. Like, don't plan a party *before* you get permission from your mom or dad, right?

So, what's the lesson of the story? Think about the chicken... and the eggs... and the milk...
(Glares, mutters) ...Stupid...eggs...milk... (Long pause, looks down, kicks the floor again) ...Don't...make plans... 'til...you have it...? Is that it? Just tell me the answer. I don't care.

You're very close! It's like, don't *depend* on something until you are *sure* it will happen. Molly *depended* on selling eggs from a chicken she didn't even have!

Can you say that? Don't depend on something until you are sure it will happen.
(Mumbles, barely audible) ...Don't... 'pend...on...something... 'til...sure... (Glares) Fine. Can I go now?
Yes, you can go. You did a good job thinking about the story, even if it was a little tough. Remember the milkmaid and her pail! <finish>

Now, tell me, who are the characters in the story?
(Shuffles feet, avoids eye contact) Uh… (long pause) … the… farmer… and… the… goose. And… his… wife.
