(Looks down at hands, nervously fidgeting) A… uh… golden… egg. (Stuttering) I… I think.
Yes, a golden egg! And what did the farmer do with the golden egg?
(Mumbles) …sold it… (looks away, kicking the table lightly)
He sold it! And what did he buy with the money from the egg?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) … Stuff… I dunno… (picks at a loose thread on clothes)
That's okay! The story said they lived a comfortable life. That means they had enough food and a nice home. So, were they happy at first?
Why do you say "maybe?" What happened to make them *un*happy?
(Sighs, looks at the floor) … He… wanted… more… (long pause, fiddling with fingers) … more eggs.
That's right! He wanted more eggs. And what did he do to get more eggs?
(Voice barely a whisper) …Cut… the goose… (looks up quickly, then down again, face gets red)
Yes, he cut open the goose. Was that a good idea?
(Shakes head violently, still looking down) …No… (mumbling) Stupid…
Why was it a bad idea? What happened after he cut open the goose?
(Forces out the answer) …No… more… golden… eggs… (starts to tear up, rubs eyes) …Nothing… just… yucky stuff…
That's right. He didn't get any more golden eggs. So, what happened to the farmer and his wife after that? Did they get richer or poorer?
(Sniffles, wipes nose with sleeve) …Poorer… (mumbles) …'cause no… more… eggs…
Exactly! Because he was greedy and cut open the goose, he lost everything. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Should we always want more and more?
(Looks down, kicks the table) …No… (mumbles) …Don't be… greedy…
That's part of it! But it's also about thinking before you do something. Did the farmer *think* about what would happen if he killed the goose?
(Shrugs, picks at nails) …Guess not… (mumbles) …Dumb farmer… Can I go now?

He wasn't thinking very well, was he? He acted without thinking. So, the story teaches us to think before we act. To think about what might happen *after* we do something. Do you understand? What's the story trying to teach us?
(Sighs loudly, leans back in chair) Uh… think… before… do… stuff… (avoiding eye contact) …And… don't… be… greedy… (rubs eyes again) Can I *please* go now?
Yes! You got it! Think before you do stuff and don't be greedy. That means think about what might happen *after* you do something. That's a very important lesson. Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story, (student's name)! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

So, tell me, who were the main people in the story?

Yes! Good job! The farmer and the neighbor.

Now, what did the farmer want from the neighbor?
He wanted the water, yes. But how did he try to get the water? What did he do first? Think back to the beginning of the story.
(Thinking, bites lip) …bought…well? …(Looks down at desk, nervously tapping fingers)

You're getting there! He bought the well! So, the farmer bought the well.

Then what happened? Could he get water from the well?
That's right! Why couldn't he get water from the well even though he bought it? What did the neighbor say?
(Sighs heavily, shifts in seat) …Uh…said…not…water… (Looks up briefly, then back down)
Good trying! The neighbor said he sold the well, but not the water *inside* the well. Do you think that was fair?
No, it wasn't fair, was it? So, what did the farmer do because he thought it wasn't fair? Who did he go to?
(Long pause, fiddles with a loose thread on shirt) …The…um… (Looks around the room) …Emperor? (Said like a question)
Yes! The Emperor! And the Emperor had someone help him decide what to do. Do you remember who that was? It's okay if you don't!
That's okay! It was the Emperor's helper, the courtier. The courtier was very smart. What did the courtier ask the neighbor to do?
(Frowns, thinking hard) …Pay…rent? (Voice is small and uncertain)
You're so close! He said the neighbor had to either pay rent for the water or take it all out right away! Why do you think he said that?
(Anxious look on face, starts to pick at fingernails) …uh… (Stares blankly) …don’t…know…Too…hard…

It's okay, it *is* a little tricky. Let's think about it. The neighbor said he sold the well but not the water. But the water is *in* the well, right? So, what was the neighbor really trying to do? Was he being honest and fair?
(Looks down, scuffing shoes on the floor) …Trick… (Barely audible)
Yes! He was trying to trick the farmer! And what happened when he tried to trick the farmer? Did it work?
No, it didn't work. He had to say he was sorry. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the lesson of the story? If you try to trick people, what might happen?

Yes! Bad things can happen! If you try to cheat or trick people, it usually doesn't work out for you in the end. So, the story teaches us that cheating will get you nowhere. Can you say that? "Cheating will get you nowhere."
(Looks down, mumbled) …Cheating…nowhere… (Whispers and fidgets) Can I be done now? (Looks up with big, anxious eyes)
Yes, you can almost be done. You are doing so well. So if you cheat it will get you nowhere. So, the neighbor tried to cheat the farmer. Did it work out for the neighbour in the end?
(Shakes head, nervously tugging at sleeve) …No…(Looks away) …Want…go…
No, it didn't work out for him. He had to apologise. You explained the story really well and you understand the lesson it teaches. Well done! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

Let's talk about it. At the beginning, how did the elephant feel?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands) ... sad?
Yes, sad! Why was the elephant sad?
(shrugs) ...uh... no... friends? ... (looks away, avoids eye contact)
That's right! The elephant didn't have any friends. And what did the elephant decide to do about it?
(long pause) ... look... for... them? (stuttering, barely audible)
Yes! The elephant went looking for friends. Who did the elephant ask first?
The monkey! And what did the monkey say? Why didn't the monkey want to be friends?
... (picks at a loose thread on their shirt) ... tree... swing... (whispers) ... can't...
You got it! The monkey said the elephant couldn't swing in the trees. Then who did the elephant ask?
Rabbit! And why didn't the rabbit want to be friends with the elephant?
... (long pause, sighs) ... burrow... too... big... (mumbles, almost inaudible)
Yes! The elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow. What about the frog? Why didn't the frog want to be friends?
Yes, the elephant couldn't jump like the frog. So, how did the elephant feel after all those animals said no?
I bet! It's not nice to be told no. Now, what happened the next day in the forest? What were the animals doing?
Running from the tiger! And who stopped the tiger?
The elephant did! How did the elephant stop the tiger?
... (hesitates, looks uncomfortable) ... kicked... (mumbles, barely a word)
The elephant kicked the tiger, that's right! And what happened after the elephant scared the tiger away? What did the other animals think then?
They wanted to be friends! Why do you think they wanted to be friends *then*, but not before?
...(long pause, fidgets with hands, anxious look on face)...dunno...(whispers)
Think about what the elephant did. Did the elephant help them?
...(eyes dart around the room, avoiding eye contact)...yes...(barely audible)
Yes! The elephant helped them when they were in trouble. Did it matter that the elephant was big and couldn't swing or jump?
No, it didn't matter! Sometimes, friends are different sizes and shapes. Sometimes, friends can do different things. What do you think this story is trying to teach us about friends?
...(looks at hands, tracing circles on them, appears nervous)...uh...(long pause)...dunno...(whispers, almost crying) ... Can I go now? (voice trembling)

It's okay! Don't worry. This is a tricky question. The story shows us that friends don't have to be all the same. The monkey, rabbit and frog all thought the elephant was too different to be their friend, but in the end, the elephant helped them because of the way it was. So, maybe friends can be different shapes and sizes? What do you think?
...(sniffles, wipes nose with sleeve)...maybe...(quietly, still avoids eye contact) ...Different...okay...(mumbles)

That's right! Friends can be different. The story shows us that what makes a good friend isn't about being the same size or being able to do the same things. It's about helping each other. What did we learn from the story? Friends can be any shape or size. <finish>

Okay! That's a great story!

So, tell me, what did the girl want from her dad?
Uh... (shrugs, looks down at the desk) Help... I guess?
Yes, she wanted help! She was feeling... how was she feeling? Was she happy?
...(shuffles feet, picks at a loose thread on my pants) No... Frustrated? (mumbles the word)
Frustrated! That's right. She was frustrated. And what did her dad do to help her? He didn't just *tell* her what to do, did he?
He did! He boiled stuff. What things did he boil? Can you remember? There were three things.
(hesitates, fidgets with a pencil) ...Potato... egg...? ...uh... don't know.
You got two! Potato and egg. The last one was tea leaves! He boiled a potato, an egg, and tea leaves. Now, what happened to the potato when it was boiled? Was it the same as before?
(eyes dart around the room, voice barely a whisper) ...Softer?
Softer! Yes. The hard potato became soft. What about the egg? What happened to the egg when it was boiled?
Harder! You got it! The soft egg became hard. And what about the tea leaves? Did they become hard or soft?
They didn't become hard or soft. What did they do to the water? Did the water stay the same?
(mumbles, looking at the floor) Changed it...?

Yes! The tea changed the water. Now, the dad said this was like when things are hard for us. The potato was hard, but became soft. The egg was soft, but became hard. And the tea changed the water. What do you think he meant? What was he trying to teach his daughter?
...(frowns, chews on end of pencil) ...Don't know! (voice raises slightly, bordering on whiny) It's stupid.

It's okay! It can be a little confusing. Let's think about it like this: the boiling water is like a hard time. The potato, the egg, and the tea leaves are like *us*.

The hard potato got soft in the hard time (the boiling water). The soft egg got hard in the hard time. The tea changed the water.

So, when things are hard, do we all have to be the same? Do we all have to become soft like the potato, or hard like the egg?
(Stares intently at my shoes, picks at the laces) ...Uh... No? (said quietly, like a question)

No! Exactly! We don't all have to be the same. The dad wanted his daughter to understand that when things get tough, we can choose how we react. We can be like the potato, the egg, or the tea. Which one do *you* want to be?
(Crosses arms, looks away, a scowl appears on my face) I dunno! Doesn't matter. (mutters under breath) It's still stupid.

It's okay if you don't know right now. Let's think about it some more.

The potato started hard but became soft. Is that good or bad, do you think, when things get tough? What if you need to be strong?

The egg started soft but became hard. Is that always good? What if you need to be flexible and bend a little?

The tea changed the water. It made the water something new and different. Do you think that's a good thing?
(Sighs dramatically, leans back in chair, and looks at the ceiling) ...Whatever. (mumbles) I wanna go play.

I know it's hard to think about this. But hang in there, you are doing so well.

Okay, how about this: the tea changed the water. It made the water into something new and different. What if the "something new and different" was *better*? What if the tea made the water taste yummy? Would that be a good thing, even though it was hard at first?
(pauses, thinking, but still looking at the ceiling) ...Maybe? If it's...juice...then yeah. Juice is good.

Juice IS good! Okay, so the tea changed the water into juice. The hard time (the boiling water) helped make something good.

So, what's the story trying to teach us about hard times? Do they *always* have to make us soft or hard? Or can we choose to change the hard time into something...better...like juice?
(lowers eyes slowly, looking at teacher with a slight flicker of interest, voice still quiet) ...Change it...? ...Maybe...make it...juice?

Yes! Make it juice! The story is trying to tell us that we can choose how we react to hard times. We can try to change them into something good, like the tea! We decide how to respond to difficult situations. Does that make a little more sense?
(nods slowly, still hesitant, picks at a fingernail) ...Uh... a little...? Can I go now?
Yes, you can go play now. You worked hard and did a great job thinking about the story. Remember, when things get tough, you get to choose: potato, egg, or tea! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was The Needle Tree.

First, tell me: What did the older brother do for work?
(Shifts feet, avoids eye contact) Uh... (Stuttering) wood... chop...
Yes! He chopped wood. And where did he chop the wood?
(Looks at the floor, fidgeting with hands) Forest... I think...

You're right! He chopped wood in the forest. Good job remembering.

Now, what did he find in the forest one day? Something special...
(Sighs, looks away) A tree... (Mumbles) Stupid tree...
It *was* a special tree, wasn't it? What did the tree *do* when the older brother wanted to chop it down?
(Shrugs) Said... uh... don't cut... (Looks around the room)
That's right! It asked him not to cut it down. And what did the tree *offer* him if he didn't cut it down?
Golden apples! Were they normal apples?
Right! They weren't normal. So, the older brother got the golden apples. Was he happy?
(Hesitates, looks down) No... wanted more... (Mumbles) Greedy...
You used a great word there! Greedy! He *was* greedy. What happened when he tried to cut the tree down *anyway*?
(Nervously picks at a loose thread on clothes) Needles... a lot... ouch...
Ouch, indeed! Needles everywhere. And who helped him?
Yes! His *younger* brother. Even though the older brother wasn't very nice to him, the younger brother still helped. What did the older brother say *after* his younger brother helped him?
(Looks down, scuffing shoes on the floor) Sorry... maybe? ...Uh... don't know. (Voice barely a whisper)
He did say sorry! He apologised for being mean. And what happened *after* he apologised? Think about the tree...
Yes! More golden apples! Why do you think the tree gave them *more* apples *after* the older brother said sorry?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) Don't know... magic? (Looks anxious) Can I go now?

It *was* magic, but the magic was also about something else. Think about how the brothers were acting. The older brother was mean, then he was sorry. The younger brother was kind. What do you think the tree liked? Kindness or meanness?
(Glares at the table) ...Kindness... I guess... Just want to be done... (Taps foot impatiently)
You're getting it! The tree liked the kindness. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us? What happens when you are kind? Do good things happen, or bad things?
(Sighs dramatically) Good things... maybe... (Looks away, slumping in chair) Can we stop now? My tummy hurts...

Almost done! The story shows us that if you are kind, good things can happen. Kindness gets rewarded! The older brother was mean, and he got needles. The younger brother was kind, and they got more apples. So, what's the big idea, the *moral* of the story? Kindness gets...?
(Mumbles, barely audible) ...rewarded... I don't feel good...
Yes! Kindness gets rewarded. You understand the story and what it's trying to teach us. Great job! <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a fun one, wasn't it?

First, can you tell me: Who was Midas?

Yes! He was a King. Good job!

And who gave him the wish?

Yes! Dionysus! That's a tricky name. Dionysus gave him a wish.

What did Midas wish for?
(Looks down at the desk, picks at a loose thread) ... Gold.
Gold, yes. But what kind of gold? What did he want to happen with the gold?
(Shrugs again, avoids eye contact) ... Everything... gold?
Almost! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold. Right? Can you say that? Everything he touched turned to gold.
Good! Now, after he got his wish, what was the first thing he touched? Do you remember?
That's okay! Maybe he touched his chair, or his table. He touched lots of things! And what happened when he touched them?
Yes! They turned to gold! Was he happy at first?
He was happy! Why was he happy?
Yes! He liked gold. He was excited to have lots of gold. But then what happened? What went wrong?
(Frowns, picks at nails) ... Uh... don't know.
He got hungry, remember? What happened when he tried to eat?
Yes! His food turned to gold! Could he eat it?
No! And then what happened with his daughter?
Yes, she turned to gold too when he hugged her. Was he happy then?
No, he wasn't happy. So, at the beginning he was happy he could turn everything to gold. At the end he was not happy. Why wasn't he happy at the end?
Think about it. He couldn't eat. And his daughter turned into gold. Was that good or bad?
Yes, very bad. He wanted more and more gold, but it made him sad. Sometimes, wanting too much can be a problem. Do you think wanting too much gold was a good idea for Midas?
Right. So, what do you think we can learn from this story about King Midas? Is it good to always want more and more?
(Looks down, picks at desk) ... Uh... no?
No! Why not? What happened to Midas when he wanted more and more gold?

Yes, he became sad. And he couldn't eat. And his daughter... It made things bad for him. So, sometimes wanting too much can make you sad. It's important to be happy with what you have. Do you understand?
Okay. So, what did we learn about wanting too much?
Bad, yes. Wanting too much can be bad. It can make you sad, like Midas. It can be better to be happy with what you have. <finish>

Okay, great job reading the story! Now, let's talk about it.

First, tell me, what was the fox looking for?
That's right! He was looking for food. And what did he find hanging on the wall?
Yes, grapes! What did the grapes look like? Were they small and green, or big and purple?
(Sticks to simple words, glances up then down) Big... purple.
Good job! And what did the fox try to do?
He tried to get them! How did he try to get the grapes? Did he ask nicely?
He jumped! He jumped really high! Did he get the grapes?
(Confident in the answer, leans back slightly) No.
No, he didn't. How did the fox feel when he couldn't reach the grapes? Do you think he was happy or sad?
Okay, that's alright. Even if you don't care about the fox, can you guess how *most* people would feel if they really wanted something and couldn't get it? Sad, or happy?
Sad. You're right. So, the fox was probably sad. What did he say about the grapes when he walked away?
Sour! He said the grapes were sour. Do you think he *really* thought they were sour? Or was he just saying that?
(Avoids asking questions, answers with a simple word) Saying.
Saying it. Why do you think he said they were sour if he didn't really think so?
(Stares at the table, mutters) ...Dunno. (Picks at a loose thread on shirt).

Okay, let's think about it this way. He wanted the grapes *really* bad, right? And he couldn't get them. Was it easier to admit he couldn't reach them, or to pretend he didn't *want* them? What's easier for *you*?
(Thinks for a moment, still looking down. Fidgets) Pretend... don't want. Easier.

Easier, right? So maybe the fox pretended he didn't want them. He said they were sour so he wouldn't feel so bad about not getting them.

So, what can we learn from this story? If you can't get something you want, should you just say you didn't want it anyway?
Hmm... Is that a good idea? What if the fox *could* have found a way to get the grapes? Maybe if he had found a box to stand on? If he pretends he doesn't want them, will he try to find a way?
(Shrugs again, showing little interest) ...Don't know. Don't care. Can I go now?

I understand that you want to leave, but let's try to understand one more thing. Imagine you really wanted a toy, but you couldn't reach it on a high shelf. Would you just say you didn't want it, or would you ask for help to reach it?
(Rude and aggressive tone) Just leave it! (Turns away completely).

Okay, I see you're feeling frustrated. It's okay to feel frustrated sometimes.

The story is trying to teach us that it's okay if we can't get something right away. But we shouldn't pretend we didn't want it in the first place. We can try again, or find a different way. And sometimes, things are hard, and that's okay too.

The fox gave up and said the grapes were sour because he didn't want to admit he couldn't get them. It's better to keep trying! <finish>
Okay, so we read a story about a rose and a cactus in the desert, right? What's the first thing that comes to your mind when you think about the rose in the story?
(Shrugs, looking down at my hands) Uh... pretty?
Yes, the rose *is* described as pretty! That's a great start. What else strikes you about her, even if it's just a feeling?
Mean is a very good word! Why do you think she was mean? Don't worry if you're not sure, just tell me what you're thinking.
(Thinking, tapping foot) ...Because she...said bad things? (Looks back quickly, then down again)
That's right! She did say bad things. Can you remember what she said or *who* she said them to? Even a little detail helps!
(Stuttering, avoids eye contact) Uh... the...cactus? ...Stuff about...ugly?
You've remembered so much already! The rose was pretty and mean, and she said mean things to the cactus about being ugly. Can you put all of that together in one sentence for me? Take your time!
(Grumbling quietly, looking at the floor) ...The rose...pretty...mean...said...ugly...to cactus.

That's a great effort! You remembered all the important parts. How about this: "The pretty and mean rose said the cactus was ugly." See? You knew all the bits, you just needed to put them together. Well done! I think that's a great place to stop for today. Goodbye!

(Shrugs, looking down at my hands) Uh... pretty?
Yes, the rose *is* described as pretty! That's a great start. What else strikes you about her, even if it's just a feeling?
(Looks away, fidgeting) ...Mean?
Mean is a very good word! Why do you think she was mean? Don't worry if you're not sure, just tell me what you're thinking.
(Thinking, tapping foot) ...Because she...said bad things? (Looks back quickly, then down again)
That's right! She did say bad things. Can you remember what she said or *who* she said them to? Even a little detail helps!
(Stuttering, avoids eye contact) Uh... the...cactus? ...Stuff about...ugly?
You've remembered so much already! The rose was pretty and mean, and she said mean things to the cactus about being ugly. Can you put all of that together in one sentence for me? Take your time!
(Grumbling quietly, looking at the floor) ...The rose...pretty...mean...said...ugly...to cactus.

That's a great effort! You remembered all the important parts. How about this: "The pretty and mean rose said the cactus was ugly." See? You knew all the bits, you just needed to put them together. Well done! I think that's a great place to stop for today. Goodbye!

record.strategy_description: Okay, given the student's low extraversion and my strategy of motivational encouragement, I'll use gentle, positive reinforcement. I'll say something like, "Yes, the rose *is* described as pretty! That's a great start. What else strikes you about her, even if it's just a feeling?" This encourages them to elaborate without pressure. (This would take 1 utterance).

record.summary: The student identifies the rose as "pretty" and "mean," demonstrating understanding of the rose's initial characteristics. Their body language (shrugging, looking down, fidgeting, looking away) suggests hesitation and a lack of confidence when expressing their opinions about the rose's motivations.

The student recalls the rose being "pretty" and "mean" to the cactus, specifically mentioning insults about its appearance. The student seems hesitant, looking down, fidgeting, and avoiding eye contact while answering. They remember details with prompting.

The student identified the rose as "pretty" and "mean", recalling she insulted the cactus for being "ugly". They showed hesitation and a lack of confidence through fidgeting, avoiding eye contact, looking down, and stuttering.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly the milkmaid. What did Molly do for work?
Uh… (shrugs) Milk… cows? (looks away, kicking at the floor)
That's right! She milked the cows. Good job remembering that! What did she *do* with the milk?
Yes, she sold it! You're doing great! Now, where did she sell the milk? Do you remember? It's okay if you don't, we can figure it out together.
Market is right! You got it! See, you *do* remember! Now, Molly was walking to the market, right? What was she thinking about as she walked?

Okay, you've remembered so much already! Molly milks the cows, sells the milk at the market, and was thinking about money while she walked. Can you put all those things together in one short sentence to tell me what the story is about so far? Just a quick recap!
(Sighs, fidgeting) Uh... Milk... market... money... (Stares at the ceiling, as if looking for an answer painted there.)

It's okay! We've got the main bits. Milk, market, money... Molly had a plan for that money, didn't she? Maybe that's where the story *really* starts. Let's leave it there for today. Well done for trying! See you next time!

history.content: Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly the milkmaid. What did Molly do for work?
Uh… (shrugs) Milk… cows? (looks away, kicking at the floor)
That's right! She milked the cows. Good job remembering that! What did she *do* with the milk?
...Sell it? (looks down, mumbling)
Yes, she sold it! You're doing great! Now, where did she sell the milk? Do you remember? It's okay if you don't, we can figure it out together.
(Stares blankly) ...Uh...Market?
Market is right! You got it! See, you *do* remember! Now, Molly was walking to the market, right? What was she thinking about as she walked?
...Money? (shrugs again, picking at fingernails)

Okay, you've remembered so much already! Molly milks the cows, sells the milk at the market, and was thinking about money while she walked. Can you put all those things together in one short sentence to tell me what the story is about so far? Just a quick recap!
(Sighs, fidgeting) Uh... Milk... market... money... (Stares at the ceiling, as if looking for an answer painted there.)

It's okay! We've got the main bits. Milk, market, money... Molly had a plan for that money, didn't she? Maybe that's where the story *really* starts. Let's leave it there for today. Well done for trying! See you next time!

record.strategy_description: Okay, given the student's low extraversion, I'll use motivational encouragement. This means positive reinforcement and gentle prompting. "That's right! She milked the cows. Good job remembering that! What did she *do* with the milk?" (1-2 utterances)

record.summary: The student recalls Molly milks cows and sells the milk, hesitantly answering the teacher's questions about Molly's job. They mentioned she sold the milk at the market. The student exhibits unsure body language like shrugging, looking away, kicking, mumbling, and staring blankly.

The student remembers Molly milks and sells the milk, eventually recalling she sells it at the market. They also recall Molly was thinking about money. The student displays unsure body language: shrugging, looking away, kicking the floor, mumbling, picking at fingernails and staring blankly.

The student recalls that Molly milks cows and sells milk at the market, thinking about money. They exhibit unsure body language like shrugging, looking away, mumbling, fidgeting and staring blankly. The student struggles to summarise the story's beginning, only repeating the key words.

dialogue: Hey! That's a cool story about the owl. What do you think the owl was doing all day by his tree? Just chilling?
Uh… (shrugs) … just…seeing things? (looks away, fidgeting with a crayon)
Okay, so he's seeing things! Was he watching squirrels chase each other, or maybe listening to children playing? Which one do you think he did more of?
… (long pause, stares at desk) … uh… talking? (shrugs again)

That's a good idea, the owl could talk! But what does the story tell us? The story says the owl would "observe". What do you think "observe" means? It's like watching and listening really carefully. What kind of things might he have been watching and listening to near his tree?
(Sticks tongue out a little) … stuff. (avoiding eye contact)

"Stuff" is a good start! Can you think of one thing that might be "stuff" near a tree? Maybe an animal, or… hmm… maybe something else? What comes to mind when you think of a tree? Don't worry, there's no wrong answer!
… Bugs? (looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)
Bugs are great! Lots of bugs live near trees. Maybe the owl saw some bugs crawling. What else could he see or hear near the tree? Take your time and think about it. You're doing a good job!
… (long pause, fiddling with shoelaces) … People? (said very quietly)
Okay, you've said the owl saw bugs *and* people! That's excellent! Now, in your own words, can you tell me the story so far, using what we've talked about? Just a quick little summary is fine!
… owl… see… bugs… and people. (looks down, avoiding eye contact)
That's a great start to the story! You remembered the owl, the bugs, and the people. Keep practicing and you'll be telling stories like a pro in no time! See you next time!

history.content: Hey! That's a cool story about the owl. What do you think the owl was doing all day by his tree? Just chilling?

Okay, so he's seeing things! Was he watching squirrels chase each other, or maybe listening to children playing? Which one do you think he did more of?

That's a good idea, the owl could talk! But what does the story tell us? The story says the owl would "observe". What do you think "observe" means? It's like watching and listening really carefully. What kind of things might he have been watching and listening to near his tree?
(Sticks tongue out a little) … stuff. (avoiding eye contact)

"Stuff" is a good start! Can you think of one thing that might be "stuff" near a tree? Maybe an animal, or… hmm… maybe something else? What comes to mind when you think of a tree? Don't worry, there's no wrong answer!
… Bugs? (looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)
Bugs are great! Lots of bugs live near trees. Maybe the owl saw some bugs crawling. What else could he see or hear near the tree? Take your time and think about it. You're doing a good job!
… (long pause, fiddling with shoelaces) … People? (said very quietly)
Okay, you've said the owl saw bugs *and* people! That's excellent! Now, in your own words, can you tell me the story so far, using what we've talked about? Just a quick little summary is fine!
… owl… see… bugs… and people. (looks down, avoiding eye contact)

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! What do you think the farmer wanted when he bought the well?
Uh... (shrugs, looks down at my shoes) Water?
Did the farmer want water, or maybe just a place to store his tools near the field? Or something else entirely?
(frowns, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) He... he bought the well. (shrugs again) For water. I dunno.
Okay, you think he bought it for water. Was it just *any* water, or did he have a specific reason to want water from *that* well? Maybe he thought the water tasted especially good?
...Uh... (looks away, kicks the desk leg) Just... water. For... the farm.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the elephant story! What do you think the elephant was feeling at the beginning of the story?

That's a great observation! It's definitely understandable the elephant would be sad.

What makes you say sad?
(Thinking, fidgeting with my hands) ...uh... no friends. (Mumbles) Nobody like him.

That's a really important point. Feeling like nobody likes you would make anyone sad. It takes courage to admit that, well done.

Can you tell me more about why the elephant having no friends makes you think he's sad? What does having friends usually mean to you?
(Looks away, uninterested) ...dunno. They just...said no. He asked.

That's right. He asked, and they said no. That must have felt pretty awful for the elephant. It sounds like you're thinking about how the elephant felt when he kept getting turned away. Can you think of a time you felt left out, or when someone said no to you when you wanted to play? It's okay if you don't want to share a story, but maybe thinking about it can help us understand the elephant's feelings better.

Okay, it seems like talking about feelings is a bit tricky right now, and that's perfectly fine.

Instead of focusing on feelings, let's just quickly recap the story so far. Can you tell me, in your own words, what has happened to the elephant? Just the main things, from when he started looking for friends until everyone said no. What did he *do*?
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on my pants) ...looked...for friends. Monkey said no. Rabbit said no. Frog said no. (Pauses) ...everyone said no.
Okay, that's a perfect summary! You've got all the important bits. Well done! Have a good rest of the day; see you next time.

dialogue: Okay, so we've got this story about a girl, an egg, a potato, and some tea. What do you think is the most interesting thing about the story?
Uh... (shrugs, looks away) The... the tea?
The tea... okay! Why the tea? Do you think it's more interesting because it changed color, or because it changed the taste of the water?
(Stares at the desk, fidgeting with a pencil) ... Uh... changed the... water.
Okay, good! It changed the water. Do you think it's more interesting because the tea *added* something new to the water, or because it took something away from the water? What do you think?
(Hesitates, looks up briefly, then back down) ... uh... added. (mumbles) Don't know.

Alright, you've said some really interesting things about the tea! It changed the water, and you think it *added* something to it. Now, can you try to put all your thoughts together? Can you tell me, in your own words, what you think this whole story is trying to tell us, based on what we've talked about with the egg, the potato, and especially the tea? Just take your time, there's no right or wrong answer!
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on his shirt) ... (long pause) ... Dunno. (Shrugs, avoids eye contact) The water... got better? (Looks up, a flicker of confidence) Maybe.

That's a really interesting thought! "The water got better"... Hmmm. It sounds like you're thinking about how the tea made a positive change. This story is about how we react to tough times, like the egg, potato, and tea in hot water. Sometimes we get hardened, sometimes softened, and sometimes, like the tea, we can change the whole situation for the better! You had some great ideas, and figuring out stories takes time and thinking. Well done for trying! See you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story. What do you think was the most important thing that happened in it? Just tell me anything that comes to mind.
Uh… (shrugs, looking at my shoes) The tree… and the apples?
That's a good start! Tell me more about the tree – what made it special?
(Sticks out tongue slightly) It… gave… apples. Golden ones. (Looks away)
That's right! Golden apples are pretty special. Why do you think the tree gave the older brother golden apples instead of, say, regular apples? What does that tell you about the tree?

Okay, let's take a step back. You've told me about the two brothers, the mean older brother, the magical tree, and the golden apples. Can you put all of those things together for me in your own words? Just tell me the story so far, like you're telling it to a friend who hasn't heard it before.
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) There was a… mean brother. He wanted to cut down a tree. The tree gave him… (hesitates) golden apples. (Looks up briefly, then back down) Is that it?

That's a good start! It sounds like you're getting the main points. But remember what happened *after* the older brother got the golden apples? He wasn't happy, was he? What did he do *then*? Maybe thinking about that will help you see why the tree isn't just any ordinary tree. I'm sure you can remember, give it your best shot! Goodbye for now!
